As far as his classwork goes—it would be hard to improve upon it. With very little persuasion by his teachers he has gone from failing grades to straight A’s in every subject.”

“劝说听起来不祥。你是什么意思？”

“Persuasion sounds ominous. What do you mean?”

“也许在这种情况下用这个词不太恰当。我认为奖励努力可能更能表达这一点。正如你所知，经验丰富的教师会确保良好的行为、出色的课堂作业得到注意和称赞。这实际上是一种积极强化，是一种行之有效的技术。相反的做法，指出失败，收效甚微——除了灌输一种几乎总是适得其反的愧疚感。在布莱恩的案例中，计算机被证明是解决他所有学习问题的关键。我看过录音——如果你愿意，你也可以看看——记录了他在短短几周内取得的成就——”

“Perhaps that was the wrong word to use in this context. I think rewards-for-effort might express it better. As you well know, experienced teachers will make sure that good behavior, good classwork, is noticed and complimented. It is really a matter of positive reinforcement, a technique with proven efficacy. Doing the direct opposite, pointing out failures, accomplishes very little—other than instilling a sense of guilt, which is almost always counterproductive. In Brian’s case the computer proved to be the key to any learning problems he had. I’ve seen the recordings—you can look at them as well if you wish—of just what he has accomplished in a very few weeks—”

“录音？我怕我看不懂。”

“Recordings? I am afraid that I don’t understand.”

吉梅尔看起来有些不自在，他把面前桌子上的回形针摆放了又摆。“这没什么不寻常的，也没有什么违法的。这是大多数学校的常见做法——事实上，UFE 要求这样做。你在签署雇佣合同时肯定看到了这一点。”

Gimelle looked uncomfortable, arranging and rearranging paper clips on the desk before him. “There is nothing unusual or illegal in this. It is common practice in most schools—in fact it is required here at UFE. You must have seen it in your employment contract when you signed it.”

“几乎不可能。这封信里有五十多页的细则。”

“Hardly. There were over fifty pages of fine print in the thing.”

“你的律师对此怎么说？”

“What did your lawyer say about it?”

“没什么——因为我没有咨询过。那时我的生活可以说是相当紧张。你是说这所学校的所有学生的电脑上都有窃听器，他们输入的所有内容都可以被看到和记录下来？”

“Nothing—since I didn’t consult one. At the time life for me was, shall we say, rather stressful. What you are saying is that all of the students in this school have taps on their computers, that everything they enter can be seen and recorded?”

“这是一种常见且被接受的做法，是一种非常有用的诊断和教育工具。毕竟，在那些有书面笔记本的时代，人们会把笔记本交上去评分。你可能会说，访问学生的计算机也是同样的事情。”

“A common and accepted practice, a very useful diagnostic and educational tool. After all, in the days of written notebooks they were turned in to be graded. You might say that accessing a student’s computer is very much the same thing.”

“我不这么认为。我们给笔记本打分，但不给个人日记打分。所有这些都不是重点。我会在其他时间考虑这种可疑做法的道德性。现在我们考虑布莱恩。这些秘密录音揭露了什么？”

“I don’t think it is. We grade notebooks—but not personal diaries. All of which is beside the point. I’ll consider the morality of this dubious practice some other time. Now we are thinking about Brian. What did these clandestine recordings reveal?”

“非常不寻常和独创的头脑。正如你所知，LOGO 更像是孩子们学习的第一种计算机语言。如果正确实施，它非常灵活。我很高兴看到 Brian 不仅解决了课堂作业的问题，而且当他有解决方案时，他试图编写一个包含所有解决方案的元程序。他为自己的编程发明了 IF-THEN 规则数据库。例如，如果需要答案，他会插入几行代码。然后稍后编辑。在 LOGO 中非常容易做到——如果你知道如何做——因为所有工具都在那里。例如，当其他学生正在学习使用 LOGO 绘制图片、图形程序时，Brian 远远领先于他们。他保存并索引每个有用的绘图片段，其中包含可更改的参数，以及绘制位置的几何约束。他的程序现在可以绘制其他学生和我自己的可识别漫画。他们甚至可以改变表情。那是上周——他已经证明了这些程序。现在这些人物可以在屏幕上行走并解决简单的问题。”

“An exceedingly unusual and original mind. LOGO, as you know, is more man a first computer language that children learn. It is very flexible when implemented correctly. I was delighted to see that Brian not only solved the problems of the class assignments, but when he had a solution he tried to write a meta-program that incorporated all of his solutions. He invented data bases of IF-THEN rules for his own programming. For example if an answer was needed then he would insert some lines of code. And edit later. Very easy to do in LOGO—if you know how— because all the tools are there. For example, while other students were learning to draw pictures, graphics programs, using LOGO, Brian was way ahead of them. He saved and indexed each useful drawing fragment with changeable parameters, along with geometric constraints on where to draw it. His programs now draw recognizable caricatures of the other students, and myself as well. They can even change expression. That was last week—and he has unproved the programs already. Now the figures can walk, and solve simple problems, right on the screen.”

那天晚上回家时，帕迪有很多事情要考虑。

Paddy had a good deal to think about when he went home that night.

 

 

贝尼科夫和外科医生都吃惊地抬起了头，这时门砰地一声打开了，肖尔希特将军冲了进来，他夹克的空袖子被别住了，他用左手的食指刺向了斯纳尔斯布鲁克。

Benicoff and the surgeon both looked up, startled, when the door slammed open and General Schorcht stamped in, the pinned-up empty sleeve of his jacket swinging as he stabbed the index finger of his left hand at Snaresbrook.

“你。如果你是斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士，你就跟我走。”

“You. If you are Dr. Snaresbrook you’re coming with me.”

外科医生慢慢转过身来面对这位闯入者。她不得不向后靠，才能抬头看到这位高大的将军的脸。她似乎并不觉得惊讶。

The surgeon turned about slowly to face the intruder. She had to lean back to look up at the tall General’s face. She appeared not to be impressed.

她冷冷地说：“你是谁？”

“Who are you?” she said coldly.

“告诉她，”肖尔希特厉声对贝尼科夫说。

“Tell her,” Schorcht snapped at Benicoff.

“我是绍尔希特将军，随行的有……”

“This is General Schorcht who is with…”

“这足以证明身份了。这是军事紧急情况，我需要你的帮助。这里有一个重症监护室的病人，布莱恩·德莱尼，他的情况非常危险。”

“That’s identification enough. This is a military emergency and I need your help. There is a patient here in intensive care, Brian Delaney, who is in great danger.”

“我很清楚这一点。”

“I am well aware of that.”

“不是医疗危险——是人身攻击。”贝尼科夫刚要说话，将军就挥手示意他闭嘴。“稍后再说。我们现在时间不多了。医院方面通知我，病人病情太重，目前无法移动。”

“Not medical danger—physical attack.” Benicoff started to speak but the General waved him to silence. “Later. We have very little time now. The hospital authorities inform me that the patient is too ill to be moved at this time.”

“没错。”

“That is correct.”

“那么记录就必须被修改。你跟我一起去修改。”

“Then the records must be altered. You will come with me to do this.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克脸色铁青，她不习惯别人这样跟她说话。贝尼科夫赶在她爆发前介入。

Snaresbrook’s skin grew livid; she was not used to being spoken to in this manner. Before she could explode Benicoff quickly intervened.

“医生，让我快速地告诉你。我们有充分的理由相信，当布莱恩被枪杀时，其他人也遇害了。这其中肯定有国家安全因素，否则将军不会在这里。我相信会有人给出解释的——但目前你能帮忙吗？”

“Doctor, let me fill you in very quickly. We have firm reason to believe that when Brian was shot, that others were killed as well. There must be national security involved or the General would not be here. I am sure that explanations will be forthcoming—but for the moment would you please be of assistance?”

脑外科医生对即时的生死抉择习以为常。斯纳尔斯布鲁克放下咖啡杯，立即转身朝门口走去。

Brain surgeons are well used to instant, life-and-death decisions. Snaresbrook put down her coffee cup, turned at once and started toward the door.

“是的，当然了。跟我去护士站吧。”

“Yes, of course. Come with me to the nurse’s station.”

将军自从进医院以来肯定没有交到朋友。愤怒的护士长在斯纳尔斯布鲁克的劝说下终于平静下来，并最终意识到事情的紧急性。她让其他护士离开，而斯纳尔斯布鲁克也设法让那位医生离开。直到他们离开后，将军才转向白发苍苍的护士长，后者狠狠地瞪了他一眼。

The General had certainly made no friends since he had entered the hospital. The angry head nurse was reluctantly pacified by Snaresbrook and finally convinced of the urgency of the matter. She dismissed the other nurses while Snaresbrook managed to do the same with the staff doctor. Only when they were gone did the General turn to the gray-haired head nurse, who matched him glare for glare.

他问：“病人现在在哪里？”

“Where is the patient now?” he asked.

她转向指示板，触摸一个亮着的数字。“这里。重症监护室。314室。”

She turned to the indicator board and touched a lit number. “Here. Intensive care. Room 314.”

“这一层还有其他空的房间吗？”

“Are there any other rooms on this floor that are empty?”

“只要330。不过这是双倍的……”

“Just 330. But it is a double…”

“那没关系。现在把指示牌和记录改成德莱尼在330，314是空的。”

“That doesn’t matter. Now change the indicator board and the records to show Delaney in 330, and 314 as being empty.”

“会有麻烦的……”

“There will be trouble…”

“做吧。”

“Do it.”

她照做了——非常不情愿。当她输入更改时，另一个护士匆匆走了进来，仍然戴着她的徽章。肖尔希特严肃地点了点头。

She did—with great reluctance. As she punched in the changes another nurse hurried in, still pinning on her badge. Schorcht nodded grimly.

“时间到了，中尉。进站。我们其他人都走了。如果有人问起，病人布莱恩·德莱尼在 330 号房间。”他快速地一挥手，让护士闭嘴。“德雷克中尉是一名军队护士，在医院工作经验丰富。不会有麻烦的。”他的传呼机响了，他打开对讲机听了听。“明白了。”他把对讲机放回腰带上，环顾四周。

“About time, Lieutenant. Get into the station. The rest of us are leaving. If anyone asks, the patient Brian Delaney is in room 330.” He silenced the staff nurse with a quick chop of his hand. “Lieutenant Drake is a military nurse with a great deal of hospital experience. There will be no trouble.” His beeper sounded and he switched on his radio and listened to it. “Understood.” He put it back on his belt and looked around him.

“我们大概还有两分钟。听着，不要问问题。我们都离开这个区域——事实上，离开这层楼。德雷克中尉知道该怎么做。我们刚刚得知，有人将试图谋杀病人。我不仅想阻止这起犯罪，还想获得有关潜在犯罪者的信息。你们现在只要离开就可以帮忙。明白了吗？”

“We have about two minutes, possibly. Listen and don’t ask questions. We will all leave this area—leave this floor in fact. Lieutenant Drake knows what to do. We have just learned that there will be an attempt on the patient’s life. I not only want to prevent this crime but obtain information about the would-be perpetrators. You can all help by simply leaving now. Understood?”

将军带路，两人没有争吵。他们匆匆走过走廊，来到楼梯间，走下三楼，德雷克护士几乎立正站着。直到他们离开，她才深吸一口气，稍微放松下来。她拉直制服，转向墙上的镜子，确保帽子是方正的。当她转过身来，看到站在柜台前的年轻人时，她控制住了自己的惊讶。

The General led the way; there were no arguments. Nurse Drake stood almost at attention as they were hurried down the corridor to the stairwell and off the third floor. Only when they were gone did she take a deep breath and relax slightly. She pulled her uniform straight and turned to the mirror on the wall to make sure her cap was square and correct. When she turned back she controlled her start of surprise when she saw the young man standing at the counter.

“我能帮你吗……医生？”她问道。他穿着医院的白色制服，口袋里挂着一个电子听诊器。

“Can I help you… Doctor?” she said. He was dressed in hospital whites and had an electronic stethoscope hanging from his pocket.

“没什么大事。我刚来。路过几个担心的访客，他们问起布莱恩·德莱尼。新来的人？”他探过柜台，敲了敲指示器。“是他吗？”

“Nothing important. I just came on. Passed some worried visitors asking about a Brian Delaney. A new admittance?” He leaned over the counter and tapped the indicator. “Is that him?”

“是的，医生。重症监护，330。危急但稳定。”

“Yes, Doctor. Intensive care, 330. Critical but stable.”

“谢谢。我出去的时候会告诉他们。”

“Thanks. I’ll tell them when I go out.”

护士朝他微笑。她长得漂亮，皮肤黝黑，二十多岁，背着一个黑色包。她仍然面带微笑，把手放在腰间，等他转过身去，她就按了两次看似普通的传呼机按钮。

The nurse smiled at him. Nice-looking, tanned, late twenties, carrying a black bag. Still smiling, she put her hand to her waist and as soon as he had turned his back pressed twice on the button of what appeared to be an ordinary pager.

年轻人轻轻地吹了声口哨，沿着走廊走去，转过一个弯，头也不回地走过了 330 号。他在下一个十字走廊停下来，向两边看了看——然后迅速而安静地跑回房间。空无一人。他把手伸进黑色的袋子里，打开门，看到空荡荡的床铺。还没等他反应过来，房间里的两个人，一个在门的两边，用自动手枪顶住了他的腹部。

Whistling softly through his teeth, the young man went down the corridor, turned a corner and past 330 without a glance. He stopped at the next cross corridor and looked both ways—then ran swiftly and silently back to the room. No one was in sight. With his hand in the black bag he threw open the door and saw the empty beds. Before he could react the two men inside the room, one to each side of the door, pushed automatic pistols into his midriff.

“无论你想做什么，别做！”高个子说道。

“Whatever you’re thinking of doing—don’t!” the taller one said.

“你好，”年轻人说道，然后把袋子扔到地上，同时举起了球形尖头左轮手枪。

“Hello there,” the young man said and let the bag drop, swinging up the bulbous-tipped revolver at the same time.

他们开枪是为了伤人，而不是为了杀人。子弹快速射中了他的胳膊和肩膀。他倒在地上时脸上还带着微笑。他们还没来得及抓住他，把他翻过来，就听到一声闷响。

They fired to wound, not kill. Quick shots into his arms and shoulder. He was still smiling as he fell face-forward. Before they could grab him and roll him over, there was a muffled pop.

当 Schorcht 大步走进来时，他们看上去非常不舒服。

They looked very uncomfortable when Schorcht came stalking in.

“先生，他自己动手了，我们还没来得及阻止他。一颗爆炸性子弹射入胸口。他身上炸出了一个大洞。已经没法再修补了——即使现在还在医院里。”

“He did it himself, sir, before we could stop him. Single shot into the chest with an explosive bullet. Blew a great damned hole in himself. Nothing left to patch up—even being right here in the hospital.”

将军的鼻孔张大，他的目光像旋转的大炮一样，先是瞄准了他们中的一个人，然后又瞄准了另一个人，比他说的任何话都要难听。他的目光中充满了降职、训斥和前途的毁灭。他转身，大步走向了等待的贝尼科夫。

The General’s nostrils flared and his glare, aimed first at one then the other of them like a swiveling cannon, was far worse than anything he could have said. It smoked with demotion, reprimand, blighted careers. He turned on his heel and stomped out to the waiting Benicoff.

“让联邦调查局调查尸体。查明一切！”

“Get the FBI onto the body. Find out anything, everything!”

“好的。现在你能告诉我这是怎么回事吗？”

“Will do. Can you tell me now what this is all about?”

“不。这是一个需要知道的情况——你不需要知道更多。我们只想说，Megalobe 事件已经与我们已经知道一段时间的更大的事件有关。这种袭击不会再发生。这里将全天候有警卫，直到病人可以被转移。当他可以的时候，他将直接从这里出发，穿过海湾到达白痴岛。科罗纳多。我不喜欢海军——但至少他们是军队的一部分。他们应该能够在世界上最大的海军基地内的医院里保护一个人。我希望如此。”

“No. This is a need-to-know situation—and you don’t need to know anything further. Let us say only that this Megalobe business has become slotted into something much larger that we have been aware of for some time. And this sort of attack will not be permitted to happen again. There will be guards here right around the clock until the patient can be moved. When he can he is going to go right out of here and over there, across the bay to Idiot’s Island. Coronado. I don’t like the Navy—but at least they are part of the military. They should be able to guard one man inside their hospital inside the largest naval base in the world. I hope.”

“我相信他们能做到。但你必须告诉我这次暗杀企图的背景。否则我的调查就会受到影响。”

“I am sure that they can. But you are going to tell me the background to this assassination attempt. Or my own investigation will be compromised.”

“到时候会通知你的。”冷冷地说。但贝尼科夫不相信；他的声音和将军一样冷淡。

“When the time comes you will be informed.” Icily. But Benicoff was not buying it; his voice was just as cold as the General’s.

“不满意。如果这事的幕后黑手和枪杀布莱恩的人是同一伙人，那我确实需要知道。现在告诉我。”

“Not satisfactory. If the people behind this are the same as the ones who shot Brian then I do need to know. Now tell me.”

双方陷入僵局——直到绍尔希特将军不情愿地做出了决定。

It was a standoff—until General Schorcht reluctantly made the decision.

“我只能告诉你最起码的信息。我们有一个犯罪组织的线人。他发现了这次暗杀企图，并尽快联系了我们。他只知道凶手是被雇来的——但目前他还不知道是谁主动联系的。如果他获得这些信息，就会转交给你。满意吗？”

“I can tell you the absolute minimum. We have an informant in a criminal organization. He discovered this assassination attempt, contacted us as soon as he could. He knows only that the killer was hired—but as yet he doesn’t know who made the approach. If and when he acquires that information it will be passed on to you. Satisfactory?”

“满意。只要你记得告诉我。”面对肖尔希特将军充满仇恨的目光，贝尼科夫开朗地笑了笑，转身离开。他在斯纳尔斯布鲁克的办公室里找到了她，关上门并锁上，然后告诉她发生了什么事。

“Satisfactory. As long as you remember to tell me.” Benicoff smiled cheerfully in response to General Schorcht’s glare of hatred, turned and left. He found Snaresbrook in her office, closed and locked the door before he told her what had happened.

“目前还没有人知道这次尝试的幕后黑手是谁，或者他们为什么要这么做？”这位外科医生问道。

“And no one knows yet who is behind this attempt, or why they are doing it?” the surgeon asked.

“原因很明显。窃取人工智能设备和细节的人想要垄断——而且没有证人。他们想确保布莱恩永远无法说话。”

“The why is pretty obvious. Whoever stole the artificial intelligence equipment and details wants a monopoly—and no witnesses. They wanted to be sure that Brian would never be able to talk.”

“既然如此，让我们看看能做些什么来干扰他们的计划。但搬迁到科罗纳多并不容易——至少不会很快。布莱恩的身体状况不适合搬迁，我也不想打断他的康复过程。正如我所说，这是一场与时间的战斗。所以你和你那讨厌的将军必须想办法确保这家医院的安全。”

“In that case—let us see what we can do to interfere with their plans. But the relocation to Coronado will not be easy—or soon. Brian’s in no condition to be moved, nor am I willing to interrupt the healing process. As I have said, this is a battle against time. So you and your obnoxious General will just have to find a way to make this hospital secure.”

“他会喜欢的。我会再喝一杯咖啡，然后再考虑面对他。”

“He is going to love that. I’ll take another coffee before I even think about facing him.”

“请随意。但我得回手术室了。”

“Help yourself. But I have to get back to the O.R.”

“我跟你一起去。我会待在那里直到看到将军会派出什么样的安保人员。”

“I’m going with you. I’m staying there until I see just what kind of security the General comes up with.”

 

 

6
6

2023 年 2 月 19 日
February 19, 2023

 

 

第二天早上，贝尼科夫在斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生前往手术室之前赶到了她的办公室。

The next morning Benicoff got to Dr. Snaresbrook’s office just before she left for the operating room.

“有时间吗？”

“Got a moment?”

“仅此而已。这将是艰难的一天。”

“Just that and nothing more. This is going to be a difficult day.”

“我想你可能想知道关于刺客的事情。正如预料的那样，没有身份证明，衣服上没有标签，没有身份证明。他的血型更能说明问题。报告说他的血型表明他的祖籍是南美洲。实际上是哥伦比亚。我不知道他们会说得这么具体。”

“I thought you might want to know about the assassin. As was expected no identification, no labels in his clothes, no identification. His blood was more revealing. The report said that his blood type placed his origin in South America. Colombia in fact. I didn’t know they could be that specific.”

“血型鉴定技术越来越精细了——你可能会发现，只要有足够的时间，他们就能准确地确定他的血统。就这些吗？”

“Blood typing is getting more and more refined—and you will probably find that given enough time they will be able to pinpoint his origin exactly. Is that all?”

“不完全是。他患有严重的艾滋病，每天要吸三袋海洛因。他刚从毒品中恢复过来，就完成了这次任务——但他包里有一个注射器，里面装的剂量足以杀死一匹马。所以我们有一个雇佣的枪手，随时准备为他昂贵的毒品杀人。线索已经断了，但调查人员正在试图通过安排与他签订暗杀合同的人来调查。我甚至不知道他们是谁，也不知道这些信息是如何传到我们这里的。所以你会明白，这并不容易。”

“Not quite. He had full-blown AIDS and was a three-bag-a-day heroin addict. He came down from his high just long enough to pull the job—but he had a hypodermic in his bag loaded with a dose that would kill a horse. So we have a hired gun, more than ready to kill for his expensive fix. The trail gets cold there but the investigators are trying to work through the people who arranged the contract with him for the hit. I have not yet even been told who they are or how this information reached us. So you will appreciate that it is not very easy.”

“我很感激。现在请原谅我，我得去上班了。跟我来。”他们默默地洗漱、穿好衣服，然后走进手术室。布莱恩的脑袋上的覆盖物再次被拉开。

“I appreciate. Now if you will excuse me I have to go to work. Come with me.” They scrubbed and dressed in silence, then went into the O.R. Once more the covering on Brian’s open brain was pulled back.

“希望这次手术是最后一次，”艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克说。“这是一台将被植入他大脑的计算机。”

“This operation will hopefully be the last,” Erin Snaresbrook said. “This is a computer that will be implanted in his brain.”

她戴着手套，手掌上平衡着一个形状奇特的黑色塑料模型，举起来以便记录手术过程的摄像机可以清晰地看到它。“这是一台拥有百万处理器的 CM-10 连接机，配有 1,000 兆赫路由器和 1000 兆字节 RAM。它每秒可以轻松进行 100 万亿次操作。即使在植入连接芯片膜后，大脑中去除死组织后仍留有空间。计算机机壳的形状恰好适合这个空间。”

She was balancing an oddly shaped black plastic form on the palm of her gloved hand, holding it up so that the camera that was recording the operating procedure could get a clear view of it. “It is a million-processor CM-10 connection machine with a 1,000-megahertz router and then a thousand megabytes of RAM. It has the capacity to easily do 100 trillion operations per second. Even after the implantation of the connection chip films there is space in the brain left for this where the dead tissue was removed. The computer case was shaped to exactly fit into this space.”

她把超级计算机放在无菌托盘上。上方机器的触须落到它上面，检查它，拿起它，然后将其旋转到正确的植入位置。准备工作完成后，计算机被抬起，然后放入布莱恩头骨的开口中。

She laid the supercomputer on the sterile tray. The tendrils of the machine above dropped down over it, examined it, picked it and rotated it into the correct position for implantation. When the preparation was complete the computer was lifted, then lowered into the opening in Brian’s skull.

“在最终定位之前，计算机和每张胶片之间都要建立连接。连接已经完成，外壳正在安装到其永久位置。一旦最后一个外部连接完成，我们就会开始关闭。即使现在，计算机也应该在运行。它已经用重新连接学习软件编程。它可以识别类似或相关的信号并重新路由芯片内的神经信号。希望这些记忆现在可以访问。”

“Before being finally positioned the connections are made between the computer and each of the films. There, the connections have been made, the case is being fitted into its permanent position. As soon as the last, external connection is complete we will begin closure. Even now the computer should be in operation. It has been programmed with reconnection-learning software. This recognizes similar or related signals and reroutes the nerve signals within the chips. Hopefully these memories will now be accessible.”

 

 

“这是一种奇怪的毕业礼物，”多莉说。“这个男孩需要衣服和一件新夹克。”

“It’s a strange kind of graduation present,” Dolly said. “The boy needs clothes and a new jacket.”

“他会拿到的，放学后带他去购物就行了，”帕迪一边说，一边弯腰系鞋带。“不管怎么说，衣服对男孩来说并不是真正的礼物。尤其是在这种场合。不到一年他就高中毕业了，很期待上大学。而且他才十二岁。”

“He’ll get them, just take him shopping after school,” Paddy said, grunting as he bent to tie his shoes. “Anyway, clothes aren’t any kind of real present for a boy. Especially on an occasion like this. He’s finished high school in less than a year and is looking forward to the university. And he’s only twelve years old.”

“你有没有想过，我们催他太急了？”

“Have you ever thought that we are pushing him too fast?”

“多莉——你知道不应该说这样的话。这里没有强迫。如果有什么事情，我们必须努力工作，不要拖他的后腿。他想这么快完成高中教育，因为他想上的课程在中学教育中没有。这就是他想看看我工作的地方的原因。安全法规阻止他到现在才来。所以这是他生命中非常激动人心的时刻，因为他现在已经具备了继续前进所需的所有基础。对他来说，大学是丰饶之角，充满了好东西可以享用。”

“Dolly—you know better than to say a thing like that. There’s no pushing here. If anything we have to work hard not to hold him back. It was his idea to finish high school so quickly because there are courses he wants to take that aren’t available in secondary education. That’s why he wants to see where I work. The security regulations prevented him coming until now. So this is a very exciting moment in his life because he now has all the grounding that he needs to go ahead. To him the university is the horn of plenty, bursting with good things to consume.”

“好吧，没关系。他确实应该多吃点。他一打开电脑就忘了自己在哪里了。”

“Well that’s all right. He really should eat more. He gets into that computer and forgets where he is.”

“一个比喻！”帕迪笑道。“知识食粮可以满足他的好奇心。”

“A metaphor!” Paddy laughed. “Intellectual food to feed his curiosity.”

她很伤心，但尽量不表现出来。“现在你就在嘲笑我，只是因为我担心他的健康。”

She was hurt, tried not to show it. “Now you’re laughing at me, just because I worry about his health.”

“我不是在嘲笑你——他的身体状况很好。他的体重也很好，他长得很快，游泳和锻炼都和其他孩子一样。但他的求知欲——这就是与众不同之处。你想和我们一起去吗？这是他的大日子。”

“I’m not laughing at you—and his health is fine. And his weight’s fine, he grows like a weed and swims and works out just like every other kid. But his intellectual curiosity— that’s what is different. You want to come with us? This is his big day.”

她摇摇头。“这不适合我。你尽情享受吧，确保六点前回来。我正在做一只火鸡，配上所有的配料，米莉和乔治一会儿要过来。我想在他们来之前洗干净——”

She shook her head. “It’s not for me. Just enjoy yourself and see that you are back by six. I’m making a turkey with all the trimmings and Milly and George are coming over later. I want to be cleaned up before they get here—”

门突然打开了，布莱恩冲了进来。

The door crashed open and Brian thundered in.

“爸爸，你还没准备好吗？该走了。”

“Aren’t you ready, Dad? Time to go.”

“你准备好了就行。”布莱恩站在前门，几乎要走出门外了；帕迪在后面喊道。“跟多莉说再见。”

“Ready when you are.” Brian was at the front door, almost out of it; Paddy called after him. “And say good-bye to Dolly.”

“再见”，然后他就走了。

“Bye,” and he was gone.

“对他来说这是一个重要的日子，”帕迪说。

“An important day for him,” Paddy said.

“当然重要，”门关上时，多莉轻声自言自语道。“而我只是这里的管家。”

“Important, of course,” Dolly said quietly to herself as the door closed. “And I’m just the housekeeper around here.”

现在，人工岛和附属的石油平台成了布莱恩的家；他不再意识到这个不寻常的环境。当这一切对他来说都是新鲜事物时，他常常探索钻井平台，偷偷溜下舷梯来到底层，海水在下面的钢腿周围翻腾。或者爬上直升机停机坪，甚至有一次绕过一道锁着的屏障，爬上梯子，到达行政大楼的通讯桅杆，这是 UFE 的最高点。但他对这些机械结构的好奇心早已得到满足；当他们走过通往实验室钻机的桥垫时，他现在有更重要、更有趣的事情要考虑。

The artificial island and attendant oil platforms were home to Brian now; he was no longer aware of this unusual environment. When it all had been new to him he used to explore the rigs, sneaking down the gangways to the bottom level with the sea surging around the steel legs below. Or up to the helipads, even climbing around a locked barrier once to clamber up the ladder to the communication mast on the administration building, the highest point in UFE. But his curiosity about these mechanical constructs had long since been satisfied; he had much more important and interesting things to think about now as they walked across the bridge mat led to the lab rig.

“所有的电子实验室都在这里，”帕迪解释道。“那是我们的发电机，圆顶，因为我们需要清洁稳定的电源。”

“All the electronic laboratories are here,” Paddy explained. “That’s our generator over there, the dome, since we need a clean and stable power supply.”

“旗鱼号潜艇的压水反应堆。1994年全球协议签署时被废弃。”

“Pressurized water reactor from the submarine Sailfish. Junked in 1994 when the global agreement was signed.”

“就是那间。我们从这里进去，二楼。”

“That’s the one. We go in here, second floor.”

布莱恩默默地环顾四周，兴奋不已。今天是星期六，所以这里完全是他们的。不过偶尔硬盘突然发出嗡嗡声，屏幕闪闪发光，说明至少有一个后台程序还在运行。

Brian stared about in silence, tense with excitement. It was Saturday so they had the place entirely to themselves. Though an occasional sudden humming of drives and a glowing screen showed that at least one background program had been left running.

“这就是我工作的地方，”帕迪指着终端机说。一根烧焦的石楠木烟斗放在键盘上，他把它拿了出来，然后为布莱恩拉开椅子。“坐下来，按任意键打开它。我告诉你，我对这个新 zed seventy-seven 感到很自豪。如果他们突然出现这样的情况，它会让你知道我们在做什么样的工作。让 Cray 看起来像一台破旧的 Macintosh。”

“Here is where I work,” Paddy said, pointing to the terminal. A charred briar pipe was resting on top of the keyboard and he removed it before he pulled the chair out for Brian. “Sit down and hit any key to turn it on. I tell you I’m proud of this yoke, the new zed seventy-seven. It gives you an idea of the kind of work we’re doing if they pop for something like this. Makes a Cray look like a beat-up Macintosh.”

“真的吗？”布莱恩的眼睛睁得大大的，他的手指沿着键盘的边缘滑动着。

“Really?” Brian’s eyes were wide as he ran his fingers along the edge of the keyboard.

“嗯，其实不是。”帕迪一边笑着一边从口袋里掏出烟草。“但它在某些计算上更快，而且我真的很需要它来进行 LAMA 的开发工作。这是我们在这里开发的一种新语言。”

“Well, not really.” Paddy smiled as he rooted in his pocket for his tobacco. “But it is faster in certain kinds of calculation and I really need it for the development work on LAMA. That’s a new language that we are developing here.”

“这是干什么用的？”

“What’s it for?”

“一种新的、快速发展的、特殊的需求。你用 LOGO 写程序，对吧？”

“A new, rapidly developing and special need. You write programs in LOGO, don’t you?”

“当然。还有 BASIC 和 FORTRAN——我正在通过书本学习E。我的教学一直在教我一些有关专家系统的知识。”

“Sure. And BASIC and FORTRAN—and I’m learning E out of a book. My teaching has been telling me something about Expert Systems.”

“那么你就会知道，不同的计算机语言有不同的用途。BASIC 是学习计算机所能做的一些最简单的事情的很好的第一手实践语言——用于逐步描述程序。FORTRAN 已经使​​用了五十年，因为它特别适合常规科学计算，尽管它现在已经被公式理解符号操作系统所取代。LOGO 适合初学者，特别是儿童，它非常图形化，很容易画图。”

“Then you will already know that different computer languages are used for different purposes. BASIC is a good first hands-on language for learning some of the simplest things computers can do—for describing procedures, step by step. FORTRAN has been used for fifty years because it is especially good for routine scientific calculations, though it now has been replaced by formula-understanding Symbolic Manipulation systems. LOGO is for beginners, particularly children, it is so graphical, making it easy to draw pictures.”

“它允许你编写程序来编写和运行其他程序。其他程序不让你这样做。当你尝试时，它们只会抱怨。”

“And it lets you write programs that write and run other programs. The others don’t let you do that. They just complain when you try.”

“你会发现你也可以在 LAMA 中做到这一点。因为和 LOGO 一样，它基于古老的语言 LISP。LISP 是最古老的语言之一，也是最好的语言之一——因为它很简单，但可以引用自身。在人工智能的早期，大多数第一批专家程序都是使用 LISP 语言开发的。但现代人工智能研究中的新型并行处理需要一种不同的方法和语言来完成所有这些事情，甚至更多。这就是 LAMA。”

“You’ll discover that you can do that in LAMA, too. Because, like LOGO, it is based on the old language LISP. One of the oldest and still one of the best—because it is simple and yet can refer back to itself. Most of the first expert programs, in the early days of artificial intelligence, were developed by using the LISP language. But the new kinds of parallel processing in modern AI research need a different approach—and language—to do all those things and more. That’s LAMA.”

“为什么以动物命名？”

“Why is it named for an animal?”

“不是。LAMA 是逻辑和隐喻语言的缩写。它部分基于 20 世纪 80 年代开发的 CYC 程序。要了解人工智能，我们首先必须了解我们自己的智能。”

“It isn’t. LAMA is an acronym for Language for Logic and Metaphor. It is partially based on the CYC program developed in the 1980s. To understand artificial intelligence it is first vital that we understand our own intelligence.”

“但如果大脑是一台计算机，那么思维又是什么呢？它们是如何联系在一起的？”

“But if the brain is a computer, what is the mind? How are they connected?”

帕迪笑了。“这个问题对大多数人来说似乎完全是个谜，包括一些最优秀的科学家。但据我所知，这其实根本不是问题，只是一个错误的问题。我们不应该认为思想和大脑是两个必须联系在一起的不同事物，因为它们只是看待同一事物的两种不同方式。思想就是大脑所做的事。”

Paddy smiled. “A question that appears to be a complete mystery to most people, including some of the best scientists. Yet as far as I can see it’s really no problem at all, just a wrong question. We shouldn’t think of the mind and brain as two different things that have to be connected, since they are just two different ways of looking at the same thing. Minds are simply what brains do.”

“我们的脑机是如何计算思想的？”

“How does our brain computer compute thoughts?”

“没有人真正知道确切原因——但我们有一个很好的想法。它实际上不只是一台大型计算机。它由数百万个相互连接的神经细胞束组成。就像一个社会。每一束细胞都像一个小代理一样，学会了做一些小工作——要么自己做，要么知道如何让其他代理帮忙。思考是所有这些代理以某种方式连接在一起的结果，这些代理彼此帮助——或者在无法提供帮助时让开。因此，尽管每个代理能做的事情都很少，但每个代理仍然可以携带一点知识与其他人分享。”

“No one really knows exactly—but we have a pretty good idea. It isn’t really just one big computer. It’s made of millions of little bunches of interconnected nerve cells. Like a society. Each bunch of cells acts like a little agent that has learned to do some little job—either by itself or by knowing how to get some other agents to help. Thinking is the result of all those agents being connected in ways that make them help each other—or to get out of the way when they cannot help. So even though each one can do very little, each one can still carry a little fragment of knowledge to share with the others.”

“那么 LAMA 是如何帮助他们分享的呢？” Brian 全神贯注地听着，听进每一个字，进行分析和理解。

“So how does LAMA help them share?” Brian had listened with complete concentration, taking in every word, analyzing and understanding.

“它通过将专家系统外壳与名为 CYC（百科全书）的大型数据库相结合来实现这一点。所有以前的专家系统都基于高度专业化的知识，但 CYC 为 LAMA 提供了数百万个常识性知识片段，即每个人都知道的东西。”

“It does this by combining an Expert System shell with a huge data base called CYC—for encyclopedia. All previous Expert Systems were based on highly specialized knowledge, but CYC provides LAMA with millions of fragments of common sense knowledge—the sorts of things that everyone knows.”

“但是，如果有这么多知识碎片，LAMA 怎么知道该使用哪些呢？”

“But if it has so many knowledge fragments, how does LAMA know which ones to use?”

“通过使用称为 nemes 的特殊连接代理，将每个知识片段与某些其他知识片段关联起来。因此，如果您告诉 LAMA 某个饮水杯是由玻璃制成的，那么 nemes 会自动让它假设杯子也是易碎且透明的——除非有相反的证据。换句话说，CYC 为 LAMA 提供了思考所需的数百万个想法之间的关联。”

“By using special connection agents called nemes, which associate each knowledge fragment with certain others. So that if you tell LAMA that a certain drinking-cup is made of glass, then the nemes automatically make it assume that the cup also is fragile and transparent—unless there is contrary evidence. In other words, CYC provides LAMA with the millions of associations between ideas that are needed in order to think.”

当帕迪停止说话并点燃烟斗时，男孩沉默地坐了将近一分钟。

When Paddy stopped talking to light his pipe the boy sat in silence for almost a minute.

“这很复杂，”帕迪说。“第一次不太容易上手。”

“It’s complex,” Paddy said. “Not easy to pick up the first time around.”

但是他误解了布莱恩的沉默，完全误解了，因为这个男孩按照他所说的话做了合乎逻辑的推论。

But he had misunderstood Brian’s silence, misunderstood completely because the boy had followed what he had said to its logical conclusion.

“如果语言能如此运作——那么为什么它不能用来创造真正能运作的人工智能？一种能像人一样独立思考的人工智能？”

“If the language works like that—then why can’t it be used to make a real working artificial intelligence? One that can think for itself—like a person?”

“毫无理由，布莱恩，毫无理由。事实上，这正是我们希望做的。”

“No reason at all, Brian, no reason at all. In fact that is just what we are hoping to do.”

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

7
7

2023 年 2 月 22 日
February 22, 2023
 
 

 

 

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克感觉睡意朦胧——尽管她只睡了五个小时。她不是自愿的，而是迫不得已，因为她已经将近三天没有上床睡觉了。她开始出现幻觉，不止一次发现自己的眼睛在手术室里因缺乏适当的休息而闭上。这实在是太过分了。她曾使用过一间空置的实习生房间，陷入了疲惫的黑洞，似乎过了一会儿，她就被警报声惊醒了。一场冷水淋浴让她恢复了活力；她涂上一层口红，镜子里红红的眼睛眨着。

Erin Snaresbrook felt logy with sleep—even though she had slept for only five hours. It had not been by choice but by necessity, since she hadn’t been to bed at all for almost three days. She was beginning to hallucinate and more than once had found her eyes closing in the O.R. for lack of proper rest. It was too much. She had used one of the vacant intern’s rooms, fallen into a black hole of fatigue and, what seemed like a moment later, had been dragged painfully awake by the clamor of alarm. A cold shower shocked her back to life; reddened eyes blinked back at her from the mirror as she put on a touch of lipstick.

“艾琳，我得告诉你。你看上去很糟糕，”她嘟囔着，伸出毛茸茸、看起来疲惫不堪的舌头。“医生，我给你开了咖啡来治疗你的病情。最好是静脉注射。”

“Erin, I have to tell you. You look rotten,” she muttered, sticking out a furred and tired-looking tongue. “I prescribe coffee for your condition, Doctor. Preferably intravenously.”

当斯纳尔斯布鲁克走进候诊室时，她发现多莉已经在那儿了，正在翻看一本破旧的《时代》杂志。她看了看手表。

When Snaresbrook came into her waiting room she saw that Dolly was already there, turning the pages on a worn copy of Time. She looked at her watch.

“病人偷走了所有新杂志，你相信吗？有钱的病人，否则他们不会在这里，他们甚至偷走卫生纸和肥皂。抱歉我迟到了。”

“Patients steal all the new magazines, would you believe it? Rich patients, or they wouldn’t be here, they even pinch the toilet paper and bars of soap. Sorry I’m late.”

“不用了，医生，没事的。”

“No, that’s fine, Doctor, it’s all right.”

“我们喝点咖啡，然后开始工作。你进去吧，我马上就来。”

“We’ll have some coffee, then get to work. You go in, I’ll be just a moment.”

玛德琳已经准备好了邮件，她快速翻阅，当门突然打开时，她抬起头来。她对愤怒的将军虚情假意地笑了笑。

Madeline had the mail ready and she flipped quickly through it, glancing up when the door flew open. She smiled insincerely at the angry General.

“你和病人为什么还在这家医院？我让他转院的命令为什么还没执行？”

“Why are you and the patient still in this hospital? Why have my orders for moving him not been carried out?”

肖尔希特将军像武器一样厉声说道。艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克想了很多答案，大多数都相当侮辱人，但她太累了，这么早没法大声争吵。

General Schorcht snapped the words like weapons. Erin Snaresbrook thought of many answers, most of them quite insulting, but she was too tired for a shouting match this early in the day.

“我会告诉你的，将军。然后你也许会从我背上爬下来。”她把信件扔到桌子上，然后被将军推到大厅里。她冲向布莱恩所在的重症监护室，听到将军沉重的脚步声在她身后。“戴上这个，”她厉声说，把一个无菌口罩扔给了肖尔希特将军。“对不起，”她说，拿起口罩，把它固定在对方的鼻子和嘴巴上；一只手戴上一个东西可不容易。戴上自己的口罩后，她把重症监护室的门打开了一点，这样他们就能看到里面了。“好好看看。”

“I will show you, General. Then maybe you will climb down off my back.” She threw the correspondence onto the desk, then pushed by the General and out into the hall. She stamped toward the intensive-care unit where Brian was, heard the General’s heavy footsteps behind her. “Put this on,” she snapped, and tossed General Schorcht a sterile mask. “Sorry,” she said, took the mask and fixed it into position over the other’s nose and mouth; it’s not easy to fit one of the things with only one hand. When her own mask was in place she opened the door to the ICU just enough so they could see in. “Take a good look.”

桌子上的身影在管子、电线和仪器组成的网络后面几乎看不清。操纵器的两只手臂放在他上方，多分支的手指伸进布上的开口。氧气面罩的软管从布帘下伸出，手臂、腿部和昏迷身体的几乎每个孔口都插着点滴和管子。一台复杂的机器上的灯光闪烁；一名护士看着屏幕上的读数并进行了调整。斯纳尔斯布鲁克关上门，把面罩从将军脸上拉下来。

The figure on the table was barely discernible behind the network of pipes, tubes, wires, apparatus. The two arms of the manipulator were positioned over him, the multibranching fingers dropping down into the opening in the cloth. The flexible tube of the oxygen mask wormed out from under the drapes and there were drips and tubes plugged into arms and legs and into almost every orifice of the unconscious body. Lights flickered on one of the complex machines; a nurse looked at a readout on the screen and made an adjustment. Snaresbrook let the door swing shut and pulled the mask from the General’s face.

“你想让我移动所有这些？当连接装置就位并运行时？它现在正在与内部计算机协作以重新路由神经信号。”

“You want me to move all that? While the connection apparatus is in place—and in operation? It is working with the internal computer now to reroute nerve signals.”

她转身离开：绍尔希特将军的持续沉默就是最好的答案。

She turned on her heel and left: General Schorcht’s continuing silence was answer enough.

她一边哼着歌，一边走进办公室，打开了笨重的咖啡机。多莉坐在椅子边上，艾琳用勺子指着她。

She was humming cheerfully when she entered her office and turned on the hulking coffee machine. Dolly sat on the edge of her chair and Erin pointed a spoon at her.

“来一杯浓咖啡怎么样？”

“How about a nice strong espresso?”

“我不喝咖啡。”

“I don’t drink coffee.”

“你应该喝。它肯定比酒精更容易促进新陈代谢。”

“You should. It is certainly easier on the metabolism than alcohol.”

“我睡不着，这是咖啡因造成的。我也不喝酒。”

“I can’t sleep, it’s the caffeine you see. Nor do I drink alcohol either.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克一边喝着咖啡，一边同情地点点头，这是对那个无法回答的问题的回答，然后她坐在办公桌前，屏幕上显示了他们上次采访的记录笔记。

Nodding sympathetically over the coffee, an answer to the unanswerable, Snaresbrook sat down at her desk and brought up on the screen the transcribed notes of their previous interview.

“上次你来这里的时候，多莉告诉我很多非常重要的事情。你不仅记忆力好，理解力也很强。你对布莱恩来说是个好妈妈，很慈爱，这一点从你谈论他的方式就可以看出来。”她抬头看了一眼，发现对方听到这句随意的赞美时脸微微红了起来；生活对多莉并不那么友善，赞美非常少见。“你还记得布莱恩什么时候进入青春期吗？”艾琳问道，脸更红了。

“You told me a lot of very vital things last time you were here, Dolly. You not only have a good memory but a deep understanding. You were a good and affectionate mother to Brian, that is obvious in the way you speak about him.” She glanced up and saw that the other woman was blushing lightly at this casual compliment; life had not been that kind to Dolly and compliments very rare. “Do you remember when Brian reached puberty?” Erin asked, and the blush deepened.

“嗯，你知道，这不像女孩那样明显。但我认为他还年轻，大约十三岁。”

“Well, you know, it’s not as obvious as with girls. But he was young I think, around thirteen.”

“这是最重要的。到目前为止，我们一直在追踪他小时候的情感生活，然后继续追踪他的学习模式和智力发展史。一切都进展顺利。但青春期到来时，他的情绪和生理会发生重大变化。我们必须深入探索那个时间和区域，并尽可能详细地记录下来。你记得他约会过——或者有过女朋友吗？”

“This is most important. Up until now we have been tracking his emotional life as a small child, then going on to follow his learning patterns and intellectual history. That is all going very well. But major emotional and physiological changes take place with the onset of puberty. That time and area must be explored in depth, charted as well as we can. Do you remember him dating—or having any girlfriends?”

“不，不是那样的。他曾经和一位女孩约会过一段时间，她有时会来他家玩他的电脑。但似乎没持续多久。她是唯一一个。当然，他们之间还有年龄差距，她比他大很多。所以他们之间的关系只能是柏拉图式的。我记得她是个漂亮的小姑娘。她叫金。”

“No, nothing like that. Well there was a girl he saw for a bit, she would come around the house to use his computer sometimes. But it didn’t seem to last very long. She was the only one. Then of course there was the matter of their age difference, she was much older than him. So the relationship could only have been platonic. I do remember that she was a pretty little thing. Name of Kim.”

 

 

“金，我现在想让你看一下你的检查结果，”贝瑟博士说。“你上周遇到了麻烦，除非你确切知道发生了什么，否则你无法进入下一步。现在看看这个。”

“Kim, I want you to take a look at your screen right now,” Dr. Betser said. “You had trouble with this last week and until you know exactly what is happening you won’t be able to move on to the next step. Now look at this.”

老师将这些方程式输入到他自己的计算机中——这台计算机不仅将它们显示在教室前面的屏幕上，还同时将它们输入到所有学生的台式计算机中。

The instructor had typed the equations into his own computer—which not only displayed them on the screen in front of the class but entered them into the desk computers of all the students at the same moment.

“给我们演示一下怎么做，”他说完，把命令转交给了她。金不情愿地触摸了键盘，所有人的目光都集中在屏幕上。

“Show us how to do it,” he said and switched command to her. All eyes were on the screen as Kim reluctantly touched her keyboard.

所有人的目光都集中在布莱恩身上。他输入问题后一分钟内就找到了解决方案。大学生活变得和高中一样令人沮丧。他几乎把所有的课堂时间都花在等待其他人赶上他身上。他们是一群愚蠢而卑鄙的人，他们把他当成怪物一样看不起。他们全都比他大四、五岁——而大多数人比他高出一个头。有时他觉得自己像个侏儒。这不仅仅是他的偏执——他们真的讨厌他，他确信这一点。不喜欢他是因为他年轻，不适合这里。也有很多嫉妒，因为他比他们做得好得多，速度也快得多。那些真正懂得如何思考的人，比如图灵、爱因斯坦或费曼，他们是如何完成学业的？

All eyes except Brian’s. He had worked out the solution within a minute after the problem had been entered. College was becoming as frustrating as high school had been. He spent almost all of his class time waiting for the others to catch up with him. They were a stupid and despicable lot who looked down on him like some kind of freak. All of them were four, five years older than he was—while most of them stood a head taller. At times he felt like a midget. And it wasn’t just paranoia on his part—they really did hate him, he was sure of it. Disliked him because he was younger, out of place here. Plenty of jealousy too, since he did the work so much better and faster than they did. How had people who really knew how to think, like Turing or Einstein or Feynman, how had they managed to live through school?

他看着屏幕，努力不让自己呻吟，因为女孩把它搞得一团糟。这实在太可怕了。他漫不经心地把袖珍计算器推到终端的侧面，输入了一个快速代码。屏幕上的一个窗口中出现了一串意大利语动词，他滚动浏览，记住了新词。

He looked at his screen and tried not to groan as the girl made a hash of it. It was too awful to watch. He casually pushed his pocket calculator against the side of his terminal and punched in a quick code. A list of Italian verbs appeared in a window on the screen and he scrolled through them, memorizing the new ones.

布莱恩很早就发现，学校窃听了每个学生的电脑，并记录了输入电脑的所有数据。从学生向他提出的一些问题中可以明显看出这一点，而这些知识只能通过这种暗中获取。一旦他发现这一点，他就会确保学校的电脑只用于做作业。他观察到，他的老师，尤其是贝特瑟博士，非常确信他们的话是金玉良言——如果他们发现他在上课时一直在玩战争游戏或访问数据库，而不是全神贯注地听课，他们会非常生气。但一切都有办法解决。如果教室里的所有电脑都通过电缆连接起来，那么误导信息可能会更容易——或者更难。但现在，窄带红外链路（如以太网系统）让整个房间充满了隐形通信。每台计算机都有一个数字可调的 LED，即发光二极管，它在低噪声信道上传输。光电探测器接收它调谐到的消息。布莱恩的解决办法是，在一个看起来像袖珍计算器的东西里安装一个拦截装置。当它被放在电脑旁边时，它会拦截传入的信号并重新广播。这样他就可以随心所欲地做任何事，而不会被任何人发现。屏幕上的内容只有他自己才能看到！Allattare可以喂食或哺乳…… allenare可以锻炼、训练。

Brian had discovered, very early on, that the school tapped into every student’s computer and recorded all the data that was entered into it. This was made obvious by some of the questions they had asked him, knowledge they could only have obtained in this underhand way. Once he had discovered it, he made sure that the school computer was just used for schoolwork. He had observed that his teachers, Dr. Betser in particular, were quite certain that their words were golden—and would be quite upset if they discovered that during their lectures he had been running war games or accessing data bases instead of giving them a hundred percent attention. But there were ways around everything. If all of the computers in the schoolroom had been connected by cables it might have been easier—or harder to misdirect information. But now narrow-band infrared links, like ethernet systems, filled the room with invisible communication. Every computer had a digitally tunable LED, a light-emitting diode, that transmitted on low-noise channels. A photodetector picked up messages it was tuned to. Brian’s solution to this was to build an intercepting device into what appeared to be a pocket calculator. When it was placed at the side of his computer it intercepted the incoming signal and rebroadcast it. So he could do whatever he wished without anyone being able to detect the operation. What was on the screen was for his eyes alone! Allattare to feed or to nurse… allenare to exercise, to train.

他仍然关注着课堂，并隐约意识到贝特瑟博士的声音里带着疲惫而唠叨的语气。

He was still keeping track of the class and became vaguely aware that Dr. Betser’s voice was taking on that weary, nagging tone.

“……对如何进行逐次逼近的基本误解。除非你理解了这个基本要点，否则你将无法取得进一步的进展。布莱恩——你能正确地做到这一点吗，这样我们才能继续前进。还有，金，我想在课后见到你。”

“… a basic misunderstanding of how we make successive approximations. Unless you get this basic point, you’ll never get any further. Brian—will you do this correctly so we can move on. And, Kim, I want to see you after class.”

布莱恩把计算器推到一边，意大利语动词消失了。他看着屏幕，发现了她的第一个错误。“误解从这里开始，”他说着，移动光标，突出显示了方程式。“找到一阶解后，你必须把它去掉——从原始方程中减去——然后才能应用相同的方法找到下一个项。如果你忘了做这件事，你就会一直得到同一个项。然后你必须除以独立变量，否则下次你只会得到零。最后，你必须再次倒退，把这些项加回去，再把变量乘回去。我认为问题在于班上的每个人都认为这里有很多不同的想法，导数、近似值、二阶近似值等等。但只有一个想法，被反复使用。我不明白他们为什么要把它弄得这么复杂……”

The Italian verbs vanished as Brian pushed the calculator aside. He looked at the screen and tracked her first error. “The misconception begins here,” he said, moving the cursor and highlighting the equation. “After you find the first-order solution, you have to remove it—subtract it from the original equation—before you can apply the same method to find the next term. If you forget to do that, you’ll keep getting the same term again. And then you have to divide out the independent variable, or you will just get zero the next time. And finally, you have to go backward again, adding the terms back in and multiplying back the variable again. I think the trouble is that everyone in the class believes that there are a lot of different ideas here, derivatives, approximations, second-order approximations, and so on. But there’s only one idea, used over and over. I don’t see why they make it out to be so complicated…”

一个小时后，布莱恩一边吃着奶酪番茄三明治，一边读着《南河三号的银河战犬》，这时，有人重重地坐到了他旁边的长凳上。这已经够不寻常的了，因为其他学生都把他单独留在那里。更不寻常的是，那根晒得黝黑的手指从他手里夺走了书，然后重重地摔在桌子上。

An hour later Brian was eating his cheese and tomato sandwich and reading Galaxy Warhounds of Procyon when someone sat down heavily on the bench beside him. This was unusual enough since he was left strictly alone by the other students. More unusual were the tanned fingers that pulled the book from him and slammed it onto the table.

“只有小孩才会读的幼稚科幻太空垃圾，”金厉声对他说。

“Juvenile science fiction space crap that only kids read,” Kim snapped at him.

他以前就经常这样说。“科幻小说使用的词汇量是所有其他通俗小说的两倍。而科幻小说读者则处于前百分之一……”

He had had this argument often enough before. “Science fiction utilizes a vocabulary twice as large as that of all other popular fiction. While SF readers are in the top percentile…”

“太空球！你今天让我看上去太蠢了。”

“Space balls! You made me look pretty dumb today.”

“好吧，你真是太蠢了！对不起。”

“Well you were pretty dumb! I’m sorry.”

布莱恩忧心忡忡的表情让她心烦意乱；无论如何，她都不会生气太久。她大笑起来，把他的书推回给他。把它推到桌上的一片西红柿上。他微笑着用餐巾擦拭封面。

Brian’s worried expression got to her; she could never stay angry very long in any case. She laughed aloud and pushed his book back to him. Pushing it through a slice of tomato on the table. He smiled and wiped the cover with his napkin.

“事实上这根本就不是你的错，”他说。“老贝特瑟可能是一位天才的编程数学家，但他根本不懂得向任何人解释这一点。”

“In fact it wasn’t even your fault anyway,” he said. “Old Betser may be a wizard programming mathematician but he doesn’t know a gnat’s fart about explaining it to anyone.”

“你什么意思？”她现在来了兴趣，伸出手掰下他三明治的一角。他注意到她的牙齿洁白整齐，嘴唇红润——而且没有涂口红。他把剩下的三明治推到她面前。

“What do you mean?” She was interested now, reached out and broke off a corner of his sandwich. He noticed that her teeth were very white and neat, her lips red—and that was without lipstick. He pushed the remains of the sandwich over to her.

“他总是离题万里，解释一些与他应该教授的内容无关的事情，诸如此类。我总是比他提前一章看完课文，这样当他开始解释某件事时，我就不会感到困惑。”

“He’s always going off on tangents, getting sidetracked into explanations that have nothing to do with the material he should be teaching, things like that. I always stay a chapter ahead of him in the text so he won’t confuse me when he starts to explain something.”

“太棒了！”金说，他指的是在有那么多精彩的事情要做的时候，你竟然可以读一篇你不必读的文章。“你能比他做得更好吗，自作聪明的人？”

“Amazing!” Kim said, meaning the thought of reading a text you didn’t have to when there were so many other wonderful things to do. “Can you do better than him, Mr. Smartass?”

“绕着他转，伯德布雷恩小姐。使用迄今为止完全保密的布莱恩·德莱尼闪电指令系统，一切都会明朗！首先，确切地知道如何解决每个问题并不是那么重要。”

“Run circles around him, Miss Birdbrain. Using the heretofore totally secret Brian Delaney lightning instruction system all will be made clear! In the first place, it’s not really so important to know exactly how to solve each problem.”

“这听起来很蠢。如果你不知道如何解决问题，你怎么能解决问题呢？”

“That sounds stupid. How can you solve a problem if you don’t know how to solve it?”

“通过做相反的事情。你可以学到很多不解决问题的方法。很多错误的方法不值得尝试。然后，一旦你找到了最常见的错误，你就很难不去尝试就去做正确的事情了。”

“By doing just the opposite. You can learn a lot of ways not to solve it. A lot of wrong methods not to try. Then, once you find the most common mistakes, you can hardly help doing the right thing without even trying.”

他清楚地记得她错在哪里，并且立刻知道她误会了什么。他耐心地解释了两三种方法，直到她终于明白了。

He remembered exactly where she had gone wrong and knew at once what her misunderstanding was. He explained it patiently, two or three ways, until she finally caught on.

“这就是我的问题所在！为什么野兽贝特瑟不这样解释呢？这很明显。”

“Is that what my trouble was! Why didn’t Beastly Betser explain it like that? It’s obvious.”

“一旦你理解了，一切都会变得显而易见。趁你头脑清楚的时候，为什么不研究一下其余的例子呢？”

“Everything is obvious once you understand it. Why don’t you work through the rest of those examples while this is clear in your head?”

“也许明天吧。我还有事要做，得走了。”

“Maybe tomorrow. Got things to do, gotta run.”

她确实跑了，或者至少是小跑着走出了餐厅，他看着她走开，摇了摇头。女孩！她们是奇怪的品种。他打开书，看到红色番茄渍时不禁皱了皱眉。马虎。思维也很马虎，她应该趁事情还新鲜的时候把事情想清楚。五块钱十块钱，她明天就会把整件事都忘了。

Run she did, or at least trotted out of the dining room, and he shook his head as he watched her go. Girls! They were a strange breed. He opened his book and winced at the red tomato stains. Sloppy. Sloppy thinking too, she should have worked this thing out while it was fresh in her head. Five will get you ten she would forget the whole thing by tomorrow.

她照做了。“你说得对！它不见了，一点儿痕迹都没有。我以为我记得，但记不太清楚。”

She did. “You were right! It was gone, zip. I thought I remembered, but not exactly.”

他夸张地叹了口气，翻了个白眼。金咯咯地笑了。

He sighed dramatically and rolled his eyes heavenward. Kim giggled.

“听着，”他说，“如果你不花更多的时间确保它一直被学习，那么花时间去学习真的没什么用。首先，如果你只以一种方式去理解任何东西，你就无法真正理解它。你必须对每个新想法进行一点思考——它和哪些旧想法相似，哪些旧想法真正不同。如果你不把它和其他一些东西联系起来，它就会在任何事情发生变化的那一刻消失。这就是我昨天说的，解决方案并不重要。重要的是差异和相似之处。”他知道这没有效果，所以他打出了王牌。“无论如何，我编写了一个自动辅导程序，可以简化逐次逼近的主题。我会给你一份副本。然后，当你的大脑开始落下帷幕时，你可以运行它，一切都会立即清晰起来。至少它能让你通过这部分课程。”

“Look,” he said, “there’s really not much use spending the time to learn something unless you spend a little more time making sure that it stays learnt. First, you can’t really understand anything if you only understand it one way. You have to think a little about each new idea—which old ones it is like, and which are really different. If you don’t connect it to a few other things, it will evaporate the moment anything changes. That’s what I meant yesterday, about the solution not being important. It’s the differences and similarities.” He could see that this was having no effect, so he played his ace. “Anyway, I worked out an auto-tutor program that simplifies the subject of successive approximations. I’ll give you a copy. Then you can run it whenever the curtain starts to fall in your brain and all will be made instantly clear. At least it will get you through this part of the course.”

“你真的有这样的程序吗？”

“You really have a program like that?”

“我会骗你吗？”

“Would I lie to you?”

“我不知道。我真的对你一无所知，IQ 小子先生。”

“I don’t know. I really don’t know anything about you at all, Mister I.Q. Kid.”

“你为什么这样叫我？”他又生气又伤心，两种感觉交织在一起。他偷听到其他学生在背后这样叫他。笑了起来。

“Why did you call me that?” He was angry, hurt, both feelings mixed together. He had overheard the other students calling him that behind his back. Laughing.

“对不起——我不是故意的，我只是没想到。任何这样叫你的白痴都是白痴。我道歉是为了让你不生气。”

“I’m sorry—I didn’t mean it, I just never thought. Any moron that calls you that must be a moron. I apologized so you can’t be angry.”

“我没有，”他说，然后意识到他是认真的。“给我你的登录 ID，我会把那个程序的副本复制到你的调制解调器上。”

“I’m not,” he said, and realized mat he meant it. “Give me your log-on ID and I’ll zap a copy of that program to your modem.”

“我总是忘记身份证，但我把它写在某个地方了。”

“I always forget the ID, but I’ve written it down someplace.”

布莱恩呻吟道：“你绝对不能忘记你的身份证。这就像忘记你的血型一样。”

Brian groaned. “You simply can’t forget your ID. That’s like forgetting your blood type.”

“但我不知道我的血型！”

“But I don’t know my blood type!”

他们都笑了，他找到了唯一的解决办法。“你最好到我家来，我会给你一份。”

They both laughed at that and he found the only solution. “You better come over to my place and I’ll give you a copy.”

“你会的？你真是个好人，布莱恩·德莱尼。”

“You will? You’re a great guy, Brian Delaney.”

她感激地握着他的手。她的手指非常非常温暖。

She shook his hand in gratitude. Her fingers were very, very warm.

 

 

8
8

2023 年 3 月 25 日
March 25, 2023

 

 

排队的人都在嘀咕，但贝尼科夫却没有。他不仅不介意，而且很享受这种安全感。当他终于找到两名宪兵时，他们冷冷地要求他出示身份证——尽管他们很了解他。他们仔细检查了他的身份证，然后检查了他的医院通行证，然后才让他走到医院的前门。里面的另一个警卫为他打开了门。

There were muttered complaints from people waiting in the line, but not from Benicoff. Not only didn’t he mind—he enjoyed the security. When he finally reached the two M.P.s they coldly asked him for his ID—although they knew him very well. They examined this closely, then his hospital pass, before they let him approach the front door of the hospital. Another guard inside unlocked it for him.

“有什么麻烦吗，警官？”

“Any troubles, Sergeant?”

“就是那个你知道是谁的人。”

“None other than the usual with you-know-who.”

贝尼科夫点点头表示理解。当绍尔希特将军训斥中士时，他就在场，中士的胳膊肘处到处都是血痕，他是一名上士，但将军并不在意。“我也和他有矛盾——这就是我来这里的原因。”

Benicoff nodded in understanding. He had been present when General Schorcht had chewed the Sergeant out, him with hash marks up to his elbows, a Master Sergeant, not that the General cared. “I got my troubles with him too— which is why I’m here.”

“生活很艰难，”警官毫无同情心地说道。贝尼科夫找到了内线电话，打电话给斯纳尔斯布鲁克的秘书，发现这位外科医生在图书馆里，并得到了如何找到它的指示。

“It’s a tough life,” the Sergeant said with marked lack of sympathy. Benicoff found the internal phone and called Snaresbrook’s secretary, discovered that the surgeon was in the library, got instructions how to find it.

墙上摆满了皮革封面的医学书籍，但这些书籍都是多年前的旧书，只是用来装饰而已。图书馆完全电脑化，因为所有技术书籍都是以数字形式出版的。只有在为插图和图形（大多数情况下都是动画）制定了惯例和标准后，这才成为可能。因此，任何医学书籍或期刊一经出版就会立即输入图书馆的数据库。艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克坐在终端机前，发出指令。

Leather-bound medical books lined the walls; but all of them were years out of date and just there for decoration. The library was completely computerized, since all technical books were published in digital form. This had only become possible when conventions and standards were set for illustrations and graphics which were animated most of the time. So any medical book or journal was entered into the library’s data base the instant that it was published. Erin Snaresbrook sat in front of a terminal speaking instructions.

“我可以打断一下吗？”贝尼科夫问道。

“Can I interrupt?” Benicoff asked.

“两秒钟后。我去电脑里复制了一份。好了。”她按下回车键，项目立即传输到楼上她自己的电脑的数据库中。外科医生点点头，在椅子上转了一圈。“我今天上午和一位俄罗斯朋友聊天，他告诉我这件事。这是在圣彼得堡，卢里亚的一名学生。一些关于神经再生的非常原创的研究。我能为您做些什么？”

“In two seconds. I went to make a copy of this in my computer. There.” She hit return and the item was instantly transferred to the data base in her own computer upstairs. The surgeon nodded and spun about in her chair. “I was talking to a friend in Russia this a.m. , he told me about this. It’s in St. Petersburg, a student of Luria. Some very original work on nerve regeneration. What can I do for you?”

“绍尔希特将军一直缠着我要更详细的报告。所以我就缠着你了。”

“General Schorcht keeps bugging me for more detailed reports. So I bug you.”

“正如我们的俄罗斯朋友所说，Niet prahblem。但你的结局如何？那里有进展吗？”

“Niet prahblem, as our Russian friends say. But what about your end? Progress there?”

“绝对的死路一条。如果有线索，我怀疑它的存在，而且每天都在变得越来越冷清。没有线索，没有线索，不知道是谁做的，也不知道他们是怎么做的。我不应该知道这些，但联邦调查局已经设法秘密窃取了每个大学、每个主要行业的每个人工智能实验室或部门的数据，以报告任何突然的变化或新信息的输入。他们正在寻找从布莱恩那里偷来的人工智能数据。当然，问题是他们不知道该找什么。”

“An absolute dead end. If there is a trail, and I doubt it, it gets colder every day. No hints, no clues, no idea of who did it or how they did it. I’m not supposed to know this, but the FBI has managed to get undercover data taps into every AI lab or department of every university, every major industry in the country, to report any sudden changes or input of new information. They are looking out for the AI data stolen from Brian. Of course the trouble is that they don’t exactly know what to look for.”

“听起来，这样的侦查有点违法。”

“Sounds sort of illegal, snooping like that.”

“是的。不过我会忍一小会儿，然后再揭发他们。不过我担心的不是这个。真正的问题是安全机构是否有足够的专家来解释部分或全部数据。我们必须找到线索。当然，这也是将军烦我的原因。”

“It is. But I’ll put up with it for a short time before I blow the whistle on them. But that’s not what worries me. The real question is whether the security agencies have enough experts to interpret any or all of that data. We must get a lead. Which of course is why the General is bugging me.”

“因为布莱恩可能记得一些事情，恢复过来，以任何方式做出反应——这是我们唯一的机会？太有趣了。我在糟糕的小说里读到过‘他沮丧地点点头’现在我知道那是什么样子了，因为你刚刚做到了。”

“Because the possibility that Brian may remember something, recover, respond in any way—is the only chance we have? Fascinating. I’ve read in bad novels ‘he nodded gloomily’ Now I know what it looks like because you just did it.”

“令人沮丧、令人沮丧、令人自杀——随便你选吧。布莱恩呢？”

“Gloomily, depressingly, suicidally—take your pick. And Brian?”

“我们的进展不错，但时间不多了。”

“Our progress has been good, but we are running out of time.”

“他的情况越来越糟，正在退步！”

“He’s getting worse, regressing!”

“不是那样，你误会了。现代医学可以稳定身体，在精神失控的情况下让它活上好几年。从身体上讲，我可以让布莱恩在康复室里待到他老死。我不认为我们想这么做。我的意思是，我已经追踪并重新连接了近一百万根神经纤维。我已经追踪并访问了布莱恩最早的记忆，从出生到大约十二岁。胶片连接器和计算机已经安装到位，在不久的将来，它们应该可以建立所有可能的连接。我已经用这种技术做到了我能做到的极限。”

“Not that, you misunderstood. Modern medicine can stabilize a body, keep it alive for years when the mind is not in control. Physically, I could leave Brian in the recovery unit until he died of old age. I don’t think we want to do that. What I mean is that I have traced and reconnected nearly a million nerve fibers. I’ve tracked and accessed Brian’s earliest memories, from birth right up until about age twelve. The film connectors and computer are in place and in the very near future they should have hopefully made all of the possible connections. I have gone about as far as I can go with this technique.”

“我们需要成年人来回答我们的问题，为什么你要关注他的童年呢？”

“Why are you working on his childhood—when it is the adult we need to answer our questions?”

“因为那句老话“儿为父”说得很对。在低级大脑开始运作之前，我们无法恢复高级大脑连接。这意味着人类大脑的庞大结构只能从下往上重建——就像最初建造它的方式一样……”

“Because the old expression about the child being the father of the man is quite true. There is no way we can restore the higher level brain connections until the lower levels begin to operate. This means that the enormous structure of the human mind can be rebuilt only from the bottom up—in much the same way it was built in the first place…”

“当你说构建心智时——由什么构建？”

“When you say building a mind—built of what?”

“心智由许多小部件组成，每个部件本身都是无意识的。我们称这些基本部件为代理。每个代理本身只能做一些简单的事情，根本不需要心智或思考。但是当代理以某种非常社会化的方式连接起来时，它们就会像社会一样一起工作——这就是智能从非智能中产生的过程。

“The mind is made of many small parts, each mindless by itself. We call these basic parts agents. Each agent by itself can only do some simple thing that needs no mind or thought at all. But when the agents get connected up, in certain very social ways, they work together as societies—-that’s how intelligence emerges from non-intelligence.

“幸运的是，大多数智能体本身都没事，因为它们的脑细胞位于未受伤的灰质中。但智能体之间的大多数连接都穿过大脑的白质——而太多的连接已被切断。这就是我现在所处的位置。在感觉和运动层面定位和重新连接大量最简单的智能体。如果我能重建布莱恩成长过程中每个阶段形成的智能体社会，这将为我修复他在下一个时期形成的结构奠定基础。一个阶段又一个阶段。一层又一层。以及它们之间不同类型的交叉连接。同时，我必须恢复每个级别智能体之间的反馈回路，以及控制推理和学习的大脑其他部分的系统。这些不同类型的回路和环至关重要，因为它们支持着将人类与动物思维区分开来的深思熟虑和反思活动。目前，我几乎已经完成了重建的第一阶段。几天后我就会知道我是否成功了。”

“Fortunately, most of the agents themselves are okay, because their brain cells are located in the uninjured gray matter. But most of the connections between the agents thread their way through the brain’s white matter—and too many of those connections have been severed. That is where I am now. Locating and reconnecting large numbers of the simplest agents, at the sensory and motor levels. If I can reconstruct enough of the society of agents formed during each stage of Brian’s development, that will give me a foundation for repairing the structures that were formed in his next period. Stage after stage. Layer after layer. And the different kinds of cross-connections between them. While at the same time I have to restore the feedback loops between the agents at each level, as well as the systems in other parts of the brain that control reasoning and learning. These different kinds of loops and rings are crucial because they are what supports the thoughtful and reflective activity that distinguishes human from animal thinking. At the present time I am almost at the end of this first period of rebuilding. In a few days I will know if I have succeeded or not.”

贝尼科夫惊讶地摇了摇头。“你让我习惯了把思考不可想象的事情当作日常习惯。你做的事情太新颖了，太不同了，以至于我发现它基本上——我很抱歉这么说——令人难以理解。你能进入布莱恩的脑海，倾听他的想法，修复造成的损害！你比我好。你这样做的时候他有什么感觉吗？”

Benicoff shook his head in wonderment. “You are getting me used to thinking the unthinkable as a daily habit. What you are doing is so new, so different, that I find it basically—I’m sorry to say this—incomprehensible. That you can enter Brian’s head, listen to his thoughts and repair the damage done! Better you than me. Does he feel anything while you are doing this?”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克耸耸肩。“这真的没办法说。我想这种体验将是难以描述的，因为它发生在一个还不是人类的头脑中。然而，我个人认为，在重建他的大脑时，他的思想很可能会回溯和重温他生命中的重要早期事件。”

Snaresbrook shrugged. “There is really no way to tell. I suppose the experience will be indescribable because it is happening to a mind that is not yet human. My personal belief, however, is that while his brain is being reconstructed his mind might very well be retracing and reliving the important early events of his life.”

 

 

* * *

*  *  *

 

 

多莉走下走廊时听到电脑键盘敲击声，她笑了。布莱恩通常都是一个人，很高兴看到他和校友在一起。

Dolly could hear the clatter of computer keys as she came down the hall; she smiled. Brian was usually alone so much, it was nice to see him with a school friend.

“有人想吃新鲜出炉的巧克力曲奇吗？”她递过盘子问道。金高兴得尖叫起来。

“Anyone for a fresh-baked chocolate-chip cookie?” she said, holding out the plate. Kim squeaked with pleasure.

“我就是其中之一，德莱尼夫人。谢谢！”

“Me for one, Mrs. Delaney. Thanks!”

“布莱恩？”

“Brian?”

“先把这个做完，”他嘀咕道。“来吧，金。如果你在休息前把这个做完，效果会好得多。你才刚刚开始理解什么是基向量。”

“Finish this first,” he muttered. “Come on, Kim. It would be a lot better if you did this before you take a break. You are just beginning to understand what basis vectors are.”

“我们可以稍后再吃。拿一个吧。”

“We can finish it later. Take one.”

布莱恩叹了口气，把一块还热着的饼干塞进嘴里。“好吃。”他结结巴巴地说。

Brian sighed and pushed one of the still-warm cookies into his mouth. “Good,” he spluttered.

“我要去拿一些冷牛奶来搭配它。”

“I’ll get some cold milk to go with that.”

多莉端着盛满酒的托盘时，还带着手提包。“我得去市场，那里会很拥挤。这意味着我会迟到，如果你父亲比我先到，他会不高兴的。告诉他晚餐会像往常一样在六点开始，现在就可以用微波炉加热了。你不会忘记吧？”

When Dolly brought the tray with the filled glasses she had her purse with her. “I’ve got to go to the market and it is going to be crowded. Which means I’ll be late and your father will be upset if he gets in before I do. Tell him that dinner will be at six like always and it’s ready for the microwave now. You won’t forget?”

多莉离开后，布莱恩摇摇头，一饮而尽。他放下杯子，转身回到电脑前。“现在，继续我们刚才的对话。”

Brian shook his head and drained the glass as Dolly left. He put it down and turned back to the computer. “Now to pick up where we left off.”

“不！”金说。“我们要休息一下，记得吗？”她把书推到一边，倒在床上，把他的枕头打成一个大堆，然后把它放在身后。“休息就是休息——你必须学会​​这一点。”

“No!” Kim said. “We’re taking a break, remember?” She pushed the books aside and dropped onto the bed, punched his pillow into a mound and settled it behind her back. “A break is a break—and you have to learn that.”

“工作就是工作，你必须学会​​这一点。比如，看看你的学期论文。”他转动转椅，按下滚动按钮。屏幕上的副本翻过，大部分都是红色方块上的白色字母。“你看到所有的红色副本了吗？你知道这意味着什么吗？”

“Work is work and you have to learn that. Just look at your term paper, for instance.” He spun his revolving chair about and punched the scroll button. The copy flipped by in the screen, most of it white letters against red blocks. “Do you see all the red copy? You know what it means?”

“你流鼻血了吗？”

“You had a nosebleed?”

“你应该认真对待这件事，金。你知道我一直在帮你写 Bastard Betser 的论文，添加一些内容，并在你做错的时候纠正它。只是为了好玩，我想检查一下我的输入，并开始用红色标记我正在做的事情，所有我所做的更正和更改。这里的红色肯定比白色多得多。”

“You ought to take this seriously, Kim. You know that I’ve been helping you with this paper for Bastard Betser, adding bits and straightening it out when you get it wrong. Just for the heck of it I wanted to check up on my input and started marking off the blocks of what I was doing in red, all the corrections and changes that I had made. There is sure a lot more red than white here.”

“这个世界除了人工智能还有很多其他东西。既然你站起来了，就给我拿块饼干过来。”

“There is a lot more to the world than AI. Since you are standing up, bring me over a cookie.”

“你这门课不会及格。”他站起来，把盘子递给她。

“You’re going to flunk this course.” He got up and passed her the plate.

“没什么大不了的。也许我会辍学，嫁给一个百万富翁，开着自己的游艇环游世界。”

“Big deal. So maybe I flunk out of school altogether and marry a millionaire and travel around the world on my own yacht.”

“你这个来自钻井平台的乡巴佬说话真夸张。我敢打赌你根本就没上过岸。”

“You talk big for a Redneck from the Rigs. I bet you’ve never even been ashore.”

“我去过很多地方，小伙子，我去过很多地方。”她舔掉指尖上的巧克力，半闭上眼睛，用沙哑的法国口音假装说，“我去过很多地方，我曾让王子为之疯狂。”

“I have been around, leetle man, I have been around.” She licked the chocolate from her fingertips and half closed her eyes, spoke huskily in a fake French accent. “I have zeen zee world, have driven ziz prince mad with passion.”

“无聊得发疯！金，你的头脑很好。只是你不喜欢用它。”

“Mad with boredom! You’ve got a good mind, Kim. You just don’t like to use it.”

“心智！心智够了。那你的身体呢？”

“Mind! Enough zee mind. What about zee body?”

她拉开上衣的上衣，露出了乳沟。她拉得太用力，上衣就大张着，露出了裸露的乳房，还有一颗甜美的粉红色乳头。她一边扣上上衣，一边咯咯地笑着。

She pulled at the top of her blouse to disclose her cleavage. Pulled a little too enthusiastically and the blouse opened wide disclosing one bare breast, a sweet pink nipple. She giggled as she buttoned the blouse.

“我让他们的男人疯狂……”

“I drive zee men mad…”

当她看到这场事故对布莱恩的影响时，她的声音渐渐消失了。他的皮肤变得苍白，眼睛睁得大大的。

Her voice died away as she saw the effect the accident had had on Brian. His skin had gone pale, his eyes wide.

“放松，”她说。“你以前在那些怪人聚集的肉体海滩上见过很多裸露的皮肤。”

“Relax,” she said. “You’ve seen lots of bare skin before down on flesh beach where all the kooks hang out.”

“我从来没有去过那里，”他声音嘶哑地说道。

“I’ve never been there,” he said, his voice hoarse.

“好吧，我不怪你。有些长得丑的男人和女人是裸体主义者。”她抬头看着他，扬起眉毛。“嘿，你多大了？”

“Well I don’t blame you. Some pretty ugly guys and gals are naturists.” She looked up at him and arched her eyebrows. “Hey, how old are you?”

“十三。”

“Thirteen.”

她跳起来跪下，直视他的眼睛。“你和我一样高，长得也不错。你吻过女孩吗？”

She bounced up onto her knees and looked him in the eye. “You’re as tall as I am and not too bad looking. Ever kissed a girl?”

“我们去工作吧，”他转身不自在地说。她抓住他的肩膀，把他拉回来。“这不是答案——我知道你了解女孩，因为我在你的床下发现了一些旧的《花花公子》杂志——上面有你眼睛在插页裸照上留下的灼痕。也许你知道它们长什么样——但我敢打赌，你只有 13 岁，从来没有被吻过——所以你现在要知道了。”

“Let’s go to work,” he said uncomfortably as he turned away. She took him by the shoulder and pulled him back. “That’s no answer—and I know you know about girls because I found some old Playboys under your bed—with scorch tracks that your eyes had left on all the centerfold nudes. Maybe you know what they look like—but I’ll bet dollars to dongles that you are sweet thirteen and have never been kissed—so you’re going to learn now.”

当她轻轻地将布莱恩的头捧在手中，将他的嘴唇拉向自己时，布莱恩并没有退开。她发出一声快乐的哼唱，将舌头伸进他的嘴唇，感觉到他的手在她背上变硬。她将手往下移；这不是唯一困难的事情。

Brian did not pull away when she took his head gently in her hands and pulled his mouth down to hers. She made a happy humming sound and let her tongue drift inside his lips, felt his hands harden on her back. She moved her hand down; that wasn’t the only thing that was hard.

她解开了他的腰带。

She opened his belt.

 

 

布莱恩无法理解的是，为什么大家只是看着他却不知道发生了什么。这件事如此重大，如此惊天动地，他脸上一定写得出来。每当他想到这件事，他都能感觉到自己的皮肤因记忆的力量而闪闪发光。多莉回家时，金已经走了；几分钟后，他听到父亲回来了。他尽可能久地待在房间里，直到第二次被叫去吃晚饭。

What Brian could not understand was why everyone didn’t know what had happened just by looking at him. It was so momentous, earth-shattering, that it must show on his face. Whenever he thought about it he could feel his skin glow with the strength of his memories. Kim was gone by the time Dolly came home; he heard his father arrive a few minutes later. He stayed in his room as long as he could, waiting until he was called a second time for dinner.

但他们俩都没有注意到。布莱恩低着头默默地吃着饭。他们正在讨论下周末有人邀请他们去参加烧烤活动，两人都不想去。但这是公事，不是消遣，最后他们做出了显而易见的决定。他们几乎没有意识到布莱恩已经离开餐桌，回到了自己的房间。

But neither of them noticed a thing. Brian ate in silence, face lowered over his plate. They were discussing a barbecue they had been invited to next weekend; neither wanted to go. But it was business not pleasure and in the end they made the obvious decision. They were barely aware that he had left the table and was back in his room.

最让布莱恩困扰的是，发生的事情似乎对金姆没有丝毫影响。第二天早上，她在走廊里和他擦肩而过，只说了声“嗨！”，没有其他反应。他在学校里整天都在想这件事，嘟囔着一些让老师大吃一惊的错误答案，然后逃掉了下午的所有课程，去钻井平台。独自一人在海上。

The thing that bothered Brian most was that what had happened did not seem to have affected Kim in the slightest. The next morning she passed him in the hall with a “Hi!” and nothing else. He thought about it all day in school, muttered some incorrect answers which shocked his teachers, then cut all of his afternoon classes and went out on the rigs. Alone above the sea.

如果他对所发生的事如此感同身受——为什么她不呢？当他这样问的时候，答案很明显。因为她以前做过。她十八岁，比他大五岁，有五年的时间对男孩产生兴趣。他嫉妒他们——但他们是谁？他不敢问她。最后他说管他呢，并试图把这件事从脑子里赶走。并找个借口尽快单独见她。

If he felt so strongly about what had happened—why didn’t she? The answer was pretty obvious when he asked the question that way. Because she had done it before. She was eighteen, five years older man him, had had five years to get interested in boys. He was jealous of them—but who were they? He couldn’t dare ask her. In the end he said the hell with it and tried to put it from his mind. And sought for an excuse to see her alone as soon as possible.

第二天早上，布莱恩在走廊里等着她，上课前发现了她。“我昨晚熬夜了，完成了你的学期论文。”

Brian was waiting in the hall next morning, caught her before class. “I stayed up late last night, finished your term paper.”

“我的听力下降了。你刚才说了什么我以为听到的话吗？”

“My hearing is going. Did you just say what I thought I heard you say?”

“嗯嗯。我觉得一次性完成比一步一步教你更容易。也许这样你会记得你写了什么。”他试图表现得比他感觉的更随意。“今天下午过来，我会给你第一次演示一下它的工作原理。”

“Mm-hmm. Thought it would be easier to get it done all at once than take you through it step by step. Maybe that way you will remember what you wrote.” He tried to be more casual than he felt. “Come over this afternoon and I’ll give you a first run-through of how it works.”

“当然了。到时候见。”

“You bet. See you there.”

这一天就这样过去了。下午是多莉打桥牌的时间，房子里空无一人。

The day dragged by. It was Dolly’s afternoon to play bridge and the house would be empty.

 

 

“这是最后一次手术，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克平静地说道。“植入物都已就位。CPU 已安装到位。新的神经连接与受损的皮质部分重新生长几乎完成。胼胝体连接的替换正在接受刺激。芯片之间的光纤接口已安装完毕，这是颅内手术的最后一次。脑膜组织已修复或更换，我现在正在覆盖被移除的骨头部分的边缘，以便进入大脑。这会生长并将颅骨部分封住。手术现在开始。”

“This is the final surgery,” Snaresbrook dictated quietly. “The implants are all in place. The CPU put into position. The regrowth of new nerve connections to the damaged portions of the cortex is almost completed. The replacements for the corpus callosum connections are being stimulated. The fiber-optic interfaces between the chips have been installed, the last of the intracranial procedures. The meningeal tissues have been repaired or replaced and I am now coating the edges of the section of bone that was removed to give access to the brain. This will grow and seal the section of skull into place. The procedure now begins.”

她没有在心里默默地想这只是手术的结束。但有望恢复布莱恩大脑内部连接的新的、未经试验的手术才刚刚开始。新的、未经证实的——它们会起作用吗？

She did not add her silent thoughts that this was just the end of the surgical procedures. But the new and untried procedures that would hopefully restore the connections inside Brian’s brain were only in their opening stages. New, unproven—would they work?

别再想了。完成这件事然后继续前进。

Stop thinking about it. Complete this and move on.

 

 

那是一个闷热的七月下午，布莱恩终于离开了计算机实验室。他已经想出了一个他希望能够改进的方案，即他父亲帮助开发的 LAMA 和 AI 编程语言。如果他的设想正确，CYC 信息网络的交叉链接网络可以加快 10 倍。但他的新技术必须经过测试，而这需要几天时间才能在他自己的计算机上完成——因此他设法在 Cray 5 上借了一些时间，如果一切顺利，他应该会在早上得到一些结果。这意味着在那之前他没有什么其他事情可以做。

It was a muggy and torrid July afternoon when Brian finally got away from the computer lab. He had worked out what he hoped would be an improvement on LAMA, and AI programming language that his father had helped to develop. If he was right the cross-linking nemes of the CYC information nets could be speeded up by a factor of 10. But his new technique had to be tested and this would have taken days to work through on his own computer—so he managed to borrow some time on the Cray 5 and if all went well he should get some results by morning. Which meant there wasn’t much else he could do until then.

而且很有可能金姆正在家里等他。他现在走得更快了，汗湿的双腿紧贴着皮肤。她今天下午没有课，所以她可能会过来接受她所谓的辅导。是的，也会有一些辅导，因为她真的需要。她现在逃课了，不听讲座，因为她知道他会在那儿告诉她考试前该做什么。她真的很讨厌学校的作业，总是很高兴能找到更好的事情做。布莱恩意识到自己喘不过气来时，就放慢了脚步。在这种高温下，要小心，否则他会死回来的。

And there was a good chance Kim might be waiting for him at home. He walked faster now and his sweat-soaked shut stuck to his skin. She had no classes this afternoon so she might come over for what she called tutoring. Yes, there would also be some tutoring because she really needed it. She was cutting classes now and ignoring lectures because she knew that he would be there to tell her what to do before the exams. She really hated the school work and was always happy to find something better to do. Brian slowed down when he realized he was gasping for breath. Easy did it in this heat or he would get back dead.

当他打开前门时，凉爽的空气扑面而来。

The cool air puffed out and embraced when he opened the front door.

“有人在家吗？”他大叫，但回答他的只有一片寂静。然后他听到了音乐声，微笑着推开了半掩的房门。

“Anyone home?” he called out, but silence was his answer. Then he heard the music playing, smiled and pushed open the half-closed door to his room.

“我叫了你——你没听见。”

“I called—you didn’t hear me.”

音响开着，调到了密西西比灵魂食物电台，但房间里空无一人。他的床很凌乱，枕头像她喜欢的那样塞在靠背上。他四处寻找便条，金仍在写便条，从未想过要访问网络，什么也没找到。他关掉音乐，唯一的声音是电脑风扇的嗡嗡声。它在访问磁盘时自言自语。厨房——就是这样。金是世界上最会吃零食的人。水槽里的玻璃杯和脏盘子证明了这一点。但她不在那里。

The stereo was on, switched to the Mississippi soul food station, but the room was empty. His bed was rumpled and his pillows pushed into a backrest the way she liked them. He looked around for a note, Kim still wrote them, never thinking to access the network, found nothing. He turned off the music and the only sound was the whir of the fan on the computer. It muttered to itself while it accessed a disk. The kitchen—that was it. Kim was the world’s best nibbler. The glass and dirty dish in the sink proved it. But she wasn’t there.

她也没有接电话。他又仔细地搜索了一遍；她不止一次给他留下手写信息，可能是 UFE 中唯一一个喜欢电脑的人，但他还是找不到任何纸条。也许她真的打破了长久以来的厌恶，在电脑里留下了信息。他打开了通讯程序，但什么也没有。

Nor did she answer her phone. He searched more carefully a second time; she had left him handwritten messages more than once, probably the only person in computer-happy UFE that did his anymore, but still couldn’t find any note. Maybe she actually broke a long-standing dislike and actually left a message in the computer. He called up his communication program but there was nothing there.

神秘莫测——他开始担心了。她会不会出什么事了？前门关着，但没有锁。通常除了晚上，门都不会锁；大学是一个与世隔绝的安全地方。但没有一个地方是真正安全的。他们不是刚在几英里外的海岸抓到毒品走私犯吗？UFE 的孤立钻井平台可能是再次尝试的理想地点。突然的声音引起了他的注意，电脑嗡嗡作响，驱动器灯亮了起来。

Mysterious—and he was beginning to get worried. Could something have happened to her? The front door had been closed, but not locked. It usually wasn’t locked except at night; the university was a cutoff and safe place. Except no place was really safe. Hadn’t they just caught the drug smugglers a few miles down the coast? The isolated rigs of UFE might be the ideal spot for another try. A sudden sound caught his attention as the computer whirred and a drive light came on.

当然！这个程序已经运行了几天，机器处于口头命令模式，大部分时间都处于这种模式，甚至当他从键盘输入数据时也是如此，它被编程为记录任何单词或声音，并在必要时做出反应。她的声音会被记录下来。

Of course! This program had been running for a couple of days and the machine was in verbal command mode, left that way most of the time even when he was entering data from the keyboard, programmed to record any words or sounds and respond if necessary. There would be a record of her voice.

很容易就找到了。他跳了回去，打开扬声器——听到自己打呼噜的声音。他跳到前面，听到他穿衣服时听的早间新闻。向前，向前——她就在那里！跟着收音机哼唱。没什么不对劲；他跳到前面，音轨发出唐老鸭的声音——然后当他听到她的声音时停了下来。她正在打电话。

It was easy enough to find. He jumped back, turned on the speakers—and heard himself snoring. Jumped forward and heard the morning news he had listened to while dressing. Forward and forward—and there she was! Humming along with the radio. Nothing wrong here; he skipped forward, the sound track making Donald Duck sounds—then stopped when he heard her voice. Talking on the phone.

“当然可以。如果你坚持的话。很快。好的。再见。”

“Sure, yes. If you insist. Soon. Right. Bye.”

对话只有一方：他从未考虑过窃听他的手机。他快速前进，听到了什么，然后回溯。那是金在笑。

Only one side of the conversation: he had never considered putting a tap on his phone. He did a high-speed forward, heard something, backtracked. It was Kim laughing.

然后一个男人的声音说道：“再来一次，就没人能阻止我了。”

Then a male voice said, “Do that again and there’s no stopping me.”

布莱恩将头靠在指尖上，俯身坐在电脑前，扬声器贴近耳边。他听着那只可能是做爱的声音。在他的床上。和别人。他听着每一声羞辱的声音和喘息，听着她发出的欢快的叫声。

Brian rested his head on his fingertips, bent over the computer, the speaker close to his ear. Listening to what could only have been sounds of lovemaking. In his bed. With someone else. Listening to every humiliating sound and gasp, to her mounting little cries of delight.

一直听着，直到一切都结束。他们在轻声交谈，但他不再听了。那些声音毫无意义，毫无意义。

Listened until it was all over. They were talking quietly but he listened no longer. The voices were nothing, meant nothing.

完了。完了。他感到一阵可怕的背叛感，他的太阳穴一阵剧痛。他对她来说毫无意义——也许除了当一名无薪导师，或者也许她就是靠这个来支付他的学费！她从来没有认真对待过他，从来没有感受到他的感受。他现在羞愧地意识到，他的初恋完全是单方面的。她没有分享过——可能甚至不知道他对她那压倒性的、强烈的感情。他的手指因愤怒和羞愧而颤抖，他抹去了程序和背叛的声音，删除了文件。然后格式化了文件，让它永远无法恢复。更多的破坏。他找出了为她做过的每一件工作，把磁盘擦干净。删除了她发来的信息。他的手在颤抖，眼里含着愤怒的泪水。爱变成了愤怒，吸引力变成了背叛。他双手颤抖着抓住键盘，准备将其举起并扔向屏幕。

Finished. Through. The blood hammered in his temples as he was possessed by a terrible sense of betrayal. He had meant absolutely nothing to her—except maybe as an unpaid tutor, or maybe that was how she paid for his lessons! She had never been serious about him, never felt what he felt. What he realized shamefully now was that his puppy love had been completely one-sided. She hadn’t shared it—probably didn’t even know his overwhelming and consuming feelings for her. His fingers were trembling with rage, mortification, as he wiped the program and the voices of betrayal, struck out the file, deleted it. Then formatted tracks over it so it could never be restored. More destruction. He sought out every piece of work he had done for her and wiped the disk clean. Wiped out a com file of messages from her. His hands were shaking and there were tears of rage in his eyes. Love turned to anger, attraction to betrayal. His hands shook as he seized the keyboard, began to lift it to throw at the screen.

这太疯狂了。他扔下它，从房间冲出，撞到走廊尽头，冲进厨房，站在门口，握紧拳头，因矛盾的情绪而颤抖。柜台上摆着一排刀架，他拿出最大的一把，用拇指试了试刀刃，渴望把它刺进她的身体。一次又一次。

This was crazy. He dropped it and rushed from the room banged down the hall into the kitchen, stood in the doorway, fists clenched, shaking with conflicting emotions. The rack of knives was before him on the counter and he pulled out the largest, tested the edge with his thumb, longed to plunge it into her. Again and again.

杀了她？他在想什么？难道他的生活被单纯而狂躁的情绪所控制？逻辑和理智怎么了？他把刀插回刀槽时，双手仍在颤抖。他站在水槽边，茫然地盯着窗外。

Kill her? What was he thinking about? Did simple, rutting emotions control his life? What had happened to logic and intelligence? His hands were still shaking as he slid the knife back into the slot. He stood at the sink staring unseeingly out of the window.

布莱恩，你有脑子。好好利用它。或者让情绪主宰你的生活。杀了她，报仇，因谋杀而入狱。这真的不是世界上最伟大的想法。发生了什么？情绪怎么会取代理智的思考？

You have a brain, Brian. Use it. Or let your emotions run your life. Kill her, get revenge, go to jail for murder. Not the world’s greatest idea, really. What is happening? How come emotion has taken the place of intelligent thought?

一个子单元已经控制了一切，这就是发生的事情。想想心灵社会及其运作方式。心灵分为许多子单元，这些子单元本身完全没有智慧。他父亲解释时举了什么例子？开车。当意识心灵忙于其他事情时，心灵子单元可以驾驶汽车。只有当发生异常情况时才会交回控制权。心灵社会通常在其所有单元合作的状态下工作。现在一个愚蠢的子单元接管了一切，控制着一切。一个愚蠢、非理性的迷恋子单元——用生殖腺当大脑，只涉及背叛、嫉妒和愤怒。这就是他想要控制自己生活的方式吗？

A subunit had taken control, that was what had happened. Think of the society of the mind and how it works. The mind is divided into many subunits, subunits with absolutely no intelligence of their own. What was the example his father had used when he explained it? Driving a car. A subunit of the mind can drive the car while the conscious mind is occupied with other things. Turning back control only when something unusual happened. The society of mind usually worked in a state of cooperation between all of its units. Now one stupid subunit had taken over and was controlling everything. One dumb, irrational subunit of infatuation—with gonads for brains and involved only with betrayal and jealousy and rage. Is this what he wanted to control his life?

“当然不行！”他打开冰箱，拿出一罐汽水，打开封口，一口气喝了一半。现在他平静多了，理智多了。他知道发生了什么，他大脑的一部分已经接管了一切，指挥着一切，压制着其他一切。没有所谓的中央自我，尽管很容易相信有中央自我。他对智力运作的研究越多，他就越相信每个人都是一个委员会。大脑是由许多小亚动物组成的——他们被称为原始专家。

“Hell, no!” He opened the refrigerator and took out a can of soda, popped the seal, drank half of it in one long chugalug. Much calmer and more rational now. He knew what was happening, one part of his brain had taken over and was calling all the shots and suppressing everything else. There was no such thing as a central me, though it was easy to believe that there was. The more he had studied the operation of intelligence, the more he had come to believe that each person was sort of a committee. The brain was made up of a lot of little subanimals—protospecialists, that’s what they were called.

寻找食物时，饥饿动物会占据上风。遇到麻烦时，恐惧动物会占据上风。而每晚，睡眠动物会取代它的位置。这是所罗门王的戒指。洛伦兹和廷伯根发现的所有机制。那些复杂的大脑中心网络，用于控制饥饿、性、防御，这些网络经过数亿年的进化才得以形成。不仅在爬行动物、鸟类和鱼类中如此，在他自己的大脑中也是如此。

The hunger-animal took over when looking for food. Or the fear-animal when there was trouble looming. And every night the sleep-animal took its place. It was King Solomon’s ring. All the machinery that Lorenz and Tinbergen had discovered. Those intricate networks of brain centers for hunger, sex, defense that had taken hundreds of millions of years to evolve. Not only in reptiles, birds and fish—but in parts of his own brain.

现在，他体内的性动物正在咀嚼、流口水，占据了主导地位。这是脑干深处的原始力量——他必须与之抗争！

And now his own internal sex-animal was chomping and salivating and taking over. A primitive agency way down in the brain stem—and he had to fight it!

“那不是我！”他大声喊道，用拳头猛击桌子，重得他都疼了。“不是完整的我。只是一个愚蠢却强大的部分。胆子很大！”
