“嗯，我也一样。点火吧。”

“Well I do too. Fire it up.”

如果发生了什么事，布莱恩肯定没有意识到。只要他一想，答案就显而易见了。如果机器真的在连接神经束，重建记忆，他就没有理由意识到这个过程。只有当他试图恢复那些记忆时，才会明显地发现它们的存在。然而，他意识到在非常遥远的意识层面上发生了一些事情。那是一个转瞬即逝的想法，当他试图接近它时，它就像鳗鱼一样溜走了。这很烦人。发生了一些他无法完全理解的事情。而且他很累。再加上现在他已经注意到了，这就像一种他无法完全理解的痒。

If anything was happening Brian was certainly not aware of it. The answer was obvious when he thought about it. If the machine really was connecting bundles of nerves, reestablishing memories, there was really no reason for him to be aware of the process. Only when he made an attempt to recover those memories would it be obvious that they were there. Yet he was aware of something happening at a very remote level of consciousness. It was a transient thought that slipped away like an eel when he tried to approach it. This was annoying. Something was happening that he couldn’t quite grasp. And he was tired. Plus the fact that now he had noticed, it was like an itch he couldn’t quite grasp.

这就足够了，他想。

That’s enough, he thought.

“我想今天就到此为止了，”医生突然说道。“这次治疗太长了。”

“I think that we’ll stop for the day,” the doctor suddenly said. “It’s been a long session.”

“当然可以。”布莱恩犹豫了一下，但后来决定为什么不呢。“斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士——我可以问你一个问题吗？”

“Sure.” Brian hesitated, but then decided why not. “Dr. Snaresbrook—can I ask you a question?”

“当然。不过等我讲完再说——现在，有什么事吗？”

“Of course. But just a second until I finish here—now, what is it?”

“你为什么决定此时结束会议？”

“Why did you decide to end the session at that moment?”

“只是有点小困难。控制非常好，而且这一切都还在试验阶段。正在建立的一个连接上有一个中止信号。我必须承认这是第一次发生这样的事情。我想重新运行该程序到那个点并找出原因。”

“Just a little difficulty. The control is very fine and this is all still experimental. There was an abort signal on one of the connections being established. I must admit this was the first time something like this has happened. I want to rerun the program to that point and find out why.”

“你不必这么做——我可以告诉你。”

“You won’t have to—I can tell you.”

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克抬起头，吃了一惊，然后笑了笑。“我怀疑你能不能做到。这不是在你的大脑里，而是在 CPU 里，或者更确切地说，是在植入的中央处理器和计算机中央处理器的交互中。”

Erin Snaresbrook looked up, startled, then smiled. “I doubt if you can. This wasn’t in your brain but in the CPU, or rather in the interaction of the implanted central processor and the one in the computer.”

“我知道。我让它关闭了。”

“I know. I told it to shut down.”

外科医生竭力保持声音平静。“这几乎不可能。”

The surgeon fought to keep her voice calm. “That’s hardly possible.”

“为什么不行？CPU 位于植入我大脑的芯片上，并且与我的大脑相互关联。有什么理由不能反馈呢？”

“Why not? The CPU is on the chip implanted in my brain—and is interrelating with my brain. Is there any reason why there can’t be feedback?”

“没有任何事——只是据我所知，以前从来没有人这样做过！”

“None whatsoever—except to my knowledge it has never been done before!”

“凡事都有第一次，医生。”

“There’s a first time for everything, Doc.”

“你肯定是对的。看来，当计算机学习你大脑中的某些连接时，你大脑的某些部分也在学习计算机的一些控制信号。”

“You must be right. It appears that while the computer was learning some of the connections in your brain, parts of your brain were learning some of the computer’s control signals.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克开始感到头晕。她走到窗边，然后又走回来，搓着双手——然后笑了起来。“布莱恩，你知道你在说什么吗？你已经将你的思维过程直接与机器对接。无需按下按钮或发出语音命令或任何其他物理动作。这不是计划好的，只是自然而然发生的。在此之前，所有的交流都是在运动动作的层面上进行的，从神经到肌肉。这是第一次直接从大脑到机器进行交流。以前从未发生过这种事情。这……太令人惊叹了。开启了各种令人难以置信的可能性！”

Snaresbrook was beginning to feel dizzy. She walked to the window then back, rubbing her hands together—then laughed. “Brian, do you realize what you are saying? That you have interfaced your thought processes directly with a machine. Without pressing buttons or giving voice commands or any other kind of physical action. It was not planned, it just happened. Before this all communication has been at the level of a motor action, from a nerve to a muscle. This is the first time that communication has been effected directly from the brain to a machine. Nothing of this kind has ever happened before. It’s… breathtaking. Opens up all sorts of incredible possibilities!”

布莱恩回答的是一声低沉的鼾声。他已经睡着了。

Brian’s answer was a low snore. He had fallen asleep.

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克拔下电脑上的神经连接线，把它卷在枕头下，不想现在就试图把它拔出来吵醒他。然后她悄悄关掉机器，拉上窗帘，走出了房间。贝尼科夫在外面等着她，脸上散发着忧郁的气息。艾琳抢在对方说话之前举起了手。

Erin Snaresbrook unplugged the neural link from the computer and coiled it under his pillow, not wanting to wake him by attempting to remove it now. Then she quietly shut down the machine, closed the curtain and left the room. Benicoff was waiting for her outside, radiating gloom. Erin raised her hand before the other man could speak.

“在你传达坏消息之前，我建议你先在办公室喝杯咖啡。今天我们俩都很忙。”

“Before you deliver the bad news I prescribe a cup of coffee in my office. It has been a busy day for both of us.”

“这说明什么？”

“It shows that much?”

“我是一名出色的诊断师。我们走吧。”

“I’m a great diagnostician. Let’s go.”

外科医生在前面带路，心里想了很多。她应该告诉贝尼科夫布莱恩的新能力吗？现在还不行，也许以后再说。她必须先进行一些控制，以确保这不是意外，不是巧合。它带来的可能性大得令人恐惧。明天，她明天再考虑。她啜了一口咖啡，咂了咂嘴，把咖啡递给贝尼科夫——然后坐到一张非常舒适的椅子上。

The surgeon had a lot to think about as she led the way. Should she tell Benicoff about Brian’s newfound ability? Not yet, later perhaps. She must run some controls first to make sure that it had not been an accident, a coincidence. The possibilities it opened were so large as to be frightening. Tomorrow, she would think about it tomorrow. She sipped the coffee and smacked her lips, passed Benicoff his coffee— then dropped into a very welcome chair.

“坏消息来了？”她问道。

“Bad news time?” she asked.

“不是坏消息，医生，只是压力。绍尔希特将军不会轻易离开。他坚持认为布莱恩在医院里呆的每一天，安全状况都会恶化。从某种程度上说，他说得有道理。而且，这肯定会给医院的日常管理带来极大的困扰。我知道——我收到了……投诉。将军已经向五角大楼汇报了，五角大楼又向总统汇报了——总统又向我汇报了。布莱恩现在恢复了意识，不再需要生命支持设备，他有可能被转移吗？”

“Not really bad news, Doctor, just pressure. General Schorcht is not going away that easily. He insists that every day Brian remains here in the hospital the security worsens. In a way he has a point. And it is sure wracking hell with normal day-to-day hospital management. I know—I get the . complaints. The General has been on to the Pentagon, who has been on to the President—who has been on to me. Is it possible that Brian can be moved now that he is conscious and off all the life support equipment?”

“是的，但是——”

“Yes, but—”

“这最好是一个震撼世界的但是。”

“It had better be a world-buster of a but.”

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克喝完咖啡，摇了摇头。“恐怕不会。只要采取非常谨慎的医疗预防措施。”

Erin Snaresbrook finished her coffee, then shook her head. “I’m afraid that it isn’t. As long as very prudent medical precautions are taken.”

“这就是为什么脸色那么难看。绍尔希特将军、一支小型军队和一架医疗直升机就在外面待命——就在此刻。如果你的答案是那样，他们现在就会这么做。我会尝试采取暂缓行动，但前提是你有非常强烈的医疗理由。”

“That’s why the long face. General Schorcht, a small army and a medevac copter are standing by right outside—at this very moment. If that’s your answer they are going to do it now. I’ll try a holding action, but only if you have some really strong medical reasons.”

“没有。事实上，如果最终必须转移他，最好现在就转移。在我太过沉迷于记忆重建之前。我相信一旦加强安保，我们都会更放松一些。”

“No. In fact, if he has to be moved eventually, it might be best to move him at the present time. Before I get too involved in the memory reconstruction. And I am sure that we will all be a bit more relaxed once security is tightened.”

当布莱恩听到即将发生的事情时，他非常兴奋。

Brian was quite excited when he heard what was going to happen.

“哇哦——乘坐直升机！我以前从来没坐过。我们要去哪里？”

“Wow—a copter ride! I’ve never been up in one before. Where are we going?”

“去科罗纳多的海军医院。”

“To the naval hospital on Coronado.”

“为什么在那里？”

“Why there?”

“我们到了之后我会告诉你。”斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生瞥了一眼正在为布莱恩的短途旅行做准备的护士们。“事实上，我觉得到了那里后我最好回答你的很多问题。恐怕我们不能再把这次私人聚会持续太久了。我们准备好了吗？”

“I’ll tell you after we arrive.” Dr. Snaresbrook glanced at the nurses who were preparing Brian for the short trip. “In fact, I think I better answer a lot of your questions when we get there. I’m afraid we can’t keep this a private party much longer. Are we ready?”

“是的，医生，”护士说道。

“Yes, Doctor,” the nurse said.

“好的。通知贝尼科夫先生。他在外面等着你。”

“All right. Inform Mr. Benicoff. You will find him waiting outside.”

护理员是海军医务兵，背后还有一队全副武装的海军陆战队员。医院的整个楼层都已清空，在围绕着轮床的队伍前后还有更多的海军陆战队员。布莱恩被推入电梯时，第一队队员加倍爬上通往屋顶的楼梯，电梯到达时，他们就在门外等候。他们并不孤单。神枪手从护墙上向下看，而屋顶的每个角落都有士兵随时准备携带笨重的地对空导弹。

The orderlies were navy medical corpsmen—and were backed up by a squad of heavily armed marines. The entire hospital floor had been cleared and there were more marines in front of and behind the party that surrounded the gurney. The first squad double-timed up the stairs to the roof when Brian was rolled into the elevator, were waiting there outside the door when it arrived. Nor were they alone. Sharpshooters looked down from the parapets, while at every corner of the roof there were soldiers with bulky surface-to-air missiles at the ready.

“您说得对，博士，您确实有很多事情需要解释！”布莱恩在直升机叶片的轰鸣声中大声喊道。

“You are right, Doctor, you do have a lot of explaining to do!” Brian called out above the roar of the copter’s blades.

在穿越城市和海湾的短途飞行中，他们被攻击直升机包围，而一队喷气式飞机在上空盘旋。降落在海军医院的停机坪后，同样的程序以相反的方式进行。当最后一名海军陆战队员离开时，房间里还剩下三个人。

During the short hop across the city and bay they were boxed in by attack choppers, while a flight of jets circled higher above. After landing on the helipad of the naval hospital the same procedure was done in reverse. When the last marine had stamped out, there were still three people left in the room.

“将军，您在外面等着好吗？”贝尼科夫问道，“我要向布莱恩解释一下这件事。”

“Will you wait outside, General,” Benicoff asked, “while I explain to Brian what this is all about?”

“消极的。”

“Negative.”

“谢谢。斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士，您能给我介绍一下吗？”

“Thanks. Dr. Snaresbrook, will you please introduce me?”

“布莱恩，我是贝尼科夫先生。他旁边的军官是绍尔希特将军，他有一些问题要问你。我现在不想让他来这里，但我听说这次采访是美国总统明确要求的。”

“Brian, this is Mr. Benicoff. The military officer next to him is General Schorcht, who has some questions to ask you. I wouldn’t have him here now but I have been informed that this interview was expressly asked for by the President. Of the United States.”

“真的吗，医生？”他们可能已经二十四岁了，但眼睛却像十四岁的孩子一样睁得大大的。艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克点了点头。

“For real, Doctor?” They may have been twenty-four years old but the eyes had the wide-eyed stare of a fourteen-year-old. Erin Snaresbrook nodded.

“贝尼科夫先生也是总统任命的。他负责一项正在进行的调查——好吧，他会自己解释的。”

“Mr. Benicoff is a presidential appointee as well. He is in charge of an ongoing investigation—well, he’ll explain that himself.”

“嗨，布莱恩。感觉还好吗？”

“Hi, Brian. Feeling okay?”

“太棒了。真是一段很棒的旅程。”

“Great. That was quite a ride.”

“你病得很重。如果你想推迟这件事……”

“You have been seriously ill. If you want to postpone this…”

“不用了，谢谢。我有点累，但除此之外，我现在感觉很好。我真的很想知道我发生了什么事，这里发生了什么事。”

“No thanks. I’m a little tired, but other than that I feel fine now. And I really would like to know what happened to me, what is going on around here.”

“那么，你知道你成功开发出可操作的人工智能了吗？”

“Well, you do know that you succeeded in developing an operating artificial intelligence?”

“医生告诉我的——我完全不记得了。”

“The doctor told me that—I have no memory of it at all.”

“是的，当然。那么，不用说得太详细，你正在演示人工智能时，你所在的实验室遭到了袭击。我们有理由相信，和你在一起的每个人都死了，而你头部受了重伤。被一颗子弹打伤。我们猜想你是被抛弃等死的。你所有的笔记、记录、设备，所有与人工智能有关的东西都被拿走了。你被送往医院，由斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生为你做了手术。你在医院恢复了意识，当然，从那时起发生的一切你都知道了。但我必须补充一点，窃贼从未被抓获，记录也从未被找回。”

“Yes, of course. Well then, without being too detailed, you were demonstrating the AI when the lab you were in was attacked. We have reason to believe that everyone there with you was killed, while you were badly wounded in the head. By a bullet. We assume that you were left for dead. All of your notes, records, equipment, everything to do with the AI was removed. You were taken to the hospital and operated on by Dr. Snaresbrook. You recovered consciousness in the hospital and of course everything that has happened since then you know about. But I must add that the thieves were never caught, the records never recovered.”

“是谁干的？”

“Who did it?”

“我很遗憾地说，我们完全不知道。”

“I am afraid to say that we have absolutely no idea.”

“那么——为什么要进行军事演习？”

“Then—why the military maneuvers?”

“当你刚出院的时候，已经有人试图谋杀你一次了。”

“There has already been one other attempt on your life, when you were in the hospital that you just left.”

布莱恩目瞪口呆地看着他们茫然的脸。“所以你们告诉我，人工智能已经被窃取了。不管是谁拥有它，都想保守这个秘密。他们甚至准备杀了我来保守这个秘密。尽管我一点都不记得了。”

Brian gaped around at their blank faces. “So what you are telling me is that the AI has been pinched. And whoever has it wants to keep it their secret. So much so that they are ready to bump me off to keep it a secret. Even though I don’t remember a thing about it.”

“这是正确的。”

“That’s right.”

“这需要一些时间来适应。”

“This takes some getting used to.”

“对我们所有人来说都是如此。”

“For all of us.”

布莱恩看着将军。“军队与此事有什么关系？”

Brian looked over at the General. “How does the Army fit into this?”

“我会告诉你的。”绍尔希特将军冲上前去。贝尼科夫开始插手，然后犹豫了。最好尽快结束。斯纳尔斯布鲁克也有同样的想法，当她看到贝尼科夫退缩时，她点头表示同意。将军举起一只手，拿出一个录音机。

“I will tell you.” General Schorcht stamped forward. Benicoff started to interfere, then hesitated. Best to get it over with. Snaresbrook was of the same mind and nodded agreement when she saw Benicoff draw back. The General raised his single hand and held out a recorder.

“你必须表明自己的身份。姓名、出生日期、出生地。”

“You will identify yourself. Name, date of birth, place of birth.”

“为什么，法官大人？”布莱恩疑惑地问道，他的爱尔兰口音突然变得很浓。

“Why, your honor?” Brian asked in a wondering voice, his Irish brogue suddenly thick.

“因为你被命令这么做。有关你的健康和精神状况的声明需要证实。你必须回答这个问题。”

“Because you have been ordered to. Statements have been made about your health and sanity that need corroboration. You will answer the question.”

“我必须这么做吗？我知道为什么。我敢打赌，这是因为这些人一直在说我的坏话。他们是不是给你讲了一些荒唐的故事，说我只有十四岁，而你用自己那双漂亮的蓝眼睛就能看出那不是真的？”

“Must I do that? I know why. I’ll bet it’s because these people here been telling lies about me. Have they told you wild stories about me being only fourteen years old when with your own fine blue eyes you can see that is not true?”

“或许是那样。”将军倾身向前，眼睛里闪着光芒。“你正在为记录而说话。”

“Perhaps something of that nature.” The General’s eyes sparkled as he leaned forward. “You are speaking for the record.”

贝尼科夫走开了，这样将军就看不到他的脸了。他曾在爱尔兰待过一段时间。他知道“嘲笑某人”是什么意思——即使将军不知道。

Benicoff moved away so the General could not see his face. He had spent time in Ireland. He knew what “putting the mickey to someone” meant—even if the General did not.

布莱恩犹豫了一下，环顾四周，舔了舔嘴唇。

Brian hesitated and looked about him, licking his lips.

“将军，我现在安全了吗？”

“Am I safe now, General?”

“我百分之百保证。从现在起，美国陆军将负责指挥。”

“I can guarantee that one hundred percent. As of this moment the United States Army is in charge.”

“很高兴知道这一点。我告诉您，我醒来时发现自己躺在医院的病床上，头痛欲裂，记忆力全无，完全没有十四岁之后的记忆。将军，我可能看上去不像，但据我所知，我只有十四岁。而且非常疲惫。突然感觉身体不适。我有一件重要的医疗事宜要与我的主治医生讨论。”

“That’s nice to know. I feel a great relief as I tell you that I woke up in me hospital bed, sore in the head. And with not a memory I could find after my fourteenth year. I may not look it, General, but as far as I know I am fourteen years old. And very tired. Feeling suddenly ill. I have something of medical importance to discuss with my attending physician.”

“贝尼科夫先生，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士准时说道，“请您和绍尔希特将军离开。你们可以在外面等着。”

“Mr. Benicoff,” Dr. Snaresbrook said, right on cue, “would you and General Schorcht please leave. You may wait outside.”

将军想说的话始终没有说出口。他的脸涨得通红，下巴不停地动。最后，他猛地转过身，制服夹克的袖子被别住了，飞了起来。贝尼科夫为将军拉着门，他们离开后，门才关上。斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生担心不已，赶紧跑到布莱恩身边。

Whatever the General had to say never came out. His face was bright red, his jaw working. In the end he spun about so sharply on his heel that the pinned-up arm of his uniform jacket flew up. Benicoff was holding the door open for the General and closed it behind them as they left. Worried, Dr. Snaresbrook hurried to Brian’s side.

“有什么问题吗，布莱恩？”

“What’s the trouble, Brian?”

“别担心，医生，这不是什么大问题。我只是受够了。但是，是的，有一件事。”

“Don’t worry, Doc, nothing terminal. I just had enough of that one. But, yes, there is one thing.”

“疼痛？”

“Pain?”

“不完全是。请原谅我这么说——我只是要上厕所。”

“Not quite. If you will excuse the expression—I just have to pee.”

十三
13

2023 年 11 月 9 日
November 9, 2023

 

 

差不多两周后，贝尼科夫才再次见到布莱恩。但他确实收到了斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士的每日进度报告，并立即将其转交给总统办公室。他没有急着提交每天必须提交的第二份报告。凌晨三点，出于纯粹的恶意，他的电子传真机被设定为将进度报告的副本发送到绍尔希特将军未公开的安全号码。希望一些兴奋的参谋人员能在报告中发现一个足够有趣的内容，从而唤醒将军。这个想法让贝尼科夫每晚都能面带微笑地入睡。

Almost two weeks passed before Benicoff saw Brian again. But he did get daily progress reports from Dr. Snaresbrook, which he passed on instantly to the President’s office. He did not hurry the second report that he had to file every day. Out of sheer malice at three in the morning, his E-fax was programmed to send a copy of the progress report to General Schorcht’s unlisted security number. In the hope that some excitable staff officer might find an item in the report that was interesting enough to wake up the General. This thought sent Benicoff to sleep with a smile every night.

同时，他还通过传真发送了 Megalobe 调查的每日案件报告。这些报告一天比一天短，也没有任何进展。在 Megalobe 不远处发现了一系列洞穴后，警方开始忙碌起来；这是当时提出的一种更离谱的理论的结果。这种理论进一步假设，那天晚上停在实验室的卡车可能最终离开了山谷。但车里空无一人。被盗物品可能被埋在准备好的地点，等情况冷却后再挖出来。因此，洞穴的发现才让人兴奋不已。但洞穴中只有蝙蝠粪便化石，贝尼科夫心想，这几乎描述了他们迄今为止发现的有关此案的所有其他信息。

He also E-faxed a daily case report of the Megalobe investigation at the same time. These were getting shorter and emptier of any progress with every passing day. There had been a flurry of activity when a series of caves had been discovered not too far from Megalobe; a result of one of the more way-out theories that had been developed. This theory expanded on the supposition that maybe the truck that had been at the laboratory that night had left the valley after all. But had left empty. The stolen items might then have been buried at a prepared site, to be dug up later when things had cooled down. Therefore all the excitement about the cave discovery. But the caves contained only fossilized bat guano which, Benicoff thought to himself, described just about everything else about the case that they had uncovered so far.

黎明时分，他穿过巴尔博亚公园慢跑了一个小时，然后洗漱完毕，穿好衣服，闷闷不乐地吃完低热量早餐，喝了一杯黑咖啡。九点钟，他给电子公司打电话，核实他安排的物品的送货时间。然后，在回复了外出时录下的来自东海岸的电话后，他封住了电脑，乘坐酒店地下室 MegaHertz 汽车租赁公司的后部电梯。他预订的黄色电动小车正在等他。他检查了一下，车上是否有备用轮胎，车身是否有明显的凹痕，电池是否充满电。交通一直很畅通，直到他到达科罗纳多大桥，安全人员的尾随队伍已经走到了桥的中途。他换到 VIP 车道，直到远处的海军陆战队警卫示意他停车，他才停了下来。

He had jogged through Balboa Park for an hour just after dawn then, showered and dressed, he had scowled through a low-cal breakfast and black coffee. At nine he had phoned the electronic company to check the delivery time of the items he had arranged for. Then, after returning the calls from the East Coast that had been recorded while he was out, he sealed his computer and took the rear elevator that connected with MegaHertz car rental in the subbasement of the hotel. The yellow electric runabout he had reserved was waiting for him. He checked that it had a spare tire, that there were no obvious dents in the body and that it had a full charge in the battery. Traffic was light until he reached the Coronado Bridge where the tail-back from security reached back halfway along it. He switched to the VIP lane and stopped only at the far end when the marine guard flagged him down.

“先生，恐怕您不能使用这条车道。”

“I’m afraid you can’t use this lane, sir.”

“恐怕我可以。”

“I’m afraid I can.”

凭借通行证和证件，他在 VIP 入口处受到了敬礼和另一次检查。在这里，又受到了更多的敬礼——还有对汽车的全面搜查。而这一切只是为了进入科罗纳多的公共区域。当他到达军事基地大门时，搜查变得更加激烈。

His pass and documents earned him a salute and another inspection at the VIP entrance. There were more salutes here—along with a complete search of the car. And all this just to get into the public part of Coronado. The searches became even more enthusiastic when he reached the gates of the military base.

布莱恩正站在窗边，贝尼科夫走了进来，转过身来，脸上带着微笑。

Brian was standing at the window when Benicoff came in, turned around with a smile.

“贝尼科夫先生，很高兴见到您。我们这里缺少访客。”

“Mr. Benicoff, it’s good to see you. We’re kind of short of visitors here.”

“很高兴见到你——你看上去棒极了。”

“Even better to see you—and you look great.”

“这就是我的感受。他们昨天把我背上和手臂上的绷带取了下来。我身上有几处漂亮的伤疤。明天我要戴上一顶帽子来代替这些绷带。每个人都在偷看我的头骨，但还没让我看到。”

“And that’s just about how I feel. They took the bandages off my back and arm yesterday. I’ve got a couple of nice scars. And I’m going to get a cap instead of these bandages tomorrow. Everyone keeps peeking at my skull but won’t let me see it yet.”

“这也许不是一个坏主意。我还可以告诉你一些好消息。在对海军当局进行正面攻击后，斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士和我已经勉强同意将一台计算机终端插入这里的房间。”

“Which is probably not such a bad idea. And I can give you some more good news. Dr. Snaresbrook and I, after a frontal assault on the naval authorities, have obtained reluctant agreement to have a computer terminal plugged into the room here for you.”

“那太棒了！”

“That’s great!”

“但你会注意到我说的是终端而不是计算机。这是医院主机的哑终端。所以你可以确保你输入的每个按键都会同时出现在 Schorcht 将军的屏幕上。”

“But you’ll notice that I said terminal and not computer. A dumb terminal to the hospital’s mainframe. So you can be sure that every keystroke you enter will simultaneously appear on General Schorcht’s screen.”

“那就更好了！我会确保这个好人有足够的书可读，以保持血压正常。”

“That’s even better! I’ll see to it that the good man has plenty to read to keep his blood pressure up.”

“一见钟情。我很欣赏你对他的嘲笑。”

“Love at first sight. I appreciate the way you put the mickey to him.”

“我不得不这么做。他看起来和听起来都像塔拉学校的一位修女，就是那个曾经用尺子打断我指关节的修女。说到突破——有没有可能从这里逃出去？出去呼吸新鲜空气？”

“I had to. He looks and sounds just like one of the nuns at school back in Tara, the one who used to break her ruler over my knuckles. And speaking of breaks—any chance of breaking out of here? Getting some fresh air?”

贝尼科夫跌坐在扶手椅上，椅子在他的重压下发出吱吱声。“我也一直在与当局抗争这件事。当医生说你的身体状况良好时，你就可以使用阳台到十楼。”

Benicoff dropped into the armchair, which squeaked under his weight. “I have been fighting with the authorities on this one as well. When the doc says that your health is up to it you can use the balcony to the tenth floor.”

“绑上绳子，这样我就不会跳下去了？”

“With ropes attached so I don’t jump off?”

“还不错——我上去的时候看过了。我想这是海军上将的个人小福利。它很大，有休息室、树木——甚至还有鱼塘。而且守卫森严。”

“Not that bad—I took a look at it on the way up. Some Admiral’s personal little perk, I imagine. It’s pretty big, with lounges, trees—even a fishpond. And well guarded.”

“我还想问您一件事，贝尼科夫先生——”

“That’s another thing I wanted to ask you about, Mr. Benicoff—”

“请您就叫我本吧，我的朋友都这么叫我。”

“Just Ben, if you please, which is what my friends call me.”

“当然。其实是跟这些警卫有关，还有我好起来后会发生什么。医生让我问你。”

“Sure. It’s about these guards, really, and what’s going to happen to me when I get better. Doc said to ask you.”

贝尼科夫站起身，开始踱步。“我想了很久——但没找到好的答案。你出院后恐怕得去一个同样安全的地方。”

Benicoff climbed to his feet and began to pace. “I’ve thought about that a lot—without finding a good answer. When you leave this hospital I’m afraid that you’ll have to go to someplace equally secure.”

“你的意思是，直到你找出是谁偷了人工智能并射杀了我——那些人后来又回来试图完成这项工作。”

“You mean until you find out who it was that stole the AI and shot me—the same people who then came back later on and tried to finish the job.”

“恐怕就这样了。”

“I’m afraid that’s it.”

“那么——我能看到自实验室遭到袭击和盗窃以来发生的所有事情以及你发现的所有事情的打印件吗？”

“Then—can I see a printout of everything that has happened since the attack and theft in the lab, and everything you have discovered since?”

“这是绝密文件。但既然都是关于你的，而且你近期不会经常旅行——我觉得没问题。我明天会给你带一份。”

“It’s classified Top Secret. But since it is all about you, and you’re not going to do much traveling for a while—I don’t see why not. I’ll bring you a copy tomorrow.”

一名护士从门里探出头来。“这里有一些设备需要安装。斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生已经批准了。”

A nurse poked her head in the door. “Some equipment here to be installed. Dr. Snaresbrook has approved it.”

“拿进来。”

“Bring it in.”

两名穿着白大褂的服务员推着手推车，后面跟随着一名制服上带着电子补丁的农夫。

Two white-coated attendants pushed in the trolley, followed by a Yeoman with electronic patches on his uniform.

“刚刚送到，先生们。拆开检查，重新组装，运行正常。谁来签收？”

“Delivered a little while ago, sirs. Taken apart and searched, put back together again and operating A-OK. Who’s going to sign for it?”

“给。”贝尼科夫说。

“Here,” Benicoff said.

“那不是终端，”布莱恩一边说，一边敲着方形的金属机器。

“That’s not a terminal,” Brian said, tapping the square metal machine.

“不是，先生。这是一台新型的永久纸打印机。终端正在启动。请在这里签上姓名首字母。纸在盒子里。”

“No, sir. That’s a new-model printer for eternitree paper. Terminal is on its way up now. And initial here, please. Paper is in the box here.”

“Eternitree？这对我来说是个新词。”

“Eternitree? That’s a new one to me.”

“不应该，”当打印机和终端插上电源并连接好后，他们又单独在一起了，贝尼科夫说道。他拿出一张纸，递给布莱恩。“它是自由企业大学为在那里出版的日报开发的。事实上，你父亲的名字——以及你的名字——都在最初的专利申请上。我知道你们俩都参与了这个过程的开发。”

“It shouldn’t be,” Benicoff said when the printer and terminal had been plugged in and connected and they were alone again. He took out a sheet of paper and passed it to Brian. “It was developed at the University of Free Enterprise for the daily newspaper published there. In fact your father’s name—as well as yours—is on the original patent applications. I understand you both helped in developing the process.”

“看起来和感觉起来就像普通的白纸。”

“Looks and feels like ordinary white paper.”

“试着折叠或撕开它——明白我的意思了吗？它是一种坚韧的塑料，经过纹理处理，摸起来感觉像纸，表面粘合有薄膜。这意味着它几乎坚不可摧，完全可重复使用。这是日报的完美之选——也是由你们大学里最聪明的男生之一开发的。”

“Try folding or tearing it—see what I mean? It is tough plastic that has been textured to feel like paper, with a bonded thin-film surface. Which means it is almost indestructible and completely reusable. The perfect thing for the daily newspaper—also developed by one of the brightest boys at your university.”

“如果我可以坐下来，喝杯水——你能告诉我这件事吗？”

“If I can sit down, with a glass of water—will you tell me about it?”

“我去拿水。给。你知道选择性电视新闻节目吗？”

“I’ll get the water. Here. You know about selective TV news programming?”

“当然。你输入你自己的节目，输入你感兴趣的内容。棒球、股市报道、选美比赛，等等。标有标签的新闻报道一天 24 小时播出。你的电视会记录你最感兴趣的内容，所以当你回家打开新闻时，哇，里面只有你关心的东西。”

“Sure. You punch in your own program, things that you are interested in. Baseball, stock market reports, beauty contests, whatever. Labeled news reports go out twenty-four hours a day. Your TV records those that interest you the most so when you come home and turn on the news, whammo, it’s only the stuff you care about.”

贝尼科夫点点头。“嗯，你们的大学报纸是同一件事情的增强版。那里的编辑已经签下了世界各地的科学家作为记者。他们随时发送有关各种科学和技术新闻的报道。这些报道被标记并存储在数据库中，与标准服务中的所有新闻项目一起。订阅系统有一个学习方案。当你按下前进按钮拒绝某项内容时，计算机会注意到这一点并避免将来的相关项目。更重要的是，它用跟踪设备跟踪你的眼球运动。然后它会进行内容分析并记录你感兴趣的主题的描述。这是一个真正的学习过程，系统在分析你的兴趣方面越来越好。它是如此的好，除非有一个截止点，否则你会发现自己除了观看你同意和认可的新闻和观点之外什么都不做。”

Benicoff nodded. “Well, your university newspaper is a high-powered version of the same thing. The editor there has signed up scientists right around the world as reporters.. They send in reports all the time about every kind of scientific and technical news. These are tagged and stored in a data bank, along with all the news items from standard services. The subscription system has a learning scheme. When you touch the advance button to reject something, the computer notes this and avoids future related items. More important is the fact that it follows your eye movements with a tracking device. Then it does a content analysis and records descriptions of the subjects that interest you. It is a true learning process and the system gets better and better at profiling your interests. It is so good that unless there is a cutoff you would find yourself doing nothing else but watching news and views that you agree with and approve of.”

“有点让你变成信息迷。但是浏览呢？”

“Sort of turn you into an info junky. But what about browsing?”

“内置于系统中。检索操作非常高效，即使在与您的主题相关的文档中也总是有很多岔路。”

“Built into the system. The retrieval operation is so efficient that there are always plenty of sidetracks even in the documents that are relevant to your subject.”

“太棒了！这样一来，每个订户都能收到自己的专属报纸。这位水力学教授除了来自世界各地的管道、泵和水花之外，还有堪萨斯州托皮卡的讣告、他的家乡，以及国际象棋新闻（如果他感兴趣的话）。真是个好主意。”

“Great! So it works out that every subscriber gets his own special newspaper. The hydraulics prof has nothing but pipes, pumps and splashes from around the world, along with Topeka, Kansas, obituaries, where he comes from, and chess news if he is into that as well. What a great idea.”

“成千上万的人都这么认为。订户支付固定费用，而计算机会跟踪任何单个项目的使用次数并自动向贡献者付款。”

“Thousands think so. The subscriber pays a fixed fee, while the computer keeps track of how many times any single item is used and automatically pays the contributor.”

布莱恩把永恒之树纸卷起来，卷得很紧，但当他松手时，它立刻就平整了。

Brian rolled up the sheet of eternitree paper, real tight, but it instantly flattened out when he let go.

“每天早上，垃圾箱里都会有一份个性化的报纸等着我们。但每周仍有相当于一棵树的纸张要扔掉。”

“A personalized newspaper waiting in the bin every morning. But still a tree’s worth of paper to be dumped every week.”

贝尼科夫点点头。“你和你父亲也是这么想的。学校的薄膜实验室正在研究平板计算机屏幕。你父亲帮忙算了算，这就是最终的结果。分层薄膜在内部和电子上从白色变为黑色。任何字体或字号似乎都印在上面——即使是视力较弱的人也可以使用大尺寸。阅读后，纸张被放回打印机中。当新报纸打印出来时，它会清除旧报纸。而且即使是这种技术也很快就会过时。市场上即将推出一种超薄书，厚度约为八分之三英寸，只有十页。边缘装订器包含一台非常强大的计算机，可控制每页的详细显示，甚至比印刷书籍的页面更详细。当你读完第十页时，你会回到第一页，其中已经包含新副本。凭借一百兆字节的内存，这本十页的书真的可以容纳一个相当大的图书馆。”

Benicoff nodded. “That’s what you and your father thought. The thin-film lab at the school was working on flat computer screens. Your father helped with the math and this was the end result. The layered film is changed internally and electronically from white to black. Any font or size of type is apparently printed on it—even large size for those with weak eyes. After reading it the sheets are dropped back into the printer. As the new newspaper is printed it clears away the old one. And even this technology is going to be redundant soon. There is a hyperbook coming onto the market that is about three-eighths of an inch thick and contains only ten pages. The edge binder contains a really powerful computer that controls a detailed display on each page, one that is even more detailed than the pages of printed books. When you finish reading page ten you turn back to the first page, which already contains new copy. With a hundred megabytes of memory this ten-page book will really contain a quite substantial library.”

“我暂时就接受这份工作了——它真的很棒。我要为自己创办一份报纸。”

“I’ll settle for this one for now—it’s really neat. I’ll set up a newspaper for myself.”

“你可以——但这不是我买打印机的原因。你一直在尝试订购一些书籍，请求已转交给我。使用打印机，你只能将它们存储在内存中，但使用 eternitree，你可以打印你想要的书，将纸张放入弹簧活页夹中，然后坐在阳光下阅读。”

“You can—but that’s not why I brought the printer. You’ve been trying to order some books, the request got passed on to me. With the printer you can only store them in memory, but with eternitree you can print the book you want, slip the sheet into a spring binder and sit in the sun while you read.”

“等我做完后再重复使用这些表格！发生了很多事我都忘了。哎，你能不能把我要的那份报告打印出来？我现在就可以拿到。”

“And reuse the sheets again when I’m through! A lot has happened that I forgot about. Say, can’t you print out that report I asked for on this? I could have it right now.”

贝尼科夫转向终端。“我不知道。如果这家医院有高安全网络，那也许有可能。只有一种方法可以找到答案。”

Benicoff turned to the terminal. “I don’t know. If this hospital has a cleared high-security network it might be possible. Only one way to find out.”

他输入了自己的密码，进入基地安全系统，找到了正确的菜单。但还没等他走多远，屏幕就清空了，一行行的印刷文字被肖尔希特将军皱着眉头的形象所取代。

He punched in his own code, accessed base security and found the right menu. But before he had gone very much further the screen cleared and the lines of print were replaced by General Schorcht’s scowling image.

“这种违反安全的行为是什么意思？”他嘶哑的声音通过终端机的微型扬声器传得更刺耳了。

“What is the meaning of this breach of security?” His rasping voice rasping even worse through the terminal’s tiny speaker.

“早上好，将军。我只是想为布莱恩弄一份机密的 Megalobe 报告的副本。”

“Good morning, General. Just trying to get a copy of the classified Megalobe report for Brian.”

“你疯了？”

“Are you crazy?”

“和往常一样。想想吧，将军。布莱恩当时在场。他是我们唯一的证人。我们需要他的帮助。如果我现在拿不到副本，我明天会带给他一份。你觉得这些有道理吗？”

“No more than usual. Think, General. Brian was there. He is our only witness. We need his help. If I can’t get a copy now I will bring him one tomorrow. Does any of this make sense to you?”

绍尔希特将军一边冷冷地凝视着，一边仔细思考着。“医院的线路并不安全。我会让五角大楼将一份一次性副本传送给 CNBSC，也就是那里的安全中心。会派信使送来副本。”他说完后，屏幕立刻一片空白。

General Schorcht stared in cold silence while he thought it through. “The hospital circuits are not secure. I’ll have the Pentagon transfer a one-off copy to CNBSC, the Security Central there. A messenger will deliver the copy.” The screen went blank as soon as he finished.

“那么再见了，先生，很高兴和你聊天。你听到了。”

“Well good-bye then, sir, nice to chat with you. You heard.”

布莱恩点点头。“我不知道我能不能帮上忙——但至少我能知道我在那里发生了什么。早些时候，斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士说其他人也被杀了。很多吗？”

Brian nodded. “I don’t know if I can help—but at least I can find out what happened to me out there. Early on, Dr. Snaresbrook said that others had been killed. Very many?”

“我们就是不知道——这是这起案件令人愤怒的地方之一。我们可以相当肯定的是，Megalobe 主席 JJ Beckworth 就是其中一员。我们发现了他的一滴血迹。但总共有十七个人失踪了。有多少人被杀——又有多少人参与了犯罪，我们根本不知道。你会在报告中读到的。”

“We just don’t know—that is one of the infuriating things about this case. One man we can be fairly certain of, the Megalobe Chairman, J. J. Beckworth. We found a drop of his blood. But seventeen men in all are missing. How many were killed—and how many were in on the crime, we just have no idea. You’ll read it in the report.”

“拿走了什么？”

“What was taken?”

“所有与你的人工智能工作有关的记录和设备都被搬走了。他们还搬走了你家里的所有电子设备和记录、每本书和每张纸。邻居们报告说，一辆搬家车在那里停了至少半天。”

“Every record and every item of equipment relating to your work on artificial intelligence. They also moved out every piece of electronic equipment and record, every book and piece of paper from your home. The neighbors reported that a moving van was there for at least a half a day.”

“你找到那辆货车了吗？”

“You’ve traced the van?”

“车牌是伪造的，搬家公司也不存在。哦，对了，搬家工人长得是东方人。”

“The plates were forgeries and the company doesn’t exist. Oh yes, the moving men were of oriental appearance.”

“中国、日本、泰国、暹罗、越南还是任何特定国家？”

“Chinese, Japanese, Thai, Siamese, Vietnamese or any specific country?”

“年长的目击者只能辨认出他们是东方人。”

“The elderly witnesses can only identify them as oriental.”

“而且这条路每天都变得越来越冷。”

“And the trail gets colder every day.”

贝尼科夫勉强点头同意。

Benicoff nodded reluctant agreement.

“我希望我能帮上忙——但就我的记忆而言，我仍然住在 UFE。也许如果我看到那所房子，我可能会得到一些线索。也许他们错过了我的电脑备份。当我第一次开始认真编程时，我丢失了两个重要的文件，我发誓这种事再也不会发生了。我编写了一个自动程序，在我工作时将其保存到外部磁盘驱动器中。”

“I wish I could be of help—but as far as my memory goes I’m still living back in UFE. Maybe if I saw the house I might get some clues. Maybe they missed my computer backup. I lost two important files when I first started programming seriously and I swore it would never happen again. I wrote an automatic program that saved to an external disk drive as I worked.”

“这个想法不错——但是他们把屋子里的所有磁盘都拿走了。”

“Not a bad idea—but they got every disk in the house.”

“但我的程序不仅仅能备份磁盘。当我十四岁的时候，我的程序还通过电话调制解调器将备份磁盘备份到我父亲实验室的主机上。我想知道我在这里有什么设置？”

“But my program did more than just backup disks. When I was fourteen years old my program also backed the backup disk through the telephone modem to the mainframe in my father’s lab. I wonder what setup I had here?”

贝尼科夫站了起来，握紧拳头。“你知道你刚才说了什么吗？”

Benicoff was on his feet, fists clenched. “Do you realize what you have just said?”

“当然。很有可能我的人工智能作品的副本就保存在某个记忆库中。那会很有帮助，不是吗？”

“Sure. There is a good chance that there is a copy of my AI work in a memory bank somewhere. That would help, wouldn’t it?”

“救命！小伙子，我们也许能用它重建你的人工智能！这并不能解决谁干的这件事——但他们不是唯一拥有人工智能的人。”他抓起电话，拨通了一个号码。“请问斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生。什么时候？让她一回来就联系我。贝尼科夫，对。告诉她，她急需知道她的病人什么时候能出院。这是一个黄金优先问题。”

“Help! My boy, we might be able to rebuild your AI with it! It wouldn’t solve the problem of who pulled this thing off—but they wouldn’t be the only ones with artificial intelligence.” He grabbed up the phone and punched in a number. “Dr. Snaresbrook, please. When? Have her contact me as soon as she gets back. Benicoff, right. Tell her that it is urgent to know just how soon her patient will be able to leave the hospital. That is a gold-placed top priority question.”

 

 

14
14

2023 年 11 月 10 日
November 10, 2023

 

 

护士匆匆忙忙地走进房间，门开着。

The nurse came bustling into the room, leaving the door open.

“你现在必须走了，贝尼科夫先生。”她一边说，一边拉开被子，拍打枕头。“该上床睡觉了，布莱恩。”

“You will have to leave now, Mr. Benicoff.” She pulled back the bedclothes and plumped the pillows as she spoke. “Time to get into bed, Brian.”

“我一定要这么做吗？我觉得还好。”

“Do I have to? I feel okay.”

“请按我说的做。你的脉搏、血压都升高了。”

“Please do as I say. Your pulse, blood pressure, both are elevated.”

“我只是对某事感到兴奋，仅此而已。”

“I’m just excited about something, that’s all.”

“床。你听见我说话了吗，贝尼科夫先生？”

“Bed. Did you hear me, Mr. Benicoff?”

“是的，太好了，当然可以。布莱恩，我看完医生后再跟你谈。”

“Yes, great, sure. I’ll talk to you later, Brian, after I’ve seen the doctor.”

尽管经过数月的休息和治疗，枪击和随后的手术带来的创伤仍然对他造成影响。布莱恩几乎立刻就睡着了，直到他听到声音，睁开眼睛看到本和医生在他床边时才醒来。

Despite the months of rest and treatment, the trauma of the shooting and the surgery that had followed was still taking its toll. Brian fell asleep almost at once and didn’t wake until he heard voices, opened his eyes to see Ben and the doctor at his bedside.

“有点太兴奋了，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士说。“不过没什么好担心的。本告诉我你很想去乡下兜风。”

“A little too much excitement,” Dr. Snaresbrook said. “But nothing to worry about. Ben tells me that you are rarin’ to go for a ride in the country.”

“可以吗？”

“Could I?”

“暂时还不行，因为你已经做了手术。不过可能没必要。”

“Not for a while yet, not after the surgery you have undergone. But it may not be necessary.”

“为什么？”

“Why?”

“本会解释的。”

“Ben will explain.”

“我的血压一定和你一样高，”贝尼科夫说。“当时我一时冲动，什么都没想。目前还不需要去那所房子。我会再搜查一次，但我怀疑他们是否能找到新证据。布莱恩，你说过，你曾经把备份文件存储在你父亲的电脑里。”

“My blood pressure must have gone as high as yours,” Benicoff said. “In the heat of the moment I just wasn’t thinking. There is no physical need to go to the house yet. I’ll have it searched again, but I doubt if they will come up with anything new. You said, Brian, that you used to store your backup files in your father’s computer.”

“这是正确的。”

“That’s right.”

“嗯，通讯技术发生了一些你记不清的重大变化。首先，现在一切都数字化了，除了最偏远的地区外，光纤已经取代了铜线。每部电话都内置调制解调器——它们已经过时了。所有大城市都有手机网络，而且它们还在不断扩张。”他敲了敲腰带上的电话。“我有自己的电话号码。几乎大部分时间，无论我身在美国大陆，它都会响。”

“Well, there have been major changes in communication technology that you can’t remember. For one thing everything is digital now and fiber optics have replaced copper wire in all but the most remote areas. Every telephone has a built-in modem—and they are already old-fashioned. All of the large cities have cellphone networks and they are expanding.” He tapped the telephone on his belt. “I have my own number for this. About most of the time it rings wherever I am in the continental United States.”

“是卫星链路吗？”

“Is it a satellite link?”

“不，卫星连接对于大多数用途来说太慢了——尤其是远程呈现。现在一切都是光纤——甚至是海底电缆。便宜又快。八千兆赫的带宽容量随处可用，有足够的通信空间——而且都是双向的。”

“No, satellite connections are too slow for most uses— particularly telepresence. Everything is fiber optics now— even the undersea cables. Cheap and fast. With plenty of room for communication with eight thousand megahertz band-width capacity available everywhere—and all of it two-way.”

布莱恩点点头。“本，我明白你的意思。你的意思是，我几乎没有可能拥有本地机械备份。毫无疑问，它是一种电子备份。这意味着要进行电子搜索。”

Brian nodded. “I get your drift, Ben. What you’re saying is that there is very little chance that I had a local mechanical backup. It was undoubtedly an electronic one. Which will mean an electronic search.”

“是的。现在有无数的邮箱、数据库和通讯程序。你可以使用其中的一个或多个。但是现在的计算机隐私法非常严格。即使是联邦调查局也必须向法院申请才能获得搜查许可。”

“Right. There are countless mailboxes, data base and communication programs now. You could have used one or more of these. But computer privacy laws are very strict these days. Even the FBI has to go to court to get permission for a search.”

“那中央情报局又如何呢？”

“What about the CIA?”

“你会很高兴听到他们已经玩了太多的谋杀伎俩，而立法刚刚通过，将他们从税务伎俩业务中剔除出去。他们又是一个公开性的受害者——而且他们不会被错过。尤其是纳税人，事实证明，他们已经为一个政府部门花费了数十亿美元，而这个部门只制作不准确的报告，在友好国家发动革命，在港口布雷，并设法在此过程中杀死数千人。他们被削减为其名称的原始含义，即中央情报机构，并且仅限于监视和平而不是发动新的战争。现在，如果你愿意签署协议，我们可以立即开始搜索。”

“You’ll be happy to hear that they pulled one murderous trick too many and legislation has just been passed to put them out of the duty tricks business. Another victim of glasnost—and they won’t be missed. Particularly by the taxpayers who, it turned out, had been shelling out billions for a government department that produced nothing but inaccurate reports, started revolutions in friendly countries, mined harbors and managed to kill thousands of people along the way. They’ve been cut back to the original meaning of their name, a central intelligence agency, and are restricted to monitoring the peace instead of starting new wars. Now, if you will sign an agreement we can start the search at once.”

“当然。”

“Of course.”

不仅要签署文件，还要进行多次电路搜索和电话回访，以及三个不同政府机构的身份检查。贝尼科夫通过挂号传真发送了所有文件，然后打着哈欠伸了个懒腰。

It was not only papers that had to be signed, but there were numerous circuitry searches and phone-backs, as well as identity checks by three different government agencies. Benicoff sent everything off by registered fax, yawned and stretched.

“现在我们等待，”他说。

“Now we wait,” he said.

“多久？”

“How long?”

“如果只需要一个小时，那时间就太长了。在电子转账出现之前，这可能需要几天甚至几周的时间。”

“If it takes an hour that will be a long time. Before electronic transfers this would have taken days—even weeks.”

“自从我离开以来的十年里，很多事情都发生了变化，”布莱恩说。“我看新闻，有些事情一点都没有改变。而我看其他新闻，却发现很多参考资料都不见了。”

“A lot has changed in the ten years since—since I have been away,” Brian said. “I look at the news and some things haven’t changed at all. Others I look at, I miss a lot of the references.”

但一小时内就完成了——不到十分钟就拿到了结果。打印机嗡嗡作响，打印出一页页永恒的纸张。贝尼科夫把它们拿给了布莱恩。

But it was done within the hour—and brought results less than ten minutes later. The printer hummed and rustled out the sheets of eternitree. Benicoff brought them over to Brian.

“您在六家不同的公司都有账户。”

“You have accounts with six different firms.”

“那么多？”

“That many?”

“就那几个。这个是科学数据库，每小时更新一次。它们取代了技术库——而且运行速度快得多。访问时间通常不到一秒。这个是邮箱，可以接收从棒球比赛到飞机航班的各种门票。这四个是最好的选择。你会先试试吗？”

“That few. This one is a scientific data base, one of the ones that are updated hourly. They replace technical libraries— and work a lot faster. Access time is usually under a second. This one is a mailbox, this gets tickets for everything from baseball games to plane flights. These four here are the best bets. Would you try them first?”

“我该怎么办？医生，我能下床吗？”

“What do I do? Can I get out of bed, Doc?”

“我宁愿你不这么做。”

“I would prefer it if you didn’t.”

“没必要，”贝尼科夫说着，走到终端机前，拔掉了键盘的插头。“它有红外线连接，不需要电线。我会打电话过去拿全息眼镜。”

“No need to,” Benicoff said, going to the terminal and unplugging the keyboard. “This has an infrared link, you don’t need wires. And I’ll phone down for holospecs.”

布莱恩非常喜欢全息眼镜。这是一种轻便的眼镜，每个耳机中都有一个微小的电路凸起。镜片似乎只是一块玻璃，不过他猜想如果他戴眼镜的话，镜片可能是用处方磨的。打开眼镜时，电脑屏幕的图像就会浮现在他面前的空间中。

Brian really enjoyed the holospecs. They were lightweight eyeglasses with a tiny bulge of circuitry in each earpiece. The lenses seemed to be just windowpane, though he guessed that they could have been ground with a prescription if he wore glasses. When they were turned on the image of a computer screen floated in space in front of him.

“好的。接下来我该怎么做？”

“Right. What do I do next?”

“打开数据库，确认身份，并告诉他们你的代码。然后猜。”

“Call up the data base, identify yourself and give them your code number. Then guess.”

“你是什么意思？”

“What do you mean?”

“每个账户都有一个只有账户所有者知道的安全代码。试试你记得的任何旧代码。如果不行，就试试新的。这些公司已经被告知发生了什么，并关闭了报警软件。通常，在第三次尝试后，连接就会被切断，警方会得到试图入侵的电话的号码。”

“Every account has a security code known only to the owner. Try any old ones that you remember. If that doesn’t work guess at new ones. These companies have been told what is happening and have switched off the alarm software. Usually, after the third attempt, the connection is cut and the police are given the number of the calling phone that is making the attempt to break in.”

“如果这不管用呢？”

“And if that doesn’t work?”

“需要法院命令才能破门而入。最快也需要几天时间。”

“A court order is needed to crack in. Which will take a couple of days at the fastest.”

布莱恩发现旧习惯很难改掉。四封信中有三封是他最喜欢的爱尔兰暗语。没有什么比“SHAMROCK”更恶心的了，但“ANLAR”打开了第一个，LEITHRAS 打开了另外两个。

Brian found that old habits die hard. Three of the four opened at once to some of his favorite Irish code words. Nothing as gross as SHAMROCK, but ANLAR opened the first and LEITHRAS the other two.

“An Lar 的意思是市中心，它位于所有公交车的前面。Leithras是盖尔语中厕所的意思，”他解释道。“孩子们非常喜欢厕所幽默。但我不知道最后一集的开头是什么。我们可以把它留到一会儿，看看其他三集里有什么吗？这有点像恢复我的记忆，不是吗？”

“An Lar means city center, it’s on the front of all the buses. Leithras is the Gaelic word for toilet,” he explained. “Bathroom humor is greatly enjoyed by kids. But I have no idea what will open this last one. Can we save it for a bit and see what’s in the other three? It’s a little like getting my memory back, isn’t it?”

“当然可以，”贝尼科夫同意了。“我告诉你——我会启动诉讼程序，要求法院下达最后一项命令，以防万一。还有更多文件要你签署。”

“Sure is,” Benicoff agreed. “I’ll tell you what—I’ll start the proceedings for a court order on the last one, just in case. More papers for you to sign.”

第一封邮件来自一个信箱，只有两年多一点的时间。布莱恩找到最早的几封信，仔细阅读。这让他感到不安。没有一封信是他熟悉的——他自己的信听起来也很陌生。是的，他签了名——但是，不，听起来根本不像他写的。这很像读别人的信件。信中偶尔提到人工智能，但只是顺便提一下——从不详细介绍。

The first account turned out to be a letter box, only a little over two years old. Brian went to the oldest letters and read through them. It gave him an uneasy feeling. None of the correspondents was familiar—and his own letters had an alien ring to them. Yes, he had signed them—but, no, it did not sound like him at all. It was very much like reading someone else’s correspondence. There were occasional mentions of AI, but only in passing—and never in detail.

他把所有东西都存入计算机内存，等到下次再看，然后看另外两份。一份是他的财务报表和国税局报告，有点令人沮丧，但又引人入胜。他记得，他很小的时候就开始靠版税赚钱，大部分是靠软件赚钱。然后是一大笔存款，是卖掉房子赚的——然后是父亲的遗产。他匆匆忙忙。钱也花光了。几年后，钱全花光了——就在他去 Megalobe 工作之前。与公司的通信非常有趣，尤其是合同的细节。这里面有很多值得深思的地方。他也把这一份也存了起来，翻到最后一本账目。

He pushed all of it into the computer’s memory for his attention at some other time, then looked at the other two. One held his financial statements and IRS reports and was fascinating in a depressing sort of way. He had started earning money from royalties when he was quite young, he remembered that, from software for the most part. Then there was a large deposit, from the sale of their house—then more from his father’s estate. He hurried on. So did the money. In a few years it was all gone—just before he went to work for Megalobe. The correspondence with the corporation made fascinating reading, particularly the details of his contract. There was much food for thought here. He stored this one as well and turned to the last account.

翻阅了几页，仔细阅读了一会儿——然后擦掉了。医生已经出去了，贝尼科夫正弯腰打电话，拨通了一个号码。天快黑了，房间里渐渐暗了下来。

Ripped through a few screens, read very closely for a while—then wiped it. The doctor had gone out and Benicoff was bent over the phone, punching in a number. It was almost sunset and the room was growing dark.

“本——有时间吗？”

“Ben—got a moment?”

“当然可以。”

“Sure thing.”

“我真的累了。我明天早上再看这些。”

“I’m really getting tired. I’ll look at these in the morning.”

“让我把键盘收起来。有发现什么关于人工智能的东西吗？”

“Let me put the keyboard away. Find anything about AI?”

“这里面什么也没有。”

“Nothing in these.”

“那我就加快法院的判决速度，睡一晚后再想其他密码，好吗？”

“Then I’ll accelerate the court order. After you get a night’s sleep try to think of more passwords, okay?”

“当然可以。明早见。”

“Sure thing. See you in the morning.”

“你看上去开始累了。休息一下吧。”

“You are beginning to look tired. Get some rest.”

布莱恩点点头，目送大个子离开。不累。完全沮丧。

Brian nodded and watched the big man leave. Not tired. Totally depressed.

他读了足够多的内容，知道自己不喜欢它。开头很熟悉，是他与金的婚外情以灾难性结局结束后所做的笔记。沮丧和仇恨稍稍消退后，他又做了更多关于管理机器理论的笔记。他记得他把这个理论发展成了他的人工智能工作——但他也记得他指出它可以成为一种个人控制手段。显然，他把这个想法进一步发展，发展成一种新的心理科学，从他在文件中看到的情况来看，它更多的是理论而不是事实，被称为 Zenome 疗法。它听起来不像戴尼提那么离谱和疯狂，但说得客气一点，它里面流淌着巨大的自大狂暗流。它读起来并不好——他很确定他不喜欢写它的人。

He had read just enough of the contents to know that he did not like it. The opening was familiar enough, the notes he had made after the disastrous end of his affair with Kim. Once the depression and hatred had ebbed a bit he had made more notes on his Managing Machine theory. This he remembered developing into his AI work—but he also remembered noting that it could be a means of personal control. Apparently he had carried this idea even further, developing it into a new mind science, more theory than fact from what he had seen in the file, called Zenome Therapy. It didn’t sound so way-out and nutty as Dianetics but there were, to put it kindly, large undercurrents of megalomania running through it. It had not made nice reading—and he was pretty sure that he did not like the person who had written it.

一旦事实摆在眼前，做出一些决定就很容易了。过去一周他一直在思考这个问题，而所谓的 Zenome 疗法的科学让他下定了决心。他按下了床头柜上的一个寻呼按钮。一会儿，护士进来了。

Some decisions are easy to make once the facts are in front of you. He had been thinking about this for the last week and the so-called science of Zenome Therapy made his mind up. One of the paging buttons was on the bedside table and he pressed it. The nurse entered a moment later.

“您知道 Doc Snaresbrook 是否还在这里吗？”

“Do you know if Doc Snaresbrook is still here?”

“我认为她正在监督设备安装。医生正在搬进这里分配给她的新办公室。”

“I believe that she is, supervising the equipment installation. The doctor is moving into a new office that has been assigned to her here.”

“请让我见见她好吗？”

“Could I see her, please.”

“当然。”

“Of course.”

黄昏的最后一抹色彩渐渐消逝，布莱恩操控灯光控制器观察着这一切。天色渐暗，他让闪烁的警告按钮发挥作用。灯光亮起，窗帘也随之拉上。一会儿，医生走了进来。

The last colors of twilight were fading and Brian overrode the lighting controls to watch them. When the sky was dark he allowed the blinking warning button to have its way. The curtains closed as the lights came on. The doctor came in a moment later.

“布莱恩，你今天很忙。感觉很糟糕吗？”

“Well, Brian, you have had a busy day. Feeling the worst for it?”

“没有。我刚才很累，但小睡一会儿就好了。我的生命体征读数怎么样？”

“Not really. I was tired earlier but a nap fixed that. How about my vital readouts?”

“再好不过了。”

“Couldn’t be better.”

“很好。那么你会说我正在康复，除了被错觉误以为自己只有十四岁之外，我的神志还算正常——虽然我实际上已经二十一岁了。”

“Good. Then you would say that I am on the road to recovery, reasonably sane other than suffering from the delusion that I am only fourteen years old—though I am really over twenty-one.”

“如果去掉‘妄想’这个词，我就同意了。”

“Take out the word ‘delusion’ and I would agree.”

“我有没有感谢过你为我所做的一切？”

“Have I ever thanked you for what you have done for me?”

“现在你做到了，我很感激——并且对事情的发展感到非常高兴。”

“You have now and I’m grateful—and tremendously happy at the way things are turning out.”

“我不想让你不开心，医生。但如果我们很快就停止记忆恢复疗程，你会不会很不高兴？”

“I don’t want to make you unhappy, Doc. But would you be terribly put out if we stopped the memory restoration sessions pretty soon?”

“我不明白-”

“I don’t understand—”

“换个说法吧。我对现在的自己很满意。我想从现在开始自己长大。变成一个更老的我，如果你明白我的意思。说实话，我并不关心另一个我，那个被子弹消灭的我。我不介意继续进行这些疗程，以了解我的记忆受到了多大的影响，如果有些事情我应该知道——但我不知道。我希望尽可能地恢复我的过去。然后，一旦你对此感到满意，也许你会考虑就此打住。不过，我想继续你建议的实验，看看我是否真的可以与内部 CPU 交互。你同意吗？”

“Put it another way. I’m satisfied with the way I am. I think that I would like to grow up on my own from now on. Become an older me, if you see what I mean. If the truth be known I don’t really care about the other me, the one that was wiped out by the bullet. I don’t mind going on with the sessions to find out how badly my memory has been affected, if there are things I should know—that I don’t. I want my past restored as much as possible. Then as soon as you are satisfied with that, maybe you will consider stopping there. Though I would like to go on with the experiments you suggested to see if I really can interface with the internal CPU. Is that okay with you?”

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克很震惊，但她尽量不表现出来。“当然，你不能被强迫。但请睡一觉。我们可以明天再谈。这是一个相当重大的决定。”

Erin Snaresbrook was shocked, tried not show it. “Well, of course you can’t be forced. But sleep on it, please. We can talk about it tomorrow. It is rather a big decision to make.”

“我知道。这就是我这么做的原因。哦，对了，还有一件事。但我们明天也可以处理这件事。”

“I know. That’s why I am making it. Oh yes, one other thing. But we can take care of that tomorrow as well.”

“那是什么？”

“What is that?”

“我想见律师。”

“I want to see a lawyer.”

15
15

2023 年 11 月 11 日
November 11, 2023

 

 

贝尼科夫等布莱恩吃完早餐才进去见他。闲聊了一下他的健康状况和天气，告诉他自己正在申请法院命令以解锁当天晚些时候可能出现的计算机文件，等待布莱恩开口。徒劳无功。最后不得不自己动手。

Benicoff waited until Brian had finished his breakfast before he went in to see him. Made small talk about his health, the weather, told him that he was trying to get a court order to unlock the computer file which might be in later in the day, waited for Brian to open the topic. Waited in vain. Had to do it himself in the end.

“我接到了斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士打来的令人不安的电话。她告诉我你想停止记忆训练。想告诉我这件事吗？”

“I got a pretty disturbed call from Dr. Snaresbrook. She tells me that you want to stop the memory sessions. Want to tell me about it?”

“嗯，这算是个人问题，本。”

“It’s, well, a kind of personal matter, Ben.”

“如果是个人问题——那我就不问了。但如果它与我的调查或人工智能有关，那我就感兴趣了。它们真的都联系在一起，不是吗？”

“If it’s personal—then I’m not asking. But if it bears upon my investigation, or AI, then I’m interested. They are all really tied up together, aren’t they?”

“我想是的——但这并不容易。那么，我可以以朋友的身份和你谈谈吗？我认为你是朋友。”

“I guess so—which doesn’t make it any easier. Can I talk to you as a friend, then? Which I think you are.”

“我把这当作一种赞美。在这一切发生之前，我们一直是很好的朋友。你所经历的真是太艰难了——我可以诚实地告诉你，很多人都无法挺过来。你是个坚强的人，我喜欢你。”

“I take that as a compliment. And we were pretty good friends before all this happened. What you have gone through was damned rough—I can tell you truthfully that a lot of people wouldn’t have made it. You’re a tough mick and I like you.”

布莱恩微笑道：“谢谢。”

Brian smiled. “Thanks.”

“不需要也不期待感谢。我很高兴得到你的信任。但你不要忘记，我仍然负责 Megalobe 的调查。你所说的任何与案件有关的事情都必须记录在案。”

“No thanks needed or expected. And I’ll be happy to be taken into your confidence. With the qualifier that you shouldn’t forget that I am still in charge of the Megalobe investigation. Anything that you say that has to do with the case will have to be for the record.”

“我知道这一点——我仍然想尽我所能提供帮助。也是为了我自己。当我长大后——或者当我长大后——过去时——我发明了人工智能，然后它连同我的记忆一起被偷走了。所以现在我知道人工智能是可以制造的，如果有必要，我会重新发明它。但我要做这件事，而不是另一个和我同名的人。我说得有道理吗？”

“I know that—and I still want to help with that as much as I can. For my own sake as well. When I grow up—or when I grew up—past tense—I invented AI, then had it stolen from me along with my memory. So now that I know that AI can be built, I’m going to reinvent it if I have to. But I am going to do it, not another guy with my name. Am I making any sense?”

“总之，不行。”

“In a word—no.”

两人听后都笑了起来。布莱恩掀开被子，穿上长袍，踢上拖鞋。窗户开着，他走到窗前，呼吸着清新的海洋空气。“这里比墨西哥湾好多了。那里太潮湿，太热，我从来没有习惯过。”他跌坐在扶手椅上。

They both laughed at that. Brian threw back the covers and put on his robe, kicked into his slippers. The window was open and he went and stood before it, breathing in the clean ocean air. “A lot better here than the Gulf. Too humid there, too hot, I never did get used to it.” He dropped into the armchair.

“我换一种说法。让我们想象一下发生在我身上的事，枪击事件和所有事情，让我们假设这件事发生在你身上。你坐在那里，三十七岁……”

“I’ll say it another way. Let’s imagine that what happened to me, the shooting and everything, let us say that this thing happened to you. There you sit, thirty-seven years of age…”

“非常感谢。五十更接近目标了。”

“Many thanks. Fifty is closer to it.”

“对。那么如果我告诉你，你被撞到了头，你​​真的已经七十岁了，你会有什么感觉？不过没关系，因为我有一项发明可以操纵你的思维，让你再次回到七十岁。”

“Right. So how do you feel if I told you that you got knocked on the head and that you are really seventy years old? But that’s okay because I’ve got an invention that will jiggle around with your mind and make you seventy again.”

贝尼科夫皱起眉头，望着远方。“我开始明白你的意思了。我本来就不想活到那么老，但又不想活到那么老。回忆起这些往事，就像是让一个陌生人进入我的脑海。”

And Benicoff frowned into the distance. “I’m beginning to get to what you mean. I don’t really want to be that old without having lived to be that old. Bringing back those memories would be like letting a stranger into my head.”

“你说得比我好。这正是我的感受。如果我发现我过去的记忆中有漏洞，那些我需要知道但却忘记的事情，我当然想填补这些漏洞，所以我们会继续进行大脑训练。但我要成长为未来，而不是把它灌输到我的脑袋里。”

“You said it better than I could. That’s exactly how I feel. If I find out that there are holes in my past memory, things that I need to know but have forgotten, sure I would like to fill the holes, so we are keeping on with the brain sessions. But I’m going to grow into the future, not have it pumped into my head.”

“那你的学历呢？你不能说你拥有某个你记不住的学位。”

“What about your education? You can’t very well say that you have a degree in something that you can’t remember.”

“我明白了。如果我记不住某件事，那我就得重新学习。我有一份研究生院的成绩单，上面列出了所有课程和讲座——我还有一份阅读清单。医生说，如果那些记忆还在，我们也许能找到它们。我愿意这么做。如果没有——我就重新学习它们。事实上，很多课本已经完全过时了，我需要阅读清单方面的帮助。”

“Point taken. If I can’t remember something then I’ll just have to relearn it. I have a transcript from graduate school, lists all the courses and lectures—and I’ve a copy of my reading list. And the doc says that if those memories are still there we might be able to find them. I’m willing to do that. If not—I’ll just learn them again. In fact a lot of the texts are completely outdated and I’ll need help on my reading list.”

“让我看看你的专家系统清单。我仍然在努力跟上文献的步伐。”

“Let me see your list for Expert Systems. I still try to keep up with the literature.”

布莱恩吃惊地抬起头。“但我以为你是……”

Brian looked up, startled. “But I thought you were…”

“公务员的苦差事！我渐渐适应了这个角色——而且不是我自愿的。我一开始是编写专家系统，后来又开始为别人排除故障。我变得非常擅长这个，最后我来到这里。这是我一生中悲伤的故事。”

“A civil service drudge! I just grew into that role—and not by choice. I started out writing Expert Systems and went from that into troubleshooting others. I got so good at it that I ended up here. The sad story of my life.”

“也不算太悲哀。不是每个人都能给总统打电话聊聊——”

“Not too sad. Not everyone can phone up the President and have a chat—”

仿佛是电话铃响了一样，布莱恩拿起电话，听了听然后点点头。“好的。叫他上来。”

As if on cue the telephone rang and Brian picked it up, listened then nodded. “Right. Tell him to come up.”

“我这就走，”本说，“我已经让你刚才打电话的那个律师等了一个小时，等我说完。”本看到布莱恩震惊的表情笑了起来。“总统的调查员无所不知——永远不要忘记这一点。这份工作的一部分就是确保你活着。所有访客都要接受检查。暂时不能有隐私。”

“And I’ll be going,” Ben said. “I already made that lawyer you had on the phone just now wait an hour until I was through.” Ben laughed at Brian’s shocked expression. “The President’s investigator is all-seeing—never forget that. Part of that job is seeing that you stay alive. All visitors are screened. For the time being privacy is out.”

说着，本将手指放在嘴唇上，然后指向上方，嘴巴张开，默默地念道“绍尔希特将军”。布莱恩表示理解地点点头，本便离开了。

As he said this Ben put his finger to his lips, then pointed upward and shaped his mouth to silently say General Schorcht. Brian nodded understanding and Ben left.

他本该自己想到这一点。他的终端直接通向将军，而这里是军事基地，按理说，这个房间可能也装了窃听器。这是他必须牢记的另一件事。

He should have thought of that for himself. His terminal led right to the General and here, on a military base, it stood to reason that the room was probably bugged as well. That was something else that he had to keep in mind.

“进来吧，”听到敲门声后他大叫道。当穿制服的陆军军官打开门时，他的眼睛睁大了。他的名牌上写着麦克·斯隆少校。

“Come in,” he called out when he heard the knock. His eyes widened when the uniformed Army officer opened the door. His name tag read Major Mike Sloane.

“你要求见我。”

“You asked to see me.”

“不是故意的。但我确实想见见律师。”

“Not knowingly. But I did want to see a lawyer.”

“那我就是了。”他微笑着，瘦削、黝黑的脸上露出一丝轻松的笑容。“副官长办公室。获得了最高机密的批准，这就是我读到你的文件的原因。那么告诉我，布莱恩——我能帮上什么忙？”

“Then that’s me.” He smiled, an easy grin on his lean, tanned face. “Adjutant General’s office. Cleared for Top Secret, which is how I got to read your file. So tell me, Brian—what can I do to help?”

“那么，你也有资格从事民法吗？”

“Are you, well, sort of cleared for civilian law as well?”

迈克笑道：“法律只有一种。我曾在华尔街的法律圈里辛苦工作过，后来才选择旅行、教育和事业。”

Mike laughed. “There is only one kind of law. I slaved in the legal snake pits of Wall Street before I opted for travel, education and career.”

“你的合同签订得怎么样了？”

“How are you on contracts?”

“一个神童。这也是我入伍的原因之一——远离公司法。”

“A whiz kid. That was one of the reasons I enlisted—to get away from corporate law.”

“那么，这是一个重要的问题。你会帮助我——还是帮助军队？”

“An important question then. Will you be helping me—or the Army?”

“好问题。如果有重叠，则军方优先。如果这纯粹是民事问题，那么它只能是我们之间的机密，或者直到你聘请民事律师。能告诉我是怎么回事吗？”

“A good question. If there is an overlap the military comes first. If this is strictly a civilian matter it is confidential between us, or until you hire civil counsel. Going to tell me what it’s about?”

“当然。只要我知道这是机密，我就会这么做。我知道我的终端被窃听了——这个房间也有可能被窃听吗？”

“Sure. As soon as I know that it is confidential. I know that my terminal is bugged—is there a chance that this room is bugged as well?”

“这就是我所说的同样好的问题。给我几分钟打个电话，看看我能否给你答案。”

“Now that is what I call an equally good question. Give me a few minutes to make a call and I’ll see if I can give you an answer.”

几分钟之后，将近一个小时之后，少校才回来。

It was more than a few minutes, closer to an hour before the Major returned.

“好的，布莱恩，我能为您做些什么？”

“Right, Brian, what can I do for you?”

“房间里有窃听器吗？”

“Was the room bugged?”

“当然我无法回答这个问题。但我可以向你保证，我们的谈话是保密的。”

“Naturally I cannot answer that. But I can assure you that our talk is confidential.”

“很好。那么请告诉我——我可以起诉 Megalobe 未能保护我，将我置于危害健康的境地吗？”

“Good. Then tell me—can I sue Megalobe for not protecting me, for putting me in a situation that was hazardous to my health?”

“我的第一反应是‘不容易’。政府拥有该公司的很大一部分股份，没有人通过起诉市政厅而致富。那么我必须看看你的雇佣合同的副本。”

“My first reaction is to say ‘Not easily.’ The government owns a good share of the company and no one ever got rich suing city hall. Then I’ll have to see a copy of your employment contract.”

“就在桌子上，就在那边。这就是让我心烦意乱的原因。我真的不想起诉他们，威胁就够了。任何威胁都可以得到比那份更好的合同。你了解我的一切吗——了解我的记忆力？”

“It’s on the table, right over there. That is what got me upset. And I don’t really want to sue them, the threat will do. Any threat to get a better contract than that one. Do you know all about me—about my memory?”

“是的。我读完了整个文件。”

“Affirmative. I read the complete file.”

“那么你就会知道，我对过去几年的事情毫无记忆。所以我读了一些我的信件，发现 Megalobe 不仅不是我的恩人，反而在我用完开发 AI 的资金后向我施压。不幸的是，我发现自己几乎完全失去了任何财务意识。但我太想完成这项工作了，以至于我被迫签署了那份合同。这似乎给公司带来的比给我的多得多。”

“Then you will know that I have no memory of the past few years. So I was reading some of my correspondence and I discovered that far from being a benefactor, Megalobe put the financial squeeze on me when I ran out of money to finish developing my AI. I discovered, unhappily, that I was almost completely bereft of any financial sense. But I wanted to finish the work so much that I let myself be bullied into signing that contract. Which appears to give the company a lot more than it gives me.”

“那么阅读它是首要任务。”

“Then reading it takes top priority.”

“去吧。我要喝橙汁。你也要喝吗？或者喝点更烈的。”

“Go to it. I’m getting an orange juice. You too? Or something stronger.”

“不用值班。喝果汁就好。”

“Not on duty. Juice will do fine.”

少校读得很慢，很仔细。布莱恩也读了卡博内尔的一篇关于数学新领域排斥几何的教程文章，他打印了这篇文章。这是一门心理学课程，主要研究的是为什么当口头解释变得太复杂时，人们开始使用图表。这是因为语言从根本上来说仍然是序列的和一维的。我们可以说前者或后者——但没有简单的方法可以同时指四五件事。人工智能一直在他脑海中，他意识到，仅仅因为人类智能以这种方式工作，并不意味着人工智能就受到任何限制。人工智能可以同时处理几十个“代词”，而不是三四个代词类的想法。当他听到律师一边放下合同一边笑的时候，他眨了眨眼，抬起头。他摇了摇头，喝光了一杯果汁，然后才开口说话。

The Major read slowly and carefully. Brian read as well, a copy he had printed out of a tutorial article by Carbonell about the new mathematical field of excluor geometry. It was a subject of psychology, concerned basically with the question of why people begin to use diagrams whenever verbal explanations get too complicated. This was because language is still fundamentally serial and one-dimensional. We can say former or latter—but there is no easy way to refer to four or five things at the same time. With AI always in the front of his mind he realized that just because human intelligence worked this way did not put any limitations on artificial intelligence. Instead of three or four pronoun-like ideas, an AI could handle dozens of “pronomes” at the same time. He blinked and looked up when he heard the lawyer laugh as he put the contract down. He shook his head and drained the glass of juice before he spoke.

“就像我们在法学院时常说的那样——你被坑了，而且没有得到任何好处。这份合同比你说的还要糟糕。我真的认为，如果你离开他们的工作，你根本不会从你的工作中获利。只要你为他们工作，利润就全是他们的。”

“As we used to say back in law school—you been screwed without the benefit of being laid. This contract is worse than you said. I really think you wouldn’t profit at all from your work if you left their employment. And as long as you worked for them the profit would be all theirs.”

“你能给我写一份更好的合同吗？”

“Can you write me a better contract?”

“非常乐意。既然陆军和其他人一样希望看到人工智能得到发展，那么立即解决这个问题对我们非常有利。但这里有一些奇怪的先例。合同是合法且具有约束力的——但你没有签署吗？”

“With pleasure. Since the Army wants to see AI developed as much as anyone does, it would be very much in our favor to sort this matter out at once. But there are some strange precedents here. The contract is legal and binding—but you didn’t sign it?”

“不，年长的我才看到。坐在这里的我直到昨天才看到。”

“No, the older me did. The me sitting here never saw it until yesterday.”

迈克一边在房间里走来走去，一边高兴地搓着双手。“哦，我真想在法庭上为这件事辩护！你掌握了这些费用，因为，如果我错了，就阻止我，你在开发真正智能的人工智能方面仍然远远领先于其他人。”

Mike rubbed his hands together happily as he walked back and forth the length of the room. “Oh, would I love the fees for arguing this one in court! You have them by the short and curlies because, stop me if I’m wrong, you are still far ahead of everyone else in developing a really smart AI.”

“我希望如此。显然，在我……事故发生之前，我的状态很好，斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士认为我很有可能回到原来的状态。但现在，我还在学习基础知识，没有人能保证我能重回领先。但我已经做好了所有的准备，我会尽我所能。”

“I hope I am. Apparently I was on the right track before my… accident, and Dr. Snaresbrook thinks there is a good chance I can get back to where I was. But right now, I’m still studying the basics and there’s no guarantee that I can get back in front. But I have all the notes, and I’ll do my best.”

“当然会的——而且你是 Megalobe 唯一的希望。世界上没有什么比垄断更能取胜的了。我要向我的上级建议，让他们建议 Megalobe 废除这份合同，重新签订一份。这样你满意了吗？你还会起诉吗？”

“Of course you will—and you are Megalobe’s only hope. Nothing wins in this world like having a monopoly. I am going to suggest to my superiors that they suggest to Megalobe that this contract be tossed out and a new one written. Does that satisfy you? Would you still sue?”

“一份新合同，没有诉讼。我应该要求什么？”

“A new contract and no lawsuit. What should I ask for?”

“简单又甜蜜。他们提供开发人工智能的准备金。你提供人工智能。未来开发人工智能的任何净利润将由有关各方五五分成。”

“Something simple and sweet. They put up the readies to develop AI. You put up the AI. Any net profit from future development of AI will be split fifty-fifty between the parties concerned.”

布莱恩震惊了。“你的意思是我要分得人工智能利润的一半？那可是数百万，甚至数十亿美元啊！”

Brian was shocked. “You mean I should ask for half of all profit from AI? That could be millions, maybe billions of dollars!”

“是的。成为亿万富翁没什么不好，不是吗？”

“Yup. Nothing wrong with being a billionaire, is there?”

“不——但这是一种新想法。”

“No—but it is kind of a new idea.”

“想让我开始做这个吗？”

“Want me to start on this?”

“是的，请。”

“Yes, please.”

麦克站起来看着合同，夸张地叹了口气。“这是我入伍以来第一次有一点点想回去当私人医生的念头。如果我是处理这份新合同的骗子，我真的会赚一大笔钱吗！”

Mike stood and looked at the contract and sighed dramatically. “This is the first time since I enlisted that I have had the slightest desire to be back in private practice. If I was the shyster handling this new contract would I really make a bundle!”

“有人曾经告诉我，律师会吃掉自己的孩子。”

“Someone once told me that lawyers eat their young.”

“布莱恩，我的孩子——这是真的！一旦我有任何消息，我会立即回复你。”

“Brian my boy—it’s true! I’ll get back to you as soon as I have any news.”

午饭后，布莱恩小睡了一会儿，下午四点，护士打开门，医院的护理员推着轮椅进来，布莱恩感觉好多了。

Brian napped after lunch and was feeling much better when the nurse opened the door and the hospital orderly pushed in the wheelchair at four in the afternoon.

“准备好与医生会诊了吗？”护士问道。

“Ready for your session with the doctor?” the nurse asked.

“当然是了。我不能走过去吗？”

“I sure am. Can’t I walk down there?”

“坐下。这是医生的嘱咐。”

“Sit. Doctor’s orders.”

布莱恩抓起他一直在阅读的一沓纸，带在身边。他坐在轮椅上，任由触须拂过他的脖子，将细小的光纤连接滑入到位。

Brian grabbed the bound sheaf of papers he had been reading and took it with him. He remained sitting in the wheelchair as the tendrils brushed his neck and slid the thin fiber-optic link into place.

“医生，我能请求你在这次会谈中帮个忙吗？”

“Doc, can I ask a favor for this session?”

“当然了，布莱恩。是什么事？”

“Of course, Brian. What is it?”

“这个。”他举起文件。“我上过一门拓扑学的研究生课程，这是一篇关于它的文章，我刚刚打印出来。我开始阅读它，发现我真的力不从心。如果我现在读它，你有没有可能获得我以前关于这个领域的记忆？你的表盘上会出现什么来表明你找到了正确的位置？然后你就可以按下按钮，把我的记忆还给我。”

“This.” He held up the papers. “I did a graduate course in topology and this is an article about it that I just printed out. I started to read it and found that I am really out of my depth. If I read it now is there any chance you can access my earlier memories of the field? Will anything show up on your dials to show you’ve hit the right spot? Then you can press the button and give me my memories back.”

“我希望事情真的那么简单——但我们当然可以尝试。无论如何，我都会提出这样的建议——所以我现在非常愿意尝试一下。”

“I wish it were that easy—but we can certainly try. I was going to suggest input like this in any case—so am more than willing to have a go at it now.”

这篇文章的内容相当难懂，布莱恩不得不反复阅读很多遍才弄明白。他几乎读了一半才放下。

The material was pretty intractable and Brian had to reread a lot for it to make any sense. He worked his way almost halfway through the article before he put it down.

“有联系方式吗，医生？”

“Any contacts, Doc?”

“活动很多，但范围很广，显然涉及大量 K 线。我的机器无法处理这样的网络。这种交叉连接只有人类大脑才擅长。”

“Lots of activity, though it is so widespread that it is obvious that a very large number of K-lines are involved. My machine is not set up to handle networking like this. This is the kind of cross-connecting that only the human brain is so good at.”

布莱恩捏了捏鼻梁，“有点累了。今天可以到此为止了吗？”

Brian pinched the bridge of his nose. “Bit tired. Can we call it a day?”

“当然。我们一致同意，只要一有疲劳迹象，就立即停止。”

“Of course. We agreed to always pull the plug at the first hint of fatigue.”

“谢谢。我希望能够使用比‘关闭’更复杂的命令来访问内置 CPU。”

“Thanks. I wish I could access the inbuilt CPU with commands more complex than ‘Turn Off.’ “

“好吧，你随时可以尝试。”

“Well, you can always try.”

“如果我能做到那不是很棒吗？只需向 CPU 发出命令。你，CPU，打开拓扑文件。”

“Wouldn’t it be great if I could? Just issue the order to the CPU. You there, CPU, open the file on topology.”

布莱恩的笑容突然变成了惊讶。他凝视着虚空，然后把目光集中到斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士身上。

Brian’s smile turned suddenly to one of surprise. He stared into space, then focused his eyes on Dr. Snaresbrook.

“这就是我所说的非常有趣。我进来的时候不是说过我对拓扑学这个数学领域知之甚少吗？我一定是太累了，无法集中注意力。但现在我记得很清楚我的论文。它有很多当时很新的东西。它一开始只是使用基于旧沃恩·琼斯多项式的结点代数理论来对混沌不变轨迹进行分类，然后将其应用于各种物理问题。没有什么特别启发性的东西，我相信现在它一定很老套了。我开始明白为什么我放弃纯数学而进入人工智能领域了。”

“Now that is what I call very interesting. Didn’t I say when I came in that I knew little or nothing about the mathematical field of topology? Well I must have been very tired or something, just not concentrating. But now I remember my thesis very well. It had a lot of what was new stuff at the time. It started simply by using an algebraic theory of knots based on the old Vaughn Jones polynomial to classify chaotically invariant trajectories, then applied this to various physics problems. Nothing very inspired and I’m sure that it must be pretty old hat now. I’m beginning to understand why I quit pure math and went into AI.”

布莱恩似乎将自己上传和移植的记忆视为理所当然——但斯纳尔斯布鲁克却不这么认为。她的手抖得厉害，不得不把它们合拢。布莱恩使用CPU 植入物与自己的记忆进行交互。确实有一个内部人机界面在运行。

Brian seemed to take his uploaded, transplanted memories for granted—but not Snaresbrook. Her hands were shaking so hard that she had to bring them together. Brian had used the CPU implant to interface with his own memories. There really was an internal man-machine interface in operation.

16
16

2023 年 11 月 14 日
November 14, 2023

 

 

医院十楼的休息区更像是屋顶花园，而不是阳台。门口的一名海军陆战队警卫检查了贝尼科夫的身份证，然后才让他在盆栽棕榈树之间前进。布莱恩坐在沙滩伞的阴影下，头靠在遮阳伞的阴影里；他前一天在阳光下睡着了，脸被晒伤了，不想再重演。他从书本上抬起头，挥了挥手。

The rest area of the tenth floor of the hospital was more like a roof garden than a balcony. A marine guard at the door checked Benicoff’s ID before he let him proceed between the potted palms. Brian was sitting with his head in the shade of the beach umbrella; he had managed to sunburn his face by falling asleep in the sun the previous day and didn’t want a rerun. He looked up from his book and waved.

“很高兴见到你，本。”

“Good to see you, Ben.”

“同样——尽管你不会喜欢这个消息。你的那些数据库不会有任何法院命令。近年来，保密法的收紧已经排除了这种访问。如果你死了，情况就会有所不同。”

“Likewise—though you are not going to like the news. There won’t be any court order for those data bases of yours. In recent years the tightening up of the secrecy laws has ruled out access of this kind. If you were dead it would be different.”

“我不明白。”

“I don’t understand.”

“偶尔有人在车祸中丧生，却没有留下任何访问密码记录。必须有听证会、关系证明，我告诉你，要获得法院命令需要做很多工作。而且没有例外。”

“Every once in a while someone gets killed in a car accident and leaves no record of his access codes. There has to be hearings, proof of relationship, a lot of work is needed to get a court order, let me tell you. And there are no exceptions to this.”

“那我该怎么办？”

“Then what can I do?”

“亲自去数据库。证明你是你，然后由公司决定是否发布这些资料。这会很棘手。”

“Go physically to the data base. Prove that you are you and then it is up to the company to decide if they will release the material or not. And that is going to be tricky.”

“为什么？”

“Why?”

“因为——我非常认真——保管您文件的公司不在美国。它在墨西哥。”

“Because—and I am deadly serious—the company with your files is not in the country. It’s in Mexico.”

“你骗我呢！”

“You’re having me on!”

“我希望如此。公司在蒂华纳。那里的工资更便宜。就在边境对面，离这里大约十二英里。那里有很多美国电子装配厂。这家公司可能就是为他们提供服务而成立的。我们是不是应该考虑去那里一趟？”

“I wish I were. The company is in Tijuana. Salaries are still cheaper there. That’s just across the border, about twelve miles from here. Lots of American electronic assembly plants there. This company was probably founded to service them. Should we start thinking about a trip down there?”

“不，暂时没有。”

“No, not for the moment.”

“我早就料到你会这么说。”贝尼科夫对布莱恩的惊讶表情笑了笑。“因为我明白，你的军方法律顾问让 Megalobe 的律师们手忙脚乱，痛苦地尖叫。他们最终会接受的。我已经上级汇报过这件事了。所以现在军方面临压力，迫使公司签订新合同。”

“That’s what I thought you would say.” Benicoff smiled at Brian’s look of surprise. “Because I understood that your military legal eagle has the Megalobe lawyers running in circles and screaming in pain. They’ll come around in the end. I’ve gone upstairs about this. So now there is pressure on the military to pressure the company to come up with a new contract.”

“楼上——和上帝说话？”

“Upstairs—talking to God?”

“差不多。我还以为你不会在确定未来之前看这些文件呢。”

“Almost. And I figured you weren’t going to look at those files until your future was set.”

“你比我领先一步。”

“You’re one step ahead of me.”

“战胜一个十四岁的孩子并不难！”

“Not hard to outwit a fourteen-year-old!”

“吹牛，吹牛。这是一个十四岁的孩子，已经喜欢上啤酒了。和我一起吗？”

“Brag, brag. This is one fourteen-year-old that has developed a taste for beer. Join me?”

“当然可以。只要是波西米亚啤酒就行。”

“Sure. As long as it’s Bohemia ale.”

“我不认识那个。”

“I don’t know that one.”

“既然我们在谈论墨西哥，我想你会喜欢它。”

“From Mexico, since we are talking about that country. I think that you’ll like it.”

布莱恩打了个电话，服务员送来了啤酒。他咂着嘴，喝了一大口。

Brian phoned down and a mess attendant brought the beers. He smacked his lips and drank deep.

“好东西。你最近和 Doc Snaresbrook 聊过吗？”

“Good stuff. Have you talked to Doc Snaresbrook lately?”

“今天早上。她说你在这里快疯了，想出去。但她希望你至少再住院一周。”

“This morning. She says that you are going stir-crazy here and want to crack out. But she wants you in the hospital for another week at least.”

“她就是这么告诉我的。我想应该没问题。”

“That’s what she told me. No problem—I guess.”

“我想你接下来会问我你是否可以去墨西哥。”

“I suppose you are going to ask me next if you can go to Mexico.”

“本——今天是你读心术的日子吗？”

“Ben—is this your mind-reading day?”

“这不难做到。你希望这些文件的安全——我们也一样。电话线可能被窃听，数据可能被复制。GRAM 也可能在邮寄过程中丢失。”

“Not hard to do. You want security for those files—and so do we. Phone lines can be tapped, data copied. And GRAMs can go astray in the mail.”

“GRAM？你是指 DRAM 吗？”

“GRAM? Don’t you mean DRAM?”

“这已经成为过去。动态随机存取存储器现在已经灭绝。这些千兆字节 ERAM 是静态的，不需要电池，而且内存容量大到可以取代 CD 和数字录音带。借助新的语义压缩技术，它们很快也会取代录像带。”

“A thing of the past. Dynamic random-access memory is now as dead as the dodo. These gigabyte ERAMs are static, no need for batteries, and have so much memory that they are replacing CDs and digital audiotape. With the new semantic compression techniques they’ll soon replace videotapes as well.”

“我想见见他们中的一个。”

“I want to see one of them.”

“行程一安排好，您就会去。我也不会让您难堪，也不会逼您拒绝，我主动提出代替您去。我已经和多位安全人员谈过这件事了。”

“You will as soon as the trip can be arranged. And I am also not going to embarrass you, force you to say no, by offering to go there in your place. I’ve talked to various security people about this already.”

“我确信，只要想到我离开这个国家，他们就会欣喜若狂。”

“I’m sure that it made them deliriously happy to even think about me leaving the country.”

“你最好相信！但当喊声平息下来时，原来联邦调查局与墨西哥政府就这类事情达成了一项持续的协议。在那里，人们经常去寻找毒资和计算机记录——通常是在银行里。全程都有武装特勤局特工陪同我们。墨西哥警察会在边境与我们汇合，然后把我们带回美国。”

“You better believe it! But when the shouting died down it turned out that the FBI has an ongoing agreement with the Mexican government about this kind of thing. There is a regular trade in going down there after drug money and computer records—usually in banks. Special armed Secret Service officers will accompany us all of the way. Mexican police will join us at the border and will bring us back to the States afterwards.”

“那么我可以去那里取回我的文件吗？”

“So I can go there and retrieve my files?”

贝尼科夫点点头。“只要医生说你身体健康，我就会送你回去。这更像是一场入侵，而不是你独自漫步越过边境。我们会一路护送你到那里，然后再送你回家。”

Benicoff nodded. “Just as soon as the doctor says you’re fit. And it will be more like an invasion than you strolling across the border on your own. You’ll be escorted all the way there and home again.”

“那么这些文件——它们会被从我这里拿走吗？”

“And the files—will they be taken away from me?”

“布莱恩·德莱尼，你的心思很卑鄙，而且多疑。你的事就是你的事。但是——我现在只是猜测——在你与 Megalobe 签订新合同之前，这次旅行可能很难安排，但并非不可能。政府确实有一项投资需要保护。”

“You have a nasty and suspicious mind, Brian Delaney. What’s yours is yours. But—and I’m just guessing now— this trip will probably be difficult, it not impossible, to set up until you have signed a new contract with Megalobe. The government does have an investment to protect.”

“如果我不同意合同——我就不去吗？”

“And if I don’t agree to the contract—I don’t go?”

“这话是你讲的——不是我说的。”

“You said it—not me.”

布莱恩不得不考虑这个问题。他喝完啤酒，当本提议再来一杯时，他摇了摇头。他一生中曾经尝试过自己开发人工智能；他所经历的记录证明了这一点。表明他也破产了，不得不与 Megalobe 签订米老鼠合同。如果你不能从经验中学习，你就学不会。如果他注定要重温人生的这一部分，他第二次肯定会做得更好。

Brian had to think about this. He finished his beer and shook his head no when Ben offered another one. Once before in his life he had tried to develop AI on his own; the records he had gone through showed that. Showed that he went broke too and had to sign that Mickey Mouse contract with Megalobe. If you can’t learn by experience you can’t learn. If he was fated to relive this part of his life he was certainly going to do a better job of it the second time around.

“这完全取决于我的新雇佣合同，”他最后说道。“如果公平的话，我们就可以取回文件，然后我就可以回去为 Megalobe 工作了。可以吗？”

“It all depends on my new employment contract,” he finally said. “If it is fair then we retrieve the file and I go back to work for Megalobe. Okay?”

“听起来很成功。我会开始安排一切。”

“Sounds like a winner. I’ll start setting things up.”

贝尼科夫刚出门，布莱恩的电话就响了；他接了起来。

Benicoff was scarcely out the door when Brian’s phone rang; he picked it up.

“谁？当然。是的，她有权限，如果有任何疑问，请咨询斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士。她以前来过这里。好的。那么请把她送上来。”

“Who? Of course. Yes, she has clearance, check with Dr. Snaresbrook if there is any doubt. She has been here before. Right. Then please send her up.”

一名海军陆战队警卫把多莉带了进来。布莱恩站起身，在她的脸颊上轻轻一吻。

A marine guard brought Dolly in. Brian climbed to his feet and gave her a peck on the cheek.

“你看起来好多了，长胖了，”她用母亲般严厉的目光看着他，然后拿出一包饼干。“我希望你仍然喜欢这些——我今天早上烤的。”

“You’re looking a lot better, filling out,” she said, looking at him with the exacting eye of maternal scrutiny, then holding out a package. “I hope you still like these—I baked them this morning.”

“不是巧克力曲奇！”布莱恩撕开包装纸，咬了一口。“多莉，我一直都很喜欢，非常感谢。”

“Not chocolate-chip cookies!” Brian tore open the wrapper and bit into one. “Always my favorite, Dolly, many thanks.”

“事情进展得怎么样？”

“And how are things going?”

“再好不过了。一周后我就能出院了。而且我很有可能在那之后尽快恢复工作。”

“Couldn’t be better. I’ll be able to get out of the hospital in a week. And the chances are I’ll be getting back to work as soon after that as I can manage.”

“工作？我以为你的记忆有问题。”

“Work? I thought that your memory, that was the trouble.”

“这不应该成为一种障碍。如果我在开始研究时发现任何差距——好吧，我会在它出现时面对它。当我真正开始再次工作时，我会很快发现我忘记了多少东西。”

“It shouldn’t be a hindrance. If I find any gaps when I start on the research—well, I’ll face that if and when it comes up. When I actually start working again I’ll quickly find out how much I have forgotten.”

“你不再做人工智能的事情了？”

“You’re not going to do that artificial intelligence thing anymore?”

“当然。你问这个干什么？”

“Of course. Why do you ask?”

多莉靠在椅子上，扭动着手指。“你不必这么做。拜托，布莱恩。你试过一次，看看结果如何。也许你注定不会成功。”

Dolly leaned back in her chair, twisting her fingers together. “You don’t have to. Please, Brian. You tried once and look where it got you. Perhaps you’re not destined to succeed.”

他不能告诉她他曾经成功过一次，他的人工智能就在某个地方。这些信息仍属机密。但他想让她明白他的工作的重要性。而“命运”与此无关。

He couldn’t tell her that he had succeeded once, that his AI was out there somewhere. This information was still classified. But he wanted to make her understand the importance of his work. And “destiny” had nothing to do with it.

“你知道我不能同意，多莉。是自由意志让世界运转。而且我并不迷信。”

“You know I can’t go along with that, Dolly. It’s free will that makes the world go round. And I’m not superstitious.”

“我不是在谈论迷信！”她热情地说道。“我在谈论圣灵，谈论灵魂。机器不可能有灵魂。你正在做的事是对神的亵渎。这是在和魔鬼打交道。”

“I’m not talking about superstition!” she said warmly. “I’m talking about the Holy Spirit, about souls. A machine can’t have a soul. What you are trying to do is a blasphemy. Dealing with the devil.”

“我从来就不相信灵魂的存在，”他轻声说道，他知道无论他说什么都会伤害到她。她生气地撅起了嘴。

“I have never been a great believer in souls,” he said softly, knowing she would be hurt whatever he said. Her mouth pursed angrily.

“你确实是你父亲的儿子。从来没去过弥撒，也不想谈论这件事。我们有上帝赋予的灵魂，布莱恩——而他不会把它们交给机器！”

“You are your father’s son all right. Never went to mass at all, didn’t want to talk about it. We have God-given souls, Brian—and He is not giving them out to machines!”

“多莉，求你了。我知道你的感受和你的信仰，记住我是天主教徒。但我的工作让我对大脑和所谓的人类状况有了一些了解。试着去理解，我不再满足于我被教导相信的东西。机器能有灵魂吗？你问我这个问题，我问你灵魂是否可以学习。如果它们不能——那么这个概念有什么重要性？空洞、空洞、永恒不变。更可取的是，我们创造了自己。缓慢而痛苦地，基本上由我们的基因塑造，被我们看到、听到和试图理解的一切不断修改。这就是现实，这就是我们运作、学习和发展的方式。这就是智能的来源。我只是想知道这个过程是如何工作的，并将其应用于机器。这有什么不对吗？”

“Dolly, please. I know how you feel and what you believe, remember that I was raised as a Catholic. But my work has given me some insight into the brain and what might be called the human condition. Try to understand that I am no longer satisfied with what I was taught to believe. Can machines have souls? You ask me that and I ask you if souls can learn. If they can’t—then of what importance is this concept? Sterile and empty and unchangeable for eternity. How much more preferable it is to understand that we create ourselves. Slowly and painfully, shaped basically by our genes, modified steadily by everything we see and hear and attempt to understand. That is the reality and that is how we function, learn and develop. That is where intelligence came from. I am just trying to discover how this process works and apply it to a machine. Is there anything wrong with that?”
