“一切！你否认上帝，你否认圣灵和灵魂本身。你将死去，永远在地狱中受火刑……”

“Everything! You deny God and you deny the Holy Spirit and the soul itself. You will die and burn in hell forever…”

“不，我不会，多莉。这种破坏性的理论是宗教沦为纯粹迷信的地方。但真正让我伤心的是，我知道你相信这种理论，为我受苦和担心。我希望你不要。我真的不想和你争论宗教，多莉。没有人会赢。但你是个聪明的女人，你知道世界在变化，甚至宗教也在变化。你离过婚。如果新教皇没有裁定计划生育不是罪恶，你就不会教节育——”

“No, I won’t, Dolly. That kind of destructive theory is where religion sinks into pure superstition. But what really hurts is that I know you believe that and suffer and worry for me. I wish you wouldn’t. I don’t really want to argue religion with you, Dolly. No one wins. But you’re an intelligent woman, you know that the world changes, even religions, change. You’ve had a divorce. And if the new Pope hadn’t ruled that family planning wasn’t a sin you wouldn’t be teaching birth control—”

“那不一样。”

“That’s different.”

“不，不是。你说人工智能是非自然的——但事实并非如此。智力的增长是进化过程的一部分。当我们了解大脑的工作原理时，将我们的工作建立在机器模型上并没有什么邪恶或错误。爸爸是这个领域的先驱之一，我很自豪能继续从事这个领域。今天的机器可以用多种方式思考、感知——甚至理解。它们很快就能更好地思考、理解、感受情绪……”

“No, it’s not. You say that artificial intelligence is unnatural— but it’s not. The growth of intelligence is part of the process of evolution. When we learn how the mind works there is nothing evil or wrong with making machine models of our work. Dad was one of the pioneers in this field and I’m proud to continue with it. Machines today can think in many ways, perceive—even understand. They’ll soon be able to think better, understand, feel emotions…”

“这几乎是亵渎，布莱恩。”

“That’s close to blasphemy, Brian.”

“是的，这可能是你的意思。我很抱歉。但这是事实。但如果你仔细想想，你就会意识到，情感一定先于大脑和智力而存在。变形虫，最简单的动物，当它感觉到疼痛时，就会把伪足拉回来。疼痛导致恐惧，恐惧导致生存。你不能否认，动物，狗，有情感。”

“Yes, it might be on your terms. I’m sorry. But it is the truth. But if you think about it you’ll realize that emotions must have come before brains and intelligence. An amoeba, about the simplest animal you can get, will pull a pseudo-pod back when it detects something painful. Pain leads to fear, which leads to survival. You can’t deny that animals, dogs, have emotions.”

“它们不是机器！”

“They’re not machines!”

“你在绕圈子，多莉。而且这也毫无意义。当我制造出第一个人工智能时，我们就会看看它是否有情感。”

“You’re arguing in circles, Dolly. And there is no point to it either. When I build the first AI we’ll see if it has emotions or not.”

“我希望你喜欢这些饼干，”她突然站起来说道。“不过我想我现在得走了。”

“I hope you enjoy the cookies,” she said, standing abruptly. “But I think I have to go now.”

“多莉，请留下来一会儿。”

“Dolly, stay a bit, please.”

“不。我知道没有办法阻止你。”

“No. I see that there is no way to stop you.”

“这不只是我一个人的问题。创意本身就具有力量。如果我不能正确地把这些碎片拼凑起来，为什么别人会这样做呢？”

“It’s not just me. Ideas have a strength of their own. If I don’t put the pieces together correctly, why then someone else will.”

她没有回答他，即使他转移了话题，试图闲聊。

She didn’t answer him, even when he changed the subject, made a feeble attempt at small talk.

“我现在得说再见了，布莱恩。再见到你还要过一段时间。我接到了很多来自家乡诊所的电话。他们很好心地在这么短的时间内给我安排了紧急休假，但他们确实人手不足。”

“I’ll have to say good-bye now, Brian. And it’s going to be a while before I see you again. I’ve had a lot of calls from the clinic back home. They were nice about giving me emergency leave at such short notice, but they really are short-staffed.”

“我很感激你对我的帮助。”

“I appreciate what you did to help me.”

“没关系，”她说道，语气已经很冷淡了。

“That’s all right,” she said, already distant.    .

“我可以给你打电话吗？”

“Can I phone you?”

“如果你认为有必要的话。你有我的电话号码。”

“If you think it necessary. You have my number.”

云朵飘来，阳台上渐渐变得寒冷。他慢慢走回房间，不再需要轮椅，打开灯。他脱下针织帽，用手指抚摸着头皮上长出的胡茬，走到镜子前。他头骨上的伤疤仍然很明显，虽然没有以前那么红了。头发开始遮住它们。他捡起医院的帽子——然后把它扔到一边。他开始讨厌这个地方了。贝尼科夫给他带来了一顶棒球帽，上面用大写字母宣传着圣地亚哥教士队的优点；他戴上它，对着镜子里的自己赞许地点点头。可怜的多莉，生活对她并不那么好。好吧，对他也不好！至少她没有被子弹射穿大脑。他的手表嗡嗡作响，一个细小的声音响起。

Clouds had come up and the balcony was getting chilly. He walked slowly back to his room, no longer needing the wheelchair, and turned on the lights. Took off the knitted cap and ran his fingers over the growing stubble on his scalp, went and looked in the mirror. The scars on his skull were still obvious, although not as red as they had been. The hair was beginning to conceal them. He picked up the hospital cap—then threw it aside. He was beginning to hate this place. Benicoff had brought him a baseball cap that advertised the virtues of the San Diego Padres in large letters; he pulled that on, nodded approvingly at his mirrored image. Poor Dolly, life had not been that nice to her. Well it had not been nice to him either! As least she didn’t get a bullet through the brain. His watch buzzed and the tiny voice spoke.

“下午四点是您与 Snaresbrook 医生的预约时间。下午四点是您……的时间。”

“Four p.m. Time for your appointment with Dr. Snaresbrook. Four p.m. Time for yo.,.”

“系好安全带！”他说道，然后一切就都安静了。

“Belt up!” he said, and it went silent.

布莱恩进来时，艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克抬起头，微笑着。“我喜欢你对帽子的品味。它肯定比你一直戴的医院发的无檐小帽好。准备去上班了吗？我今天想尝试一些新东西。”

Erin Snaresbrook looked up and smiled when Brian came in. “I love your taste in hats. It sure beats that hospital-issue beanie that you have been wearing. Ready to go to work? I want to try something new today.”

“那是什么？”布莱恩摘下盖子，靠在牙医的椅子上，感受着金属手指蜘蛛般的触感。

“What’s that?” Brian took off the cap and settled back in the dentist’s chair, felt the spidery touch of the metal fingers.

“如果您不介意的话，我想推迟这次会议的记忆工作，看看我们是否可以利用您访问内置 CPU 的新才能做更多的事情。”

“If you don’t mind I would like to hold off on the memory work for this session and see if we can’t do more with your new talent of accessing your inbuilt CPU.”

“当然。我从来没想过要问——但它是什么样的中央处理器？”

“Sure. I never thought to ask—but what kind of a central processor is it?”

“这是一个 CM-9 并行处理单元，包含 1.28 亿台简单但快速的计算机。它耗电量非常小，运行时温度非常低——几乎不高于你的体温。几乎不消耗任何电流。事实上，这台计算机消耗的能量比同等的脑细胞还要少。而且内存充足。除了 16 个 640 亿字节的 GRAM 外，你的植入物还包含 40 亿字的 B-CRAM。”

“It’s a CM-9 parallel processing unit that contains 128 million simple but fast computers. It has a very small current drain and runs very cool—imperceptibly above your body temperature. Uses hardly any current at all. In fact, this computer uses less energy than the equivalent brain cells. And plenty of memory. In addition to sixteen 64-billion-byte GRAMs, your implant contains four thousand million words of B-CRAM as well.”

“B-CRAM。那肯定是我不知道的新东西。”

“B-CRAM. That must be something new I don’t know.”

“是的，它们是新的。B-CRAM 是一种最佳匹配内容访问存储器。它们是为数据库应用程序开发的，非常适合在这里使用，因为它们几乎可以立即找到与输入匹配的记录。B-CRAM 会自动并行地对每个数据条目进行模式匹配，并与提供给其输入的匹配“权重”向量进行匹配。这些是存储输入输出神经重新连接信息的组件。”

“Yes, they are new. A B-CRAM is a best-matching content-accessed memory. These were developed for database applications and are perfect for use here, since they can almost instantly find records that match inputs. The B-CRAM automatically does pattern matching of every data entry, in parallel, against a vector of matching ‘weights’ provided to its input. These are the components that store your input-output nerve-reconnection information.”

“一些设置！但即使冷却运行，它仍然需要一些电力。难道你还要再一次打开我的脑袋来换电池吗？”

“Some setup! But even running cool it will still need some electricity. Don’t tell me you will have to open my head again to change batteries?”

“绝不是！电子植入物，比如心脏起搏器，不再依赖需要从体外充电的复杂电源。这都已成为过去。它们现在由代谢电池供电，能量来自血糖。”

“Hardly! Electronic implants, like pacemakers, no longer depend on tricky power supplies that have to be recharged from the outside of the body. That’s all a thing of the past. They are now powered by metabolic batteries that get their energy from blood sugar.”

“电池真棒——科技发展迅猛。那么你现在想做什么呢？”

“Sweet batteries—technology run rampant. So what is it that you want to do now?”

“运行一个基准测试序列。这大概需要十分钟。我想让你看看你是否意识到中央处理器的存在，是否能够利用它或听到它的声音——或者无论我们怎么称呼它。你记得当 CPU 连接记忆时，你是意识到它的。我想看看你是否能重新产生这种意识。”

“Run a benchmark sequence. This will take about ten minutes. I want you to see if you are aware of the central processing unit, can tap into it or hear it—or whatever we might call it. You remember that you were aware of the CPU when it was connecting memories. I want to see if you can re-create that awareness.”

“听起来不错。”

“Sounds good to me.”

几分钟后，布莱恩大声打了个哈欠。

After a few minutes Brian yawned loudly.

“还有什么事吗？”外科医生问道。

“Anything yet?” the surgeon asked.

“什么也没有。它真的在运行吗？”

“Absolutely nothing. Is it really running?”

“非常好。刚刚重新开始基准测试。”

“Perfectly. Just started the benchmark run again.”

“别这么沮丧，博士。现在还为时过早。你为什么不重新运行我接触它的会话，看看我们能否重新创造条件。”

“Don’t look so depressed, Doc. Early days yet. Why don’t you rerun the session where I did contact it, see if we can re-create the conditions.”

“这是个好主意——我们明天就尝试一下。”

“That’s a good idea—we’ll try it tomorrow.”

“一周之内我真的能摆脱困境吗？”

“Will I really be able to get out of stir in a week?”

“身体上，可以，只要你不做任何剧烈运动就行。不要爬楼梯或快走，跟你平常在这里的行走量差不多。过一段时间我们可以增加这个量。这是旅行的身体方面；你的安全是另一回事。你得问问本。”墨西哥的记忆库里有他人工智能工作的记录吗？这事关重大。

“Physically, yes, as long you do nothing strenuous. No stairs or fast walking, just about the same amount you do here in a normal day. After a while we can increase that. That is the physical side of the trip; your security is another matter. You’ll have to ask Ben about that.” Would the memory bank in Mexico have the records of his AI work? A lot was riding on that.

17
17

2023 年 11 月 20 日
November 20, 2023

 

 

“就是这个！我给你带来了好消息，”贝尼科夫兴高采烈地冲进门说道。布莱恩合上他正在读的书《应用排阻几何导论》，抬起头，起初没认出在本后面进来的另一个人。三件套深色西装，苏尔卡领带，闪闪发光的黑色靴子。

“This is it! I bring you Mr. Good News,” Benicoff said, bursting enthusiastically through the door. Brian closed the book he was reading, Introduction to Applied Excluor Geometry, and looked up, at first not recognizing the other man who came in behind Ben. Three piece dark suit, Sulka tie, gleaming black boots.

“麦克·斯隆少校！”

“Major Mike Sloane!”

“一样。这是必要的伪装，因为那些高高在上的 Megalobe 律师鄙视我们国家的制服——但请谦卑地尊敬地看着我平民时代的这件服装纪念品。他们已经转变了。”他打开手工制作的保时捷皮革公文包，拿出一叠厚厚的纸。“就是这个。我坚信这正是你想要的合同。”

“The same. A necessary disguise, since the high-powered Megalobe lawyers sneer with contempt at our country’s uniform—but look with humble respect at this sartorial souvenir of my civilian years. They’ve come around.” He opened his hand-tooled leather Porsche attache case and took out a thick wad of paper. “This is it. And it is my positive belief that it is just the contract that you wanted.”

“我怎么能确定呢？”

“How can I be sure?”

“因为我检查过了，”贝尼科夫说。“不是亲自检查，而是我把它发到了华盛顿。我们那里的律师可以把 Megalobe 当早餐吃掉。他们向我保证，这是铁板钉钉的事情，你得到了你想要的条件，薪水比预期的要高。而且，扣除管理费用、开发成本和所有常规扣除后，你的利润将接近五五分成。准备好去边境以南一趟了吗？”

“Because I checked it,” Benicoff said. “Not personally, but I sent it on down the line to Washington. We’ve got attorneys there that could eat Megalobe for breakfast. They assure me it’s brassbound, you got the terms you asked for, a better salary than expected. And after overhead, development costs and all the usual deductions, you’ll have something very close to a fifty-fifty split on profits. Ready for a little trip south of the border?”

“当然。在我读完这个之后。”

“You bet. After I read through this.”

“祝你好运。这很艰难。”

“Good luck. It’s tough going.”

迈克向他讲解了那些条理不清、内容繁杂的法律术语，并解释了一切。两小时后，律师离开时，合同已经签署、登记并正式归档到法律数据库中。同时，一份古老的纸质副本被锁在医院的保险柜里。

Mike guided him through the less coherent and densest legalese clauses, explained everything. By the time the lawyer left two hours later the contract was signed, registered and duly filed in the legal data bank. Along with an archaic paper copy locked away in the hospital’s safe.

“满意吗？”贝尼科夫一边看着农夫封好保险柜，一边问道。布莱恩看着收据，点了点头。

“Satisfied?” Benicoff asked as they watched the Yeoman seal the safe. Brian looked at his receipt and nodded.

“这比第一份合同好多了。”

“It’s a lot better than the first contract.”

“这意味着你有一份工作——当你能够回去工作的时候。你有没有注意到这个条款，如果你无法恢复你的备份文件（希望这些文件在 TJ 中），公司保留雇用或不雇用你的权利？或者，如果他们选择在没有备份文件的情况下雇用你，他们可以随时解雇你，然后你就得到 bupkas。”

“Which means that you have a job—when you’re able to go back to work. You did notice the clause about how if you can’t recover your backup files, which are hopefully in TJ, the company reserves the right to employ you or not? Or if they choose to employ you without your backup files, they can fire you whenever they feel like it and you get bupkas.”

“你在打电话的时候，麦克·斯隆向我详细指出了这一点。这似乎很公平。那么让我们打开那个墨西哥文件，看看里面有什么。我想你一直在想我该怎么做吧？”

“Mike Sloane pointed that out to me in very great detail while you were on the phone. It seems fair. So let’s open that Mexican file and see what’s in it. I suppose you have been thinking about how I’m going to do that?”

“不只是我，海军情报局、陆军和联邦调查局也参与其中。更不用说海关和消费税局了。我们已经制定了一项得到所有人认可的计划。简单而不复杂，但希望万无一失。”

“Not just me—Naval Intelligence, the Army and the FBI. Not to mention Customs and Excise. A plan has been produced which has the approval of everyone. Simple instead of complex, but hopefully foolproof.”

“那就说吧。”

“So tell.”

“我们去你的房间谈吧。”

“Let’s go talk in your room.”

“至少告诉我这一切什么时候会发生。”

“At least tell me when all this is going to happen.”

本用手指碰了碰嘴唇，指着出口。直到布莱恩的房间门关上后，他才回答了这个问题。

Ben touched his finger to his lips and pointed to the exit. Only when the door to Brian’s room had closed behind them did he answer the question.

“明天早上八点，正是科罗纳多海军高峰期。你的医生已经批准了所有安排。”

“Tomorrow morning, eight a.m., height of the navy rush hour here in Coronado. And your doctor has approved all arrangements.”

“我被弹开了！这要怎么办？”

“I’m being sprung! How is it going to work?”

“明天早上你就会知道了，”贝尼科夫带着一种虐待狂般的快感说道。“目前我们中只有少数人知道所有细节。我们不想出现任何失误，也不想泄露任何消息。如果有人泄露消息，再好的计划也会变成毫无计划。”

“You’ll find out in the morning,” Benicoff said with sadistic relish. “As of now only a handful of us know all the details. We want no slipups and no leaks. The best plan becomes no plan at all if someone talks.”

“来吧，本，至少给我一个线索。”

“Come on, Ben, give me a clue at least.”

“好的。你的要求是七点吃早餐，然后就躺在床上。”

“All right. Your instructions are to eat your breakfast at seven and to remain in bed after that.”

“一些说明！”

“Some instructions!”

“耐心是一种美德。明早见。”

“Patience is a virtue. See you in the morning.”

对布莱恩来说，这是无所事事的一天，当他强迫自己休息时，他却难以入睡。他现在很担心。他一直以为他的备份在墨西哥的文件中。但如果不在呢？没有它们，他怎么能重新发现他在人工智能方面的工作？这是否意味着他要与斯纳尔斯布鲁克和她的机器进行更多会话，试图找回他并不真正想要的未来记忆、他的过去记忆？当他打电话给护士要一些能让他入睡的东西时，时钟指向午夜。他需要尽可能多地休息以迎接新的一天。

It was a slow day for Brian, and when he forced himself to retire he had trouble going to sleep. He was worried now. He had always assumed that his backups were in the files in Mexico. But what if they weren’t? How could he rediscover his work on AI without them? Would it mean more sessions with Snaresbrook and her machine in an attempt to get back memories of the future, his past, that he did not really want? The clock said midnight when he called the nurse for something to make him sleep. He would need all the rest he could get for the day to come.

第二天早上八点，他坐在床上盯着早间新闻，却什么也没看到。整点时，传来一阵急促的敲门声，两名海军医务兵推着轮床走了进来。他们身后是楼层护士，还有两名可能是医生的人，只是他们背对着关着的门站着，手指拂过白色夹克的前襟。他们都是大个子，不知为何，显得有些眼熟。腋窝里有凸起吗？布莱恩想。或者现在他们的做法不一样了。

At eight the next morning he was sitting up in bed staring at the morning news and not seeing it. Precisely on the hour there was a quick knocking and two navy corpsmen came in wheeling a gurney. Behind them was the floor nurse and what could have been two doctors, except for the fact that they stood with their backs to the closed door, fingers brushing the fronts of their white jackets. They were both big men and, for some reason, strangely familiar. And were those bulges in the armpits? Brian thought. Or do they do it different these days.

“早上好，布莱恩，”护士说着，把一卷绷带放在床头柜上。“如果你能坐起来的话，这很快就能完成。”

“Good morning, Brian,” the nurse said, laying a roll of bandages on the bedside table. “If you will sit up this won’t take a moment.”

她打开绷带，迅速熟练地将绷带完全包住，只留出一个呼吸的开口和眼睛的缝隙。然后剪掉绷带末端，用塑料夹子将其固定到位。

She opened the roll and swiftly and expertly swathed his head completely, leaving just an opening for him to breathe through and a slit for his eyes. Then cut off the end of the bandage and secured it in place with plastic clips.

“你需要帮忙上担架吗？”她问道。

“Do you want help getting onto the stretcher?” she asked.

“决不。”

“No way.”

他爬上轮床，毯子被裹住，一直盖到脖子。他们把他推到走廊上，他成了繁忙医院里一个身份不明的病人。大电梯里的其他乘客小心翼翼地把目光移开。不管是谁想出了这个主意，他一定想出了一个好主意。

He climbed onto the gurney and the blankets were tucked in around him, right up to the neck. They pushed him out into the corridor, an unidentifiable patient in a busy hospital. There were other passengers in the big elevator who carefully looked away. Whoever had dreamed this one up had produced a really good idea.

救护车已在等候，布莱恩被抬进船舱。他看不到外面，但知道车流很拥挤，因为经常停车，车速很慢。当后门终于打开，他被轻轻抬出船舱时，他发现自己正抬头看着尼米兹号航空母舰。片刻之后，他被抬上船舱。他们还没到达军官舱，他就听见船舱驶离码头时传来低沉的命令声和远处的汽笛声。海军人员一言不发地离开了，贝尼科夫走了进来，关上身后的门并锁上。

The ambulance was waiting and Brian was carried inside. He couldn’t see out but knew that traffic was heavy by the frequent stops and slow progress. When the back doors were finally opened and he was gently lifted out, he found himself looking up at the aircraft carrier Nimitz. A moment later he was being carried aboard. Even before they reached the wardroom he heard muffled commands and a distant whistle as the vessel started away from the wharf. Still without a word, the navy personnel left and Benicoff came in, closing and locking the door behind him.

“让我把那东西从你头上拿下来，”他说。

“Let me take that thing off your head,” he said.

“你就是为了我才躺在这艘航空母舰上的吗？”布莱恩问道，他的声音被布料捂住了。

“Did you lay on this aircraft carrier just for me?” Brian asked, his voice muffled by the cloth.

“不是真的。”贝尼科夫把绷带扔进了废纸篓。“反正它今天早上就要离开港口了。但你得承认，这是一个漂亮的掩护。”

“Not really.” Benicoff threw the bandage into a waste-basket. “It was leaving harbor this morning in any case. But you have to admit that it’s a beautiful cover.”

“确实如此。现在你能告诉我接下来会发生什么吗？”

“It certainly is. Now can you tell me what comes next?”

“是的。不过你先下车，穿上衣服。我们正向西驶入太平洋，直到船看不见陆地为止。然后我们向南转。我们将经过马德雷斯群岛以西，这是墨西哥边境下方的一座无人居住的小岛。昨晚天黑后有一艘船出发了，会在那里等我们。”

“Yup. But get off that cart first and put these clothes on. We are heading west into the Pacific and carrying on until the ship is out of sight of land. Then we turn south. We will pass west of the Islas Madres, small uninhabited islands that are just below the Mexican border. A boat went out after dark last night and will be waiting for us there.”

布莱恩穿上裤子和运动衫。虽然不熟悉，但非常合身。莫卡辛鞋虽然磨损了，但非常舒适。“我的？”

Brian pulled on the trousers and sport shirt. They were unfamiliar but fit perfectly. The moccasins were scuffed and worn and very comfortable. “Mine?”

贝尼科夫点点头。“上次搜查你家的时候，我们找到了它们。你感觉怎么样？”

Benicoff nodded. “We picked them up last time we searched your place. How are you feeling?”

“很兴奋，但除此之外状态很好。”

“Excited, but otherwise in great shape.”

“斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生命令我让你躺下，或者至少在这次航行中的任何间歇坐下来——就像这次一样。但首先我要你穿上这条毯子，留上与之相配的胡子。”

“Doc Snaresbrook ordered me to make you lie down, or barring that at least sit down during any lulls in this voyage—like this one. But first I want you to put on this rug and matching mustache.”

假发和衣服一样，与他的头完美贴合。好吧，经过所有的手术，他们现在应该知道他头的大小和形状了。卷曲的八字胡背面有某种粘合剂；他看着镜子，把它按到位。

The wig fitted his head perfectly, just as the clothes had. Well, after all the operations they should know the size and shape of his head by this time. The curling handlebar mustache had some kind of adhesive on its backing; he looked into the mirror and pressed it into place.

“你好，伙计，”他对着自己的形象说道。“我看上去就像西部枪手。”

“Howdy, pardner,” he said to his image. “I look like some kind of western gunslinger.”

“你看上去不像你自己——这才是关键。坐下，医生吩咐的。”

“You don’t look like yourself—which is what counts. Sit, doctor’s orders.”

“我坐吧。我们的航程要多久？”

“I’ll sit. How long will our cruise take?”

“一旦我们离开港口，驶上大海，不到一个小时。”听到轻轻的敲门声，他抬起头。“是谁？”

“Once we’re out of the harbor and at sea, less than an hour.” He looked up when he heard the light knock on the door. “Who is it?”

“我是德莫德。雷和我在一起。”

“Dermod here. Ray is with me.”

贝尼科夫打开门，让医院的两名医生进来，他们穿着格子长裤和运动夹克，看上去像一名游客。

Benicoff unlocked the door and admitted the two doctors from the hospital, now looking very touristy in plaid slacks and sport jackets.

“布莱恩，我来给你介绍一下。这里的大个子是德莫德，更大的是雷。”

“Brian, let me introduce you. The big guy here is Dermod, the even bigger one is Ray.”

“我没想到你们是医生，”布莱恩说道。当他们握手时，他发现他们两人身上都是结实的肌肉。

“I didn’t think you were doctors,” Brian said. When they shook hands he realized that the bulk was solid muscle on both of them.

“我们很高兴来到这里，”德莫德说。“离开华盛顿之前，我们的老板祝你好运，早日康复。”

“Our pleasure to be here,” Dermod said. “Before we left Washington our boss said to wish you the best of luck and a speedy recovery.”

“老板？”布莱恩突然顿悟，“你的老板不会也是本的老板吧？”

“Boss?” Brian had a sudden insight. “Your boss isn’t by any chance Ben’s employer as well?”

德莫德微笑道：“没有别人了。”

Dermod smiled. “None other.”

难怪他们看起来很眼熟。布莱恩在新闻上见过他们，在一次游行中。身材魁梧的男人走在总统旁边，目光四处游移，就是不看他。他们之所以高大，是因为他们挡在总统和子弹或炸弹碎片之间。他们的存在比任何关于总统安全的重要性的话语都更能说明问题。

No wonder they looked familiar. Brian had seen them on the news, in a parade. Big solid men walking next to the President and looking everywhere but at him. Big because they were there to stay between him and any bullets or bomb fragments. Their presence was more revealing than any amount of words about the importance attached to his safety.

“好吧——替我谢谢他，”布莱恩虚弱地说。“别以为我不感激。”

“Well—thank him for me,” Brian said weakly. “Don’t think I don’t appreciate it.”

“医生的嘱咐！”本厉声说道。布莱恩跌坐在深躺椅上。

“Doctor’s orders!” Ben snapped. Brian dropped into the deep lounge chair.

“你知道我们会在墨西哥待多久吗？”雷问道。“我们没有得到任何细节。我们被告知的只是关于医院和转移到航母和船上的指示。还有我们在岸上有人接我们。我问这个问题只是因为我们有一架飞机准备好今晚把我们送回雾谷。我们明天一早出发去维也纳。”

“Do you have any idea how long we will be in Mexico?” Ray asked. “We were given no details at all. What we were told about was just the instructions about the hospital and the transferral to the carrier and the boat. And that we were being met onshore. I’m only asking because we have a plane ready to take us back to Foggy Bottom tonight. We leave early tomorrow morning for Vienna.”

“我想手术最多需要两个小时。当然，我们回去的路不同。维也纳？那一定是艾滋病治疗和控制会议吧？”

“I would say that the operation will take two hours at most. We’re going back a different way of course. Vienna? That must be the conference on AIDS treatment and control?”

“是的，而且也是时候了。治疗正在改善——但即使有了新疫苗，世界上仍有超过一亿例病例。仅控制这种疾病所需的资金就如此之大，以至于富裕国家不得不出资——仅仅出于自私的理由。”

“It is—and about time as well. Treatment is improving— but even with the new vaccine there are still over a hundred million cases in the world. The sums involved in just containing the disease are so large that the richer countries have to contribute—for selfish reasons alone.”

布莱恩发现自己的眼睛闭上了；即使吃了药，他昨晚也没睡好。本轻轻摇晃他的肩膀，他醒了过来。

Brian found his eyes closing; even with the pills he had not slept well the night before. He woke when Ben shook him lightly by the shoulder.

“该行动了，”他说。

“Time to get moving,” he said.

德莫德在前面带路，当他们登上甲板时，雷跟在他们后面。水面平静，天气晴朗。当布莱恩小心翼翼地走下德莫德身后的台阶时，航空母舰还在水中轻轻摇晃。等待他们的船原来是一艘三十英尺长的深海巡洋舰，鱼竿垂直固定。他一被人扶上船，其他人也跟着跳下船，马达发出轰鸣声，他们绕过岛屿，把尼米兹号甩在身后。墨西哥海岸映入眼帘，他们绕过另外两艘渔船，向码头驶去。布莱恩发现自己的手掌突然湿润了。

Dermod led the way and Ray fell in behind them when they went on deck. The water was smooth, the day sunny. The aircraft carrier was barely slipping through the water when Brian made his way carefully down the steps behind Dermod. The boat waiting for them turned out to be a thirty-foot deep sea cruiser with its fishing poles secured vertically. As soon as he was helped aboard, and the others jumped down behind him, the motors burbled and roared and they swung away around the island, leaving the Nimitz behind. The Mexican coast came into view and they cut around two other fishing boats as they headed toward the marina. Brian found that the palms of his hands were suddenly moist.

“接下来会发生什么？”

“What happens next?”

“两辆没有标记的警车会等着我们，由我之前提到的墨西哥便衣警察驾驶。我们直接开车去 Telebasico——他们正在等着我们。” Ben 从口袋里掏出两个黑色塑料盒，大小和重量与多米诺骨牌差不多。Brian 把它们翻过来，注意到每个盒子底部都有插座。

“Two unmarked police cruisers will be waiting for us, driven by the Mexican plainclothesmen I told you about. We drive directly to Telebasico—who are expecting us.” Ben dug into his pocket and handed over two black plastic boxes, about the size and weight of dominoes. Brian turned them over, noticed the socket each had in its base.

“内存，”本说。“这些就是我跟你说过 GRAM。”

“Memory,” Ben said. “These are GRAMs I told you about.”

布莱恩看起来有些怀疑。“这些文件中可能有很多记录，可能长达数年。这两个文件有足够的内存空间来保存它们吗？”

Brian looked dubious. “There may be a lot of records in those files, years’ worth maybe. Is there enough memory space in these two to hold it?”

“我希望如此。其实你不需要两个——第二个是用于备份。每个都有一千兆字节。应该足够了。”

“I should hope so. You don’t really need both—the second one is for backup. Each of them holds a thousand megabytes. Should be more than enough.”

“我当然这么说！”

“I should say so!”

车厢又长又黑，车窗颜色很深，几乎看不清车内的情况。车厢旁等候的两名墨西哥便衣留着自然的胡子，比布莱恩的假胡子更令人印象深刻。

The cars were long and black, the windows so heavily tinted that very little could be seen of the insides. The two Mexican plainclothesmen who were waiting by the cars had natural mustaches that were even more impressive than Brian’s fake one.

“前面那个人是丹尼尔·萨尔达纳，”本说。“我和他以前合作过。他是个好人。祝你好运 ，骑士们。 一切都好吗？”

“The guy in front is Daniel Saldana,” Ben said. “He and I have worked together before. He’s a good man. Buenos dias, caballeros. ¿Todos son buenos?”

“没关系，本。轻而易举。很高兴再次见到你。”

“No sweat, Ben. Easy as falling off a log. Good to see you again.”

“一样。准备好出去兜风了吗？”

“The same. Ready for a little drive?”

“没错。我们奉命将你和你的朋友送到这里的一个商业场所，然后安全抵达边境。我很乐意开车送你们去那里。”他打开了第一辆汽车的车门。雷走上前去。

“You betcha. We have been instructed to take you and your friends to a business premise here, and after that safely to the border. I will be pleased to drive you there.” He opened the door of the first car. Ray stepped forward.

他问道：“把三辆车放到后面没问题吧？”

“No problem getting three in the back of this, is there?” he asked.

“如果这就是你想要的。”

“If that’s the way you want it.”

本和另一名便衣警察一起乘坐第二辆车。布莱恩坐在后座中间，感觉自己就像三明治里的馅料。两个大个子男人都盯着外面的街道。德莫德坐在布莱恩的左边，用右手解开夹克的扣子——之后一直把手放在腰上。当他们拐弯时，夹克打开了，布莱恩很快就瞥见了皮革和金属。所以他刚才看到的腋窝处有一个凸起。

Ben traveled with the other plainclothesman in the second car. Brian, sitting in the middle of the backseat, felt like the filling in a sandwich. Both big men kept their eyes on the street outside. Dermod, sitting on Brian’s left, unbuttoned his jacket with his right hand—and kept his hand at his waist after that. When they swayed around a turn the jacket gaped open and Brian had a quick glimpse of leather and metal. So it had been a bulge he had seen in his armpit.

开车很快就到了工业区，典型的低矮、没有窗户的高科技制造工厂。两辆车驶入建筑群，停在其中一栋建筑后面，通过装卸区进入。侦探们显然以前来过这里，带我们来到一间小小的木板办公室。办公室里已经有两个男人坐在电脑终端前。除了留在走廊里的雷，其他人都推门进来并关上了门，办公室里挤得人有些不舒服。

It was a brief drive to the industrial area, the typical low and windowless factories of high-tech manufacturing. The two cars drove into the complex and parked behind one of the buildings, entered it through the loading bay. The detectives had obviously been here before and led the way to a small, wood-paneled office. There were two men already there, sitting before a computer terminal. It was uncomfortably crowded when all of them except Ray, who stayed behind in the hall, pushed in and closed the door.

“你们中哪位先生负责会计工作？”一位技术人员拿起一叠文件问道。

“Which of you is the gentleman with the account?” one of the technicians said, taking up a sheaf of papers.

“我是。”

“I am.”

“我了解到您忘记了您的身份证号码和密码，德莱尼先生？”

“I understand that you have forgotten your identification number and password, Mr. Delaney?”

“你可以这么说。”

“You might say that.”

“我们以前也遇到过这种事，但你会明白我们仍然必须采取一切预防措施。”

“This has happened to us before, but you will understand we must still take every precaution.”

“当然。”

“Of course.”

“很好。请你在这里和这里签字。这是你的协议，如果你无法访问你的文件，你不会对我们提出指控。它还说你保证你就是你说的那个人。现在，只剩下最后的验证了。请你签字。”

“Good. Could I please have your signature here—and here. This is your agreement not to bring charges against us if you cannot access your files. It also says that you guarantee you are who you say you are. Now—all that is left is to make the final verification. Could I have your hand, please.”

他拿出一个大约有便携式收音机大小的电子仪器，将其触碰到布莱恩的手背。

He held out an electronic instrument about the size of a portable radio, touched it to the back of Brian’s hand.

“这需要一点时间，”他说着，把它带到房间的另一边，然后插到那里的一台更大的机器上。

“It will take a few moments,” he said, carrying it across the room and plugging it into a larger machine there.

“是什么？”布莱恩问道。

“What is it?” Brian asked.

“便携式 DNA 匹配，”贝尼科夫说，“刚刚投入商业使用。手柄上的粘合剂会剥离一些表皮细胞，这些细胞经常会脱落。现在它会将你的 MHC 复合体与档案中的 MHC 复合体进行匹配。”

“Portable DNA matching,” Benicoff said. “Just coming into commercial use. The adhesive on the handpiece picked off a few of your epidermal cells, the ones that flake off all the time. Now it’s matching up your MHC complex with the one on file.”

“从来没听说过。”

“Never heard of that.”

“主要组织相容性复合体。这些是所谓的自我识别抗原，每个人的抗原都完全不同。最好的部分是它们位于皮肤表面，因此无需从细胞核中提取 DNA。”

“Major histocompatability complex. These are the so-called self recognizing antigens and are completely different for every person. The best part is that they are on the surface of the skin so DNA doesn’t have to be extracted from the cell nucleus.”

“你能过来吗，德莱尼先生？请使用这个终端。你带了一些记忆吗——我明白了，很好。一切都很顺利，我们对你的身份很满意。我们已经解锁了安全文件并获得了你的身份证号码和密码。”

“Would you come over here, Mr. Delaney? Please use this terminal. Did you bring some memory—I see, fine. Everything checks out perfectly and we are satisfied re your identity. We have unlocked the security files and obtained your identification number and password.”

接线员接通了 GRAM，布莱恩坐在背对着房间其他部分的屏幕前。他还递过一张纸。“这是您的接入号码。输入后，系统会要求您输入密码——就是这个。”

The operator plugged in the GRAMs as Brian sat in front of the screen that faced away from the rest of the room. He also passed over a piece of paper. “This is your access number. After you have entered it you will be asked for a code—this is it.”

帕德莱格·科伦巴，布莱恩读道。爱尔兰最重要的两位圣人——难怪他没猜到。

PADRAIG COLUMBA, Brian read. The two most important saints in Ireland—no wonder he hadn’t guessed it.

“输入密码后，您将进入您的文件。在您确认它们是您的文件后，控制键 F12 将下载到内存中。加载过程中的验证是自动的。您想输入新的密码吗？还是要关闭此帐户？”

“After you enter that you will be in your files. After you have verified that they are yours, control key F12 will download to memory. Verification during loading is automatic. Do you want to enter a new code word—or are you closing this account?”

“我要把它关掉。”

“I’m closing it.”

“尚有余额……”

“There is a balance due of…”

“我来付钱，”贝尼科夫拿出一卷钞票说道。“我需要一张收据。”

“I’ll pay that,” Benicoff said, taking out a roll of bills. “I’ll need a receipt.”

布莱恩输入了号码，然后输入了密码，最后按下回车键。他快速浏览了一遍，然后靠在椅子上叹了口气。

Brian entered the number, then the code, then hit return. He scrolled through quickly, then leaned back in the chair and sighed.

“怎么了？”贝尼科夫担心地问道。“这难道不是我们所期待的、所寻找的吗？”

“What’s wrong?” Benicoff asked, worried. “Isn’t it what we were expecting, what we were looking for?”

布莱恩抬起头并微笑。

Brian looked up and smiled.

“Bingo，”他说，然后把手指按到了 F12 上。

“Bingo,” he said, and stabbed his finger down on F12.

 

 

18
18

2023 年 11 月 21 日

November 21, 2023

 

 

德莫德带路走回大厅，但到达外门时停了下来。

Dermod led the way back down the hall, but stopped when he reached the outside door.

“萨尔达纳先生——我可以问您一个问题吗？”他说。

“Mr. Saldana—could I ask you a question?” he said.

“当然。”

“Of course.”

“你们有没有派其他车辆跟踪我们，监视我们的后方？”

“Did you have other cars tailing us, keeping an eye on our rear?”

“没有。我觉得没必要。”墨西哥侦探皱起眉头。“为什么？你看见了吗？”

“No. I did not think it was needed.” The Mexican detective frowned. “Why? Did you see one?”

“有一段时间我以为是的，但是当我们穿过独立广场时，它就关闭了。”

“I thought I did for a while, but it turned off when we crossed Independencia.”

“那么，另一辆车可能也跟踪到了这条路吗？”

“And another car might have picked up the trail?”

“总是有可能的。”

“Always a possibility.”

现在他们都没有笑容了。布莱恩看着一张张紧张的脸，双手深深地插在口袋里——每只手都紧紧地抓着一张 GRAM。“怎么了？”他问道。

None of them were smiling now. Brian looked from face to strained face, his hands plunged deep into his pockets— with one of the GRAMs clutched tightly in each. “What’s up?” he asked.

“没什么——我们希望如此，”丹尼尔说道，然后用西班牙语对他的同伴快速命令道，他轻松地走出了门并关上了门。

“Nothing—we hope,” Daniel said, then snapped a quick command in Spanish to his companion, who eased out the door and closed it behind him.

“你想呼救吗？”本问道。

“Do you want to shout for help?” Ben asked.

丹尼尔摇摇头，表示不同意。 “这里的制服是旅游警察。我可以找到受过训练的人——但不会很快。如果那里有人，我们等待增援——他们可能会做同样的事情。我们要带你去圣伊西德罗边境——对吗？”

Daniel shook his head no. “The uniforms here are tourist police. I can get trained people—but not quickly. If there is anyone out there and we wait for reinforcements—they might be doing the same thing. We are to take you to the border at San Ysidro—is that correct?”

“这就是计划。”

“That’s the plan.”

“那我说赶紧做。你的 Doe 先生会坐在第二辆车里，你开着车，本。我和我的同事会带路。你觉得怎么样？”

“Then I say do it and do it fast. Your Mr. Doe here will be in the second car with you driving, Ben. My associate and I will lead the way. What do you say?”

“我们走吧，”德莫德说。“不过我会开第二辆车，因为我很了解 TJ 和蒂华纳。如果遇到麻烦，我们不会停下来等你。”

“We go,” Dermod said. “But I’ll be driving the second car, since I know TJ, Tijuana, very well. If there’s trouble we are not stopping for you.”

丹尼尔露出灿烂的笑容。“做其他事都是不专业的。”

Daniel flashed a large toothy grin. “It would be unprofessional to do anything else.”

外面的门开了一英寸——然后停了下来。布莱恩眨了眨眼，意识到这三个人现在都拿着一把健康大小的手枪。指着门。外面传来一声用西班牙语的低语，丹尼尔把枪塞进了腰带里。

The outside door opened an inch—then stopped. Brian blinked and realized that all three of the men were now holding healthy-sized pistols in their hands. Pointed at the door. There was a quick whisper in Spanish from outside and Daniel pushed his gun into his waistband.

“Venga。用英语告诉我们，你看到了什么？”

“Venga. Tell us in English, what did you see?”

“街道上无论哪个方向都什么都没有。”

“Nothing in the street in either direction.”

“我们赶紧出去，”丹尼尔说。“外面可能有东西——也可能什么都没有。我们不想冒险——就当真的有东西。一直跟在我后面三十米。不要靠近——也不要再远了。所有的玻璃都是防弹的。如果你要开枪，就打开窗户。我们走吧。”

“We’re going out fast,” Daniel said. “There may be something out there—or nothing. We don’t take chances—we act like there is something. Stay thirty meters behind me all the way. No closer—or any further back. All the glass is bulletproof. Open the window if you have to fire. Let’s go.”

本现在坐在布莱恩的左边。车门一关上，雷就掏出他的重型左轮手枪放在膝盖上。德莫德启动引擎，倒车并转弯，直到他面对出口，就在另一辆车后面。他闪了一下车灯。第一辆车向前冲去，他们驶出车道，驶上街道。

Ben sat on Brian’s left now. As soon as the door was closed Ray took out his heavy-barreled revolver and held it on his lap. Dermod started the engine and backed and turned until he was facing the exit, just behind the other car. He blinked his lights. The first car jumped forward and they were out of the drive and into the street.

布莱恩正看着领头的车，突然车子突然转向，后窗上出现了一些白点。“趴下！”雷喊道，他用手扶住布莱恩的肩膀，把他痛苦地按倒在地。他们自己的车子突然转向，轮胎发出尖叫声，他们加速绕过拐角。他身后的座位传来两声巨大的撞击声和一声闷响。随后是一连串震耳欲聋的爆炸声，手枪从敞开的窗户射出。他们尖叫着转向相反的方向，德莫德回头大喊。

Brian was looking at the lead car when it suddenly swerved; what appeared to be white dots appeared on the rear window. “Down!” Ray shouted, his hand on Brian’s shoulder pushing him painfully to the floor. Their own car swerved and the tires shrieked as they accelerated around the corner. There were two loud crashing sounds and a thud in the seat behind him. Followed by an ear-destroying series of explosions as the handgun fired through the open window. They shrieked a turn in the opposite direction and Dermod shouted back over his shoulder.

“那边有人遇到麻烦吗？”

“Anyone in trouble back there?”

雷迅速看了一眼另外两个人。“我们没事。另一辆车怎么了？”

Ray glanced quickly at the other two. “We’re okay. What happened to the other car?”

“撞到灯柱了。有撞到什么东西吗？”

“Rammed into a lamp pole. Did you hit anything?”

“可能不会。他只是想低着头。我看到有人探出窗外。他开枪了，是某种步枪。子弹速度很快，可以穿透这种玻璃。”

“Probably not. Just wanted to keep his head down. I saw someone leaning out of a window. Firing a rifle of some kind. High-velocity, the sort of a gun that can punch right through this kind of glass.”

他指着汽车后窗，指着那里整齐钻出的洞。布莱恩惊恐地看着，雷把手指戳进了座椅垫上的一个洞里。他刚才就坐在那里。

He pointed to the rear window of the car, to the neatly drilled hole there. Brian looked on, horrified, as Ray poked his finger into a hole in the seat cushion. Where he had been sitting.

他们飞快地绕过另一个拐角，沿着后面的林荫大道加速行驶。“有尾巴吗？”德莫德喊道。

They rocketed around another corner, accelerated down the boulevard beyond. “Any tails?” Dermod called out.

“没有。我认为他们刚好有足够的时间设下陷阱。我指望着这一点。也接近了。”

“Negative. I think they had just enough time to set up the trap. Counted on that. Close too.”

“那我们就在这里改变路线吧，”德莫德说着，猛踩刹车，驶入一条小巷。在安静的郊区里，他似乎随意地拐弯。

“Then we change the route here,” Dermod said, braking hard and heading into a side street. Turning corners apparently at random through the quiet suburb.

“很抱歉逼迫你，布莱恩——但你知道为什么。”雷把枪放回枪套里，然后把布莱恩拉回座位上。

“Sorry to push you, Brian—but you see why.” Ray’s gun was back in the holster and he gave Brian a tug back into the seat.

“有泄漏，”贝尼科夫冷冷地愤怒地说道。“他们一直在等着，从码头一直跟着我们。”

“There’s been a leak,” Benicoff said with cold anger. “They were waiting, followed us from the marina.”

“我就是这么认为的，”雷表示同意。“有多少人知道我们的回归计划？”

“That’s the way I read it,” Ray agreed. “How many people know about our return plans?”

“我本人。你们两个。还有两名将在边境与我们会合的联邦调查局人员。”

“Myself. You two. And the two FBI men who will be meeting us at the border.”

“那我们就没事了。多久，德莫德？”

“Then we should be all right. How long, Dermod?”

“还有五分钟。我不认为萨尔达娜能逃脱。至少有两把枪朝我们射击。”

“Five minutes more. I don’t think Saldana walked away from that one. Must have been two guns shooting at us at least.”

“我只看到一个。”

“I only saw the one.”

“一个是后座乘客，一个是司机。我这里也有一个小洞。如果我没有在看到领头车撞上时拉动方向盘，它就会正中目标。丹尼尔·萨尔达纳是个好人。”

“One for the backseat passenger, one for the driver. I’ve got a nice little hole up here as well. Would have been centered if I hadn’t pulled the wheel when I saw the lead car hit. That Daniel Saldana was a good man.”

除此之外，再也没有什么可以补充的了。接下来的短暂旅程，他们一直默默地开车。他们一定感到有些惊慌，因为当他们接近边境时，他们遇到了一名骑摩托车的警察，警察挥手示意他们过去，然后在他们通过后对着对讲机说了些什么。

There was nothing that could be added to that. They drove in silence the rest of the brief trip. Some alarm must have gone out because when they came closer to the border they passed a motorcycle policeman who waved them on, then spoke into his radio when they had passed.

又走了几个街区，一辆摩托车护送他们，车灯闪烁，鸣笛高鸣，在等待进入美国的车流中开辟出一条道路。海关大楼后面是一个停车场，围栏后面有一扇敞开的大门，整个区域只有一堵空白的墙。

A few blocks further on they were picked up by a motorcycle escort which, with flashing lights and loud sirens, cleared a path through the traffic waiting to cross into the United States. Behind the customs buildings was a parking lot with an open gate through the fence, the entire area overlooked only by blank walls.

“等在这儿，”雷说道。他和德莫德迅速下了车，拔出武器，慢慢地、小心地朝四面八方张望。“你现在可以穿过停车场了——我们会跟在你后面。”

“Wait here,” Ray said. He and Dermod exited the car quickly, weapons drawn and pointed, looking slowly and carefully in all directions. “You can cross the lot now—and we’ll be right behind you.”

他们是布莱恩和任何可能的威胁之间的屏障。

And they were, bodies between Brian and any possible threat.

“我们的交通工具就在那儿，”贝尼科夫说。停车场里唯一的车辆是一辆布林克斯装甲送货卡车；他们走近时后门打开了，一名穿制服的警卫从车里出来。

“There’s our transportation,” Benicoff said. The only vehicle in the lot was an armored Brinks delivery truck; the back door opened when they approached and a uniformed guard got out.

“你们赶紧离开这里吧，”德莫德说道。

“Get yourselves safely away from here,” Dermod said.

“你应该跟我们一起去，”贝尼科夫说。

“You’re supposed to come with us,” Benicoff said.

“现在你不需要我们了。总统会想要一份完整的报告。你能给我们办公室打电话，告诉他们发生了什么吗？告诉他们通知飞机我们最迟六点到达。”

“You won’t need us now. The President will want a complete report on this. Would you call our office, tell them what has happened? Tell them to let the plane know that we will be there by six at the latest.”

“一切都会完成。”

“It’ll be done.”

两名守护者没有等他们道谢，还没来得及说什么，就上车走了，转身朝装甲车走去。

The two guardians did not wait around for thanks, were in the car and gone before anything more could be said. They turned and walked toward the armored truck.

“下午好，先生们，”警卫说道。“你们都放心吧。”他没有看到车上的弹孔，也不知道发生了什么。贝尼科夫开始解释，但后来意识到这毫无意义。

“Afternoon, gentlemen,” the guard said. “It’s all yours.” He hadn’t seen the bullet holes in the car, did not know anything had happened. Benicoff started to explain, then realized there was no point to it.

“很高兴见到你，”他说。“我们想离开这里。”

“Good to see you,” he said. “We would like to get out of here.”

“现在上路了。” 等他们上车后，警卫关上了车门，然后走到驾驶室，坐在了司机旁边。

“On the way now.” After they had climbed in, the guard closed the door behind them, then went to the cab and took a seat next to the driver.

布莱恩说道：“非常接近了。”

“That was pretty close,” Brian said.

“太近了，”贝尼科夫严肃地说。“肯定是基地泄露了消息，我只能这么想。联邦调查局最好赶紧调查此事。布莱恩，我很抱歉发生这种事。我只能怪我自己。”

“Too close,” Benicoff said grimly. “There must be a leak from the base, that’s all I can think of. The FBI had really better get cracking on this one. I’m sorry this happened, Brian. I can only blame myself.”

“你不应该这么做。你已经尽了一切努力。我对你朋友的遭遇感到遗憾。”

“You shouldn’t. You did everything you could. I’m sorry about your friend back there.”

“他正在做他的工作。他是个非常好的人。我们完成了我们来这里要做的事情。你找到了你要找的东西吗？那些 GRAM 是你工作的副本吗？”

“He was doing his job. A very good man. And we accomplished what we came here to do. You did find what you were looking for? Those GRAMs, are they copies of your work?”

布莱恩慢慢地点点头，他很难忘记刚刚发生的事情。“是的，我很确定。当我翻阅的时候，它们看起来像是，但没有足够的时间完全确定。”

Brian nodded his head slowly, finding it hard to forget what had just happened. “Yes, I’m pretty Sure of it. They looked like it when I flipped through, but there wasn’t enough time to be completely certain.”

本掏出手机。“我能接通这个电话吗？我都数不过来有多少人正咬着指甲等着新闻。”他输入一个号码，等着电子哔哔声响起，电话接通了。“自由女神像，”他说完就挂断了。

Ben pulled out his phone. “Can I call this through? I can’t begin to tell you how many people are chewing their fingernails and waiting for the news.” He tapped in a number and waited for the electronic bleep that told him he was connected. “Statue of Liberty,” he said, and hung up.

“成功的秘诀？”本点点头。“如果没有这些记录，你会说什么？”

“The code for success?” Ben nodded. “What would you have said if the records hadn’t been there?”

“格兰特之墓。计算机现在正在同时拨打 17 个电话来传递好消息。你今天让很多人高兴。我不能说我肯定事情会这样发展——只是非常有希望。”他伸手到座位下面拿出一个包裹。“所以我把这个装上飞机了，以防万一。”

“Grant’s Tomb. The computer is now making seventeen simultaneous calls to pass on the good news. You’re making an awful lot of people happy today. I can’t say that I was positive it would turn out like this—just very hopeful.” He reached under the seat and took out a parcel. “So I had this loaded aboard, just in case.”

里面的黑色塑料盒大约有一个大钱包那么大。本触摸了一下门闩，屏幕弹开，发出白光，照亮了下面的键盘。

The black plastic case inside was about the size of a large wallet. Ben touched the latch and the screen flipped open and glowed whitely, illuminating the keyboard below it.

“一台电脑，”布莱恩钦佩地说道。“我想你会告诉我，这个小玩意儿能处理我所有的笔记、电子表格、数学和图形吧？”

“A computer,” Brian said admiringly. “And I suppose you are going to tell me this little thing will handle all my notes, spreadsheets, maths and graphics?”

“是的。还有全息技术。十五年前你无法想象这种装置能装下多少东西。它还包含一个电话网络收发器和一个卫星定位系统，这样你就可以随时知道它在哪里。这个黑色外壳的整个表面都是非常高效的光伏涂层，可以自行充电——还有……看这个！”

“I am. Holographics too. Fifteen years ago you wouldn’t have imagined how much could be put in a gadget like this. It also contains a phone-net transceiver and a satellite-based location system, so that you can always tell where it is. The entire surface of this black case is an extremely efficient photovoltaic coating for recharging itself—and…watch this!”

贝尼科夫用力拉了一下门闩按钮，门闩随着绳子的拉动发出呜呜的声音。

Benicoff pulled firmly on the latch-button, which came out with a whining sound on a length of cord.

“您也可以用内置发电机手动充电。它可以做任何您想做的事情。在我们离开之前，我确保打开了它的电话网络切断装置，这样就没有人，甚至连 Schorcht 将军都无法追踪到您的位置，或者查看您在做什么。您为什么不插上一个 GRAM 看看那里有什么呢？”

“You can also charge it by hand with this built-in generator. It will do anything you want. And before we left I made sure to turn on its phone-net cutoff so that no one, not even General Schorcht, could track where you are, or take a look at what you are doing. Why don’t you plug in one of the GRAMs and see what you have there?”

布莱恩毫不费力地就查阅了这些记录。很快，他抬头看着本。“毫无疑问。我能认出最早的东西，记得很清楚。这是我和父亲一起开发的 LAMA。然后，看这里，我们可以跳到一些后来的开发工作。这似乎有点熟悉，但我肯定记不太清楚了。所有这些后来的东西，我确信我以前从未见过。最后一条记录是几个月前写的。就在突袭实验室的几天前！”

Brian had no problem at all in getting access to the records. Pretty soon he looked up at Ben. “No doubt about it. The earliest stuff there I can recognize, remember it well. It is the LAMA development I worked on with my father. Then, look here, we can jump ahead to some later developmental work. It seems sort of familiar, but I certainly don’t remember it clearly. And all this later stuff, I feel sure that I’ve never seen it before. This last entry, made some months ago. It is only a few days before the raid on the lab!”

“太棒了。比我们期望的还要好。现在我们走吧。斯纳尔斯布鲁克希望你在今天外出后立即回到医院的病床上。她认为你不会介意。我同意了——特别是如果你房间里有这台电脑的话。而且我还希望有人看管你，这样我就不用担心你了，我会把所有人都交给保安。”

“That’s fantastic. Better than we could have hoped for. Now let’s go. Snaresbrook wants you right back in a hospital bed after this day’s excursion. She didn’t think that you would mind. I agreed—particularly if you had this computer in the room with you. And I also want you under guard where I won’t have to worry about you while I turn over everyone in security.”

“我本来可以过这样的一天。我现在真的很期待回到医院。安静祥和，有机会阅读这些文件。”

“This has been the kind of day I could have lived without. I’m actually looking forward to getting back inside the hospital now. Peace and quiet and the chance to read my way through these files.”

“我没意见。在我开始安全调查后，我会和 Megalobe 商量，然后再回复你。然后我们再决定下一步怎么做。”

“That’s fine by me. After I get the security investigation started I’ll confer with Megalobe, then get back to you. Then we’ll decide what happens next.”

装甲车减速驶离帝国海滩出口的 5 号高速公路。穿过城市后，他们看到海岸巡逻车正在堤道上等着他们。他们加快了速度，护送他们穿过科罗纳多市中心——他们到达时，所有红灯都变成了绿灯——然后穿过一扇敞开的大门再次进入基地。直到回到房间，布莱恩才意识到自己有多累。斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士进来时，他倒在床上。

The armored truck slowed and left Freeway 5 at the Imperial Beach exit. Once they had passed through the city they saw that Shore Patrol vehicles were waiting for them at the causeway. They picked up speed then as they were escorted right through the center of Coronado—with all the red lights turning to green at their approach—and through a waiting open gate onto the base once more. Only when he was back in his room did Brian realize how very tired he was. He dropped onto the bed as Dr. Snaresbrook came in.

“我敢肯定，我的确是过度了——但也没有办法阻止。”她把一个测距仪戴在布莱恩的手腕上，看着读数点了点头。“没有生命危险。吃点东西，休息一下。不，”布莱恩伸手去拿电脑时，她补充道。“先上床睡觉。吃点东西。然后我们再考虑工作。”

“Overdid it, I am sure—but there was no way of preventing it.” She slapped a telemeter onto Brian’s wrist and nodded at the readout. “Nothing life-threatening. Get some food and rest. No,” she added when Brian reached for the computer. “Get into bed first. Eat something. Then we’ll think about work.”

布莱恩一定是吃着巧克力布丁打瞌睡了。他突然惊醒，发现天色已经快黑了。床头柜上空无一物，他突然感到一阵恐惧，然后他感觉到枕头下有凸起，于是拿出了电脑和 GRAM。他可能睡着了——但在此之前他已经把所有东西都收拾好了。门开了，护士朝里面看了一眼。

Brian must have dozed off over the chocolate pudding. He awoke with a start and saw that it was almost dark. The bedside table was empty and he had a quick burst of fear before he felt the bumps under his pillow and pulled out the computer and the GRAMs. He may have fallen asleep—but not before stowing everything away. The door opened and the nurse looked in.

“你肯定醒着，”她说。“你睡着的时候脉搏不会跳得那么快。我能给你拿点什么吗？”

“You just had to be awake,” she said. “You don’t get a pulse jump like that in your sleep. Can I get you anything?”

“我很好，谢谢。等一下，如果你不介意的话，你可以抬起床头。”

“I’m doing fine, thanks. Wait, you can lift the head of the bed, if you don’t mind.”

他浏览文件直到他们送来晚餐。他吃东西时没有注意自己吃了什么，几乎没有意识到托盘被拿走了。当夜班护士过来并指着时间时，他吓了一跳。

He read through the files until they brought in his dinner. Ate without noticing what he ate, was barely aware that the tray was removed. Was startled when the night nurse came and pointed to the time.

“斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士下达了明确命令。最迟十一点关灯——不接受任何借口。”

“Firm orders from Dr. Snaresbrook. Lights out at eleven at the latest—no excuses accepted.”

他没有抗议，因为他意识到自己已经很累了。把电脑放在枕头下可能很愚蠢——但它确实缓解了紧张情绪。

He didn’t protest, realizing how tired he had become. It was probably foolish to put the computer under his pillow— but it drained away the tension.

早上醒来时，贝尼科夫就在那里，脸色严肃。

Benicoff was there when he woke up in the morning, his face grim and set.

“枪击事件有什么消息吗？”布莱恩问道。

“What’s the news about the shooting?” Brian asked.

“糟糕。两名侦探都死了。没有发现凶手的踪迹。这是我们逃脱的一次。”

“Bad. Both detectives are dead. No sign of the killers. This is one that got away from us.”

“我很抱歉，本。我知道那位侦探是你的朋友。”

“I’m sorry about this, Ben. I know the one detective was a friend of yours.”

“他完成了他的工作。现在——回去工作吧。有什么消息告诉我吗？”他问道。假装很放松，但紧张得像上紧发条的弹簧。

“He did his job. Now—back to work. Got any news for me?” he asked. Pretending to be relaxed; tight as a wound-up spring.

“有好有坏。不过，本，别脸色这么苍白！我觉得住院是患冠心病的好地方，但你还是不去医院比较好。我看过文件了，跳过了很多，但没错过什么重要的东西。”

“Some good—some troublesome. But don’t get so pale, Ben! I suppose that being in the hospital is a good place to have a coronary, but you’re still better off without one. I’ve been through the files, skipping a lot, but not missing anything important.”

“那么，为了我的心脏着想，我先听一个好消息。”

“For my heart’s sake, then—the good news first.”

“凭借我目前所拥有的，我百分之九十九的确定我可以设计出一个可以工作的人工智能。我想这就是你想听到的。”

“With what I have here I am ninety-nine percent sure I can design an AI that will work. I guess that’s what you wanted to hear.”

“确实。现在麻烦的是这个。”

“Definitely. Now the troublesome part.”

“我记忆中的不是计划或设计。有一些已经制定的具体细节，以及详细的查询和注释。但大多数情况下，这些都是我在 AI 道路上迈出的步骤，而不是道路本身。”

“What I have in memory is not plans or designs. There are specific bits and pieces that have been worked out, and there are detailed queries and notes. But for the most part these are my steps along the path to AI—not the path itself.”

“你能做到吗？”

“Can you do it?”

“我相信我能。每个问题都得到解决的保证，以及可能的解决方案的说明，应该能让我走上正确的道路。死胡同都标记得很清楚。我能做到，本，我相信我能做到。那么接下来呢？”

“I’m sure I can. The assurance that each problem was solved, along with the notes of possible solutions, should keep me on the right track. The dead ends are pretty carefully marked out. I can do it, Ben, I’m sure that I can. So what comes next?”

“我们和斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生核实一下。看看你什么时候才能完全康复，出院。”

“We check with Dr. Snaresbrook. See when you will be fit enough to be completely discharged from this hospital.”

“然后会发生什么？我们已经掌握了一些相当可怕的证据，表明那些恶棍仍在追捕我。”

“What happens then? We’ve had some pretty gruesome evidence that the nasties are still gunning for me.”

贝尼科夫站起来，开始在房间里踱步。“我们现在可以肯定，他们还在那里等着。他们知道你经历了之前的两次袭击——否则他们就不会再次尝试。我们生活在一个自由的社会，秘密很难保守。如果他们真的想这么做，他们会找到你的下落，不管你去哪里。所以我们必须确保无论你在哪里，无论你在哪里工作，你都会尽可能地难以接近。相信我，我们为这件事经过了深思熟虑。”

Benicoff stood and began to pace the length of the room. “We know now for sure that they are still waiting out there. They know that you lived through the two earlier attacks—or they would not have tried again. We live in a free society and secrets are hard to keep. If they really want to work at it, they are going to find your whereabouts, no matter where you go. So we must see to it that wherever you are, wherever you are working, you will be as inaccessible as possible. There has been a lot of hard thought about this one, believe me.”

“在诺克斯堡的金条堆里给我建一个实验室？”

“Build me a laboratory in Fort Knox, down among the gold bars?”

“别笑——这是真正考虑过的可能性之一。在这一切发生之前，你只是一个在研究项目上工作的人。我检查了 Megalobe 的记录，不管你信不信，你的工作几乎没有商业或开发兴趣。现在一切都变了。某个或某些不知名的政党不遗余力地想要得到你的发明，这一事实引起了每个政府部门的注意。每个人都想参与其中，他们都在匆忙制定计划，研究如何在他们的部门中使用人工智能。这让 Megalobe 非常高兴——也应该让你高兴。所有的研究资金都在那里等着你去争取。所以，赶紧去争取吧。”

“Don’t laugh—that was one of the possibilities that was actually considered. Before all this happened you were just one more guy working away on a research project. I checked the records at Megalobe and believe it or not there was little or no commercial or development interest in your work. All that is changed now. The fact that party or parties unknown went to all that trouble to lay their paws on your invention has drawn the attention of every government department. Everyone wants to get into the act and they are all rushing through planning programs on how they can use AI in their departments. Which cheers Megalobe very much— and should cheer you as well. All the research funds are there for the grabbing. So grab.”

“我非常想这么做。但是这些抓捕行动将在哪里进行呢？”

“I would dearly like to. But where will all this grabbing take place?”

贝尼科夫搓着双手，邪恶地笑着。“答应我告诉你的时候别笑。等你准备好了，你就回奥科蒂洛威尔斯的旧 Megalobe 实验室去吧。”

Benicoff rubbed his hands together and smiled wickedly. “Promise not to laugh when I tell you. As soon as you are up to it you are going back to your old Megalobe lab in Ocotillo Wells.”

“经历了那里发生的一切之后，我想那是我最不应该去的地方了！”

“After what happened there I should think it would be the last place to go!”

“不会，谷仓门锁上的时候不会。除了一件小事外，那里的安保是一流的。”

“Not really, not when it is barn-door-locking time. The security there was top class except for one small thing.”

“Quis custodiet ipsos custodies？”

“Quis custodiet ipsos custodies?”

“完全正确。谁来监督守卫？一个或多个守卫背叛了他们的信任。袭击和抢劫是精心策划的内部行动。这种事不会再发生了。我们有一些新的守卫，都是专业人士。”

“Exactly right. Who is going to watch the watchmen? One or more of the watchmen betrayed their trust. The attack and robbery was a well-planned inside job. That won’t happen again. We’ve got some new watchmen, professionals.”

“别保守秘密！”

“Don’t keep it a secret!”

“就是美国陆军。他们拥有 Megalobe 六分之一的股份，他们对发生的事情很不满意。海军陆战队也自愿承担这项工作。在保护了你之后，他们觉得他们在这次行动中也占有一席之地。甚至有人说要让陆军和海军陆战队轮流值班，看看谁做得更好——你可以想象，这个计划很快就被放弃了。现在，停车场正在搭建营房。但这不是必需的，因为将来车辆的通行将非常有限。我认为你这次可以完成你的工作。”

“The United States Army, that’s who. They have a one-sixth share in Megalobe and they are not pleased at what happened. The Marines also volunteered for the job. Felt they had a stake in the operation after guarding you here. There was even some talk of letting the Army and the Marines alternate months and see who did the better job— that plan was quickly abandoned, as you might imagine. Right now barracks are being put up in the parking lots. Which won’t be needed, since there will be very limited access for vehicles in the future. I think that you will be able to finish your work this time.”

“我不喜欢这样。持续不断的威胁让人难以集中注意力。但我想不出更好的办法了。我想你还在寻找这些罪犯吧？”

“I don’t like it. The constant threat doesn’t make for easy concentration. But I can’t think of anything better. I imagine you are still looking for these criminals?”

“昨天之后，这个案件又重新成为焦点。”

“After yesterday the case is back on the front burner.”

布莱恩想了想，然后把手伸到枕头下，拿出了 GRAM 的副本。“给，你最好留着它。这是我所有笔记的备份。以防万一。”

Brian thought about this, then reached under his pillow and took out the duplicate GRAM. “Here, you better hold on to this. It’s the backup of all my notes. Just in case.”

“我永远都不需要它。”本试图让自己听起来真诚一些，但没能做到。“但就像你说的——以防万一。”

“I’ll never need it.” Ben tried to sound sincere, didn’t quite make it. “But as you say—just in case.”

19
19

2024 年 1 月 28 日

January 28, 2024

 

 

“今天是知识库日，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士说，检查了控制器以确保布莱恩的大脑和机器之间的连接已经完成。“我建议我们从最新版的大英百科全书开始吧？第十九版真是太棒了。几乎所有的插图都包含动画，所有的文本都是超文本。”

“Today is knowledge base day,” Dr. Snaresbrook said, checking the controls to be sure that the connection between Brian’s brain and the machine was complete. “Might I suggest that we begin with the latest edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica? The nineteenth is really a doozy. Almost all the illustrations involve animations and all the text is hypertext.”

“对我来说太笼统了。我需要具体信息。”他打开数据库菜单，指着屏幕。“这就是我所说的东西。技术手册。我想要这份清单上的所有内容，从材料科学到地质学和天体物理学。确凿的事实。如果我的植入物有内存的话？”

“Too general for me. I want specifics.” He punched up a data-base menu and pointed to the screen. “Here is the sort of thing I mean. Technical handbooks. I want everything on this list from material science to geology and astrophysics. Hard facts. That is if my implant has the RAM for it?”

“足够了。只要下载你想让我用到的就行。”

“More than enough. Just download the ones you want me to work with.”

过了好久，布莱恩在舒适的椅子上几乎打瞌睡了。斯纳尔斯布鲁克说话时，他闭上了眼睛，开始说话。

It took a long time and Brian almost dozed off in the comfortable chair. Did close his eyes and started when Snaresbrook spoke.

“今天就够了，”她说。

“More than enough for today,” she said.

“既然你这么说，那我们现在可以看看事情进展了吗？”

“If you say so. Can we see now things went?”

“你是说运行基准测试？为什么不呢？等一下，我会将其中一篇文本随机加载到我的机器中，然后我会给它一个随机页码。这里的一切看起来都是医学的——”

“Run a benchmark, you mean? Why not? Wait a moment while I load one of the texts at random into my machine, then I’ll hit it with a random page number. Everything here looks medical—”

“多兰医学词典，第四十五版。”

“Dorland’s Medical Dictionary, forty-fifth edition.”

“就是这个。你听说过 parendomyces 吗？”

“That’s it. Have you ever heard of parendomyces?”

“那是一种酵母状真菌属，其中一些是从人类的各种病变中分离出来的。”

“That’s a genus of yeastlike fungi species of which some have been isolated from various lesions of man.”

“那 kikekunemalo 呢？”

“And kikekunemalo?”

“很简单。它是一种树脂，像柯巴脂一样。”

“An easy one. It’s a resin, like copal.”

“布莱恩，你拥有它。我们下载的所有内容都在那里。你可以随意使用它。”

“You have it, Brian. Everything we downloaded, it’s all there. And you can tap into it at will.”

“就好像它们是真实的记忆一样。”

“Just as if they were real memories.”

“对你来说，这些都是真实的记忆。只是以不同的方式归档了。现在——很抱歉，我们得在这里停下来了。我有一个必须赴约的事。”

“They are real memories as far as you are concerned. Just filed away in a different manner. Now—I’m sorry, but we’ll have to break off here. I have an appointment that I must keep.”

当他回到房间时，发现有贝尼科夫正在给布莱恩留言，他立即拨通了电话。

When he got back to his room there was a message from Benicoff waiting for Brian; he dialed the number at once.

“我接到你的电话了……”

“I got your call…”

“有时间和我谈谈吗，布莱恩？”

“Got a moment to speak with me, Brian?”

“当然。你想上我的房间吗？”

“Of course. You want to come up to my room?”

“我更喜欢十楼的空中花园。”

“I would prefer the tenth-floor hanging garden.”

“我没意见。我现在就走。”

“Fine by me. I’m on my way now.”

布莱恩最先到达，当时他刚喝了一半啤酒，一杯皮尔森欧克啤酒，本到达时，他重重地摔倒在椅子上。

Brian arrived first, was halfway through his beer, a Pilsner Urquell, when Ben arrived, dropped heavily into a chair.

“你看上去很累，”布莱恩说。“想要这个吗？”

“You look beat,” Brian said. “Want one of these?”

“谢谢，不过我改日再来。现在说新闻。你会很高兴听到第八十二空降师的一个连队已经搬进 Megalobe 兵营。他们的指挥官伍德少校是一名战斗老兵，他非常不赞成科研人员被枪杀。他不希望你去那里，直到他安排好安全措施和值班表——并进行了一些测试。在那之后，行动的选择权就在你手中。当然还有斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士。”

“Thanks, but I’ll take a rain check. Now the news. You’ll be pleased to hear that a company of the Eighty-second Airborne has moved into the Megalobe barracks. Their commanding officer, Major Wood, is a combat veteran who takes a very dim view of research scientists being shot. He doesn’t want you to get there until he has his security arrangements and rosters set—and has run a few tests. After that the choice of a move is yours. And Dr. Snaresbrook’s of course.”

“我要求的东西都订好了吗？”

“Has everything been ordered that I asked for?”

“已订购、发货并已送达实验室。这引出了下一个项目。您的助手。”

“Ordered and shipped and in the lab. Which leads us to the next item. Your assistant.”

“我从来没吃过这种东西。”

“I’ve never had one.”

“在这个美丽新世界里，你会的。让你的工作变得更容易。”

“In this brave new world you will. Make your work that much easier.”

布莱恩喝完啤酒，放下啤酒，仔细看着本毫无表情的脸。

Brian finished his beer and put it down, looking closely at Ben’s expressionless face.

“我知道那个眼神。这意味着还有更多——但我应该能够自己弄清楚。而且我可以。他们已经三次试图杀死我。我可能活不过第四次了。所以如果至少有一个人知道人工智能研究的进展，每个人都会更高兴。”

“I know that look. It means that there is more—but I should be able to figure it out for myself. And I can. They have made three attempts to kill me. I might not live through the fourth. So everyone would be very much happier if there was at least one other person who knew what was going on with the AI research.”

“安全——你已经猜到了。接下来最棘手的部分是找到一个可以完成工作但又值得信任的人。工业间谍现在是大多数大学的研究生课程，也是一个主要的增长行业。像人工智能这样的东西可能非常诱人——正如你不幸发现的那样。我已经将我的候选名单缩小到更短的名单——两个。我明天早上要去见一个非常有前途的领头人，他是 MTT 的一名研究生。但在见到他之前，我不会知道。所以让我们讨论另一种可能性。你对军队有什么看法？”

“Security—you figured it out. The tricky part mat comes next is getting someone who can do the work—but who can be trusted as well. Industrial espionage is a graduate course in most universities now, a major growth industry as well. Something like AI can be very tempting—as you have unhappily found out. I have narrowed my short list down to an even shorter list—two. I am off in the morning for a meet with a very promising lead, a graduate student at MTT. But until I get to see him I won’t know. So let us run with the other possibility. How do you feel about the military?”

“除了我们的朋友将军，我对此事没有太多想法。海军和海军陆战队在这里的表现确实不错。我认为陆军在 Megalobe 也会做得很好。你为什么这么问？”

“Outside of our friend the General I don’t have much feeling one way or the other. Certainly the Navy and the Marines have done a good job here. And I assume the Army will do the same at Megalobe. Why do you ask?”

“因为我找到了一位空军上尉卡恩，他在科罗拉多州博尔德学院的专家项目部门担任一项非常重要的工作。第二代也门绿人——这是对新手、移民的俚语。卡恩正在研究飞机控制项目。有兴趣吗？”

“Because I’ve tracked down a Captain Kahn who is in the Air Force and has a very responsible job in the Expert Program section at the academy in Boulder, Colorado. Second-generation Yemenite greenie—slang term for a greenhorn, an immigrant. Kahn is working on programs for aircraft control. Interested?”

“为什么不呢？联系博尔德然后……”

“Why not? Contact Boulder and…”

本摇摇头。“没必要。希望你会同意，所以我让船长飞过来了。”

Ben shook his head. “No need. In the hopes you would say yes I had the Captain flown here.”

“好吧，把他推过来，让我们希望如此。”

“Well wheel him in and let’s hope.”

本微笑着拨打了电话。军官肯定在附近等候，因为海军陆战队警卫一会儿就出现了。

Ben smiled and made the call. The officer must have been waiting close by because the marine guard appeared a moment later.

“先生，您是来客。”

“Your visitor, sir.”

本站了起来；布莱恩转过身，看到了原因。他也站了起来。

Ben climbed to his feet; Brian turned and saw why. He stood as well.

“卡恩队长，我是布莱恩·德莱尼。”

“Captain Kahn, this is Brian Delaney.”

“很高兴见到你，先生，”她说。她的手很凉，握得很紧。快速握了一下，然后就回到了身边。她身材结实，魅力十足，黑发黑皮肤。而且非常严肃。她站得笔直，沉默不语，面无笑容——就像布莱恩一样。贝尼科夫意识到这次采访进展不顺利。

“Very pleased to meet you, sir,” she said. Her hand was cool, her grip good. One quick shake and back to her side. She was a firmly built and attractive woman, dark-haired and dark-skinned. And very serious. She stood straight, silent, her face set and unsmiling—as was Brian’s. Benicoff realized that the interview was not going that well.

“请坐，船长，”他拉过一把椅子说道。“我可以给你拿点喝的吗？”

“Please sit down, Captain,” he said, pulling over a chair. “Can I get you something to drink?”

“不用了，谢谢。”

“No, thank you.”

“我要喝啤酒。你也想喝吗，布莱恩？”他迅速摇了摇头，回答道“不”。他跌坐在自己的椅子上。“那么，船长——这不可能是你的名字吧？”

“I’m going to have a beer. You too, Brian?” A quick shake of the head no was his only answer. He dropped into his own chair. “Well then, Captain—that can’t be your first name?”

“我叫雪莉，先生。至少大多数人都这么叫。舒拉米德是我希伯来语名字，这个名字不太好发音。”

“It is Shelly, sir. At least that is the name most people use. Shulamid is my name in Hebrew, which is not that easy to pronounce.”

“那么——雪莉——谢谢你来。恐怕我没有告诉你太多关于这项工作的事情，因为安全措施很严。但现在你来了，我知道布莱恩能解释得更清楚。布莱恩？”

“Well then—Shelly—thanks for coming. I’m afraid I didn’t tell you much about the work, since security is tight. But now that you are here I know that Brian will be able to explain much better. Brian?”

记忆开始干扰他。贝尼科夫应该告诉他船长是女性。这并不是什么坏事。或者说是坏事？对金的记忆太过新鲜。但现在对他来说，只有部分记忆是新鲜的。对于成年的布莱恩来说，那些不幸的事件早已过去，是他过去的一部分，最好忘记。他意识到沉默已经持续了很长时间，他们都在看着他。

Memories were getting in the way. Benicoff should have told him that the Captain was female. Not that this was bad. Or was it? Memories of Kim were too recent. But recent only to parts of him now. To the adult Brian those unfortunate events were long gone, part of his past, best forgotten. He realized that the silence had lengthened and that they were both looking at him.

“对不起。我有点走神了——有点走神了。我想我要喝杯啤酒，本，和你一起喝吧。”

“I’m sorry. My mind was wandering—it does that a bit. I think I will have a beer, Ben, join you.”

本点菜的时候，布莱恩试着理清思绪和情绪。船长不是金——她现在可能又胖又老，结婚了，还有五个孩子。忘了她吧。他笑着想到这个主意，深吸了一口气。重新开始，忘掉过去。他转向雪莉。

While Ben was ordering, Brian tried to get his thoughts and emotions straightened out. The Captain was not Kim— who by this time was probably fat and old and married and five kids. Forget her. He smiled at the idea and took a deep breath. Start over, forget the past. He turned to Shelly.

“我不知道该从哪里开始——只能告诉你，我需要一些帮助来完成我即将启动的一个研究项目。你能告诉我你现在在做什么吗，你的工作是什么？”

“I’m not sure where to begin—except to tell you that I could use some help on a research project that I will be launching soon. Could you tell me what you are doing now, about your work?”

“我不能详细告诉你，因为我做的每件事都是机密。但整个计划是公开的，很容易解释。它的起源是因为现代军用飞机的速度太快，超出了飞行员的反应能力，仪表也太复杂了。如果飞行员必须亲自监控所有电子系统，那么就真的没有时间驾驶飞机了。为了协助飞行员，专家系统一直在开发和改进，以承担尽可能多的职责。这是一项非常有趣的工作。”她的声音低沉，略带嘶哑，说话时充满自信，她坐在椅子的前缘，背挺直，双手紧握在膝盖上。布莱恩感到有点不确定；她肯定没有。这与他想象中的助手完全不同。

“I can’t tell you about it in detail because everything that I do is classified. But the overall program is public knowledge and easy enough to explain. It was originated because modem military planes are entirely too fast for the pilot’s reflexes, the instrumentation too complex as well. If a pilot had to personally monitor all of the electronic systems, there would really be no time left to fly the plane. In order to assist the pilot, Expert Systems are always being developed and improved that assume as many as possible of his responsibilities. It is very interesting work.” Her voice was low-pitched and ever so slightly hoarse and she spoke with self-assurance, sitting straight-backed on the front edge of the chair, her hands clasped in her lap. Brian was the one who felt a little unsure; she certainly wasn’t. Not exactly what he had imagined he would get as an assistant.

他问道：“你曾经与人工智能合作过吗？”

“Have you ever worked with artificial intelligence?” he asked.

“不是。除非你认为专家系统开发是人工智能的一部分。但我会跟上发展步伐，因为其中一些适用于我自己的工作。”

“Not really. Unless you consider that Expert System development is a part of AI. But I keep up with the developments since some of it is applicable to my own work.”

“这都是好事。我宁愿让你学习，而不是忘记。有人告诉你要做什么工作吗？”

“That’s all for the good. I would rather have you learn than unlearn. Have you been told what the work is to be?”

“没有。只是说这很重要，与人工智能有关。贝尼科夫先生还向我解释了其中涉及的暴力工业间谍活动。他主要担心的是我应该知道我实际参与了什么。他让我读了一份关于未破案件的报告。他还说从那时起，你的生命还遭受了其他袭击。如果我参与这个项目，我自己可能也会有危险。他想确保我在得到这份工作之前就了解这一切。”

“No. Only that it is important and relates to AI. Mr. Benicoff also explained to me about the violent industrial espionage that has been involved. His main concern was that I should know what I was getting involved with physically. He let me read a copy of his report on the unsolved crime. He also said there had been other attacks on your life since that time. If I work on the project I might be at risk myself. He wanted to be sure I knew all about this before I was even offered the job.”

“我很高兴他这么做。因为确实有可能造成人身伤害。”

“I’m glad he did that. Because there is a real chance that there might be physical danger.”

她第一次改变了严肃的表情，露出了笑容。“空军军官随时准备战斗。我出生时，以色列还是一个武装营地。我的父母和其他人一样，都在军队中战斗。我六岁时，全家移民到美国，所以我很幸运能在一个和平的国家长大。但我仍然喜欢认为，他们的一些力量和生存能力传给了我。”

For the first time there was a change in her stern expression as she smiled. “An Air Force officer is assumed to be ready for combat at any time. When I was born Israel was still an armed camp. My father and mother, like everyone else, fought in the Army. When I was six years old my family emigrated to America so I was lucky to grow up in a country at peace. But I still like to think that some of their strength and ability to survive was passed on to me.”

“我确定是的，”布莱恩几乎笑着回答。他开始喜欢雪莉，喜欢她自信的气质。但他不确定自己是否真的想和一个女人一起工作——无论她有多有资格。对金的回忆仍然妨碍着他。但如果雪莉足够优秀，可以为空军做专家系统工作，她可能有资格帮助他。而且她从未做过人工智能研究这一事实是一项优势。一些科学家在一段时间后就变得视野狭窄，并认为他们解决问题的方法是唯一的方法——即使他们被证明是错误的。他只需要试着忘记她的性别；他转向本问了一个问题。

“I’m sure it was,” Brian said, almost smiling in return. He was beginning to like Shelly, liked her air of self-assurance. But he was not sure that he really wanted to work with a woman—no matter how qualified she was. Memories of Kim still got in the way. But if Shelly was good enough to do Expert System work for the Air Force she might be qualified enough to help him. And the fact that she had never done AI research was an asset. Some scientists developed tunnel vision after a while and believed that their approach to the problem was the only one—even after they were proven wrong. He would just have to try to forget her sex; he turned to Ben with a question.

“有什么理由我不能告诉雪莉我正在做的事情？在她做出决定之前，她应该知道自己将参与哪些工作。”

“Is there any reason I can’t give Shelly some information about what I’m doing? She deserves to know what she will be involved in before she makes her mind up.”

“船长拥有绝对最高的安全权限，”本说。“我会承担责任。你可以告诉她你认为她需要知道的一切。”

“The Captain has an absolutely top security clearance,” Ben said. “I’ll take the responsibility. You can tell her whatever you think she needs to know.”

“那好吧。雪莉，我正在开发一种人工智能。不是我们现在所说的人工智能。我指的是真正完整、高效、独立、清晰、真正有效的人工智能。”

“Okay then. Shelly, I am in the process of developing an artificial intelligence. Not the sort of program that we call AI now. I mean a really complete, efficient, freestanding and articulate artificial intelligence that really works.”

“但是，如果你不知道智能到底是什么，你怎么能制造出智能机器呢？”

“But how can you make an intelligent machine until you know precisely what intelligence is?”

“通过制作一个可以通过图灵测试的程序。我相信你知道它是如何工作的。你把一个人放在一个终端上，与另一个终端上的人交谈，可以提出无数的问题——并回答——以说服一端的人相信另一端还有另一个人。正如你所知，人工智能的历史充满了未能通过这项测试的程序。”

“By making one that can pass the Turing Test. I’m sure that you know how it works. You put a human being at one terminal, talking to a human being on another terminal, and there are numberless questions that can be asked—and answered—to convince the human at one end that there is another human at the other terminal. And as you know the history of AI is filled with programs that failed this test.”

“但这只是一种让别人相信机器是人的方法。它仍然没有给我们智能的定义。”

“But that’s only a trick to convince someone that the machine is a person. It still doesn’t give us a definition of intelligence.”

“确实如此，但这正是图灵的观点。真的没有必要定义，事实上，我们真的不想要定义。你无法定义事物，只能定义词语。如果我们认为某人擅长解决问题，或学习新技能，或做其他人做的事情，我们倾向于称其为聪明。毕竟，我们认为其他人聪明的唯一原因是他们在智力上表现得像人类。”

“True enough, but that was precisely Turing’s point. There’s really no need to have a definition and, in fact, we really don’t want one. You can’t define things, but only words. We tend to call someone intelligent if we think that they’re good at solving problems, or learning new skills, or doing what other people do. After all, the only reason we consider other people to be intelligent is that they behave intellectually like human beings.”

“但是，难道某些生物不可能既有智慧，又能与人类思维方式完全不同吗？比如海豚或大象？”

“But couldn’t something be intelligent and yet think completely different from a person? Like maybe a porpoise or an elephant?”

“当然——如果你愿意，你可以称它们为智能。但对我来说，智能这个词只是用来描述我希望自己做得更好的所有事情——以及我希望我们未来的人工智能能够做到的一切。问题是我还不知道那些到底是什么。使用这些终端的原因很简单，只要它能回答所有问题，给出无法从其他人的答案中分辨出来的答案，它的外观并不重要。很抱歉我要说教，告诉你你已经知道的东西。但我正在开发一种人工智能来通过这项测试。所以我的问题是——你愿意帮忙吗？”

“Certainly—and you can call them intelligent if you want to. But for me, the word intelligence is just a handle to describe all the things I wish I were better at—and everything I’d like our future AI to do. The trouble is that I don’t know just what those are yet. The reason for using those terminals is simply that it shouldn’t matter what the thing looks like, so long as it responds to all questions asked, with answers that cannot be told from those of another person. Sorry about the lecture, for telling you what you already know. But I am developing an AI to pass that test. So my question is—would you like to help?”

自从他们谈话以来，这是雪莉第一次失去镇静，她更像是一个女人而不是军官。布莱恩说话时，她的眼睛睁大了，她用指尖触摸着下巴，难以置信地微微摇了摇头。“我听到了你所说的话——虽然这听起来完全不可能——而且令人难以置信。你是说你正在研究一台我认为是智能的机器吗？”

For the first time since they had been talking Shelly lost her composure, was more woman than military officer. Her eyes had widened while Brian spoke and she touched her fingertips to her chin, shaking her head slightly with disbelief. “I hear what you are saying—though it sounds both completely impossible—and incredibly exciting. Do you mean to say that you are working on a machine that I would recognize as intelligent?”

“是的，”本坚定地说。“我可以向你保证，真正的人工智能已经设计出来了，而且它将会诞生。”

“He is,” Ben said firmly. “I can assure you that a real AI has been designed and that it will be built.”

“如果是这样，那我确实想参与其中！这是一个如此重大而重要的发展，我心中毫无疑问。”她皱起眉头。“还有很多人申请这个职位吗？”

“If that is the case, then I do want to be part of it! This is such a momentous and important development that there is no question in my mind.” She frowned. “Are there many others applying for the post?”

“我明天要见其他人，”本说。“这就是全部名单了。”

“I’m seeing someone else tomorrow,” Ben said. “That’s the entire list.”

“我相信我能暂时控制住自己的不耐烦。但如果你愿意让我帮忙，我现在可以做些事情来帮你。”

“I am sure that I can control my impatience for a while. But if you will let me help, there is something I can do to be of assistance right now.”

“我们暂时还不能进入实验室，”布莱恩说道。

“We won’t be able to get into the lab for some time yet,” Brian said.

“我不是这个意思。我说的是整体安全问题。”她转向本。“你给我看的那份盗窃报告完整吗？”

“That’s not what I mean. I’m talking about the overall security matter.” She turned to Ben. “That report you showed me of the theft—is it complete?”

“我删除了所有与人工智能相关的内容。除此之外，是的，它是完整的。”

“I took out all the references to artificial intelligence. Other than that, yes, it’s complete.”

“我不是这个意思。我指的是犯罪调查。你知道是谁负责的吗？”

“I don’t mean that. I’m referring to the investigation of the crime. Do you know who was in charge of it?”

“我当然相信。我保证报告的这一部分是完整的。”

“I certainly do. Me. I can guarantee that that part of the report is complete.”

“自从盗窃和布莱恩被枪杀以来，还发生过另外两起威胁他生命的事件吗？”

“And since the theft and Brian’s being shot—there have been two other threats on his life?”

“没错。”

“That is correct.”

“那么我认为破案应该是首要任务。”

“Then it seems to me that solving the crime should take top priority.”

贝尼科夫不知道是该笑还是该觉得受辱。“你知道我是调查负责人吗？我已经全职工作了几个月了？”

Benicoff did not know whether to laugh—or be insulted. “You do realize that I am in charge of the investigation? That I have been working on it full-time for some months?”

“先生，请不要误会！我并没有贬低您的努力——只是想提供帮助。”

“Sir, please don’t misunderstand! I was not denigrating your efforts—just offering to help.”

“那你该怎么做呢？”

“And how will you do that?”

“通过编写一个专家程序，心中只有一个目标：破获这起犯罪事件。”

“By writing an Expert Program with only one aim in mind. To solve this crime.”

贝尼科夫跌坐在椅子上，默默地揉了揉下巴，然后高兴地点点头。“队长，谢谢您。我以前在这件事上真是太愚蠢了。我以后也不打算再这样了。您多久能调到这里来？”

Benicoff dropped back into his chair and rubbed his jaw in silence for a moment—then nodded happily. “Captain—my thanks. I have been very, very dumb about this. I don’t intend to be in the future. How soon can you transfer here?”

“我是团队的一员。他们非常优秀，我知道他们没有我也能继续工作。我可能一两天就到这里。我首先要记录下我正在从事的开发工作，这样他们才能得到这些意见。然后，只要他们将来能联系到我，我几乎可以立即调到这里。如果你愿意的话，这周末就可以。那里的工作很重要——但没有这里重要。如果你愿意的话，我想为你开发这个专家程序。并随时准备进一步研究人工智能。这样可以吗？”

“I’m part of a team. They are very good and I know that they’ll be able to carry on without me. I could be here in a day or two. I’ll first have to make some notes of developments that I am working on so they’ll have that input. Then, as long as they can contact me in the future, I could transfer here almost immediately. The end of this week if you want. The work there is important—but not as important as this. If you would let me I would like to develop this Expert Program for you. And keep myself available for further work on the AI. Is that agreeable?”

“太好了。我会整理好所有的材料，这样你就可以一次找到它们。我会为自己没有想到这一点而懊悔不已。像这样的调查主要是愚蠢、无聊的整理事实和寻找无尽的线索。这是计算机的工作——不是人类的工作。”

“Perfect. I’ll organize all the material so you can access it at once. And I’m going to kick myself around the block for not thinking of it myself. An investigation like this one is mostly a dumb, boring, sorting of facts and running down endless leads. Which is a job for a computer—not for a human being.”

“我完全同意。我会尽快回来。再次感谢您邀请我。”

“I couldn’t agree more. I’ll be back as soon as I can. And thank you again for asking me.”

当她离开时，他们起立握手，目送她离开——海军陆战队警卫也只用眼睛跟随着她。

They stood when she did, shook hands, watched her leave—as did the marine guard who allowed only his eyes to follow her.

“她对解决 Megalobe 犯罪的程序的看法百分之百正确，”Brian 说道。“如果我们能找回我的第一个人工智能，我的工作就会轻松很多。”

“She is one hundred percent right about that program to solve the Megalobe crime,” Brian said. “If we can get my first AI back it will make my job an awful lot easier.”

“如果你还活着，你的工作就会容易得多。我想阻止袭击——并破案。”

“Your job will be a lot easier if you stay alive. I want to stop the attacks—and solve the case.”

“既然你这么说——那我就同意了。”

“When you put it that way—I agree.”

 

 

 

 

20
20

2024 年 2 月 15 日
February 15, 2024

 

 

贝尼科夫看了看手表。“好消息是，从今天起，您就可以出院了。斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生说，您身体状况非常好。您准备好搬家了吗？”

Benicoff looked at his watch. “The good news is that as of today you’re out of this hospital. Dr. Snaresbrook says that you are fit as a fiddle. You ready to make the move?”

“我随时准备好，随时准备出发，”布莱恩说着，关上并锁上手提箱，把它放在电脑旁边的地板上。“这个箱子怎么样！看起来像皮革——但它是由交联聚四氟乙烯和氮化硼细丝制成的。不会撕裂，而且可以永久使用。这是斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士的礼物……”

“I’m ready whenever you are—and rarin’ to go,” Brian said, closing and locking the suitcase and putting it on the floor next to his computer. “How about this case! Looks like leather—but it’s made of cross-linked teflar and boron nitride filaments. Can’t rip or tear and will last forever. A present from Dr. Snaresbrook…”

本叹了口气。“我知道。当她发现我用塑料袋把你的衣服带到这里时，她轻蔑地撇了撇嘴。而你却很高兴地用同一个袋子把它们带走了。”他看了一眼手表。“我们还有一些时间。这是好消息。”

Ben sighed. “I know. She curled her lip with scorn when she discovered that I had brought your clothes here in a plastic bag. And that you were happy enough to carry them away again in the same bag.” He glanced at his watch. “We have some time yet. That’s the good news.”

“那么坏消息是什么呢？”

“Now what’s the bad news?”

“关于你的助手。麻省理工学院的博士后领导没有成功。他确实有资格——但他已婚并有三个孩子，而且他不可能离开波士顿。”

“About your assistant. The MIT post-doc lead didn’t work out. He was qualified all right—except he was married with three kids and no way was he going to leave Boston.”

布莱恩揉了揉下巴，皱起眉头。“那么——这意味着船长得到了这份工作？”

Brian rubbed at his jaw and frowned. “Then—that means that the Captain gets the job?”

“从纸面上看，她同样优秀。如果你想要她，并且认为她有资格。决定权在你手里。如果你愿意，我会继续寻找更多候选人。”

“On paper she is equally good. If you want her and think that she’s qualified. The decision is yours. I’ll go on looking for more candidates if you want me to.”

“我不知道，本——我想我只是在犯傻。如果船长雪莉是个男人，我一秒钟都不会犹豫。这是一种直觉，没有别的。”本沉默了，把决定权留给了布莱恩。布莱恩在房间里走来走去，然后回来坐在椅子上。

“I don’t know, Ben—I guess that I am just being stupid. If the Captain, Shelly, were a man I wouldn’t hesitate for a second. It’s a gut feeling, nothing else.” Ben was silent, leaving the decision up to Brian. Who paced the length of the room, came back and dropped into the chair.

“她还好吗？”

“She’s good?”

“没有比这更好的了。”

“None better.”

“我是性别歧视者吗？”

“I’m being sexist?”

“我没这么说。决定权还在你手里。”

“I didn’t say that. The decision is still yours.”

“那她就留下来。她和专家检测程序一起怎么样了？”

“She stays then. How is she coming with the Expert Detection Program?”

“很好。你想让她告诉你这件事吗？”

“Very well. You want her to tell you about it?”

“当然可以——只要开始行动就行。这样我就有机会看看她是如何工作的。”

“Sure—as soon as it gets rolling. And it will give me a chance to see how she works.”

本又看了看手表。“时间到了。我会打电话让他们知道我们准备好了。我想让你见见负责你安全的人。他叫伍德。经验丰富，非常可靠。我不是随便说说的，因为你的生命很可能就取决于他。我想——不，我知道他是最好的。”

Ben looked at his watch again. “It’s time. I’ll phone down and let them know we’re ready. And I want you to meet the man who will be in charge of your security. Name of Wood. Very experienced, very reliable. I don’t say that lightly because your life might very well depend upon him. I think—no, I know that he is the best.”

伍德少校敲门进来。他身材高大，像个拳击手，腰窄肩宽。右脸颊上的伤疤在他黑褐色的皮肤上形成一道脊线，一直延伸到嘴角，让他永远露出一丝微笑。

Major Wood knocked and entered. A big man, built like a boxer with a narrow waist and wide shoulders. The scar on his right cheek made a ridge on his black-brown skin, ran down to his mouth and tucked up the corner of it to give him a tiny perpetual grin.

“布莱恩，我是伍德少校，现在负责 Megalobe 的安全事务。”

“Brian, this is Major Wood, who is in charge of security now at Megalobe.”

“很高兴见到你，布莱恩。如果要直呼其名，我的朋友会叫我伍迪。但不会当着部队的面。我们会好好照顾你的。比上一批人好。”他鼻孔因愤怒而微微张开。“他们以前在 Megalobe 的安保唯一的好处就是我们可以从他们的错误中吸取教训。他们犯了一个大错误。”

“Pleased to meet you, Brian. If it is going to be first names my friends call me Woody. But not in front of the troops. We’re going to take good care of you. Better than the last bunch.” His nostrils flared slightly with anger. “The only thing good about the security that they used to have at Megalobe is that we can learn from their mistakes. Their one big mistake.”

“告诉我，”贝尼科夫说。“我还在调查发生了什么。”

“Tell me,” Benicoff said. “I’m still investigating what happened.”

“安全在于人，而不是机器。一个人能造出的东西，另一个人也能弄虚作假。当然，我会使用那里安装的所有安全设备，再加上我自己的一些附加设备。机器和铁丝网会有所帮助。但布莱恩，保护你和其他人的人将是我的人。这就是安全。”

“Security is people—not machines. Anything one man can build another man can trick. Of course I’m going to use all the security apparatus that has been built in and installed there—plus some additions of my own. Machines and wire fences help. But it will be my men who will be guarding you and the others, Brian. That is security.”

“我感觉好些了，”布莱恩如实说道。

“I feel better already,” Brian said—truthfully.

“那就保持这个姿势，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生进来时说道。“不管你是否意识到，今天都会是压力很大的一天。最多睡五个小时——然后你就躺下。明白了吗？”

“Then stay that way,” Dr. Snaresbrook said as she entered. “This is going to be a stressful day whether you realize it or not. Five hours maximum—then you lie down. Understood?”

“我有选择吗？”

“Do I have a choice?”

“不。”她的微笑软化了命令的专横。“我给你几天时间开始工作。我需要这段时间将我的设备搬到 Megalobe 医务室。既然你不会再来这家医院了，我们将在那里进行机器操作。看看我们是否能让你访问你将需要的所有技术记忆。现在——好好照顾自己。”

“No.” Her smile softened the imperiousness of her command. “I’ll give you a few days to get into your work. I’ll need that time to move my equipment to the Megalobe infirmary. Since you won’t be coming to this hospital anymore we’ll do the machine sessions there. See if we can give you access to all those technical memories you are going to need. Now—take care of yourself.”

“我会的，医生——别担心。”

“I will, Doc—don’t worry.”

“你准备好了吗？”她一走，伍德少校就问道。

“Are you ready?” Major Wood asked as soon as she had gone.

“只是等待命令。”

“Just waiting for orders.”

“这是正确的态度。按我说的做，你就能安全到达目的地——而且会一直平安。中士。”

“That’s the correct attitude. Do what I say and you’ll get there safely—and will stay safe. Sergeant.”

士兵在听到尖锐的命令后立即进入房间，将他随身携带的两把短小丑陋的自动武器中的一把交给少校。贝尼科夫抓起布莱恩的包和电脑，他们一起离开了。

The soldier entered the room an instant after the sharp-barked command and handed the Major one of the two stubby, ugly automatic weapons he was carrying. Benicoff grabbed up Brian’s bag and computer and they all left together.

虽然这次行程不像将布莱恩送往医院的海军陆战队转运那样华丽，但一切仍然以专业效率进行。一队士兵就位，在他们走过大厅时包围他们；其他人则在他们前后跟进。尽管高层提出了很多抗议，但军官停车场上已经没有任何车辆，一架大型运输直升机停在停车场中间，旋翼转动。他们一上车，直升机就起飞了。快速攻击直升机在他们上升时绕着他们盘旋，在他们飞过海湾、圣地亚哥的街道和房屋之前达到高度。他们沿着高速公路向西，然后转弯，飞得更高，越过群山。这是一个阳光明媚的好日子，能见度似乎无限。

Although this trip lacked the showiness of the Marine transfer that had brought Brian to the hospital, everything still proceeded with professional efficiency.
