“双眼立体视觉可能会出现一些错误。第三只眼睛增加了错误检查能力。它可以看到更多的物体，更容易定位和识别物体。”她绕着机器走了一圈。“看起来你把除了大脑之外的所有东西都给了它。”

“There are errors that two-eye stereo can make. The third eye adds error-checking ability. And it can see more of a subject, making it easier to locate and identify things.” She walked around the machine. “Looks like you gave it everything here except a brain.”

“对——这就是接下来要发生的事情。”

“Right—and that’s what comes next.”

“太好了。那我们从哪儿开始呢？”

“Great. Then where do we start?”

“一开始。我的计划是遵循原始笔记。首先，我们为系统提供大量预先编程的常识知识。然后，我们将添加完成各种工作所需的所有附加程序。以及足够多的额外替代单元（包括管理器），这样即使某些单元发生故障，系统仍将继续工作。设计人工思维就像进化动物一样，所以我的计划是使用进化的原则来管理大脑。这样，我们最终会得到一个既不太集中也不太分散的系统。事实上，我已经在 Robin-1 中运用了其中的一些想法。”

“At the very beginning. My plan is to follow the original notes. First we provide the system with a huge reservoir of preprogrammed commonsense knowledge. Then we’ll add in all the additional programs it will need to do all its various jobs. And enough extra alternative units—including the managers—so that the system will continue to work even if some units fail. Designing an artificial mind is like evolving an animal—so my plan is to use the principles that evolved to manage the brain. That way, we’ll end up with a system that is neither too centralized nor too diffusely distributed. In fact I’m already using some of those ideas right here with Robin-1.”

“你为什么给它起这个名字？”

“Why did you give it that name?”

“笔记上就是这么称呼的——显然是‘机器人智能’的缩写。”

“That’s what it was called in the notes—apparently an acronym for ‘robot intelligence.’ “

“你说你已经将部分管理者社会系统上线了。你能向我展示更多它是如何工作的吗？因为我的《迪克·特雷西》系统中的子程序也有管理者——但每个程序的管理者不会超过一名。如果有多名管理者，当出现任何问题时，我就不知道该把责任归咎于谁了。让这样的系统可靠地运行难道不是几乎不可能吗？”

“You said you already had some of your society-of-managers system on line. Could you show me more of how it works? Because the sub-programs in my Dick Tracy system have managers too—but never more than one manager for each program. With more than one manager I wouldn’t know where to put the blame when anything fails. Won’t it be almost impossible to make such a system work reliably?”

“相反，这样做应该更容易，因为每个经理都与其他备选经理密切合作，这样当其中任何一位经理开始失败时，另一位经理就可以接替。等我修好这个连接器后，解释起来就容易多了。你能把那把剪刀递给我吗？”

“On the contrary, it should make that easier to do, because each of the managers works closely with other alternative managers, so that when any one of them starts to fail another one can take over. It will be easier to explain after I finish repairing this connector. Would you please hand me that clipper?”

雪莉走到工作台旁，把工具拿给布莱恩。

Shelly went over to the workbench and brought Brian the tool.

“你刚才做了什么？”布莱恩问她。

“What did you just do?” Brian asked her.

“我把剪刀递给你了。你问这个干什么？”

“I handed you the clipper. Why do you ask?”

“因为我希望你解释一下你是如何得到它的。”

“Because I want you to explain how you got it.”

“什么意思？我只是走到工作台上把它带回来给你而已。”

“What do you mean? I simply walked over to the workbench and brought it back to you.”

“是的，很简单——但是你怎么知道它有多远呢？”

“Simply, yes—but how did you know how far away it was?”

“布莱恩——你是在故意刁难你吗？我看过去，它在长凳上。”

“Brian—are you trying to be difficult? I looked over and saw it on the bench.”

“我不是在刁难你。我只是在说明一个观点。你是怎么决定走路而不是直接伸手去拿的？”

“I’m not being difficult. I’m only making a point. How did you decide to walk, instead of simply reaching for it?”

“这太遥不可及了，这就是原因。”

“It was too far out of reach, that’s why.”

“你怎么知道的？”

“And how did you know that?”

“你现在太愚蠢了。我能看到它有多远。大约两米。太远了，够不着。”

“Now you’re being stupid. I could see how far it was. About two meters. Much too far to reach.”

“抱歉，我并不是故意装糊涂。我只是想问你如何做到这一点。也就是说，我问的是你的大脑中有什么机制可以计算出从你的手到剪刀的距离。”

“Sorry, I didn’t mean to seem obtuse. I meant to ask you for a theory of how you did it. That is, I’m asking what mechanism in your brain figured out the distance from your hand to the clipper.”

“嗯，我真的不知道。这完全是无意识的。但我想我用我的两只眼睛来感知远距离。”

“Well, I don’t know, really. It was entirely unconscious. But I suppose I used both of my eyes for distance perception.”

“好的，但是它实际上是如何运作的呢？”

“Okay, but how does that actually work?”

“立体距离感知。”

“Stereoscopic distance perception.”

“你确定你就是这样判断距离的吗？”

“Are you sure that’s how you judged the distance?”

“不是。从它的外观来看，可能是这样的。而且我也知道长凳离这儿有多远。”

“Not really. It could have been by its apparent size. And I know how far away the bench is as well.”

“没错。所以判断距离的方法有很多。罗宾的大脑肯定和你的一样，经理和副经理会选择适用的正确子系统。”

“Exactly.  So there are really lots of ways to judge distance. Robin’s brain must work like yours, with managers and submanagers choosing the correct subsystems that apply.”

“而且你使用的是笔记中勾勒出的系统。”

“And you’re using the system that’s sketched in the notes.”

“是的，我已经设法使其中一部分发挥作用了。”

“Yes, and I’ve managed to make some of it work.”

“你的系统中的代理模块真的可以自行学习吗？”

“Have you actually got the agent-modules in your system to learn for themselves?”

“我做到了。目前，大多数代理只是基于规则的小型系统，每个系统都有几十条规则来调用 UCSD 测距过程。代理只需添加新规则即可学习。每当代理意见不一致时，系统就会尝试寻找产生较少冲突的其他方法。”

“I have. Right now, most of the agents are just small rule-based systems, each with a few dozen rules for invoking the UCSD range-finding processes. The agents learn simply by adding new rules. And whenever agents disagree, the system tries to find a different way that produces less conflict.”

电话的嘟嘟声打断了布莱恩的谈话，他把电话放到耳边。

The bleep of the telephone interrupted Brian and he put it to his ear.

“我是 Brian。”

“Brian here.”

“我是贝尼科夫，德莱尼先生。如果您不忙， 可以来行政大楼参加一个会议吗？ 还有卡恩少校。这件事情很重要。”

“Benicoff speaking, Mr. Delaney. If you are not busy could you join a meeting here in the executive building? Major Kahn as well. It is a matter of some importance.”

本的声音冰冷而冷漠。有人和他在一起——一定有什么事发生了。

Ben’s voice was cold and impersonal. Someone was with him—and something was up.

“我们会去的。”他挂了电话。“是本，他说那次会议很重要。听他说话的语气，他就是这么想的。他希望我们俩都去。”

“We’ll be there.” He hung up. “It was Ben, a meeting that he says is important. Sounded that way too the way he spoke. He wants us both there.”

“现在？”

“Now?”

“现在。让我关闭 Robin 的电源，然后我们看看发生了什么。”

“Now. Let me power Robin down and we’ll see what is going on.”

考虑到本的语气，布莱恩看到这位沉默寡言的人物坐在会议桌的末端，身旁是两名高级陆军军官，他并不感到惊讶。布莱恩说话时，口音带着浓重的威克洛口音。

Considering Ben’s tone of voice, Brian was not surprised to see the silent figure, flanked by two high-ranking Army officers, sitting at the end of the conference table. When Brian spoke it was with the darkest Wicklow brogue.

“是您本人吗，绍尔希特将军？确实是您？像您这样的大人物为什么要浪费时间和我们这种人在一起？”

“Is that yourself, General Schorcht? Sure and it is? What is a grand man like you wasting his time with the likes of us?”

将军没有忘记他们在病房里的最后一次会面，因为他冷酷的眼神中闪烁着卑鄙的光芒。他转过身来面对贝尼科夫，然后开口说话。

The General had not forgotten their last meeting in the hospital room, for there was a mean glitter in his cold eyes. He turned back to Benicoff before he spoke.

“这个房间安全吗？”

“How secure is this room?”

“百分之百。它配备了所有内置安全措施——而且在我们进来之前，安全人员已经检查过了。”

“One hundred percent. It has all the built-in safeguards— plus it was swept by the security officer just before we came in.”

“你现在必须解释，为什么向我隐瞒信息，以及为什么在这些人出现之前拒绝解释。”

“You will now explain why you are withholding information from me—and why you refused to explain yourself before these people were present.”

“绍尔希特将军，并非每一种情况都是一场对抗，”本镇定地说道。“我们都是站在同一边的——或者说，我们所有人都是站在同一边的。我很遗憾我们过去有过分歧，但让我们把这留在过去吧。你以前见过布莱恩。这是卡恩少校，她正在协助我进行调查。她编写了专家程序，产生了新的信息，这是我们在这个案件中取得的第一个突破。我相信你会知道，少校拥有最高安全权限，因为一旦她被派到这里工作，你就会对她进行调查。她会详细概述所有新进展——只要你告诉我们你所知道的关于布莱恩的暗杀企图。”

“General Schorcht, every situation is not a confrontation,” Ben said with studied calm. “We are both on the same side—rather all of us are on the same side. I regret that we have had differences in the past, but let us leave that in the past. You have met Brian before. This is Major Kahn, who is assisting me in my investigation. She wrote the Expert Program that produced the new information, the first breakthrough that we have had in this case. The Major has top security clearance, as I’m sure you will know, since you would have had her investigated as soon as she was attached to the work here. She will outline in detail all of the new developments—as soon as you have told us what you know about the attempts on Brian’s life.”

“我已经把你需要知道的都告诉你了。少校——你的报告。”

“I have told you all you need to know. Major—your report.”

雪莱正端正坐着，准备讲话，这时贝尼科夫举起了手。

Shelly was sitting at attention, starting to speak, when Benicoff raised his hand.

“请稍等片刻，少将，正如我之前所说，这不是一个对抗性的情况。我可以提醒您一些高度相关的事实。总统亲自任命我负责这项调查。我相信您不希望我第二次就此事咨询他。”

“Just hold that report for a moment, Major. General, as I said before, this is not a confrontational situation. May I remind you of some highly relevant facts. The President himself has put me in charge of this investigation. I am sure that you don’t want me to consult him about this—a second time.”

绍尔希特将军保持着沉默——但他的脸上却充满着冷酷的仇恨。

General Schorcht remained silent—but his face was a mask of cold hatred.

“很好。我很高兴事情已经明朗。如果你仔细检查一下，你会发现布莱恩也已被证明与此案无关。他——还有我——想知道你所掌握的关于最近两次谋杀他事件的所有事实。你能不能告诉我？”本坐下来，微笑着。

“Good. I am glad that is clear. If you will check you will discover that Brian has also been cleared for all and any information relating to this case. He—and I—would like to know all of the facts that you have about the two recent attempts on his life. Would you please?” Ben sat back and smiled.

将军是个行动派，知道自己何时被包抄或被击败。“上校——关于试金石行动与本次调查有关方面的完整报告。”

The General was a man of action and knew when he was outflanked and outfought. “Colonel—a full report on those aspects of Operation Touchstone as it relates to this investigation.”

“是的，将军。”上校拿起面前的一叠文件。“试金石行动”是多国军队和缉毒部门的联合行动。这是多年努力的成果。您无疑知道，由于过去十年内城区的重建和发展，国际毒品市场的低端和暴力活动已经有效减少，甚至消除。所有较小的毒枭都被消灭了，只剩下两个最大的国际贩毒集团，它们实际上是本国的政府。合作特工已经对它们进行了调查和渗透。我们正处于最终消灭它们的最后阶段。然而，在这次行动中，我们得知一个拥有大量资源的第三方正在寻求帮助，我认为这就是所谓的“暗杀”。

“Yes, General.” The Colonel picked up the sheaf of papers that rested before him. “Operation Touchstone is a joint operation between the armed forces and the narcotic investigation divisions of a number of countries. It is the culmination of years of work. As you undoubtedly know, due to the reconstruction and development of the inner cities in the last decade, the lower and violent end of the international drug market has effectively been reduced if not eliminated. All of the smaller drug barons have been wiped out, which leaves only two of the largest international drug cartels, virtually governments of their own in their home countries. They have been investigated and penetrated by cooperating agents. We are in the final stages of finally eliminating them. However, completely incidental to this operation, we learned of an approach by a third party with great resources enlisting aid for what I believe is referred to as a ‘hit.’ “

“我在医院遭到袭击？”布莱恩说。

“The attack on me in the hospital?” Brian said.

“没错，先生。我们的特工冒着极大的风险警告我们。他本人并不知道是谁联系了该组织，他只是知道有暗杀合同。从那时起，我们就没有再了解到有关这一特殊情况的任何消息。”

“That is correct, sir. Our agent put himself at great risk to warn us. He himself did not know who contacted the organization, he was just aware of the hit contract. Since that time nothing more has been learned relating to this particular situation.”

“你对我们在墨西哥遭受的袭击了解多少？”本打断道。

“What do you know about the attack on us in Mexico?” Ben broke in.

“我们确信两次袭击之间唯一的联系就是德莱尼先生。由于袭击者从未被找到，这当然只是推测。另外，第二次袭击不在我的管辖范围内……”

“We are sure that the only connection between the two attacks was Mr. Delaney. Since the attackers were never found this is of course supposition. Also, the second attack is not within my jurisdiction…”

“我负责调查，”第二军官说道，他是一位白发苍苍、面目狰狞的上校。“我叫戴维斯，军事情报局的。这件事让我们非常担忧，因为泄漏似乎源自军事基地内部。一个海军机构。”从他的语气中，毫无疑问可以看出他对海军机构的看法。

“I am in charge of that investigation,” the second officer said, a grizzled and menacing-looking Colonel. “My name is Davis, Military Intelligence. This concerns us greatly because the leak appears to have originated from inside a military base. A Navy establishment.” There was no doubt from his tone of voice how he felt about naval establishments.

“你的进展如何？”贝尼科夫问道。

“What has your progress been?” Benicoff asked.

“我们有一些线索正在跟进。但是，我们没有发现第一次和第二次袭击事件中人员之间有任何联系。”

“We have some leads that we are following up. However we have found no trace of any connection between the individuals who were in the first and second attacks.”

“那我来总结一下，”本说，“如果你把 Megalobe 的盗窃案和对 Brian 的袭击案的损失加起来——那肯定有数百万。所以我们知道，一些非常有钱的人雇佣了毒瘾患者在医院谋杀 Brian。当他们在那里没有成功时，我们假设，同一个人又在墨西哥尝试了一次。对吗，上校？”

“Let me sum up then,” Ben said. “If you add up what the theft at Megalobe and the attacks on Brian have cost—it must be up in the millions. So we know that some very well heeled source hired the hopheads to kill Brian at the hospital. When they did not succeed there, this same source, we assume, tried again in Mexico. Is that correct, Colonel?”

“这符合我们自己对形势的估计。”

“It conforms to our own estimates of the situation.”

“所以实际上我们所知道的只是，一个有钱人曾两次试图谋杀布莱恩，但两次都失败了。我们是否可以假设这个来源也是实施最初袭击和盗窃的人？”

“So in reality all we know is that someone with a lot of money has tried to kill Brian twice and has failed both times. Can we assume that this source is also the same one that committed the original attack and theft?”

他沉默地等待着，直到获得两次不情愿的、轻快的军人点头；将军还是像往常一样冷静。

He waited in silence until he obtained two reluctant and brisk military nods; the General was as stolid as ever.

“那么看来我们都在调查同一群人。因此，我会随时向您通报我们的进展情况——我坚信您也会这么做。同意吗，将军？”

“Then it would appear that we are all investigating the same people. Therefore I will keep you appraised in the future of our progress—firm in the knowledge that you will be doing the same. Is that agreed, General?”

“同意。” 这句话是硬生生说出的，听起来非常勉强。本在桌边微笑着。

“Agreed.” The word could not have been more reluctantly produced had it been squeezed from a rock. Ben smiled around the table.

“我很高兴我们都站在同一边。卡恩少校，你能解释一下你的专家计划以及它产生的结果吗？”她的报告简洁明了。她说完后，他们转身回到贝尼科夫身边。

“I am glad that we are all on the same side. Major Kahn, will you explain about your Expert Program and the results that it has produced?” Her report was succinct, clear and brief. When she was done they turned back to Benicoff.

“我从那里开始调查。到目前为止，结果还不错。首先，当时在那个地方有一架飞机。它被圣地亚哥米拉马尔记录下来。调查人员找到了一位住在计算出的飞行路线下的牧场主。他被一架低空飞行的直升机惊扰了——他记得这件事，因为它干扰了他当时在电视上观看的电影的结尾。我们从节目中得到了完美的时间匹配。”

“I took the investigation from there. The results so far are good. Firstly there was a flight at that time in that place. It was recorded by San Diego Miramar. The investigators found a cattle rancher who lives under the calculated flight path. He was disturbed by a low-flying chopper—he remembers it because it interfered with the end of a film he was watching on television at the time. We have a perfect time match from the program.”

“你找到直升机了？”将军厉声问道。

“You have located the helicopter?” the General snapped.

“一旦我们把所有零碎的东西拼凑在一起，这就是最简单的部分。这架飞机一定是在施工现场工作的 TS-69。任何来自该地区以外的机器都必须提交飞行计划，但没有任何记录。直升机租赁公司的记录显示，在当天下午，飞机发生了电气故障，导致飞机暂时停飞。这架飞机没有返回其驻扎的布朗菲尔德，而是留在了瓜泰的现场。第二天早上，机械师飞到了那里，修复了故障，这是一个轻微的电气故障。我必须补充一点，故障非常小，飞行员自己就可以修复它。其中一个仪器的连接松动了。”

“Once we put all the bits and pieces together that was the easiest part. It had to be the TS-69 that was working on the construction site. Any machine from outside the area would have to have filed a flight plan and there was no record of one. The copter rental company’s records reveal that on the afternoon of the evening in question there had been an electrical malfunction that temporarily grounded it. The machine did not return to Brown Field where it was based, but remained at the site in Guatay. The following morning mechanics were flown there and the fault, a minor electrical one, was repaired. So minor, I must add, that the pilot himself could have repaired it. A loose connection on one of the instruments.”

“那天晚上飞机起飞了吗？”将军问道。

“Was the machine flown that night?” the General asked.

“根据记录——没有，”本说。“这才是有意思的地方。飞行记录保存在飞行员的飞行日志中，因为与汽车不同，飞机上没有里程表，没有任何东西可以显示飞机飞行了多少英里。但每个发动机都有一个小时表，记录它运行了多少小时。在这里我们确实发现了一个差异。飞行员报告说那天晚上没有飞行，机器在地面上，直到第二天才起飞。这与发动机的记录不符。现在我们到了有意思的地方。在我向联邦调查局报告这种可能性后，他们立即查看了公司的记录。他们在两小时内就拘留了飞行员——这是我来这里之前对他的采访记录。”

“According to the records—no,” Ben said. “That is the interesting part. Flight records are kept from the pilot’s logbook since, unlike an automobile, there is no odometer on an aircraft, nothing to indicate how many miles the thing has flown. But every engine has an hour meter that records how many hours it has been on. And here we did find a discrepancy. The pilot reported no flight that night, that the machine was on the ground and never flew until the next day. That does not match the engine’s records. So now we come to the interesting part. The FBI were into the company’s records as soon as I reported this possibility to them. They had the pilot in custody within two hours—and this is a recording of an interview I had with him just before I came here.”

本把录像带放进书桌内置的播放器时，周围一片寂静。屏幕滑到远处墙壁上的位置，他打开它时，房间灯光变暗。摄像机位于他的头部后面，可以看到他的轮廓。刺眼的灯光显示出他正在交谈的那个男人脸上表情的每一个细节。

There was absolute silence as Ben slipped the cassette into the built-in player in the desk. The screen slid down into position on the far wall and the room lights dimmed as he turned it on. The camera had been located behind his head, which could be seen in silhouette. Harsh lights revealed every detail of expression on the face of the man he was talking to.

“你叫奥维尔·罗德斯吗？”他们听到本的声音问道。

“Your name is Orville Rhodes?” they heard Ben’s voice ask.

“当然。但没人会这样叫我。达斯蒂，就像达斯蒂·罗兹，明白了吗？另外，PS，我已经跟你说过好几次了——所以你最好告诉我我到底在这里干什么？或者你是谁。我只知道联邦调查局没有说一句话就把我拖到这里。我有我的权利。”

“Sure. But nobody calls me that. Dusty, as in Dusty Rhodes, get it? And also, PS, I’ve told you all this a couple of times already—so how’s about you telling me just what the hell I am doing here? Or even who you are. All I know is the FBI dragged me here without a word of explanation. I have my rights.”

达斯蒂年轻、强壮、生气勃勃——长得帅。他也知道这一点，他用手背拂过金色大胡子，快速摇头甩动头发，是女孩的梦想。

Dusty was young, strong, angry—good-looking. And he knew it too, a girl’s dream the way he brushed his big blond mustache with the back of his hand, tossed his hair back with a quick motion of his head.

“我马上就解释，达斯蒂。先问几个简单的问题。你是 SkyHigh 有限公司雇用的直升机飞行员吗？”

“I’ll explain it all in a moment, Dusty. A few simple questions first. You are the helicopter pilot employed by SkyHigh Ltd.?”

“你也问过我这个问题。”

“You’ve asked me that too.”

“今年一月和二月，你们正在协助加利福尼亚州瓜泰（Guatay）建造一些建筑物。”

“And in January and February of this year you were aiding in the construction of some buildings in Guatay, California.”

“是的，那个时候我在那里工作。”

“About that time, yes, I was working there.”

“很好。告诉我一个具体的日子，2 月 8 日星期三。你还记得那一天吗？”

“Good. Tell me about one specific day, Wednesday February 8. You remember that day?”

“得了吧先生，不管你叫什么名字，几个月过去了，我怎么能记得住某一天？”达斯蒂怒气冲冲地说——但他的眼光却飞快地转来转去，不再完全放松。

“Come on mister, whatever the hell your name is, how could I remember any one day in particular all these months later?” Dusty said it with anger—but he moved his eyes about quickly, no longer completely at ease.

“我相信你一定还记得那一天。那是你因为手腕扭伤而无法飞行的三天中的一天。”

“I’m sure you can remember that day. It was one of the three days you were not able to fly because of a sprained wrist.”

“哦，那我当然记得了，你一开始为什么不说呢？我当时在家喝啤酒，因为医生说我不能坐飞机。”

“Oh, then, of course I remember it, why the hell didn’t you say so in the first place? I was home drinking beer because the doc said I couldn’t fly.”

他语气很真诚，但在刺眼的灯光下，他额头上的汗珠清晰可见。

He said it quite sincerely—but a beading of sweat on his forehead could be clearly seen in the harsh lights.

“那三天谁代替了你？”

“Who took your place for those three days?”

“另一名飞行员，公司雇用了他。你为什么不问问他们呢？”

“Another pilot, company hired him. Why don’t you ask them about it?”

“是的。他们说你认识这个飞行员本·索布里奇，而且你推荐了他。”

“We did. They say that you knew this pilot, Ben Sawbridge, that you recommended him.”

“他们这么说？也许他们是对的。那是很久以前的事情了。”他喃喃地说着，眨着眼睛看着灯光。他不再梳理下垂的胡子。当本再次开口说话时，他的声音冷若冰霜。

“They say that? Maybe they’re right. It was a long time ago.” He muttered the words, blinked into the lights. He was no longer brushing his sagging mustache. When Ben spoke again his voice was arctic cold.

“达斯蒂，先听我说完，再回答我的下一个问题。医生开具的关于你手腕扭伤的证明文件已在公司备案。这是伪造的。记录还显示，在涉案日期前后几周内，你还清了汽车的所有逾期款项，并在支票账户中存入了一些大额款项。这些款项被追溯到一个州外的支票账户，1 月 20 日，账户上有一笔 2.5 万美元的存款。尽管账户上的名字不同，但支票上的笔迹与你的相符。现在，有两个重要问题：谁给了你贿赂款，你推荐的那三天接替你的飞行员是谁？”

“Listen to what I have to say, Dusty, before you answer my next question. The doctor’s certificate about your sprained wrist was on file with the company. It is a forgery. It is also on record that over the weeks before and after the date in question you cleared up all the overdue payments on your car and made some large deposits in your checking account. These were traced to an out-of-state checking account where a deposit of twenty-five thousand dollars had been made on January 20. Although the account is in a different name the handwriting on the check matches yours. Now, two important questions—who gave you the bribe money and who was the pilot you recommended to take your place those three days?”

“我不知道是否有贿赂。那是赌资，来自蒂华纳的场外投注。你知道，我有点不想让国税局参与进来。还有飞行员——我已经告诉你了。名字叫本·索布里奇。”

“I don’t know from any bribery. And that was gambling money, from the off track betting in Tijuana. I sort of didn’t want the IRS involved, you know. And the pilot—I already told you. Name of Ben Sawbridge.”

“本·索布里奇从来没有获得过飞行执照。我想知道钱从何而来。我想知道飞行员是谁——你最好在回答之前仔细考虑一下。这还不是刑事案件，也没有提出任何指控。如果提出指控，你的处境将非常艰难。那架直升机被用于非常严重的犯罪。已经造成死亡。你将因共犯被起诉。在最好的情况下，你会被判收受贿赂、撒谎、危及生命。你将失去飞行执照，你将受到罚款，你将入狱。这是你最不希望发生的事情。但如果你拒绝合作，我会让你因谋杀而受审。”

“No flying license has ever been issued to a Ben Sawbridge. I want the truth about where the money came from. And I want to know who the pilot is—and you had better think carefully before you answer. This is not a criminal matter yet and no charges have been filed. If charges are filed you are in a very distressful position. That chopper was used in a very serious crime. There have been deaths. You will be indicted for complicity. At best you will be convicted of accepting bribes, lying, endangering life. You will lose your flying license, you will be fined and you will go to prison. That is the least that will happen to you. But if you refuse to cooperate I will see to it that you stand trial for murder as well.”

“我对任何谋杀案一无所知！”

“I don’t know anything about any murder!”

“没关系。你是自愿从犯。但那是最坏的情况。如果你愿意帮助我，我也会帮助你。如果你全力合作，这件事很有可能会被搁置——如果你能带我们找到那些贿赂你的人。在你回答之前，再想想这个。他们没有试图隐瞒贿赂或伪造的文件。因为他们不在乎你。他们知道这种联系迟早会被建立起来——也知道你的线索会断绝。”

“It doesn’t matter. You were a willing accessory. But that is a worst-case scenario. If you will help me I will help you. If you cooperate completely there is a good chance that this matter might be dropped—if you can lead us to the people who bribed you. Again before you answer—think of this. They made no attempt to hide the bribe or the forged documents. Because they didn’t care about you. They knew that this connection would be made sometime—and knew also that the trail would run cold with you.”

达斯蒂的头发紧贴着他湿漉漉的皮肤，他心不在焉地揉着胡子，把胡子弄得又皱又乱。“你真的能让我高潮吗？”他终于脱口而出。

Dusty’s hair was plastered to his wet skin and he rubbed distractedly at his mustache, crumpling and disarraying it. “Can you really get me off?” he finally blurted out.

“是的，收费较低——或者可能免费——以换取您的全力合作。这可以做到。但前提是你能告诉我们任何有助于我们调查的事情。”

“Yes, a lesser charge—or perhaps no charge—in exchange for your full cooperation. This can be done. But only if you can tell us anything that could help us in this investigation.”

达斯蒂咧嘴一笑，坐回椅子上。“好吧，我可以帮你，绝对可以。我不喜欢安排这一切的那个混蛋。我从未见过他，但他身上散发着真正的肮脏气息。他打电话给我，说如果我帮他，钱就会存入这个银行账户。我不喜欢这样，但我当时身无分文。钱在那里，我收到了一张邮寄的签名卡，这样我就可以把它取出来。一旦我开始用这笔钱，他就会对我百般阻拦，我根本没办法摆脱它。”

Dusty grinned widely and sat back in his chair. “Well, I can do that for you, do that for certain. I didn’t like the little shit who arranged the whole thing. I never met him but he had the smell of real dirty work. Called me and said the money would be deposited in this bank account if I helped him out. I didn’t like it but I was but broke. The money was there, I got a signature card in the mail so I could get it out. Once I started using the money he was all over me and there was no way of getting out of it.”

“他表明身份了吗？说说这是怎么回事？”

“Did he identify himself? Say what this was all about?”

“没有。他只是告诉我要听从指示，不要问问题，钱是我的。不过有一件事我可以告诉你。他是加拿大人。”

“No. Just told me to follow instructions and not ask questions and the money was mine. One thing I can tell you about him though. He’s Canadian.”

“你怎么知道？”

“How do you know?”

“天啊——你以为我怎么会知道？我在加拿大工作了两年，我知道该死的加拿大人说话的声音是什么样的。”

“Christ—how the hell do you think I know? I worked two years in Canada and I know what a goddamned Canuck sounds like.”

“冷静点，”贝尼科夫说道，声音里带着一种不祥的抱怨。“我们稍后再谈这个男人。现在跟我说说飞行员的事。”

“Calm down,” Benicoff said, an ominous grumble in his voice. “We’ll get back to this man later. Now tell me about the pilot.”

“你知道我不想卷入其中。我之所以同意这整件事，只是因为我真的需要钱。我欠了很多债，赡养费真的让我透不过气来。所以你帮我——我也会帮你。让我彻底摆脱这件事，我会告诉你一些他们不知道的事情，甚至我自己都不知道，直到这个飞行员走进来。我被告知要为他担保，我按照吩咐做了。他是一个傲慢的老混蛋，头发花白——只剩下一点。他参加过越南战争或海湾战争，从他走路的样子就能看出来。他看着我，看穿了我，但同时又假装认识我，这样他就可以驾驶直升机。这就是安排。我要说我认识他，推荐他。我同意了整件事，当时我真的很高兴。”

“You know I didn’t want to get involved. I only went along with this whole thing because I really needed the cash. I had a lot of debts and my alimony was really killing me. So you help me—and I’ll help you. Get me outta this thing whole and I’ll tell you something that they didn’t know, what I didn’t even know myself until this pilot walked in. I was told to vouch for him and I did just as I had been told. He was a big arrogant old sonofabitoh, had gray hair—what was left of it. He had flown in Nam or the Gulf War, you could tell that just by the way that he walked. He looked at me, right through me, but at the same time making believe that he knew me so he could get to fly the chopper. That was the arrangement. I was to say I knew him, to recommend him. And I went along with the whole thing, I was really happy about it then.”

达斯蒂笑了笑，伸了个懒腰，用指关节碰了碰胡子。“我们假装认识，因为这是交易的一部分。但我要告诉你，那个老家伙忘了，我以前见过他一次。我甚至还记得他的名字，因为后来有一个人跟我胡说八道，说这个老家伙以前有多厉害。”

Dusty smirked and stretched, touched his knuckle to his mustache. “We made believe that we knew each other because that was part of the deal. But I’ll tell you something, the old fart had forgotten, but I had seen him once before. And I even remember his name because one of the guys afterwards was bullshitting my ear off about what a hotshot this old guy had been in the old days.”

“你知道他的真名吗？”

“You know his real name?”

“是的。但我们得做个交易……”

“Yup. But we got to make a deal…”

本的椅子摔倒在地，他大步走到摄像机镜头前，抓住飞行员的衣领，把他拖起来。“听着，你这个可怜的混蛋——我唯一的条件就是如果你不大声喊出那个名字，你就终身监禁——现在！”

Ben’s chair crashed to the floor and he strode forward into the camera’s view, seized the pilot by the collar and dragged him to his feet. “Listen you miserable piece of crap—the only deal I make is to send you to jail for life if you don’t shout that name out loud—now!”

“你不能。”

“You can’t.”

“我能——我会的！”本摇晃着飞行员，就像摇晃一只大布娃娃一样，飞行员的脚趾在地上拖着。“名字。”

“I can—and I will!” The pilot’s toes were dragging on the floor as Ben shook him like a great rag doll. “The name.”

“让我走吧——我会帮忙的。一个古怪的外国名字，就是这样。听起来像 Doth——或者两者兼而有之。”

“Let me go—I’ll help. A screwball foreign name, that’s what it was. Sounded like Doth—or Both.”

本慢慢地把他放回椅子上，身体前倾，几乎要碰到他们的脸。他轻声威胁道。

Ben dropped him slowly back into the chair, leaned forward until their faces were almost touching. Spoke with quiet menace.

“可能是托特吗？”

“Could it have been Toth?”

“是的——就是这个！你认识这个人吗？托特。名字好有趣。”

“Yes—that’s it! Do you know the guy? Toth. A funny name.”

磁带播放完毕，当录音声音渐渐消失时，贝尼科夫大声说道。

The tape ended, and when his recorded voice died away Benicoff spoke aloud.

“托斯。事件发生时，阿帕德·托斯是 Megalobe 的安全主管。我立即查看了五角大楼的记录。

“Toth. Arpad Toth was head of security here at Megalobe when the events occurred. I checked the Pentagon records at once.

“看起来他有一个兄弟，名叫亚历克斯·托特。一名在越南飞行的直升机飞行员。”

“It appears that he has a brother, by the name of Alex Toth. A helicopter pilot who flew in Vietnam.”

24
24

2024 年 2 月 22 日
February 22, 2024

 

 

“现在这是我的责任，”绍尔希特将军说道，他的眼睛里闪烁着坚定的决心，声音里带着一丝冷酷的愤怒。“托特。亚历克斯·托特。一名陆军飞行员！”

“This is my responsibility now,” General Schorcht said, a glint of grim determination in his eye, a touch of cold anger in his voice. “Toth. Alex Toth. An army pilot!”

“这是个好主意，”本同意了。“这是你的地盘，你有能力做这件事。我们当然会继续调查。我建议戴维斯上校和我每天至少联络一次，如果有任何重大进展，就更频繁。我们必须让对方充分了解彼此的进展。这样还满意吗，将军？”

“That is a very good idea,” Ben agreed. “This is on your patch and you have the organization to do it. We will of course keep the investigation going at this end. I suggest that Colonel Davis and I liaise at least once a day, oftener if there are any dramatic developments. We must keep each other fully informed about our mutual progress. Is that satisfactory, General?”

“满意。团员解散。”

“Satisfactory. Company dismissed.”

两名陆军军官跳起，立正，跟随将军走了出去。

The two Army officers jumped to their feet, stood at attention, followed the General out.

“祝您今天过得愉快，将军，”布莱恩对着那僵硬的背影说道。“本，您曾经参过军吗？”

“And you have a good day too, General,” Brian said to the stiff, vanishing backs. “Were you ever in the Army, Ben?”

“幸好没有。”

“Happily, no.”

“你了解军人心态吗？”

“Do you understand the military mind?”

“是的，很不高兴。但我不想在军官面前失礼。”本看到雪莉表情严肃，便笑着缓和了语气。“雪莉，开个玩笑而已。可能玩笑的语气最差——所以我很抱歉。”

“Unhappily, yes. But I don’t want to be rude in the presence of a serving officer.” Ben saw Shelly’s grim expression and softened his words with a smile. “A joke, Shelly, that’s all. Probably in the worst possible taste—so I apologize.”

“没必要，”她微笑着回答道。“我不知道我为什么要为参军辩护。我加入罗特西是为了支付大学学费。然后我加入了空军，因为这是完成研究生学业的唯一途径。我的父母在洛杉矶的农贸市场有一个蔬菜摊，对其他人来说，那将是一座金矿。我的父亲是一位伟大的犹太法典学者，但却是一个糟糕的商人。空军让我能够做我唯一想做的事情。”

“No need,” she said, returning a slight smile. “I don’t know why I should be defensive about the military. I joined rotsee to pay for college. Then I enlisted in the Air Force as the only way to get through graduate school. My parents had a vegetable stand in Farmers Market in L.A. Which for anyone else would have been a gold mine. My father is a great Talmudic scholar but a really lousy businessman. The Air Force enabled me to do the only thing I wanted to do.”

“这必然会牵涉到下一代，”布莱恩说。“接下来的调查会如何进行？”

“Which leads inexorably to the next generation,” Brian said. “Where does the investigation go from here?”

“我会跟进直升机开发所揭示的所有线索，”本说。“至于专家计划，我们的巫师侦探迪克·特雷西——这取决于你，雪莉。下一步呢？”

“I’m going to follow up all the leads that the copter development opened,” Ben said. “As to the Expert Program, our wizard detective Dick Tracy-—that is up to you, Shelly. What’s next?”

她从会议桌上的水瓶里给自己倒了一杯水；给自己一点时间思考。

She poured herself a glass of water from the carafe on the conference table; gave herself a moment to think.

“我仍在运行《迪克·特雷西》项目。但我不指望它能找到任何新东西，除非我们能获得更多数据。”

“I’m still running the Dick Tracy program. But I don’t expect it to find anything new until we get more data for it.”

“这样你就有空闲时间了——这意味着你可以和我一起全职研究人工智能，”布莱恩说。“因为我们所做的工作最终会被输入到《迪克·特雷西》计划中。”

“Which leaves you with free time—and that means you can work full time on the AI with me,” Brian said. “Because the work we do will eventually be fed into the Dick Tracy program.”

本一脸疑惑。“再说一遍。”

Ben looked puzzled. “Say again.”

“想一想。现在你只是从犯罪行为这一单一角度进行调查。很好——我希望你能在他们再次找到我之前成功。否则我支持屠杀者。但我们也应该采取第二种方法。你有没有想过他们到底偷了什么？”

“Think about it for a moment. Right now you are approaching the investigation from only the single point of view of the crime that was committed. Well and good—and I hope you succeed before they reach me again. Otherwise I’m for the knackers. But we should also be taking a second approach. Have you thought about just what it was that they stole?”

“显然，是你的人工智能机器。”

“Obviously, your AI machine.”

“不，不止这些。他们试图杀死所有了解人工智能的人，窃取或销毁所有现有记录。他们现在还在试图杀死我。这让一件事变得非常清楚。”

“No—it was more than that. They tried to kill everyone who had any knowledge of the AI, to steal or destroy every existing record. And they are still trying to kill me. That makes one thing very clear.”

“当然！”本说。“我应该意识到这一点。他们不仅想要人工智能——还想垄断全球。他们现在可能正试图推销它。他们想将其商业化以赚取利润。但他们犯了谋杀和盗窃罪，当然不想被发现。他们必须隐瞒他们正在使用它的事实，所以他们必须以一种无法被人工智能追溯到他们的方式利用它。”

“Of course!” Ben said. “I should have realized that. They not only wanted the AI—but they wanted a world monopoly on it. They might possibly be trying to market it now. They will want to use it commercially to turn a profit. But they have committed murder and theft and certainly don’t want to be found out. They have to conceal the fact that they’re using it, so they must exploit it in such a way that the AI cannot be traced back to them.”

“我明白你的意思，”雪莉说，“一旦他们让它运转起来，被盗的人工智能几乎可以用于任何目的。它可以控制机械过程，也许可以编写软件，跟踪新的研究方向，帮助产品开发——几乎可以用于任何事情。”

“I see what you mean,” Shelly said. “Once they get it working, the stolen AI could be used for almost any purpose. To control mechanical processes, maybe to write software, follow new lines of research, aid product development—it could be used for almost anything.”

贝尼科夫严肃地点头表示同意。“因此，要想抓住他们就相当困难了。我们必须时刻保持警惕，不是针对任何非常具体的东西，而是针对几乎任何类型的看起来特别先进的程序或机器。”

Benicoff nodded solemn agreement. “And that makes it rather hard to catch them out. We have to be on the lookout, not for anything very specific, but for virtually any type of program or machine that seems peculiarly advanced.”

“这对我的程序来说太笼统了，无法处理，”Shelly 说。“迪克·特雷西只能处理精心构建的数据库。它没有足够的知识或常识来帮助解决如此广泛的问题。”

“That’s much too general for my program to be able to deal with,” Shelly said. “Dick Tracy can only work with carefully structured data bases. It just doesn’t have enough knowledge or common sense to help with a problem as broad as this.”

“那我们就得改进它，”布莱恩说。“这正是我要说的。现在我们该做什么已经非常清楚了。首先我们必须让《迪克·特雷西》更聪明，让它具备更多的常识。”

“Then we will have to improve it,” Brian said. “This is exactly what I’m driving at. It is now perfectly clear what we have to do. First we have to make Dick Tracy smarter, to equip it with more general knowledge.”

“你的意思是让它变成更好的人工智能？”贝尼科夫问道。“然后用它来找到其他人工智能。就像让小偷阻止小偷一样。”

“You mean to make it into a better AI?” Benicoff asked. “And then use it to find the other AIs. Like setting a thief to stop a thief.”

“这只是一半。另一半是我对机器人罗宾所做的工作。让它更像笔记中的人工智能。如果我能做到这一点，那么我们就会更了解这台被盗机器的功能。这将有助于缩小搜索范围。”

“That’s half of it. The other half is what I’m doing with the robot Robin. Making it more like the AI in the notes. If I can do that, then we’ll know more about what the stolen machine is capable of. And that will help narrow the search.”

“特别是如果我们能将同样的功能上传到《迪克·特雷西》中，”谢利说。“那么它就能真正知道要搜索什么了！”

“Especially if we can upload those same capabilities into Dick Tracy,” Shelly said. “Then it could really know what to search for!”

他们面面相觑，但似乎没有什么话可说。他们每个人要做的事情都很清楚。

They all looked at one another, but there seemed to be little more to say. It was clear what each of them had to do.

当他们起身离开时，本拦住了他们。“还有最后一件重要的事情要讨论。雪莉的住处。”

Ben stopped them as they rose to leave. “One last and important matter to discuss. Shelly’s living quarters.”

“很抱歉你提到了这一点，”她说。“我以为我会得到一套漂亮的小公寓。但在最后一刻，整个交易失败了。”

“I’m sorry you mentioned that,” she said. “I thought I was getting a lovely little apartment. But at the very last moment the whole deal fell through.”

本看起来有些不自在。“对不起，不过，那是我做的。我一直在想着对布莱恩生命的攻击，我意识到你现在也一定是目标。一旦你开始开发人工智能，外面的杀人力量就会……很难说，会想杀死你和布莱恩。你同意吗？”

Ben looked uncomfortable. “I’m sorry but, well, that was my doing. I have been thinking about the attacks on Brian’s life and I realized that you must also be a target now. Once you start developing AI, the murderous power out there will… it’s not easy to say, will want to kill you as well as Brian. Do you agree?”

雪莉勉强地点点头。

Shelly nodded a reluctant yes.

“这意味着你必须和布莱恩一样生活在同样程度的安全环境中。在 Megalobe 这里。”

“Which means you will have to live with the same degree of security as Brian. Here in Megalobe.”

“如果我必须住在我现在住的商人廉价旅馆里，我肯定会自杀的。”

“I’ll get suicidal if I have to live in the businessmen’s flophouse where I am staying now.”

“毫无疑问！我说话时很有感触，因为我自己也在那里度过了许多悲惨的夜晚。现在我可以提个建议吗？这里的军营里有 WAC 宿舍，为女兵提供住宿。如果我们把几个房间拼在一起，把它们改造成一个小公寓——你介意住在那里吗？”

“No question of that! I speak with feeling because I have spent many a miserable night there myself. Now can I make a suggestion? There are WAC quarters in the barracks here with provision for female Army personnel. If we knocked a couple of rooms together and fitted them up as a small apartment—would you mind staying there?”

“我希望对装修有发言权。”

“I’ll want a say in the decorating.”

“您自己挑选——我们来付账。电子厨房、按摩浴缸——任何您想要的东西。军队工程师会为您安装。”

“You pick it out—we’ll pick up the tab. Electronic kitchen, Jacuzzi bath—anything you want. The army engineers will install it.”

“接受报价。我什么时候能拿到目录？”

“Offer accepted. When do I get the catalogs?”

“我现在把它们放在我的办公室里。”

“I have them in my office right now.”

“本——你太糟糕了。你怎么知道我会同意这个计划？”

“Ben—you’re terrible. How did you know I would go along with this plan?”

“我不知道——只是希望。当你从各个角度来看，这确实是唯一安全的做法。”

“I didn’t know—just hoped. And when you look at it from all sides it really turns out to be the only safe thing to do.”

“我现在可以看一下目录吗？”

“Can I see the catalogs now?”

“当然了，就在这个楼412室，我去叫我的助理过来，让她把他们挖出来。”

“Of course. In this building, room 412. I’ll call my assistant and have her dig them out.”

雪莉朝门口走去——然后转过身。“对不起，布莱恩。我应该先问问你是否需要我。”

Shelly started for the door—then spun about. “I’m sorry, Brian. I should have asked you first if you need me.”

“我觉得这是个好主意。无论如何，今天我还有一些其他事情要做，不用去实验室。我们明天早上九点在那里见面怎么样？”

“I think it’s a great idea. In any case I have some other things to do today away from the lab. What do we say we meet there at nine a.m. tomorrow?”

“正确的”

“Right”

布莱恩等到门关上才转身对本，默默地咬着嘴唇，才开口说话。“我还没告诉她我脑子里植入了 CPU。她也没问我那次植入 CPU 并得出盗窃线索的会议。她跟你提过吗？”

Brian waited until the door had closed before he turned to Ben, chewed his lip in silence before he managed to speak. “I still haven’t told her about the CPU implant in my brain. And she hasn’t asked me about that session where it produced the clue about the theft. Has she mentioned it to you?”

“不会——而且我认为她不会。雪莉是一个非常注重隐私的人，我认为她也会对其他人保持同样的隐私。这重要吗？”

“No—and I don’t think she will. Shelly is a very private person and I think she extends the same privacy to others. Is it important?”

“只有我才这样。我之前跟你说过感觉自己像个怪物——”

“Only to me. What I told you before about feeling like a freak— “

“你不是，你知道这一点。我怀疑这个话题不会再被提起。”

“You’re not, and you know it. I doubt if the topic will come up again.”

“我总有一天会告诉她这件事的。只是现在还不行。特别是因为我已经安排了与斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士的一些长时间的会谈。”他看了看手表。“第一次会谈很快就要开始了。我这样做的主要原因是我决心加快人工智能的工作。”

“I’ll tell her about it, someday. Just not now. Particularly since I have arranged some lengthy sessions with Dr. Snaresbrook.” He glanced at his watch. “The first one will be starting soon. The main reason I am doing this is that I am determined to speed up the AI work.”

“如何？”

“How?”

“我想改进我的研究方法。现在我所做的就是翻阅我们从墨西哥带回来的备份数据库中的材料。但这些大多是关于正在进行的工作的笔记和问题。我需要做的是找到真正的记忆和基于这些记忆的研究结果。目前这项工作进展缓慢，令人恼火。”

“I want to improve my approach to the research. Right now all that I am doing is going through the material from the backup data bank we brought back from Mexico. But these are mostly notes and questions about work in progress. What I need to do is locate the real memories and the results of the research based upon them. At the present time it has been slow and infuriating work.”

“什么方式？”

“In what way?”

“我曾经、现在、现在……”布莱恩苦笑着。“我想没有正确的语法来表达它。我的意思是，做这些笔记的我是一个马虎的笔记制作者。你知道，当你给自己写笔记时，你通常会潦草地写下几个词来提醒你整个想法。但那个特定的我已不复存在，所以我的旧笔记不会让我想起任何事情。所以我开始与斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士合作，看看我们是否可以使用 CPU 植入物将笔记与我大脑中仍然存在的其他断开的记忆联系起来。我第一次开发人工智能花了十年时间——如果没有帮助，恐怕还要花这么长时间。我必须找回那些丢失的记忆。”

“I was, am, are…” Brian smiled wryly. “I guess there is no correct syntax to express it. What I mean is the me that made those notes was a sloppy note maker. You know how, when you write a note to yourself, you mostly scribble a couple of words that will remind you of the whole idea. But that particular me no longer exists, so my old notes don’t remind me of anything. So I’ve started working with Dr. Snaresbrook to see if we can use the CPU implant to link the notes to additional disconnected memories that are still in my brain. It took me ten years to develop AI the first time—and I’m afraid it will take that long again if I don’t have some help. I must get those lost memories back.”

“你访问这些记忆有什么结果吗？”

“Are there any results of your accessing these memories?”

“现在还为时过早。我们仍在尝试找到一种可以随时可靠地激活的连接方式。CPU 是一台机器，而我不是，而且我们在最好的情况下交互效果也很糟糕。在其他时候，这就像电话连接不良。你知道，两个人同时说话，却什么也没接通。或者我只是无法理解正在传递的信息。不得不停止所有输入并回到原点 A。我告诉你，这很令人沮丧。但我会克服它。它只会有所改善。我希望如此。”

“Early days yet. We are still trying to find a way to make connections that I can reliably activate at will. The CPU is a machine—and I’m not—and we interface badly at the best of times. It is like a bad phone connection at other times. You know, both people talking at once and nothing coming across. Or I just simply cannot make sense of what is getting through. Have to stop all input and go back to square A. Frustrating, I can tell you. But I’m going to lick it. It can only improve. I hope.”

本陪着布莱恩去了 Megalobe 诊所，把他留在了斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生的办公室外面。他看着布莱恩走进来，站在那里沉思了一会儿。有很多事情要考虑。

Ben walked Brian over to the Megalobe clinic and left him outside Dr. Snaresbrook’s office. He watched him enter, stood there for some time, deep in thought. There was plenty to think about.

治疗进行得很顺利。布莱恩现在可以随意访问 CPU，用它来提取特定的记忆。系统运行得更好了——尽管有时他会检索到一些难以理解的知识片段。就好像它们是来自别人的建议，而不是来自他自己的记忆。偶尔，当他访问早期成年自我的记忆时，他会发现自己无法跟上自己的想法。当他重新获得控制权时，他发现很难回忆起那种感觉。真奇怪，他心想。我是不是保持着两种人格？一个头脑能 同时容纳两种 人格吗——一个是旧的，另一个是新的？

The session went well. Brian could, access the CPU at will now, use it to extract specific memories. The system was functioning better—although sometimes he would retrieve fragments of knowledge that were hard to comprehend. It was as though they came as suggestions from someone else rather than from his own memories. Occasionally, when he accessed a memory of his earlier, adult self, he would find himself losing track of his own thoughts. When he regained control he found it hard to recall how it had felt. How strange, he thought to himself. Am I maintaining two personalities? Can a single mind have room for two personalities at once—one old, the other new?

探索确实为他的研究节省了大量时间，随着新鲜感逐渐消退，布莱恩的思绪又回到了人工智能中仍然困扰他的最严重问题上。所有导致故障的不同错误——机器最终会陷入一种极端行为或另一种极端行为。

The probing certainly was saving a great deal of time in his research and, as the novelty began to wear off, Brian’s thoughts returned to the most serious problems that still beset him on the AI. All the different bugs that led to failures—to breakdowns in which the machine would end up at one extreme of behavior or another.

“布莱恩——你在吗？”

“Brian—are you there?”

“什么-？”

“What—?”

“欢迎回来。我问了你三次同样的问题。你是不是在胡思乱想？”

“Welcome back. I asked you the same question three times. You were wandering, weren’t you?”

“抱歉。这看起来太难了，笔记里也没什么可以帮我的。我需要的是让一部分大脑观察自己，而其他部分却不知道发生了什么。这将有助于保持系统控制电路的平衡。当系统本身稳定、没有太多变化或学习时，这并不难——但当系统学习新的学习方式时，似乎什么都行不通。我需要的是某种系统，某种可以保持一定控制力的独立子思维。”

“Sorry. It just seems so intractable and there is nothing in the notes to help me out. What I need is to have a part of my mind that is watching itself without the rest of the mind knowing what is happening. Something that would help keep the system’s control circuitry in balance. That’s not particularly hard when the system itself is stable, not changing or learning very much—but nothing seems to work when the system learns new ways to learn. What I need is some system, some sort of separate submind that can maintain a measure of control.”

“听起来很弗洛伊德。”

“Sounds very Freudian.”

“请再说一遍？”

“I beg your pardon?”

“就像西格蒙德·弗洛伊德的理论一样。”

“Like the theories of Sigmund Freud.”

“我不记得在任何人工智能研究中出现过这个名字的人。”

“I don’t recall anyone with that name in any AI research.”

“原因很容易理解。他是 19 世纪 90 年代的一名精神病学家，那时还没有计算机。当他首次提出他的理论时——关于大脑如何由许多不同的机构组成——他给这些机构起了名字，如本我、自我、超我、审查者等等。众所周知，每个正常人都在无意识中不断处理各种冲突、矛盾和不相容的目标。这就是为什么我认为如果你学习弗洛伊德的心理理论，你可能会得到一些反馈。”

“Easy enough to see why. He was a psychiatrist working in the 1890s, before there were any computers. When he first proposed his theories—about how the mind is made of a number of different agencies—he gave them names like id, ego, superego, censor and so on. It is understood that every normal person is constantly dealing, unconsciously, with all sorts of conflicts, contradictions, and incompatible goals. That’s why I thought you might get some feedback if you were to study Freud’s theories of mind.”

“我觉得不错。我们现在就行动吧，把弗洛伊德的所有理论都下载到我的记忆库里。”

“Sounds fine to me. Let’s do it now, download all the Freudian theories into my memory banks.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克很担心。作为一名科学家，她仍然认为植入式计算机的使用是一项实验研究——但布莱恩已经将其视为生活方式中自然的一部分。他不再需要仔细阅读印刷文本。立即将所有内容记在脑子里，然后再处理。

Snaresbrook was concerned. As a scientist, she still regarded the use of the implant computer as an experimental study—but Brian had already absorbed it as a natural part of his lifestyle. No more poring over printed texts for him. Get it all into memory in an instant, then deal with it later.

他没有回到房间，而是在地板上踱步，同时在脑海中思考文本的一部分，又思考另一部分，建立联系并进行修改——然后大声喘着气。

He did not go back to his room, but paced the floor, while in his mind he dipped first into one part of the text, then another, making links and changing them—then gasped out loud.

“一定是这个——真的是这个！这个理论完全符合我的问题。超我似乎是一种目标学习机制，可能在早期进化的印记机制之上进化而来。你知道，康拉德·洛伦兹发现的系统，用于将许多幼年动物置于安全的养育和保护范围内。这些系统在孩子身上产生了一个相对永久、稳定的目标系统。一旦孩子内化了母亲或父亲的形象，这个结构就会在孩子的余生中一直存在。但我们如何为我的人工智能提供超我？考虑一下——如果我们能找到某种方法下载足够多的我自己潜意识价值结构的细节，我们应该能够为我的人工智能下载一个功能齐全的超我。为什么不呢？激活我的每条 K 线和恩宠，感知并记录与它们相关的情感价值。使用这些数据首先构建我有意识的自我形象的表示。然后添加我的自我理想——超我认为我应该成为什么样子。如果我们可以下载它，我们可能在稳定和调节机器智能的道路上会走得更远。”

“This has to be it—really it! A theory that fits my problem perfectly. The superego appears to be a sort of goal-learning mechanism that probably evolved on top of the imprinting mechanisms that evolved earlier. You know, the systems discovered by Konrad Lorenz, that are used to hold many infant animals within a safe sphere of nurture and protection. These produce a relatively permanent, stable goal system in the child. Once a child introjects a mother or father image, that structure can remain there for the rest of that child’s life. But how can we provide my AI with a superego? Consider this—we should be able to download a functioning superego for my AI if we can find some way of downloading enough of the details of my own unconscious value structure. And why not? Activate each of my K-lines and nemes, sense and record the emotional values associated with them. Use that data to first build a representation of my conscious self-image. Then add my self-ideal—what the superego says I ought to be. If we can download that, we might be much further on the way toward being able to stabilize and regulate our machine intelligence.”

“我们开始吧，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克说，“即使还没有人证明这个东西存在。我们只是假设你的脑子里确实有一个完美的记忆。我们也许是有史以来第一个能够找到它的人。看看我们几个月来一直在做的事情，搜索和下载你的记忆和思维过程矩阵。现在我们不妨再往前推一点——只是往回而不是往前。我们可以尝试更多地回溯到你的婴儿期，看看我们是否能找到一些可能与你最早的价值体系相对应的记忆和相关记忆。”

“Let’s do it,” Snaresbrook said. “Even if no one has proven yet that the thing exists. We’ll simply assume that you do indeed have a perfectly fine one inside your head. And we are perhaps the first people ever to be in a position to find it. Look at what we have been doing for months now, searching out and downloading your matrix of memories and thought processes. Now we may as well push a little further—only backward instead of forward in time. We can try to do more backtracking toward your infancy, and see if we can find some nenies and attached memories that might correspond to your earliest value systems.”

“你认为你能做到吗？”

“And you think that you can do this?”

“我认为没有理由不这样做——除非我们寻找的东西根本不存在。无论如何，搜索可能涉及定位另外几十万个旧的 K 线和尼姆。但要小心。在这里，让你接触到如此深埋的活动可能会带来一些严重的危险。我首先想办法使用外部计算机来做到这一点，同时暂时禁用你自己的内部连接机器。这样，我们就能以外部形式记录我们发现的结构，这可能会用于改进罗宾。这将防止实验影响到你，直到我们对自己更有信心为止。”

“I don’t see any reason why not—unless what we’re seeking just doesn’t exist. In any case the search will probably involve locating another few hundred thousand old K-lines and nemes. But cautiously. There might be some serious dangers here, in giving you access to such deeply buried activities. I’ll first want to work up a way to do this by using an external computer, while disabling your own internal connection machine for a while. That way, we’ll have a record of the structures we discover in external form, which might be used in improving Robin. This will prevent the experiments from affecting you until we’re more sure of ourselves.”

“那么——我们就尝试一下吧。”

“Well, then—let’s give it a try.”

二十五
25

2024 年 5 月 31 日

May 31, 2024

 

 

“布莱恩·德莱尼——你整晚都在这里工作吗？昨晚我离开你的时候，你答应过我再给你几分钟就好了。当时是十点。”雪莉冲进实验室，脸上洋溢着不悦。

“Brian Delaney—have you been working here all night? You promised it would just be a few minutes more when I left you here last night. And that was at ten o’clock.” Shelly stamped into the lab radiating displeasure.

布莱恩用手指摩挲着粗糙的胡须，眨着红红的、满怀愧疚的眼睛。语无伦次。

Brian rubbed his fingers over rough revelatory whiskers, blinked through red-rimmed guilty eyes. Equivocated.

“是什么让你这么想的？”

“What makes you think that?”

雪莉张大了鼻孔。“好吧，光是看着你就足以证明这一点了。你看上去很糟糕。除此之外，我试着给你打电话，但没人接。你可以想象，我当时非常担心。”

Shelly flared her nostrils. “Well, just looking at you reveals more than enough evidence. You look terrible. In addition to that I tried to phone you and there was no answer. As you imagine I was more than a little concerned.”

布莱恩抓着腰带，手机不见了。“我肯定是把它放在什么地方了，没听到它响。”

Brian grabbed at his belt where he kept his phone—it was gone. “I must have put it down somewhere, didn’t hear it ring.”

她拿出自己的手机，按下记忆键拨通了他的号码。远处传来一阵嗡嗡声。她把手机放到咖啡机旁边，然后冷冷地把手机还给了他。

She took out her own phone and hit the memory key to dial his number. There was a distant buzzing. She tracked it down beside the coffeemaker. Returned it to him in stony silence.

“谢谢。”

“Thanks.”

“它应该一直就在你身边。我不得不去找你的保镖——他们告诉我你还在这里。”

“It should be near you at all times. I had to go looking for your bodyguards—they told me you were still here.”

“叛徒，”他嘀咕道。

“Traitors,” he muttered.

“他们和我一样担心。没有什么事情比这更重要，不值得你为此牺牲自己的健康。”

“They’re as concerned as I am. Nothing is so important that you have to ruin your health for it.”

“雪莉，事情就是这样。你还记得昨晚你离开时，我们在新管理程序上遇到的问题吗？无论我们昨天做什么，系统都会卷曲并死机。所以我从一个非常简单的程序开始，对彩色块进行分类，然后用不同形状和颜色的块使其复杂化。下次我查看时，管理程序仍在运行——但程序的所有其他部分似乎都已关闭。所以我记录了再次尝试时发生的情况，这次安装了一个自然语言跟踪程序来记录管理器对其他子单元的所有命令。这让事情慢了下来，足以让我发现发生了什么。让我们看看发生了什么。”

“Something is, Shelly, that’s just the point. You remember when you left last night, the trouble we were having with the new manager program? No matter what we did yesterday the system would simply curl up and die. So then I started it out with a very simple program of sorting out colored blocks, then complicated it with blocks of different shapes as well as colors. The next time I looked, the manager program was still running—but all the other parts of the program seemed to have shut down. So I recorded what happened when I tried it again, and this time installed a natural language trace program to record all the manager’s commands to the other subunits. This slowed things down enough for me to discover what was going on. Let’s look at what happened.”

他打开了晚上录制的录音。屏幕上显示人工智能正在快速地对彩色方块进行分类，然后速度变慢——然后几乎不动了，直到最后完全停下来。罗宾三号的低音从扬声器中快速传出。

He turned on the recording he had made during the night. The screen showed the AI rapidly sorting colored blocks, then slowing—then barely moving until it finally stopped completely. The deep bass voice of Robin 3 poured rapidly from the speaker.

“…K 行 8997，输入 10983 需要响应 — 您太慢了 — 立即响应 — 禁止。选择子问题 384。接受来自 K-4093 的响应，禁止来自 K-3724 和 K-2314 的较慢响应，选择子问题 385。来自 K-2615 和 K-1488 的响应存在冲突 — 禁止两者。选择…”

“…K-line 8997, response needed to input 10983—you are too slow—respond immediately—inhibiting. Selecting subproblem 384. Response accepted from K-4093, inhibiting slower responses from K-3724 and K-2314, Selecting subproblem 385. Responses from K-2615 and K-1488 are in conflict—inhibiting both. Selecting…”

布莱恩关掉了电视。“你明白了吗？”

Brian switched it off. “Did you understand that?”

“没有。只不过程序忙着阻止某些事情——”

“Not really. Except that the program was busy inhibiting things——”

“是的，这就是它的问题所在。它本应从经验中学习，奖励成功的下属单位，抑制失败的下属单位。但经理的成功门槛设得太高，以至于它只接受完美和即时的服从。因此，它只奖励反应迅速的单位，而切断反应较慢的单位的联系——即使他们试图做的事情最终可能会更好。”

“Yes, and that was its problem. It was supposed to learn from experience, by rewarding successful subunits and inhibiting the ones that failed. But the manager’s threshold for success had been set so high that it would accept only perfect and instant compliance. So it was rewarding only the units that responded quickly, and disconnecting the slower ones—even if what they were trying to do might have been better in the end.”

“我明白了。这会引发多米诺骨牌效应吗？因为每个子单元受到抑制，会削弱其他单元与它的连接？”

“I see. And that started a domino effect because as each subunit was inhibited, that weakened other units’ connection to it?”

“正是如此。然后其他单位的反应也变得越来越慢，直到它们依次受到抑制。不久之后，管理程序就将它们全部杀死了。”

“Exactly. And then the responses of those other units became slower until they got inhibited in turn. Before long the manager program had killed off them all.”

“多么可怕的想法！你实际上是在说，它是自杀的。”

“What a horrible thought! You are saying, really, that it committed suicide.”

“一点也不。”他的声音嘶哑，疲惫让他脾气暴躁。“你这么说，就是在拟人化。机器不是人。一个电路断开另一个电路到底有什么可怕的？天啊——这里除了一堆电子元件和软件什么都没有。因为没有人类参与，所以不可能发生什么可怕的事情，这是很明显的——”

“Not at all.” His voice was hoarse, fatigue abraded his temper. “When you say that, you are just being anthropomorphic. A machine is not a person. What on earth is horrible about one circuit disconnecting another circuit? Christ—there’s nothing here but a bunch of electronic components and software. Since there are no human beings involved nothing horrible can possibly occur, that’s pretty obvious—”

“不要用那种方式跟我说话，也不要用那种语气！”

“Don’t speak to me that way or use that tone of voice!”

布莱恩的脸气得通红，然后垂下了眼睛。“对不起，我收回刚才的话。我觉得我有点累了。”

Brian’s face reddened with anger, then he dropped his eyes. “I’m sorry, I take that back. I’m a little tired, I think.”

“你以为——我知道。我接受道歉。我也同意，我当时是拟人化的。问题不在于你对我说了什么——而在于你说话的方式。现在我们别再互相指责了，出去呼吸新鲜空气吧。然后带你去睡觉。”

“You think—I know. Apology accepted. And I agree, I was being anthropomorphic. It wasn’t what you said to me—it was how you said it. Now let’s stop snapping at each other and get some fresh air. And get you to bed.”

“好吧——不过让我先看看这个。”

“All right—but let me look at this first.”

布莱恩径直走到终端机前，开始追溯机器人的内部计算。屏幕上出现了一张又一张的图表。最后他郁闷地点了点头。“当然是另一个错误。在我修复了最后一个错误后，它才出现。你还记得吗，我设置了一些功能来抑制过度抑制，这样机器人就不会自动关闭。但现在它走向了另一个极端。它不知道什么时候该停下来。

Brian went straight to the terminal and proceeded to retrace the robot’s internal computations. Chart after chart appeared on the screen. Eventually he nodded gloomily. “Another bug of course. It only showed up after I fixed the last one. You remember, I set things up to suppress excessive inhibition, so that the robot would not spontaneously shut itself down. But now it goes to the opposite extreme. It doesn’t know when it ought to stop.

“这种人工智能似乎非常擅长回答简单的问题，但前提是答案可以通过一些浅显的推理找到。但你看到了当它不知道答案时会发生什么。它开始随机搜索，迷失了方向，不知道什么时候停下来。你可能会说它不知道它不知道什么。”

“This AI seems to be pretty good at answering straightforward questions, but only when the answer can be found with a little shallow reasoning. But you saw what happened when it didn’t know the answer. It began random searching, lost its way, didn’t know when to stop. You might say that it didn’t know what it didn’t know.”

“在我看来，它简直就是疯了。”

“It seemed to me that it simply went mad.”

“是的，你可以这么说。我们有很多词来形容人类思维缺陷——偏执狂、紧张症、恐惧症、神经衰弱、非理性。我想我们需要一套新的词来形容我们的机器人将拥有的所有新缺陷。而且我们没有理由期望任何新版本在第一次启动时就能正常工作。在这种情况下，发生的事情是它试图将所有专家系统一起用于同一个问题。管理器没有足够的力量来抑制不适当的系统。所有这些混乱的词语表明，它正在抓住任何可能引导它解决需要解决的问题的关联——无论表面上看起来多么不可能。它还表明，当一种方法失败时，这个东西不知道什么时候放弃。即使这个人工智能有效，也没有规则，它必须按照我们的条件保持理智。”

“Yes, you could say that. We have lots of words for human-mind bugs—paranoias, catatonias, phobias, neuroses, irrationalities. I suppose we’ll need new sets of words for all the new bugs that our robots will have. And we have no reason to expect that any new version should work the first time it’s turned on. In this case, what happened was that it tried to use all of its Expert Systems together on the same problem. The manager wasn’t strong enough to suppress the inappropriate ones. All those jumbles of words showed that it was grasping at any and every association that might conceivably have guided it toward the problem it needed to solve—no matter how unlikely on the face of it. It also showed that when one approach failed, the thing didn’t know when to give up. Even if this AI worked there is no rule,that it had to be sane on our terms.”

布莱恩揉了揉长满胡茬的下巴，看着现在安静下来的机器。“我们再仔细看看。”他指着机器上的图表。“你可以在这里看到这次发生了什么。在 Rob-3.1 中，抑制太多，所以一切都关闭了。所以我改变了这些参数，现在抑制不够了。”

Brian rubbed his bristly jaw and looked at the now silent machine. “Let’s look more closely here.” He pointed to the chart on the machine. “You can see right here what happened this time. In Rob-3.1 there was too much inhibition, so everything shut down. So I changed these parameters and now there’s not enough inhibition.”

“那么解决方案是什么？”

“So what’s the solution?”

“答案是没有答案。不，我的意思不是任何神秘的东西。我的意思是这里的经理必须拥有更多的知识。正是因为没有魔法，没有通用的答案。没有适用于所有情况的简单解决方案——因为所有情况都不同。一旦你认识到这一点，一切都会变得清晰得多！这个经理必须以知识为基础。然后它才能学会该做什么！”

“The answer is that there is no answer. No, I don’t mean anything mystical. I mean that the manager here has to have more knowledge. Precisely because there’s no magic, no general answer. There’s no simple fix that will work in all cases—because all cases are different. And once you recognize that, everything is much clearer! This manager must be knowledge-based. And then it can learn what to do!”

“那么你的意思是，我们必须让经理通过回忆过去有效的策略来了解在每种情况下应该使用哪种策略？”

“Then you’re saying that we must make a manager to learn which strategy to use in each situation, by remembering what worked in the past?”

“没错。与其试图找到一个始终有效的固定公式，不如让它从经验中逐一学习。因为我们想要一台可以自行智能化的机器，这样我们就不必永远待在它身边，一有错误就去修理它。相反，我们必须让它学会在出现新错误时立即修复它们。让它自己学习，不需要我们的帮助。”

“Exactly. Instead of trying to find a fixed formula that always works, let’s make it learn from experience, case by case. Because we want a machine that’s intelligent on its own, so that we don’t have to hang around forever, fixing it whenever anything goes wrong. Instead we must give it some ways to learn to fix new bugs as soon as they come up. By itself, without our help.”

“所以现在我知道该怎么做了。还记得它似乎陷入了循环，重复着关于红色的相同事情吗？我们很容易看出它没有取得任何进展。它看不到自己被卡住了，正是因为被卡住了。它无法跳出那个循环，看看它在更大范围内做了什么。我们可以通过添加一个记录器来记住它最近所做的事情的历史记录来解决这个问题。还有一个时钟，可以频繁中断程序，这样它就可以查看该记录，看看它是否一直在重复自己。”

“So now I know just what to do. Remember when it seemed stuck in a loop, repeating the same things about the color red? It was easy for us to see that it wasn’t making any progress. It couldn’t see that it was stuck, precisely because of being stuck. It couldn’t jump out of that loop to see what it was doing on a larger scale. We can fix that by adding a recorder to remember the history of what it has been doing recently. And also a clock that interrupts the program frequently, so that it can look at that recording to see if it has been repeating itself.”

“或者更好的是，我们可以添加第二个处理器，让其始终在同一时间运行，并观察第一个处理器。B 大脑观察 A 大脑。”

“Or even better we could add a second processor that is always running at the same time, looking at the first one. A B-brain watching an A-brain.”

“也许甚至还有 C 脑，看看 B 脑是否卡住了。该死！我刚想起来我的一个旧笔记上写着，‘在这里使用 B 脑来抑制循环。’我当然希望我第一次就写了更清晰的笔记。我最好开始设计那个 B 脑。”

“And perhaps even a C-brain to see if the B-brain has got stuck. Damn! I just remembered that one of my old notes said, ‘Use the B-brain here to suppress looping.’ I certainly wish I had written clearer notes the first time around. I better get started on designing that B-brain.”

“但你最好现在不要这么做！以你现在的状态，你只会让事情变得更糟。”

“But you’d better not do it now! In your present state, you’ll just make it worse.”

“你说得对。该睡觉了。我会去的，别担心——但我想先吃点东西。”

“You’re right. Bedtime. I’ll get there, don’t worry—but I want to get something to eat first.”

“我跟你一起去，喝杯咖啡。”

“I’ll go with you, have a coffee.”

布莱恩把它们放了出来，对着明亮的阳光眨了眨眼睛。“听起来你好像不信任我。”

Brian let them out and blinked at the bright sunshine. “That sounds as though you don’t trust me.”

“我不知道。昨晚之后就不知道了！”

“I don’t. Not after last night!”

谢莉小口喝着咖啡，布莱恩则吃着德克萨斯早餐——牛排、鸡蛋和烙饼。他没能吃完，叹了口气，把盘子推开。除了两名刚下班的警卫坐在远处墙壁的一张桌子旁外，食堂里就只有他们俩。

Shelly sipped at her coffee while Brian worked his way through a Texas breakfast—steak, eggs and flapjacks. He couldn’t quite finish it all, sighed and pushed the plate away. Except for two guards just off duty, sitting at a table on the far wall, they were alone in the mess hall.

“我感觉自己没那么不近人情了，”他说。“再来点咖啡？”

“I’m feeling slightly less inhuman,” he said. “More coffee?”

“我受够了，谢谢你。你认为你能修复你那颗失灵的人工智能吗？”

“I’ve had more than enough, thank you. Do you think that you can fix your screw-loose AI?”

“没有。我对这个东西太恼火了，所以我把它的内存都抹掉了。我们必须重写一些程序才能再次加载它。这将需要几个小时。即使是 LAMA-5 的汇编程序在这么大的系统上也要花很长时间。这次我要在运行新版本之前制作一个备份。”

“No. I was getting so annoyed at the thing that I’ve wiped its memory. We will have to rewrite some of the program before we load it again. Which will take a couple of hours. Even LAMA-5’s assembler takes a long time on a system this large. And this time I’m going to make a backup copy before we run the new version.”

“备份意味着复制。当你真的得到一个可以正常运作的人形人工智能时——你认为你也能复制它吗？”

“A backup means a duplicate. When you do get a functioning humanoid artificial intelligence—do you think that you will be able to copy it as well?”

“当然。无论它做什么——它仍然只是一个程序。程序的每个副本都是完全相同的。你为什么问这个？”

“Of course. Whatever it does—it will still just be a program. Every copy of a program is absolutely identical. Why do you ask?”

“我想，这是身份问题。第二个人工智能会和第一个一样吗？”

“It’s a matter of identity, I guess. Will the second AI be the same as the first?”

“是的——但只是在被复制的那一刻。一旦它开始运行，开始独立思考，它就会开始改变。记住，我们就是我们的记忆。当我们忘记某件事，或者学到新东西，我们会产生新的想法或建立新的联系——我们会改变。我们是不同的人。这同样适用于人工智能。”

“Yes—but only at the instant it is copied. As soon as it begins to run, to think for itself, it will start changing. Remember, we are our memories. When we forget something, or learn something new, we produce a new thought or make a new connection—we change. We are someone different. The same will apply to an AI.”

“你能确定吗？”她怀疑地问道。

“Can you be sure of that?” she asked doubtfully.

“肯定的。因为这就是思维的运作方式。这意味着我在加权记忆方面还有很多工作要做。这也是为什么许多早期版本的 Robin 失败的原因。我们之前讨论过的信用分配问题。仅通过短期刺激-反应-奖励方法进行学习是远远不够的——因为这只能解决简单的短期问题。相反，必须进行更大规模的反思分析，在这种分析中，你要从更长远的角度思考自己的表现，以识别哪些策略真正有效，哪些策略导致了岔路，这些举动似乎取得了进展，但最终却走进了死胡同。”

“Positive. Because that is how mind functions. Which means I have a lot of work to do in weighting memory. It’s the same reason why so many earlier versions of Robin failed. The credit assignment problem that we talked about before. It is really not enough to learn just by short-term stimulus-response-reward methods—because this will solve only simple, short-term problems. Instead, there must be a larger scale reflective analysis, in which you think over your performance on a longer scale, to recognize which strategies really worked, and which of them led to sidetracks, moves that seemed to make progress but eventually led to dead ends.”

“您说的头脑听起来就像——嗯——洋葱！”

“You make the mind sound like—well—an onion!”

“是的。”想到这里，他笑了。“这是一个很好的比喻。层层叠加，相互关联。人类记忆不仅仅是联想，将情况、反应和奖励联系起来。它也是前瞻性和反思性的。建立的联系还必须与长期目标和计划有关。这就是为什么短期记忆和长期记忆之间存在这种重要区别。为什么长期记忆需要大约一个小时的时间？因为必须有一个缓冲期来决定哪些行为实际上足够有益，值得记录下来。”

“It is.” He smiled at the thought. “A good analogy. Layer within layer and all interconnected. Human memory is not merely associative, connecting situations, responses and rewards. It is also prospective and reflective. The connections made must also be involved with long-range goals and plans. That is why there is this important separation between short-term and long-term memory. Why does it take about an hour to long-term memorize anything? Because there must be a buffer period to decide which behaviors actually were beneficial enough to record.”

突然间，他感到一阵疲惫。咖啡已经凉了，他的头开始疼，抑郁的情绪正在逼近。雪莉看到这一幕，轻轻地摸了摸他的手。

Sudden fatigue hit him. The coffee was cold; his head was beginning to ache; depression was closing in. Shelly saw this, lightly touched his hand.

“该休息了。”她说。他懒洋洋地点点头表示同意，然后费力地把椅子往后推。

“Time to retire,” she said. He nodded sluggish agreement and struggled to push back the chair.

二十六
26

2024 年 6 月 19 日

June 19, 2024

 

 

贝尼科夫敲门时，雪莉打开了公寓的门。“布莱恩刚进来，”她说，“我要给他拿瓶啤酒。你也是吗？”

Shelly opened her apartment door when Benicoff knocked. “Brian just came in,” she said, “and I’m getting him a beer. You too?”

“请。”

“Please.”

“进来看看吧——毕竟你花了这么多钱。”她领着我走进客厅，这里军营的痕迹已被仔细清除。落地窗帘是用彩色手工编织的布料制成的。地毯与窗帘图案的深橙色相得益彰。丹麦柚木家具的纤细线条与地毯相得益彰，与占据了大部分墙壁的后立体派绘画的绚丽色彩形成鲜明对比。

“Come in and take a look—after all you paid for it.” She led the way into the living room where all traces of the army barracks had been carefully removed. The floor-to-ceiling curtains that framed the window were made from colorful handwoven fabric. The carpeting picked up the dark orange from the curtain pattern. The slim lines of the Danish teak furniture blended pleasantly with this, providing a contrast to the spectacular colors of the post-Cubist painting that covered most of one wall.

“太令人印象深刻了，”本说。“我现在明白为什么财务部门这么尖叫了。”

“Most impressive,” Ben said. “I can see now why the accounts department was screaming.”

“这里不贵——布料和地毯都是以色列设计的，但阿拉伯制造的，一点也不贵。这幅画是我从一位艺术家朋友那里借来的，以帮助她出售。大部分钱都用来买高科技厨房了。想看看吗？”

“Not at this—the fabric and rugs are Israeli-designed but Arab-manufactured and not at all expensive. The painting is on loan from an artist friend of mine, to help her sell it. Most of the money went for the high-tech kitchen. Want to see it?”

“喝完啤酒之后，我最好做好准备。”

“After the beer. I better brace myself for it.”

“今天要解释你邀请我去吃泰式午餐的秘密吗？”布莱恩一边说，一边舒舒服服地靠在软垫扶手椅里。“你知道，雪莉和我都是 Megalobe 的囚犯，直到你找到凶手为止。那么我们怎么才能去你那家泰国餐厅呢？”

“Going to explain the mystery of your invitation to a Thai lunch today?” Brian said, lolling back comfortably in the depths of a padded armchair. “You know that Shelly and I are prisoners of Megalobe until you run down the killers. So how do we get out to this Thai restaurant of yours?”

“如果你不能去泰国，泰国怎么会来找你呢。当你告诉我你想让我了解你的人工智能的最新进展时，我就觉得我们应该开个派对。谢谢，雪莉。”

“If you can’t get to Thailand, why Thailand will come to you. As soon as you told me you wanted to bring me up to date on your AI I thought we ought to make a party of it. Thanks, Shelly.”

本深吸了一口冰镇特卡特啤酒，叹了口气。“好东西。这一切都始于上周的一次安全检查。我和军事情报局一起审查任何要调到这里来的士兵。就在那时，我发现一等兵拉特·弗罗阿参军是为了离开他父亲的餐馆。他说他受够了做饭，想去打仗。但吃了一年军餐后，他非常乐意在这里的厨房做一顿真正的泰国菜，如果我能弄到食材的话。我做到了。厨师们同意了，部队也期待着这一变化。两点过后，我们将拥有自己的食堂。我们将成为实验鼠，如果我们同意的话，拉特答应今晚给其他人提供食物。”

Ben took a deep swig of cold Tecate and sighed. “Good stuff. It all began with a security check last week. I sit in with Military Intelligence when they vet any soldiers to be transferred here. That was when I discovered that Private First Class Lat Phroa had joined the army to get away from his father’s restaurant. He said he had enough of cooking and wanted some action. But after a year of army food he was more than happy to cook a real Thai meal in the kitchen here, if I could get the ingredients. Which I did. The cooks went along with it and the troops are looking forward to the change. We’ll have the mess hall to ourselves after two. We’ll be the guinea pigs and if we approve, Lat promised to feed everyone else tonight.”

“我等不及了，”雪莉说。“并不是说这里的食物不好——只是我想换换口味。”

“I can’t wait,” Shelly said. “Not that the food here is bad—but I would love a change.”

“调查进行得怎么样了？”布莱恩问道。他一直想着这个问题。本皱着眉头，喝着啤酒。

“How is the investigation going?” Brian asked. It was never far from his thoughts. Ben frowned into his beer.

“我希望我能带来一些好消息，但我们似乎已经走进死胡同了。我们有亚历克斯·托斯的军事记录。他是一名出色的飞行员，有很多推荐信。但他也是一个边缘酒鬼和麻烦制造者。战争结束后，他们尽快把他赶了出去。在他当时提供的地址没有他的踪迹。联邦调查局通过他的飞行员执照找到了一些他的就业记录，保持最新状态。但他本人已经消失了。线索一片空白。达斯蒂·罗兹的故事得到证实。他被骗了，然后被留在风中晾干。绝对没有办法追踪存入他账户的钱。”

“I wish I could bring some good news, but we seem to have hit a dead end. We have Alex Toth’s military record. He was an outstanding pilot, plenty of recommendations for that. But he is also a borderline alcoholic and a troublemaker. After the war they threw him out as fast as they could. No trace of him at the address he gave at the time. The FBI has found some records of his employment through his pilot’s license, kept up to date. But the man himself has vanished. The trail is ice cold. Dusty Rhodes’ story checks out. He was conned into it and then left to hang out and dry in the wind. There is absolutely no way to trace the money that was paid into his account.”

“罗德斯会怎么样？”雪莉问道。

“What’s going to happen to Rhodes?” Shelly asked.

“现在什么都没有了。他们给他的剩余钱已被扣押用于犯罪受害者基金，他签署了一份完整的声明，记录了发生的一切、他所做的一切。他将来会保持清白，否则将面临多项指控。我们希望在调查仍在进行时尽可能保持这件事的低调。”

“Nothing now. The remaining money they gave him has been sequestered for the crime victims’ fund and he signed a complete statement of everything that happened, everything he did. He’ll keep his nose clean in the future or will be hit with a number of charges. We want to keep this thing as quiet as we can while the investigation is still in progress.”

雪莉点点头，转身对布莱恩说：“你必须告诉我最新情况。你有没有让那个 B 脑子运转起来？”

Shelly nodded and turned to Brian. “You must bring me up to date. Did you ever get that B-brain to work?”

“我确实这么做了，有时它的效果非常好。但还不够可靠。它总是以令人着迷和奇怪的方式崩溃。”

“Indeed I did, and sometimes it works amazingly well. But not often enough to trust very far. It keeps breaking down in fascinating and peculiar ways.”

“还是？我认为使用 LAMA-5 会使调试更容易。”

“Still? I thought that using LAMA-5 made debugging easier.”

“确实如此——但我认为这更多的是设计问题。如你所知，B 脑应该监视 A 脑，在需要时做出改变，以使其远离各种麻烦。理论上，当 A 脑不知道发生了什么时，这种方法最有效。但似乎随着罗宾的 A 脑变得更聪明，它学会了检测这种篡改——然后试图找到方法来改变一切。这最终演变成一场权力斗争，两个大脑争夺控制权。”

“It certainly does—but I think that this is more a problem of design. As you know, the B-brain is supposed to monitor the A-brain, make changes when needed to keep it out of various kinds of trouble. Theoretically this works best when the A-brain is unaware of what is happening. But it seems that as Robin’s A-brain became smarter it learned to detect that tampering—then tried to find ways to change things back. This ended up in a struggle for power as the two brains fought for control.”

“这听起来就像人类的精神分裂症或多重人格！”

“It sounds like human schizophrenia or multiple personalities!”

“确实如此。人类的疯狂反映在机器的疯狂中，反之亦然。为什么不呢？无论是机器还是人，大脑出现故障都会因相同的原因出现相同的症状。”

“Exactly so. Human insanity is mirrored in machine madness and vice versa. Why not? A malfunctioning brain will have the same symptoms from the same cause, machine or man.”

“被盒子里的疯子大脑所阻碍，一定很令人沮丧。”

“It must be depressing, being set back by lunatic brains in a box.”

“不是。从某种程度上来说，这其实是令人鼓舞的！因为，机器人犯的错误越像人类，我们就越接近人类机器智能。”

“Not really. In a way, it’s actually encouraging! Because, the more the robot’s foul-ups resemble human ones, the closer we are getting to humanlike machine intelligence.”

“如果事情进展得这么顺利——你为什么这么沮丧？”

“If it is going that well—why are you so upset?”

“这很明显吗？好吧，可能是因为我终于搞定了我们找到的笔记。我几乎搞定了笔记上描述的所有内容。以至于现在我正在游向未知的海洋。”

“Is it obvious? Well, it’s probably because I’ve finally come to the end of the notes we retrieved. I’ve worked through just about everything that those notes described. So much so that now I am swimming out into uncharted seas.”

“有没有规定说，你们实验室里的人工智能必须和被盗的人工智能一样？”

“Is there any rule that the AI in your lab must be the same as the one that was stolen?”

“是的，除了一些小细节外，基本如此。问题是它有太多错误，我担心我们只能困在当地的山峰上。”

“Yes, pretty much so, except for some minor details. And the trouble is that it has so many bugs that I am afraid that we’re stuck on a local peak.”

“你是什么意思？”本说。

“What do you mean?” Ben said.

“打个简单的比方。把科研人员想象成一个盲人登山者。他不断向上攀登，最终到达了山顶，无法再往上攀登。但是，由于他什么都看不见，所以他根本不知道他还没有到达山顶。那只是一座小山的山顶——一条死路。成功是不可能的——除非他再次下山，寻找另一条路。”

“Just a simple analogy. Think of a scientific researcher as a blind mountain climber. He keeps climbing up the mountain and eventually reaches a peak and can climb no higher. But because he can’t see anything he has no way of knowing that he’s not at the top of the mountain at all. It is merely the peak of a local hill—a dead end. Success is then not possible—unless he goes back down the mountain again and looks for another path.”

“有道理，”本说，“你是说你刚刚制造的人工智能——可能和被盗的那个几乎一模一样——可能停留在智力的局部顶峰，而不是更高的顶峰？”

“Makes sense,” Ben said. “Are you telling me that the AI you have just built—which is probably almost the same as the one that was stolen—may be stuck on a local peak of intelligence and not on some much higher summit?”

“恐怕就这样了。”

“I’m afraid that’s it.”

本高兴地高声唱道：“但这是最好的消息了！”

Ben yodeled happily. “But that is the best news ever!”

“你绕过弯角了吗？”

“Have you gone around the twist?”

“想一想。这意味着偷走你旧型号的人也必须以同样的方式被困住——但他甚至不知道这一点。而你可以去完善你的机器。到那时我们就会得到它——而他们不会！”

“Think for a second. This means that whoever stole your old model must also be stuck in about the same way—but he won’t even know it. While you can go and perfect your machine. When that happens we’ll have it—and they won’t!”

布莱恩听完后，脸上露出了灿烂的笑容。“你当然是对的。这是最好的消息。那些骗子被困住了——而我将继续推进工作。”

As this sunk in a broad grin spread across Brian’s face. “Of course you’re right. This is the best news ever. Those crooks are stuck—while I’m going to push right ahead with the work.”

“现在不行——午饭后！”雪莉放下酒杯，指着门说道。“出去。两点多了，我饿坏了。先吃饭，一会儿再说。”

“Not at this moment you’re not—after lunch!” Shelly said, putting down her wineglass and pointing to the door. “Out. It’s after two and I’m starving. Eat first, talk later.”

吃完 See Khrong Moo sam Rot（尽管名字如此，但味道绝对美味——酸甜咸咸的排骨）后，他们甚至还吃了一些南瓜蒸蛋奶冻作为甜点。

After eating See Khrong Moo sam Rot—which despite its name was absolutely delicious—sweet, sour and salty spareribs— they even managed some custard steamed in pumpkin for dessert.

“我再也不吃军粮了，”布莱恩开心地呻吟着，揉着自己的腹部。

“I’ll never eat army chow again,” Brian groaned happily and rubbed his midriff.

“告诉厨师，让他开心起来，”雪莉说。“这就是我要做的。”

“Tell that to the cook—make his day,” Shelly said. “That’s what I’m going to do.”

拉特·弗罗亚对他们的称赞表示了应有的认可，点头表示同意。“味道不错，不是吗？如果其他部队喜欢，我会努力让这种食物成为常规菜单。哪怕只是为了我自己。”

Lat Phroa took their praise as his due, nodding in agreement. “It was pretty good, wasn’t it? If the rest of the troops like it I’m going to work hard to get this kind of chow in the regular menu. If only for my own sake.”

本把他们留在那里，然后他们漫步走回实验室，消化掉一些午餐。

Ben left them there and they walked off some of the lunch by strolling back to the lab.

“我很热情，但也有顾虑，”布莱恩说。“游向未知的海洋。到目前为止，我一直在按照图表和我自己笔记行事，但它们已经用完了。十四岁的我以为我可以在二十四岁的我失败的地方取得成功，这有点妄自尊大。”

“I’m enthusiastic—but apprehensive,” Brian said. “Swimming out into uncharted seas. Up until now I have been following the charts, my own notes—but they have just run out. It’s a little presumptuous of fourteen-year-old me to think that I can succeed where the twenty-four-year-old me pooped out.”

“别那么肯定。斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士坚持认为你现在比以前更聪明了——你的植入物赋予了你一些杰出的能力。此外，在你与斯纳尔斯布鲁克合作的研究中——分析你自己的大脑——你可能比一群心理学家更了解自己。布莱恩，我很清楚你正在走向成功。给这个世界带来一些新的东西。

“Don’t be so sure. Dr. Snaresbrook maintains that you’re smarter now than ever before—your implants have given you some outstanding abilities. And furthermore, in the work you’ve done with Snaresbrook—analyzing your own brain—you’ve probably discovered more about yourself than a squad of psychologists ever could. It’s clear to me that you’re getting there, Brian. Bringing something new into the world.

“真正像人类一样的机器智能。”

“A truly humanlike machine intelligence.”

 

 

二十七
27

2024 年 7 月 22 日
July 22, 2024

 

 

本醒来后在手机里发现了这条信息，是布莱恩的声音。

Ben found the message in his phone when he woke up. It was Brian’s voice.

“本——现在是凌晨四点，我们终于拿到了！ 罗宾的数据差不多够了，斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士完成了工作，从我的大脑中解码了更多材料。这是一项艰巨的工作，但我们设法完成了它。 所以现在，理论上，罗宾包含了我的超我的副本 ，我已经设置计算机重新组装罗宾的所有 程序，以尝试将旧内容与新内容整合在一起。需要 睡一会儿。如果你有时间，请在 午餐后来实验室进行演示。完毕——晚安。”

“Ben—it’s four in the morning and we have it at last! The data in Robin was almost enough, and Dr. Snaresbrook finished the job by decoding some more material from my brain. It was an awful job, but we managed to get it done. So now, theoretically, Robin contains a copy of my superego and I’ve set the computer to reassembling all of Robin’s programs to try to integrate the old stuff with the new. Need some sleep. If you can make it please come to the lab after lunch for a demo. Over and out—and good night.”

“我们成功了，”布莱恩在实验室见面时说道。“已经下载到罗宾的数据已经足够了。斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士完成了这项工作，添加了一个模板，一个下载的我超我的副本。你可以说，这是我大脑最高级别控制功能运作方式的副本。所有与控制无关的记忆都被剥离，直到我们得到一个我们希望的、功能齐全的智能模板。接下来是将这些程序与已经在运行的人工智能程序集成起来的大工程。这并不容易，但我们成功了。但在此过程中，我们经历了一些惊人的失败——其中一些你已经知道了。”

“We’ve done it,” Brian said when they met in the laboratory. “The data already downloaded into Robin was almost enough. It was Dr. Snaresbrook who finished the job, adding what might be called a template, a downloaded copy of my superego. You could say that it was a copy of how the highest-level control functions of my brain operate. All memory that was not associated with control was stripped away until we had what we hoped would be a template of a functioning intelligence. Then came the big job of integrating these programs with the AI programs that were already running. This was not easy but we prevailed. But along the way we had some spectacular failures—some of which you already know about.”

“就像上周实验室的灾难一样。”

“Like the lab wreck last week.”

“还有周二的那次。不过那都是过去的事情了。斯文现在可真是胆小鬼了。”

“And the one on Tuesday. But that is all in the past. Sven is now a real pussycat.”

“斯文？”

“Sven?”

“实际上是 Robin 7 号，我们发现 6.9 无法访问我们所需的所有内存。”

“Really Robin number 7, after we found out that 6.9 couldn’t access all the memory we needed.”

“这都要怪雪莉，”布莱恩说。“她声称我说‘seven’听起来更像‘sven’。所以当我不注意的时候，她就用瑞典口音编程。Sven 这个名字就流传下来了。”

“Blame Shelly for that,” Brian said. “She claims that when I say ‘seven’ it sounds more like ‘sven.’ So when I wasn’t looking she programmed in a Swedish accent. The name Sven stuck.”

“我想听听你关于瑞典人工智能的演讲！”

“I want to hear your Swedish AI talk!”

“抱歉。我们不得不去掉口音。歇斯底里太多，工作完成得不够。”

“Sorry. We had to take the accent out. Too much hysteria and not enough work getting done.”

“听起来不错。我什么时候可以见到你的人工智能？”

“Sounds good to me. When do I get to meet your AI?”

“现在就去。不过我得先叫醒斯文。”布莱恩指着一动不动的遥控机器人。

“Right now. But first I’ll have to wake Sven up.” Brain pointed to the motionless telerobot.

“唤醒还是开机？”本问道。

“Wake up or turn on?” Ben asked.

“当然，电脑一直开着。但新的内存管理方案与人类睡眠非常相似。它会整理一天的记忆，解决冲突并删除冗余。没有必要在你已经知道的事情上浪费更多的内存。”布莱恩提高了声音。“斯文，你现在可以醒了。”

“The computer stays on all the time, of course. But the new memory management scheme turned out to be very much like human sleep. It sorts through a day’s memories to resolve any conflicts and to delete redundancies. No point in wasting more memory on things that you already know.” Brian raised his voice. “Sven, you can wake up now.”

三个镜头盖咔嗒一声打开了，斯文转过身来，双腿动了动。“下午好，布莱恩和雪莉。还有陌生人。”

The three lens covers clicked open and the legs stirred as Sven turned toward them. “Good afternoon, Brian and Shelly. And stranger.”

“我是本。”

“This is Ben.”

“很高兴认识你，本。这是你的名字还是姓氏？”

“A pleasure to meet you, Ben. Is that your given name or family name?”

“昵称，”本说道。罗宾又把他忘记了——这是第三次了——因为记忆被改变了。“全名，阿尔弗雷德·J·贝尼科夫。”

“Nickname,” Ben said. Robin had forgotten him again— for the third time—as its memory was changed. “Complete name, Alfred J. Benicoff.”

“很高兴见到您，贝尼科夫女士或先生。”

“A pleasure to meet you, Ms. or Mr. Benicoff.”

本扬起了眉毛，布莱恩笑了。

Ben raised his eyebrows and Brian laughed.

“斯文还没有整合所有与性别识别相关的社会知识。事实上，在很多方面，他都是从零开始，有着全新的优先事项。最重要的是完整性。我希望斯文拥有与成长中的孩子一样全面的智力。现在，就像一个孩子一样，我想教他如何安全地过马路。我们现在要去散步——你想一起去吗？”

“Sven has still not integrated all the social knowledge involved with recognizing sexual distinctions. In fact, in many ways, it is starting from scratch, with entirely new priorities. The main thing is completeness first. I want Sven to have as well rounded an intelligence as that of a growing child. And right now, like a child, I want to teach him how to safely cross streets. We’re going for a walk now—would you like to come?”

本看着杂乱的电子机械，眉毛竖了起来。布莱恩看着他的表情笑了笑，指了指实验室的另一端。

Ben looked at the clutter of electronic machinery and his eyebrows shot up. Brian laughed at his expression and pointed to the other end of the lab.

“虚拟现实。我简直不敢相信它在过去十年里进步了这么多。我们会穿上那些数据服，斯文会通过电子方式加入我们。雪莉会监督模拟器。”

“Virtual reality. I can’t believe how much it’s improved in the last ten years. We’ll get into those datasuits and Sven will join us electronically. Shelly will supervise the simulators.”

服装的后背打开，布莱恩和本脱下鞋子，踏入其中。他们的腰部被悬挂起来，因此他们可以边走边转身。二维跑步机地板让他们的脚可以向任何方向移动，而靴子里的其他效应器则模拟了正在模拟的地形的形状和纹理。轻如羽毛的头盔随着他们的头部转动，而他们看到的屏幕则显示了完全由计算机生成的场景。本抬头看见了树梢上方的华盛顿纪念碑。

The suits opened at the back; Brian and Ben took off their shoes and stepped in. They were suspended at the waist so they could turn and twist as they walked. The two-dimensional treadmill floor panels let their feet move in any direction, while other effectors inside the boots simulated the shapes and textures of whatever terrain was being simulated. The featherweight helmets turned with their heads, while the screens they looked into displayed the totally computer-generated scene. Ben looked up and saw the Washington Monument above the treetops.

“我们在雾谷，”他说。

“We’re in Foggy Bottom,” he said.

“为什么不呢？城市的详细信息都在计算机内存中——这让斯文有机会对付那些糟糕的地区司机。”

“Why not? Details of the city are in the computer’s memory—and this gives Sven a chance to deal with the rotten District drivers.”

幻象近乎完美。斯文站在他身边，转动眼睛环顾四周。本转向布莱恩的形象——只是那不是布莱恩。

The illusion was almost perfect. Sven stood erect next to him, swiveling its eyes to look around. Ben turned to the image of Brian—only it wasn’t Brian.

“布莱恩——你是个女孩——一个黑人女孩！”

“Brian—you’re a girl—a black girl!”

“为什么不呢？我在虚拟现实中的形象是电脑生成的，所以我可以是任何人。这给斯文带来了额外的好处，让他认识了新朋友、女人、少数群体、任何人。我们去散散步好吗？”

“Why not? My image here in virtual reality is computer generated so I can be anything. This gives Sven an extra bonus of meeting new people, women, minority groups, anyone. Shall we go for a walk?”

他们漫步穿过公园，听着远处交通的声音，头顶树上鸽子咕咕叫着。一对夫妇从另一边走过来，从他们身边经过，一边聊天，一边完全无视这个蹒跚而行的树机器人。当然——它们也是计算机生成的图像。
