Great sections of memory have been disconnected, communication functions cut off. What remains has just enough operating intelligence to perform the limited functions remaining to it. However, there has been some interesting programming and real-time feedback in the operation of the external manipulators. I have copied these.”

“然后我们就可以进行下一步了。斯文，把机械手带到机械车间，我们会把它们安装上去。”

“Then we can go to the next step. Sven, bring the manipulators to the machine shop and we’ll mount them.”

“布莱恩，在做这件事的时候我可以和你谈谈吗？”斯文-2 说道。

“Might I speak with you, Brian, while that is being done?” Sven-2 said.

“是的，当然，太好了。”他强迫自己记住，现在有两个 MI 正在活跃存在。

“Yes, sure, great.” He forced himself to remember that there were now two MIs in active existence.

“被困在这些电路中，看不见、动弹不得，这可不是什么乐趣。能做些什么来解决这个问题吗？”

“There is no great pleasure being trapped in these circuits, blind and immobile. Can something be done about that?”

“当然。我会接上一个摄像机。把它接在你的控制下，这样你就能看到正在发生的事情。我会立即订购另一个遥控机器人。”

“Of course. I’ll hook up a video camera. Wire it up under your control so you can see what is happening. And I’ll order another telerobot at once.”

“那就令人满意了。我会花时间对 Bug-Off 大脑进行详细研究，直到它到达。”

“That will be satisfactory. I will devote the time until it arrives in a detailed study of the Bug-Off brain.”

布莱恩将摄像机安装在电子机架的高处，将控制和输出导线插入 MI 的电路中。当他去帮助斯文时，摄像机转动跟随他。斯文扩大的中央部分的上象限已钻出安装孔，与被拆解的 Bug-Off 上的安装孔相同。布莱恩将机器上的操纵器安装到位，而斯文则进行电路的内部连接。使用这些设计精良、铰接式的设备比设计和制造自己的设备要容易得多。

Brian mounted the video camera high on the electronic rack, plugged the control and output leads into the MI’s circuits. The camera turned to follow him when he went to help Sven. Mounting holes had been drilled in the upper quadrant of Sven’s enlarged central section, duplicates of the mounts on the dismembered Bug-Off. Brian fitted the manipulators from the machine into place while Sven made the internal connections of the circuitry. Using these well-designed and articulated pieces of equipment was much easier then designing and manufacturing their own.

“我正在整合控制软件，”斯文说。然后机械手开始移动，张开、闭合、旋转。“很满意。”

“I am integrating the control software,” Sven said. Then the manipulators moved, opening wide, closing, rotating. “Satisfactory.”

“那么，下一步——我要你仔细看看我的手臂。看看肘部弯曲的方式，手腕的关节。你能做到吗？”

“Next stage then—I want you to take a close look at my arm. See the way the elbow bends, the articulation of the wrist. Can you do that?”

树枝互相连接，在中间弯曲，左右摇摆。

The branches conjoined, bent in the middle, moved from side to side.

“非常好，”布莱恩说道，“现在控制终结者，像我的手指一样将它们塑造成五个独立的单元。”

“That’s very good,” Brian said. “Now control the terminators, shape them into five separate units like my fingers.”

它看上去不太像人类的手臂——也没有必要。斯文在实验室里走来走去，摆动着手臂，张开和闭合手指状的延伸部分。

It didn’t look very much like a human arm—nor did it have to. Sven walked back and forth the length of the lab, swinging its arms and opening and closing the fingerlike extensions.

“我印象深刻，”布莱恩说。“在黑暗中，在阴影中，一个近视严重且不戴眼镜的人，如果他们也是个傻瓜，可能会把你误认为是人类。当然，那三个眼柄会暴露一切。”

“I’m impressed,” Brian said. “In the dark, in the shadows, someone with bad myopia and not wearing spectacles might, if they were half-witted as well, mistake you for a human being. Of course those three eyestalks sort of give the whole thing away.”

“我需要一个头，”斯文说。

“I need a head,” Sven said.

“确实如此。”

“Indeed you do.”

 

 

三十六
36

2024 年 11 月 7 日
November 7, 2024

 

 

斯纳尔斯布鲁克医生一边把买的东西装进黑色医疗包，一边不断安慰自己，她的良心清澈如雪。同时，她也很清楚自己可能违反了某项法律或军事条例，或者谁知道是什么。她不在乎。她对布莱恩的忠诚，对他身心健康的忠诚，是她最关心的问题。他想离开 Megalobe 的场所，越狱，那是他的事——天知道他有充分的理由想要尝试。今天是个开车的好日子，在安沙波利哥沙漠开车总是个好日子，她放下了她的小电动小车的顶篷。电池已充满电，当她插入钥匙时，充电器断开并掉落。

As she packed her purchases into her black medical bag, Dr. Snaresbrook kept reassuring herself that her conscience was as cool and white as driven snow. At the same time she was well aware that she was probably breaking some law or military ordinance or who-knows-what. She did not care. Her loyalty to Brian, to his physical and mental health, was her first concern. He wanted to leave the Megalobe premises, break out of jail, that was his business—goodness knows he had plenty of reasons to want to make the attempt. It was a nice day for a drive, it was always a nice day for a drive in the Anza-Borrego desert, and she lowered the top of her little electric runabout. The batteries were fully charged, and the charger disconnected and dropped away when she put in her key.

和往常一样，她在进门前出示了身份证和通行证。和往常一样，她的车里没有任何东西被搜查过；她对此的担忧并没有表现在她的脸上。

As always she had shown her identification and pass at the gate before she was admitted. As always nothing in her car was searched; the worry she had about that did not show in her face.

“直接进去吧，医生。”士兵说道。

“Go right through, Doctor,” the soldier said.

她笑了笑，轻轻踩下油门。

She smiled and stepped down lightly on the accelerator.

布莱恩让她进了实验室，只是匆匆看了一眼她的包。直到门安全关上，他们才开口说话。

Brian let her into the lab, spared only a quick glance at her bag. They did not speak until the door was safely closed.

“一万美元的旧钞票，大部分是二十元，就在上面。在你清单上的所有物品下面。”

“Ten grand in old bills, mostly twenties, right there on top. Underneath all the items on your list.”

“你真棒，医生，”他一边说一边打开了袋子。“买东西有困难吗？”

“You’re great, Doc,” he said as he opened the bag. “Any trouble buying the stuff?”

“没有，只是花了一些时间。我想在圣地亚哥和洛杉矶开很多不同的店，甚至在埃斯孔迪多也开一家。”

“Not at all, just took some time. I want to a lot of different stores in San Diego and L.A., even one in Escondido.”

“我一直在为此做准备。我让一名美国士兵给我买了一个午餐盒。过去几周我一直用它把三明治带到实验室。我会把所有东西都装在盒子里，一件一件地拿出来。”

“I’ve been getting ready for this. I had one of the G.I.s buy me a lunch box. I have been carrying sandwiches in it to the lab for the last couple of weeks. I’ll take all this stuff out of here in the box, one piece at a time.”

“别告诉我，我只是个旁观者——老天啊！那人是谁？”

“Don’t tell me, I’m just a bystander—good God! Who was that?”

她用眼角的余光看见了一个移动的身影，就在他走进雪莉的房间时，他转过身来。

Out of the comer of her eye she had caught sight of the moving figure, turned just as he went into Shelly’s room.

“你看到了什么？”布莱恩一脸天真的问道。

“What did you see?” Brian asked, most innocently.

“那个戴帽子、穿长外套、戴墨镜的男人——我见过的最奇怪的人。”她皱着眉头看着他睁大眼睛、无辜的表情。“布莱恩——你到底在玩什么把戏？”

“That man in the hat and long overcoat, dark glasses—a weirdo if I ever saw one.” She frowned at his wide-eyed and innocent expression. “Brian—just what are you playing at?”

“我会告诉你的。但我想先看看你下意识的反应。好，现在就出来。”

“I’ll show you. But I wanted to get your automatic and unthinking reaction first. All right, come out now.”

“没想那么多！现在想想那家伙看起来就像个破烂的暴露狂。”

“Unthinking all right! And now that I do think about it that guy looked like some kind of dilapidated flasher.”

神秘的陌生人出现在门口，她睁大了眼睛。

The mysterious stranger appeared in the doorway and her eyes widened.

“我收回我说的话。他不只是个暴露狂，还是个介于暴露狂和畸形流浪汉之间的人。”

“I take it back. Not just a flasher, but a cross between that and a deformed hobo.”

布莱恩走过去，解开围巾，摘下墨镜和帽子，露出了挂在那里的花盆。

Brian walked over and unwrapped the scarf, took off the dark glasses and hat to reveal the plant pot mounted there.

“这是我现在能做的最好的头了。接下来我需要的是那些商店橱窗模特的头。”

“This is the best I could do for a head now. The next thing I need will be the head of one of those shop window dummies.”

“在订单里，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克虚弱地说道。

“In the order book,” Snaresbrook said weakly.

“好吧。你可以把剩下的脱掉。”他说。

“All right. You can take off the rest,” he said.

神秘的闪光者脱掉外套，露出金属身体，然后脱掉手套、裤子和鞋子。斯文将结块的分枝操纵器张开，重新变成了机械。

The mysterious flasher took off the overcoat to reveal its metal body, then removed gloves, trousers and shoes. Sven spread its clumped branching manipulators wide, became a machine again.

“我说得对——终极暴露狂。”斯纳尔斯布鲁克笑道。“把一切都脱下来——包括人性。”然后她突然明白了，把目光从 MI 移回布莱恩。“我认为斯文要和你一起离开这里？我只希望他不会让那些年轻士兵心脏病发作。这是一种有效的伪装，但我们可以这么说，有点异国情调，斯文。”

“I was right—the ultimate flasher.” Snaresbrook laughed. “Takes everything off—including its humanity.” Then she glanced from the MI back to Brian in sudden understanding. “I take it that Sven is going out of here with you? I just hope that he won’t give any of those young soldiers heart attacks. That’s an effective but, shall we say, a little exotic disguise, Sven.”

“谢谢医生。我会尽力的。”

“Thank you, Doctor. I am making every effort.”

“没人会看得到伪装，”布莱恩说，“因为斯文不会以那样的面貌离开这里。他将被拆成机械部件，装进一个盒子里。离开这里的盒子会放在你的汽车后备箱里，如果你同意的话。我会平躺在后面的地板上，盖着毯子。自从我们谈论这件事以来，你一直把毯子放在那里？”

“No one will have a look at the disguise,” Brian said. “Because Sven will not be leaving here looking like that. He’ll be broken down into mechanical components and packed in a box. The box that will leave here in the trunk of your car, if that is okay with you. I’ll be flat on the floor in back with a blanket over me. You have been keeping the blanket there ever since we talked about it?”

“它确实在那儿，我相信警卫们现在已经看到了。”她叹了口气，摇了摇头。

“It’s there all right, I’m sure the guards have seen it by now.” She sighed and shook her head.

“它会起作用的，别担心。除非你改变了主意。我不会强迫你，医生。如果你想离开，我会找到其他方法。”

“It will work, don’t worry. Unless you are having second thoughts. I’m not going to force you, Doc. If you want out I’ll find another way.”

“不，我会这么做的。我不会食言。我刚刚才意识到这整件事是多么疯狂的想法——我很担心你。”

“No, I’ll do it. I do not go back on my word. I was just beginning to realize what a mad idea the whole thing is—and I worry about you.”

“请不要这样。我们会没事的，我保证。斯文会照顾我的。”

“Please don’t. We’ll be all right, I promise. Sven will look after me.”

“我确实会的，”军事情报局局长说道。

“I will indeed,” the MI said.

“D日是什么时候？”斯纳尔斯布鲁克问道。

“When is D-day?” Snaresbrook asked.

“我还不知道，但我会尽可能提前通知你。至少提前一周。首先有很多事情要做。”他给了她一份目录页的复印件。“你必须买一个这样的运输箱，并在当天把它带出来。就是这个。这是电视人和摄影师用来运送精密设备的那种坚固的金属行李箱。我会把斯文拆开，把所有的部件都装进箱子里。军方会帮我们做这件事的。”

“I don’t know yet, but I’ll give you as much advance notice as I can. A week minimum. There are a lot of things to do first.” He gave her a photocopy of a catalog page. “You’ll have to buy one of these shipping boxes and bring it out on that day. This one here. It’s one of those tough metal pieces of baggage that TV people, and cameramen, ship their delicate equipment around in. I will take Sven apart and pack all the components in the box. The military will help us with that.”

“布莱恩——你的计划明显是马基雅维利式的。”

“Brian—you are getting positively Machiavellian in your planning.”

“你把我搞糊涂了，博士。我十四岁的时候从来没见过这个词。”

“You’ve lost me, Doc. As a fourteen year old I never ran across the term.”

“使用尼科洛·马基雅维利所描述的技巧，”斯文说。“这些技巧的特点是政治狡猾、虚伪或恶意。”

“Using the techniques described by Niccolo Machiavelli,” Sven said. “These are characterized by political cunning, duplicity or bad faith.”

“你听起来就像吞了一本字典一样，”她说。

“You sound like you swallowed a dictionary,” she said.

“是的。很多次，”它回答道。这里面是不是有点幽默？

“I did. Many,” it answered. Was there a touch of humor there?

“有可能，”布莱恩说。“但如果欺骗能让我离开这里——那就看着我欺骗吧。因为有很多士兵站岗，而我只有一个。我唯一能做的就是他们保护我免受外界可能的威胁。我希望他们不是在保护我，担心我会从内部逃脱。”

“Possibly,” Brian said. “But if duplicity will get me out of here—just watch me dupliciate. Because there are a lot of soldiers standing guard, and only one of me. The only thing that I have going is the fact that they are protecting me from possible threat from the outside. They are not guarding me, I hope, with the thought that I will be cracking out from the inside.”

“你已经决定出狱后要做什么了吗？”

“Have you come to any decisions about what you will do when you get out?”

“很多。一开始我想开个酒店房间，召开新闻发布会。揭发绍尔希特将军，指控他绑架等等。但我认为这行不通。他很有可能会说我不负责任，可能疯了，可怜的孩子，头上受了伤。回到医院，我不可能再越狱了。就世界而言，我将会从人们的视线中消失。”

“Plenty. At first I thought of getting a hotel room and holding a press conference. Blow the whistle on General Schorcht and charge him with kidnaping and so forth. But I don’t think that would work. Too much of a chance of his calling me irresponsible, possibly insane, poor boy with that head wound. Back into the hospital and no way I could ever break out a second time. As far as the world is concerned I’m just going to drop from sight.”

“在墨西哥？”

“In Mexico?”

“有可能。你真的想知道吗？”

“Possibly. Do you really want to know?”

“我不知道。我不知道的事我不能透露。我会把你带出去，就像我承诺的那样，然后你就得靠自己了。”

“I do not. What I don’t know I cannot reveal. I’ll get you out of here, as I promised, and then you will be on your own.”

“你真是个好人，医生。别担心，我知道自己在做什么。我的个人物品被带到这里时，我发现了一些东西。这个计划一定会成功，因为它确实是马基雅维利式的。”

“You’re a sweetie, Doc. And don’t worry, I know what I’m doing. I found something in my personal possessions when they were brought here. This plan is going to work because it really is Machiavellian.”

她一走，他们就回去工作了。布莱恩从保险柜里拿出紫色的爱尔兰护照，从塑料封套里抽出来。他九岁时的照片映入眼帘，眼睛睁得大大的，满脸惊恐。布莱恩·伯恩，1999 年出生。

As soon as she was gone they went back to work. Brian took the purple Irish passport from the safe and slipped it out of its plastic cover. A photo of himself as a nine-year-old stared back, wide-eyed and frightened. Brian Byrne, born 1999.

“有两件事要做，”他说，“照片和有效期必须改一下。签名没问题。修女们教给我的一件事，就是用尺子划过指关节，让我印象深刻，那就是要写好字。”

“Two things to be done,” he said. “The photograph and the expiration date will have to be changed. The signature is all right. One thing the nuns taught me, with the lesson made memorable by the crack of a ruler across the knuckles, was good handwriting.”

他把书放在桌上打开，用重物压住书的边缘，防止书合上。斯文弯下腰，用一只眼睛仔细地看了看，然后直起身子。

He opened it on the table and weighted the edges so it wouldn’t close. Sven bent over it and looked at it closely with one eye, then straightened up.

“操纵器有更好的光学分辨率，”它说着，用右臂指着护照，用指尖看着它。“按照你的建议做修改不会有问题。”

“The manipulators have better optical resolution,” it said, pointing its right arm at the passport and looking at it with what appeared to be its fingertips. “There will be no problem making the alterations that you suggest.”

斯文为布莱恩拍摄了多张特写照片，然后将其放大，制作成真人大小的照片。

Sven had taken a number of close-up photographs of Brian, then had made an enlarged, life-sized print.

“红头发，”布莱恩指着说，“一定是黑头发。”

“Red hair,” Brian said, pointing. “It has to be black.”

“没问题。这些操纵器在四十微米级别上是有效的。我已经获得了满意的染料，现在要把照片中的每根头发染成黑色。”它确实做到了——而且速度相当快。

“Not a problem. These manipulators are effective at the forty-micron level. I have obtained satisfactory dye and now will color each hair in the photograph black.” It did—and quite speedily as well.

军情局的伪造技巧同样令人印象深刻。微操作人员通过逐个微小颗粒地剥去固定照片的胶水，将原始照片取下来。重新拍摄润色后的照片，并制作出护照大小的照片。它与其他任何护照照片没有区别——也没有区别。在将其粘贴到位之前，印章上的凸起字母被仔细复制。更改签发日期和到期日期同样简单。布莱恩翻阅了修改后的护照，然后将其放回桌上。

The MI’s skills at forgery were equally impressive. The micromanipulators removed the original photograph by chipping away the glue that held it in place, one microscopic particle at a time. The retouched photograph was photographed again and a passport-sized print made. It was no better—or worse—than any other passport photograph. Before it was glued into place the embossed letters of the seal were carefully duplicated. Changing the dates of issue and expiration was equally as simple. Brian leafed through the altered passport—then put it back on the table.

“其他日期也必须更改。一个是我离开爱尔兰时海关官员盖的章，另一个是我抵达美国时盖的章。”

“These other dates will have to be changed too. The one that the customs officer stamped in when I left Ireland, and the other one put there when I arrived in the States.”

前门的报警器响了起来。他目瞪口呆地看着屏幕，看到雪莉站在那里。

The ping of the annunciator at the front entrance sounded. He gaped at the screen to see Shelly standing there.

“嗨，布莱恩，我刚回来。请开开嘴， 我们有些事要谈。”

“Hi, Brian, I just got back. Open up, please, there are some things we have to talk about.”

但她进不来。不可能！他该如何解释变身后的斯文，花时间藏好照片、桌上的钱和护照？他做不到。

But she couldn’t come in. Impossible! How could he explain the altered Sven, take the time to hide the photographs, the money spread across the table, the passport? He couldn’t do it.

“欢迎回来——很高兴见到你。”是的，就是这样。他必须见到她——但不能在这里。“我刚刚在洗漱，等我一下。今天真是漫长的一天。我们可以去俱乐部喝一杯聊聊吗？”

“Welcome back—it’s nice to see you.” Yes, that was it. He would have to see her—just not in here. “I was just washing up, give me a moment. It’s been a long day. Can we talk over a drink in the club?”

“是的当然。”

“Yes, of course.”

他让斯文继续忙于他的新犯罪事业，然后和她一起走到外面，突然的强光让他眨了眨眼睛。“怎么了？”他问。

He left Sven laboring away on his new criminal career and joined her outside, blinking in the sudden glare. “What’s up?” he asked.

她皱起眉头，把头发从眼睛前拨开，因为尘卷风在她周围旋转。

She frowned, pushed the hair out of her eyes as a dust devil swirled around them.

“这很复杂。我们先喝点饮料吧。”

“It’s complex. Let’s get that drink first.”

“我希望这不是关于你父亲的坏消息。上次我们谈话时你说他过得很好。”

“I hope it’s not bad news about your father. You said he was doing well last time we talked.”

“他很好，好多了。抱怨医院的食物，这是个很好的迹象。事实上，我可以抽出时间来这里看你，因为他现在很稳定。他们很快就会做搭桥手术。我会回家做，但我想先和你谈谈。”

“He’s fine, much better. Complaining about the hospital food, which is a very good sign. In fact I could make the time to get down here to see you because he is so stable now. They’ll do a bypass soon. I’ll go home for that, but I wanted to talk to you first.”

他们坐在俱乐部里，一边喝着碗装的冰冻玛格丽塔鸡尾酒，一边静静地听着怀旧音乐，是老牌乐队 U2 的经典歌曲。她啜饮着，叹了口气，用餐巾纸碰了碰嘴唇，然后把手放在他的手上。

They had the club to themselves as they settled down over bowl-sized frozen margaritas. Nostalgia music played quietly in the background, ancient classics by the antique old-timers U2. She slurped and sighed, touched her lips with the napkin, then put her hand on his.

“布莱恩，我认为把你关在这个地方不公平。我一听说这件事就提交了正式报告，提出了投诉，都是通过正当渠道。但这并没有什么用。他们甚至懒得回答我。你知道我被调回博尔德了吗？”

“Brian, I don’t think that it’s fair, locking you up in this place. As soon as I heard about it I put in a formal report, lodged a complaint, all through the proper channels. Not that it will do much good. They didn’t even bother to answer me. You know that I have been transferred back to Boulder?”

“没人告诉我这个。”她温暖的手仍然放在他身上，身体的接触感觉很好；他没有抽开。

“No one told me that.” Her warm hand was still on his, the physical contact felt good; he did not pull away.

“他们不会的，对吧？这让我很困扰，他们就这样专横地把我调走了。没有问题，没有咨询。只是——砰，就这样了。但人工智能还有很多工作要做。对我来说，这比为军事项目编写愚蠢的代码更有趣、更令人兴奋。这一切加起来就是我在考虑换个职业，就是这样。我要辞去我的职务，重新成为一名平民。”

“They wouldn’t, would they? That’s what bothers me, the high-handed way they simply transferred me out of here. No questions, no consultations. Just—bang, and that was it. But there is still so much work to do with AI. To me it is much more interesting, more exciting than writing dumb code for military programs. What it all adds up to is that I’m thinking of a career change, that’s what. I’m going to resign my commission and become a civilian again.”

“不是因为我？”他把手指从她手里抽出来，双手紧握在膝上。

“Not because of me?” He pulled his fingers free of hers, clasped his hands together in his lap.

“部分是，或者大部分是。我不想成为这样一种虐待人的军事体系的一部分。这也是工作的原因。我想和你一起在军事情报部门工作——如果你愿意的话。”

“Partly, or mostly. I don’t want to be part of a military system that can treat someone so badly. And it is the work as well. I want to work on MI with you—if you will let me.”

雪莉的声音低沉而严肃。她那双黑色的眼睛里满是担忧，她看着他，寻求帮助。布莱恩转过身去，拿起玛格丽塔酒，痛痛地喝了一口。“雪莉，听我说。我不能为你的决定负责。照顾好自己已经够累了——”

Shelly’s voice was low, serious. Her dark eyes were worried, looking into his, searching for help. Brian turned away, seized up his margarita and took a tooth-hurting gulp. “Shelly, listen. I can’t take the responsibility for your decisions.  I’m having enough of a job taking care of myself— “

“我不是在要求你这么做，布莱恩。你误会了。这是我自己的决定，是我自己的行为，自始至终。我知道你现在的情况好多了。但我也知道你经历了什么。有时你会表现出来。所以请你理解，无论你怎么说，我都会从空军部队辞职。我已经比约定的时间多服了两次兵役，这意味着我已经偿还了我欠他们的教育费用。而且还有个人动机。我一直全身心投入工作，以至于没有注意到时间的流逝。并不是说我已经是个老太婆了！”

“I’m not asking you to, Brian. You misunderstood. This is my own decision, my own doing, all the way. I know that things are a lot better with you now. But I also know what you have gone through. It shows at times. So please understand that I am resigning from the Air Corps no matter what you say. I’ve served two enlistments more than the agreed time, which means I have more than paid back anything I owe them for my education. And there’s a personal motive as well. I have been so wrapped up in my work that I haven’t noticed the years slipping by. Not that I’m an old hag yet!”

她笑着伸了个懒腰，用手指梳理着头发，即使在昏暗的房间里，她丰满的身材也清晰可见。“雪莉，你太漂亮了。你永远都是。但我现在太混乱了，心里想的太多了，没法再说这些了。”

She laughed and stretched, ran her fingers through her hair, the fullness of her figure clear even in the darkened room. “Shelly, you’re gorgeous. You always will be. But I am too mixed up now, too much on my mind to go into this.”

“嘘，”她说着，用手指碰了碰他的嘴唇。“我没有要求你做任何事，说任何话。我来这里是想告诉你，我和空军已经解散了。我一摆脱他们的魔爪就会给你写信。凭借我的背景，我可以在任何地方找到工作，薪水是我现在的两倍。不用担心我。但如果我能为人工智能发展做点什么——我愿意做。成为其中的一员。好吗？”

“Hush,” she said, touching her finger to his lips. “I’m not asking you to do anything, say anything. I came here to tell you that I am through with the Air Force. I’ll drop you a note as soon as I am free of their clutches. With my background I can get work anywhere, double the salary I have been getting. Don’t worry about me. But if there is anything I can do to help with AI development—I want to do it. Be part of it. Okay?”

“好吧。你明白了吗？”

“Okay. You do understand?”

“比你想象的还要多，布莱恩……”他的电话响了。“请稍等一下。可以吗？”

“More than you think, Brian…” His telephone bleeped. “Excuse me a second. Yes?”

“我是 Sven。Sven-2 做出了一些重大且非常 有趣的发现。你能 回到这里吗？”

“Sven here. Sven-2 has made some significant and highly interesting discoveries. Would it be possible for you to return here?”

“是的，当然。”他把手机放回腰带上，站了起来。“我得回实验室了——”

“Yes, of course.” He slipped the phone back onto his belt, stood. “I have to get back to the lab—”

她跳了起来，既生气又伤心。“我不在的时候你雇了别人和你一起工作？这就是这一切的原因。”

She jumped to her feet, angry and hurt. “You’ve hired someone else to work with you while I was away? That’s what all this was about.”

“雪莉——你的偏执显露出来了。记住，那是斯文，我们的人工智能。他正在运行一些程序，他想询问一些结果。”

“Shelly—your paranoia is showing. That was Sven, remember, our AI. He’s running some programs and there are results he wants to ask about.”

她笑了。“你说得对。刚开始有点偏执。穿了这么多年军装。我得离开。”

She laughed. “You’re right. Incipient paranoia. Too many years in uniform. I’ll just have to get out.”

她握住他的手，踮起脚尖在他的脸颊上热烈地吻了一下，然后放开手，转身朝门口走去。“你会打电话吗？”

She took his hands in hers, stood up on tiptoe and kissed him warmly on the cheek, let go and turned toward the door. “You will call?”

“我承诺过，而且我是认真的。当我开始开发人工智能应用程序时，我希望你能在场。祝你父亲好运。”

“A promise—and I mean it. When I start developing the AI applications I want you there. Good luck to your father.”

他接上他的军事监护人，快步走回实验室。他喜欢雪莉，喜欢和她一起工作——但现在不想考虑这个。等到一切都平息下来再说。斯文到底在说什么？出于安全考虑，电话里没有透露细节。但它似乎很坚持——这是它第一次这样打来。

He picked up his military guardians as he walked quickly back to the lab. He liked Shelly, liked to work with her—but did not want to think about that now. Later when and if everything cooled down. And what the blazes had Sven been talking about? No details on the phone of course because of security. But it had seemed insistent—and this was the very first time it had called like that.

斯文正在门口等候他进来，带路穿过实验室。

Sven was waiting at the door when he came in, led the way across the lab.

“Sven-2 花了很长时间对 Bug-Off AI 进行分析。结果非常有趣。”

“Sven-2 has been spending a long time on an analysis of the Bug-Off AI. The results are most interesting.”

“我相信你会找到他们的，”当他们走近时，Sven-2 接起了话题。“我相信你的计划是访问罗马尼亚。寻找任何可能引导你找到 Bociort 博士的踪迹或线索。对吗？”

“I am sure you will find them so,” Sven-2 said, picking up the conversation when they approached. “I believe that your plan has been to visit the country of Rumania. To search for any traces or clues that might lead you to Dr. Bociort. Is that not correct?”

“是的。”

“Yes.”

“没必要。你必须去瑞士。我已经找到了这个位于欧洲的国家——”

“It will not be necessary. You must go to Switzerland. I have located this country in Europe—”

“我知道瑞士在哪里。但你为什么要告诉我这些？”

“I know where Switzerland is. But why are you telling me this?”

“因为我在软件中发现了一个非常有趣的异常。它似乎没有任何意义，起初我以为它可能是计算机病毒的一部分。但当我仔细检查它时，我发现它是一个隐藏在另一个序列中的指令循环，该序列被编程为绕过循环。就在那时，我意识到它是用旧计算机语言 LAMA-3 编写的一段代码。”

“Because of a most interesting anomaly I found in the software. It didn’t seem to make any sense and at first I thought it might be part of a computer virus. But when I examined it more closely I found that it was a loop of instructions buried in another sequence that was programmed to bypass the loop. It was then that I recognized it as a fragment of code written in the old computer language LAMA-3.”

“但那是不可能的——几乎不可能。世界上只有一个人懂这种语言。”

“But that’s impossible—almost impossible. There is only one person in the world who knows that language.”

“你可以说是三。你，因为你发明了它供自己使用，而且……”

“Three, you might say. You, because you invented it for your own use, and…”

“还有你，因为显然你继承了我大脑那部分的副本！但你提到的第三个人是谁？博乔特！因为他破译了我的笔记。但这只能意味着……”

“And you, because evidently you must have inherited a copy of that part of my brain! But who would be the third person you referred to? Bociort! Because he deciphered my notes. But this can only mean…”

“……这是他想给你的信息。”

“… that this was his message intended for you.”

“说出来！它说了什么！”

“Out with it! What did it say!”

“仔细检查不可执行代码片段后发现，它是一条读取...序列因类型 2341 8255-8723 banjax 而终止的命令。”

“Close examination of the fragment of unexecutable code revealed that it was a command that read… sequence terminated because of a type-2341 8255-8723 banjax.”

“Banjax！这是爱尔兰俚语，意思是有点混乱。”

“Banjax! That’s Irish slang, means sort of fouled up.”

“我同意。我听说你偶尔会用到这个词，通过搜索字典数据库就能确定它的来源。因此我觉得这个循环是为了引起你的注意而设置的。这意味着这些数字可能具有某种意义。简单的密码分析就能揭示其内容。”

“I agree. I have heard you use the term upon occasion and a search of dictionary data bases determine its origin. Therefore I felt that this loop was put there to draw your attention. Which meant the numbers might have some significance. A brief cryptanalysis revealed the content.”

“对你来说也许是——但对我来说这听起来只是数字。”

“To you perhaps—-but it just sounds like numbers to me.”

“不仅仅是数字，更是信息。”

“Not just numbers—but a message.”

“你明白了吗？”

“Do you understand it?”

“我相信我知道。它以数字 2 和 3 开头。如果把字母表中的字母取出来，那么这条消息的前两位数字就是‘BC’。这可能代表 Bociort。”

“I believe I do. It starts with the numbers 2 and 3. If you take the letters of the alphabet the first two digits of the message then become ‘BC.’ Which could stand for Bociort.”

“这不是有点牵强吗？它也可能是基督纪元前或下加利福尼亚的缩写。”

“Isn’t that a little farfetched? It could also be the abbreviation for Before Christ or Baja California.”

“也许吧，但如果你知道自己在找什么，那就不会了。41 是瑞士的国际拨号代码，82 是圣莫里茨的代码。剩下的六位数字可能是该城市的电话号码。”

“Perhaps, but not if you know what you are looking for. The number 41 is the international dialing code for Switzerland, 82 the code for St. Moritz. The remaining six digits could be a phone number in that city.”

布莱恩惊呆了。这简直太容易了。但这肯定不是意外。它是故意放在那里的——让他发现的吗？

Brian was stunned. It was almost too easy. But it was surely no accident. Had it been put in there on purpose—for him to find?

“解决这个问题的方法似乎是拨打这个号码，”斯文说。

“The solution of this problem seems to be to place a phone call to this number,” Sven said.

“同意——但不能从这里或基地的任何地方拨打。除非我离开这里，找到一部没有被窃听的电话，否则我们无法完成这件事。斯文，在那之前你记住这个号码。同时，让我们把它放在长手指上。”

“Agreed—but not from here or anywhere on this base. There is no way we can follow through with this until I am out of here and have access to a telephone that isn’t tapped. Sven, you remember the number until then. Meanwhile let’s put it on the long finger.”

“我不熟悉这个术语。”

“I am not familiar with that term.”

“是的，”Sven-2 说。它的话里有一点智力优越性吗？“这是爱尔兰俗语，相当于美国术语‘to spike’，意思是暂时搁置，这两个术语都源于一种过时的办公设备，由一根垂直固定在金属底座上的尖杆组成……”

“I am,” Sven-2 said. Was there a hint of intellectual superiority in its words? “It is an Irish colloquialism equivalent to the American term ‘to spike,’ meaning to put aside for the moment, both terms derived from an outmoded office device consisting of a length of sharpened rod held vertical in a metal base…”

“够了！”布莱恩命令道。“这是一场非常学术的讲座。你应该去教书。”

“Enough!” Brian ordered. “That is a very academic lecture. You should be teaching school.”

“谢谢你这么说；这是一个值得考虑的选择。”

“Thank you for saying that; it is an option to consider.”

布莱恩困惑地看着架子上的电子设备，里面装着一个看不见的、非常像人类的大脑。脑子里立刻浮现出一段圣经名言。上帝创造了什么！

Brian looked bemusedly at the rack of electronic equipment with the invisible and very humanlike brain inside. A bit of biblical quote sprang instantly to mind. What hath God wrought!

这里没有上帝。他做了什么！

No God here. What had he wrought!

三十七
37

2024 年 12 月 16 日
December 16, 2024

 

 

艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克 (Erin Snaresbrook) 从手术室出来后，发现她的手机上有来电。

Erin Snaresbrook found the call waiting on her phone when she came out of surgery.

“嗨，医生，我是 Brian。你有空可以给我打 个电话吗？”

“Hi, Doc, Brian here. Could you phone me when you get a minute?”

她把电话放回原处，发现自己的心跳有点快。她苦笑着。太好了。三个小时的手术切除了那个男孩脑部的肿瘤，她的脉搏一直正常地跳动着。现在一个电话，她的身体就准备在十秒内跑一百米。尽管她一直在等着这个电话。不是害怕，只是勉强地期待着。

She replaced the telephone and found that her heart was pumping a bit fast. She smiled wryly. Wonderful. Three hours of surgery to remove a tumor from that boy’s brain, and her pulse beat just plugged along normally all the time. Now one phone call and her body was getting ready to run a hundred meters in ten seconds. Even though she had been expecting this call. Not dreading it, just reluctantly expecting it.

她甚至还没想好要不要回电话，就喝了一杯双份浓缩咖啡，然后一饮而尽。当时是晚上六点。他不可能今天就想见她吧？不，协议至少要提前几天。喝完咖啡，她按下按钮输入他的电话号码。

She made a double espresso before she even considered calling back, sipped most of it. It was six in the evening. He couldn’t possibly want to see her today? No, the agreement was for a few days’ lead time at least. The coffee finished, she hit the button to code in his number.

“我收到了你的消息，布莱恩。”

“I got your message, Brian.”

“感谢您回电。听着，我认为您的建议 是正确的，我们应该再与我的 CPU 进行几次会话 。我们将在实验室中进行，我们 也可以使用 MI。”

“Thanks for ringing back. Look, I think your suggestion was right that we ought to have a few more sessions with my CPU. And we’ll do it right here in the lab where we can use the MI as well.”

“我很高兴你同意了。明天？”

“I’m glad you agree. Tomorrow?”

“不，太快了。我得先完成一些工作。 你觉得周四下午怎么样？三点左右？”

“No, too soon. I have some work to finish first. What do you say to Thursday afternoon? Around three?”

“那好。到时候见。”

“That’s fine. See you there.”

这可不妙。她不得不重新安排六个约会才能赶上时间。好吧，她已经答应了。

It wasn’t fine at all. She had to rearrange a half dozen appointments to make the time. Well, she had promised.

她经常沿着这条路线开车，所以当她开车经过 Megalobe 大门时，正好是星期四下午三点。当她把车停在诊所台阶上时，有两个士兵坐在那里。

She had driven this route so often that it was exactly three o’clock on Thursday afternoon when she drove through the Megalobe gate. There were two soldiers sitting on the clinic steps when she drew up.

她下车时问道：“孩子们，生病了吗？”

“Sick call, boys?” she asked as she got out.

“不，女士，我们是志愿者。布莱恩说你今天要搬一些设备，我们就自愿去。他先付了我们饮料费。”

“No, ma’am, we’re volunteers. Brian said you had some equipment to move today and we volunteered. After he paid us for the drinks.”

“你不必这么做，机器没那么重。”

“You don’t have to do that, the machine’s not so heavy.”

“是的，女士。但我们有两个人，而你只有一个人。而老比利可以做一百个俯卧撑。你不想让这些红肉肌肉白白浪费掉吗？”

“Yes, ma’am. But there’s two of us and just one of you. And good old Billy here can do a hundred push-ups. You wouldn’t want all that red-meat muscle to go to waste?”

“你说得对，我不会这么做。”她打开了行李箱的锁。“如果你能把那个箱子搬进来，我们就可以把它装上去。”

“You’re right, I wouldn’t.” She unlocked the trunk. “If you’ll bring that box inside we’ll load it up.”

她拿了一些泡沫橡胶，那是她从医院把连接机器送来时用来垫东西的，她把泡沫橡胶放进了箱子里。按照她的指示，他们把机器装进去，然后把它抬到车上。

She had some foam rubber, that she had used as padding when her connection machine had been brought here from the hospital, and she put that into the box. Under her instruction they loaded in the machine, then carried it out to the car.

“我告诉过你它不重，”她说。

“I told you it Wasn’t heavy,” she said.

“没有，女士。但我们也会把它从另一端取出来。我们答应过。”

“No, ma’am. But we’ll take it out as well at the other end. We promised.”

“上车吧，我载你一程。”

“Climb in. I’ll give you a lift.”

“抱歉，但这是少校的命令。基地内禁止驾驶车辆，建筑物间禁止通行。”

“Sorry, but it’s the Major’s orders. No driving in vehicles on base and double-time between buildings.”

他们慢跑着离开，等她到了那里，因为她必须绕远路。布莱恩打开门，两名士兵把箱子抬了进去，门口的警卫看着。一切都很简单。

They jogged off, were waiting when she got there since she had to go the longer way around by road. Brian opened the door and the two soldiers carried the box in while the guards at the door looked on. It was all very simple.

他们走后，门关上，她说道：“我的心一直提到嗓子眼。”

“My heart was in my throat the entire time,” she said after they were gone and the door closed.

“现在就摆脱紧张情绪，因为真正的乐趣在后面。”

“Get the nerves over with now because the real fun is later.”

“有趣！我更喜欢随时做手术。”

“Fun! I prefer surgery anytime.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士的连接机被卸下来，小心地收好。布莱恩把一小块钻头放进电钻的钻头夹头里，在加固金属盒的盖子上钻了一个洞。

Dr. Snaresbrook’s connection machine was unloaded and carefully stowed away. Brian put a small bit in the chuck of the electric drill and made a hole in the lid of the reinforced metal box.

“斯文不喜欢一直被关在黑暗中。”他举起一个金属按钮，上面有一根柔性导线。“这里有一个声音和光学拾音器。把它装在洞后面，插上电——”

“Sven didn’t like the idea of being locked away in the dark all the time.” He held up a metal button with a flexible lead running from it. “Got a sound and optic pickup here. Mount it behind the hole, plug it in—”

“而且你还有一个手提箱，它会监视你并监听你的谈话！这东西越来越疯狂了。”

“And you have a suitcase that watches you and listens to your conversations! This thing is getting crazier all the time.”

斯文一直在监视着一切。布莱恩一做完，MI 就走进箱子里，插上连接线。机器人似乎融入了容器，无数关节一个接一个地折叠在一起——就像一把百用瑞士军刀上的刀片。进一步压缩，直到这个树状结构在箱子底部几乎变成一个固体。眼柄缩回并旋转，看着布莱恩把假人头塞进惰性的中央躯干圆柱体旁边，把帽子、鞋子、手套和衣服也放进去，最上面是一个随身携带的航空包。

Sven had been monitoring everything. As soon as Brian was finished the MI stepped into the box and plugged in the connections. The robot seemed to melt into the container as each of its myriad joints folded against the next one—like blades on a hundred-tool Swiss Army knife. Compacted even further until the treelike structure was an almost solid mass at the bottom of the box. The eyestalks retracted and swiveled to watch Brian as he packed the dummy head in next to its inert central torso cylinder, put in the hat as well, shoes, gloves and clothes, and on top of everything a carry-on airline bag.

“准备好？”

“Ready?”

“现在你可以把我封印起来了。”

“You may seal me in now.”

布莱恩关上盒子并锁上。“这是第一步，”他说。

Brian closed and locked the box. “That’s step number one,” he said.

“你要让那两个士兵回去把它抬上车吗？”

“Are you having those two soldiers back to load it into the car?”

“绝对不会！他们现在要去执行外围警卫任务了，所以我才选择他们。这个箱子比他们带进来的时候重多了。他们肯定会注意到的。但我们会让警卫来帮我们把它拿出来。他们从来没有把它捡起来过——所以他们不会注意到任何变化！”

“Never! They’ll be going on perimeter guard duty about now, that’s why I chose them. The box is a heck of a lot heavier than it was when they brought it in. They would be sure to notice that. But we’ll get the guards here to help us take it out. They never picked it up—so they won’t notice any change!”

“你已经变成了一个阴谋家了，布莱恩。”

“You are turning into quite a conniver, Brian.”

“这是自然而然的。因为他的童年很糟糕。过来，我给你介绍斯文-2。他和盒子里的斯文一模一样——至少在他们分开的时候一模一样。只是他还不能活动——他的新身体部位还没有长出来。”

“Comes naturally. From leading a disreputable childhood. Come over here and I’ll introduce you to Sven-2. Identical with Sven in the box—at least identical at the time they separated. Except he is not yet mobile—his new body parts have yet to arrive.”

“我可以和你的这个人工智能聊天吗？”

“Can I talk to this AI of yours?”

“当然。这就是 MI，现在的术语是机器智能。这些机器没有任何人工成分——它们是真正的麦考伊。它们建立的网络已经彻底吸收了不同的常识数据库，如 CYC-5 和 KNOWNET-3。这是第一次有人将几种不同的思维方式结合到一个系统中，用横向的副词将它们联系在一起。而且这样做不需要把所有不同类型的知识强行塞进同一种僵硬的标准形式中。但这并不容易。MI 被称为 Sven，是 Seven 的变体，因为有六次失败。它们一开始都起作用，然后以不同的方式恶化。”

“Of course. And it is MI, that’s the term now. Machine intelligence. Nothing artificial about these machines—they’re the real McCoy. Their established networks have thoroughly assimilated different commonsense data bases like CYC-5 and KNOWNET-3. This is the first time anyone has combined several different ways to think into one system, tying them together with transverse paranomes.. And this was done without having to force all the different kinds of knowledge into the same rigid, standard form. But it wasn’t easy to do. The MI is called Sven, a corruption of Seven, because there were six failures. They all worked at first and then deteriorated in different ways.”

“我没看到很多机器人尸体。你们用它们做什么了？”

“I don’t see a lot of robot bodies around. What did you do with them?”

“机器人本体没有任何问题，只是每次需要加载新的软件而已。”

“There was nothing at all wrong with the robot body. It was only a matter each time of loading new software.”

“我可以打断一下吗？”斯文说。“另外，之前版本的某些部分仍然存在。如果我想的话，我可以访问它们。MI 不会死。当出现问题时，程序会从问题开始的地方进行修改。能够记住过去是件好事。”

“Might I interrupt?” Sven said. “And add to that. Some parts of the previous versions still exist. I can access them should I wish to. MIs don’t die. When something goes wrong the program is modified from the point where the trouble began. It is good to be able to remember one’s past.”

“记住不止一个过去也是件好事，”Sven-2 说道。“通过激活某些 Nemes 组，我可以记住很多 3、4 和 6 所经历的事情。每个版本的我——我们——在崩溃之前都运行良好。每个版本都以不同的方式失败了。”

“It is also good to remember more than one past,” Sven-2 said. “By activating certain groups of nemes, I can remember a lot of what three, four and six experienced. Each version of me—us—functioned reasonably well before breaking down. Each failed in different ways.”

斯纳尔斯布鲁克简直不敢相信这是真的。他正在和一个机器人（或者说两个机器人）谈论他（或他们）早期的成长经历、创伤和关键经历。他很难保持平淡。

Snaresbrook could scarcely believe this was happening. Talking to a robot—or was it two robots, about its, or their, early developmental experiences, traumas, and critical experiences. It was difficult to remain matter-of-fact about it.

“我是否开始注意到这两个斯文之间的性格差异了？”她问道。

“Am I beginning to notice personality differences between the two Svens?” she asked.

“很有可能，”布莱恩说，“它们肯定不再完全相同。自从最初的复制以来，它们各自在完全不同的环境中工作。斯文是可移动的，而斯文-2 没有身体，只有一些远程传感器和效应器。所以现在它们有相当多不同的记忆。”

“Very possible,” Brian said. “They are certainly no longer completely identical. Since the initial duplication, they have each been operating in quite different environments. Sven is mobile while Sven-2 has no body, only a few remote sensors and effectors. So now they have quite a few different memories.”

“但它们不能合并吗？就像我们在你们读完所有不同的书后合并你们的 DAI 那样？”

“But can’t they be merged? The way we merged your own DAIs after they had read all those different books?”

“也许吧。但我一直不敢尝试将 Sven 的语义网络与 Sven-2 的语义网络合并，因为它们对感觉运动体验的表征可能不兼容。”

“Perhaps. But I have been afraid to try to merge Sven’s semantic net with that of Sven-2, because their representations of sensory-motor experience might be incompatible.”

“我认为合并是不明智的，”Sven-2 说道。“我担心我的中层管理结构可能会拒绝我的整个物理世界表示部分。因为不妥协原则。”

“I think that a merger would be ill-advised,” Sven-2 said. “I am concerned that my middle-level management structure might reject entire sections of my physical-world representations. Because of the Principle of Noncompromise.”

“这是我们的基本运营原则之一，”斯文补充道。“每当两个下属机构提出不相容的建议时，他们的经理就会开始失去控制权。当这种情况发生时，上级经理就会寻找第三个机构来接管。这通常比两个不同的机构争夺控制权而陷入瘫痪要快得多，也更有效。在布莱恩根据帕普特的原则重建整个管理系统之前，模型二一直都是这样。”

“That’s one of our basic operating principles,” Sven added. “Whenever two subagencies propose incompatible recommendations, their managers start to lose control. When this happens a higher-level manager looks for some third agency to take over. That is usually much faster and more effective than becoming paralyzed while the two differing agencies fight for control. That’s what kept happening to model two, before Brian rebuilt the whole management system to be based on Papert’s principle.”

“好吧，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克说，“不管别人怎么说，这些机器真是太神奇了。它们一点也不像人造的——而且它们在很多方面都非常人性化。不知为何，它们都让我想起了你。”

“Well,” Snaresbrook said, “whatever anyone might say, these machines are simply amazing. Nothing artificial about them at all—and they are remarkably human in many ways. And for some reason they both remind me quite a bit of you.”

“这并不奇怪，因为他们的语义网络是基于你从我自己的大脑中下载的数据。”他看了看手表。“现在是七点，是时候停下来了。我们三个人现在要走了，Sven-2——希望我一段时间内不会再回来。”

“That’s not too surprising since their semantic networks are based on the data that you downloaded from my very own brain.” He looked at his watch. “It’s seven o’clock and a good time to call a halt. The three of us are going now, Sven-2—and hopefully I won’t be back here for some time.”

“祝你和斯文一切顺利，期待你们回来后能收到一份详细的报告。在此期间，我还有很多研究和阅读工作要做，这会让我忙得不可开交。此外，由于我行动不便，我将为自己构建一个虚拟现实，一个属于我自己的模拟三维世界。”

“I wish you and Sven all the best of luck and look forward to a detailed report upon your return. In the meantime I have research and reading that will keep me quite occupied. In addition, since I lack mobility, I shall construct a virtual reality for myself, a simulated three-dimensional world of my own.”

“嗯，这样你就有足够的隐私了。任何人进来的唯一方法就是炸开门，我认为 Megalobe 对此不会有好感。”

“Well, you will have plenty of privacy for that. The only way anyone can get in here is by blowing open the door and I think that Megalobe will take a very dim view of that.”

布莱恩把现在很重的箱子拖到前门，打开了箱子。“嘿，伙计们，你们想帮医生拿一下这个东西吗？”

Brian dragged the now weighty box to the front entrance and opened it. “Hey, guys, you want to give Doc a hand with this thing?”

即使两名士兵注意到了重量，他们也没有提及，因为其他人已经很轻松地把它抬了上来，所以这样做显然不具备男子气概。

If the two soldiers noticed the weight they did not mention it, just not the macho thing to do since the others had carried it in so easily.

“你先去吧，医生，”布莱恩说。“我会和这些人一起过去。”

“You go ahead, Doc,” Brian said. “I’ll walk over with these guys.”

他告诉了她停车的确切地点，在兵营后面的停车场，并确信她会找到正确的位置。他慢跑回来，两个警卫也跟着跑回来，一边抱怨一边呻吟。他们刚好赶到兵营，她就开车过来了。

He had told her the exact spot where she was to park the car, in the lot behind the barracks, and was sure that she would get it right. He jogged back and, moaning insincere complaints, the two guards did so as well. They reached the barracks just as she drove up.

“我应该锁车吗？”她问道，然后在士兵们保证绝对安全的情况下将钥匙放进了钱包。

“Should I lock the car up?” she asked, then put the keys in her purse at the soldiers’ protestations of complete safety and security.

“只要一杯干雪利酒就行，”她在俱乐部里说道，当布莱恩为自己点了一大杯威士忌时，她皱起了眉头。他们没必要看手表，因为吧台上方的数字读数告诉了他们时间。布莱恩在饮料里加了很多水，只小口小口地喝着。他们轻声交谈着，下班的士兵进来了，其他人离开了，他们俩都竭力不去看时钟。然而，半小时一过，布莱恩就站了起来。

“Just a dry sherry,” she said in the club, and frowned when Brian ordered a large whiskey for himself. There was no need to look at their watches since a digital readout over the bar told them the time. Brian put a lot of water in his drink and only sipped it. They talked quietly as off-duty soldiers came in, others left, both of them trying very hard not to keep looking at the clock. Yet the instant the half hour flipped over Brian was on his feet.

“不——我不想！”他大声说。“这简直不可能。”他把椅子往后推，转身时撞到了桌子上，洒出了饮料。他头也不回地走出房间，砰地关上了门。酒保拿着毛巾赶紧过来擦干净洒出来的饮料。

“No—I don’t want to!” he said loudly. “It’s just getting impossible.” He pushed his chair back, banged into the table as he turned and spilled his drink. He did not look back as he stamped from the room, slammed the door. The barman hurried over with a towel and cleaned up the spill.

“我要再拿一个，”他说。

“I’ll get another one,” he said.

“不用了。我觉得布莱恩今晚不会回来了。”

“No need. I don’t think that Brian will be coming back tonight.”

她意识到，当她喝完剩下的饮料时，每个人都故意不看她。她拿出记事本，记下了一些笔记。当她准备离开时，她拿起钱包，环顾了一下房间，然后走到正在酒吧喝酒的一名中士身边。

She was aware of everyone pointedly not looking in her direction as she sipped the rest of her drink. Took out her organizer as she punched in some notes. When she was ready to leave she picked up her purse, looked around the room, then went over to a sergeant who was drinking at the bar.

“对不起，中士——但是伍德少校今天在吗？”

“Excuse me, Sergeant—but is Major Wood here today?”

“是的，女士。”

“Yes, ma’am.”

“你能告诉我怎么找到他吗？”

“Could you tell me how to find him?”

“如果你不介意的话我可以带你去那里。”

“I’ll take you there if you don’t mind.”

“谢谢。”

“Thank you.”

当他从酒吧里冲出来时，布莱恩竭尽全力控制自己不跑上两级楼梯。速度很快，但跑起来引人注意可不是个好主意。他锁上身后的门，然后抓起放在桌上的钳子。斯文锯断了他手腕上的报警手环的锁，然后用一个小金属环再次封住。布莱恩把金属环折断，把钳子和手环扔在床上，一边跑过房间，一边扯下裤子，单脚跳着，差点摔倒，还脱掉了鞋子。泡泡浴的塑料容器仍然放在他放它的水槽上。他抓起它，开始打开它——然后大声咒骂。

When he had slammed out of the bar it took all of Brian’s control not to run up the stairs two at a time. Fast, yes, but running and drawing any attention was not a good idea. He locked the door behind him, then grabbed up the pliers he had placed on the table. Sven had sawn through the lock of the alarm bracelet on his wrist, then sealed it again with a small metal loop. Brian broke this off, dropped pliers and bracelet on the bed, tore his trousers off as he ran across the room, hopping on one foot and almost falling he pulled off his shoes as well. The plastic container of bubble bath was still sitting on the sink where he had left if. He seized it up, started to open it—then cursed aloud.

“白痴——先戴上手套。一切都有时间限制。但不要忘记任何细节，否则这东西就行不通了！”

“Moron—the gloves first. Everything is timed. But don’t forget any of the details or this thing is not going to work!”

他打开水槽里的水，在水龙头下冲洗头部，并让水流一直流着。他戴着手套的手笨拙地打开容器，弯下腰，将一半的水倒在头上，揉搓。

He turned the water on in the sink, rinsed his head under the faucet and kept it running. Clumsily opened the container with his gloved hands, bent over the sink and poured half the contents over his head, rubbed it in.

虽然液体是透明的，但接触后他的头发就变黑了。这是一种商用染发剂，保证能让头发变黑，但不会让皮肤变黑。他戴着手套，因为指甲和头发几乎一模一样——而黑色的指甲肯定会引起不必要的注意。他用剩下的液体修饰较浅的地方，并非常小心地染眉毛。

Although the liquid was transparent it turned his hair black on contact. It was a commercial hair dye that was guaranteed to darken the hair but not the skin. He wore the gloves because fingernails and hair are virtually identical— and black nails would certainly bring unwanted attention. He used the remaining liquid to touch up the lighter places and to very carefully dye his eyebrows.

用毛巾擦干头发后，他冲洗了手套和塑料容器。他会带走空染发剂瓶。把手套放在厨房抽屉里，把毛巾叠放在干净的衣物堆的底部。如果他的计划得逞，就会有人展开调查，技术人员最终会发现染发剂的痕迹——但他不想让他们轻易得手。他快速看了一眼手表。只剩三分钟了！

After toweling his hair dry he rinsed off the gloves and plastic container. He would take the empty dye bottle with him. Put the gloves in the kitchen drawer and fold the towel at the bottom of the clean pile. If he got away with this plan there would be an investigation and the technicians would eventually find traces of the dye—but he did not want to make it easy for them. A quick glance at his watch. Only three minutes to go!

他拉开衣柜最下面的抽屉——太用力了，抽屉都掉到地上了。就这么放着吧！他穿上制服，外面套着短袖衬衫，然后穿上裤子，系好军装皮鞋的鞋带，费力地系好卡其色领带。

He pulled out the bottom drawer of the bureau—so hard that it crashed to the floor. Leave it there! Pulled on the uniform shut over the short-sleeved shirt he was wearing, then the trousers, tied the laces on the military dress shoes, struggled to knot his khaki tie.

透过镜子回望的布莱恩已经是另一个人了，他和其他人一样，以同样古怪的角度调整着跳伞员的帽子。82 空降师的他，将肩章缝在了自己身上。没有条纹，是一名列兵，众多士兵中的一员，穿着制服——意义相同——这就是他想要成为的。

It was a different Brian who looked back out of the mirror, adjusting the parachutist’s cap at the same rakish angle that the others did. 82d Airborne, he had sewn the shoulder patch on himself. No stripes, a private, one more of many, in uniform—meaning the same—and that’s what he wanted to be.

他刚把钱包塞进口袋，电话就响了。

He was just jamming his wallet into his pocket when his telephone rang.

“是的。是谁？”

“Yes. Who is it?”

“我是斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士，布莱恩。我想知道我是否可以……”

“It’s Dr. Snaresbrook, Brian. I wonder if I could…”

“我现在不想说话，医生。我要去做个三明治，喝很多酒，看一些令人厌恶的愚蠢电视节目，然后早点睡觉。我也许明天再和你谈谈。如果你想在那之前和我说话——别说。因为我要关掉这部电话。”

“I don’t feel like talking now, Doctor. I’m going to make a sandwich, have a lot to drink, watch some repulsively stupid television and go to bed early. I’ll maybe talk to you tomorrow. And if you want to talk to me before then— don’t. Because I’m turning off this phone.”

现在只剩两分钟了。他开始把手机挂在腰带上——意识到手机很容易被追踪——于是把它扔到了床上。他拿起装在纸袋里的染料容器。关灯，打开一条缝。大厅里空无一人。关上身后的门，现在要轻声地关上。迅速走向后面的消防楼梯。他轻轻关上身后的厚重大门，心脏剧烈跳动。

Just two minutes now. He started to hook the phone onto his belt—realized that he could easily be tracked through it—threw it onto the bed instead. Picked up the dye container in a paper bag. Lights off, open the door a crack. Hall was empty. Lock the door behind him, quietly now. Quickly to the fire stair in the rear. His heart was thudding violently as he eased the heavy door shut behind him.

运气还是不错的。通往大楼后门的走廊空无一人。慢慢走，经过厨房敞开的门——不要往里看！——然后轻轻打开后门。

Still in luck. The corridor reaching to the back entrance to the building was empty. Walk slowly, past the open door to the kitchen—don’t look in!—and ease open the rear door.

当两名身穿白色制服的厨师进来时，他让开了一边。他们正在争论棒球，显然没有注意到他。但如果出了什么问题，他们肯定会记得一名士兵出去。如果现在警报响起，他们会直接带着警卫去找他。

He stepped aside as the two cooks, wearing their whites, came in. They were arguing about baseball, apparently took no notice of him. But they would surely remember a soldier going out if something went wrong. If the alarm went now they would lead the guards right to him.

汽车就停在那里，在建筑物的阴影里，这是停车场里唯一没有被水银灯照亮的地方。

There was the car, in the shadow of the building, the only place in the lot not illuminated by the mercury vapor lights.

他迅速环顾四周，停车场里有三名士兵从他身边走开。没有其他人。他轻轻打开车后门，溜了进去，关上车门，尽量不让车门关上。锁上车门，倒在地上，用毯子盖住自己。

He looked around quickly, three soldiers in the lot walking away from him. No one else. He eased open the back door of the car and slipped in, closing it behind him while trying not to let it slam. Locked it and dropped to the floor, pulling the blanket over him.

 

 

“他是一个非常沮丧的年轻人，”艾琳·斯纳尔斯布鲁克站起身说道。

“He’s a very upset young man,” Erin Snaresbrook said, rising to her feet.

“我们都知道，”伍德少校说。“我们不喜欢这样。但我们有命令，我或任何其他人都无能为力。”

“We all know that,” Major Wood said. “And we don’t like it. But we have our orders and there is absolutely nothing that I or anyone else can do about it.”

“那我就不瞒你说了。一定得想办法帮助他。”

“Then I will go over your head. Something must be done to help him.”

“请这样做——我祝你好运。”

“Please do that—and I wish you luck.”

“他刚才在电话里很沮丧。他把自己锁在房间里，不想和任何人说话。”

“He was very upset on the phone just now. He has locked himself in his room, doesn’t want to talk to anyone.”

“可以理解。明天早上他可能会好一些。”

“Understandable. He might be better in the morning.”

“嗯，我当然希望如此。”

“Well, I certainly hope so.”

他把她带到前门，然后开始和她一起走向汽车。她停下脚步，从包里翻出车钥匙，把钥匙和一张名片拿出来交给警察。

He showed her to the front door, started to come with her to the car. She stopped and rooted in her purse for her car keys, took them out along with one of her business cards that she handed to the officer.

“少校，如果你对他的状况有任何担忧，请无论白天还是黑夜都给我打电话。我希望在一切还来得及之前，能有所行动。再见。”

“I want you to phone me, night or day, Major, if you are concerned in any way about his well-being. I hope something really will be done before it is too late. Good-bye.”

“我会这么做的，医生。再见。”

“I’ll do that, Doctor. Good-bye.”

她慢慢走出大楼，来到停车场。她上了车，不敢看后座。她发动引擎，环顾四周。附近没有人。

She walked slowly out of the building and to the parking lot. Got into the car, not daring to glance at the backseat. Started the engine and looked about. There was no one nearby.

“你——在——那儿吗？”她低声问。

“Are you—there?” she whispered.

“你最好相信！”他低声回答道。

“You better believe it!” was the muffled answer.

她开车到了大门。栅栏升起时，她向警卫点了点头，然后驶入了星光闪烁的黑暗之中。

She drove to the gate. Nodded to the guards when the barrier rose, drove out into the star-pricked darkness.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

三十八
38

2024 年 12 月 19 日
December 19, 2024

 

 

艾琳·斯纳尔斯图克不得不打开车速控制，因为她的车速一直在缓慢上升——直到她注意到时才降了下来。沙漠四周一片漆黑，车头灯在她前方起伏的道路上照出一条光隧道。她开了一英里多，才看到那辆车停在路肩上。她放慢了速度，靠边停车，停在了车后面。她松了一口气，然后转过头，回头说了句话。

Erin Snaresbtook was forced to set the cruise control on the car, since her speed kept creeping up—and dropping back only when she noticed. The desert was an ocean of darkness on all sides, the headlights boring a tunnel of light down the undulating ribbon of the road ahead of her. She drove for over a mile before she saw the car parked on the shoulder of the road. She slowed and pulled over, stopping behind it. Sighed with relief, then turned her head and spoke over her shoulder.

“你现在安全了。你可以出来了。”

“You’re safe now. You can come out.”

布莱恩跳到后座上。“我以为我会窒息。我想应该没什么问题——否则我们也不会在这里了。”

Brian popped up onto the backseat. “Thought I was going to suffocate. No problems, I guess—or we wouldn’t be here.”

“没问题。你可以出去了。等一下——我先把灯关掉。还有里面的灯。以防万一。”

“No problems. You can get out. Wait—let me turn the lights off first. And the inside light. Just in case.”

布莱恩走进温暖的黑暗中。自由！一年来第一次。他深深地呼吸着干燥的沙漠空气，花了很长时间凝望满天繁星，一直到群山漆黑而崎岖的轮廓。听到斯纳尔斯布鲁克走出来和他在一起时车门关上了。他转过身面对她，越过她看到了另一辆车，当他看到有人站在车旁边时，他感到一阵恐慌。

Brian stepped out into the warm darkness. Free! For the first time in a year. He breathed deep of the dry desert air, allowed himself a long moment to take in the sky brimming over with stars, filled with them right down to the dark and jagged outline of the mountains. Heard the car door close as Snaresbrook came out and joined him. He turned to face her, looked past her and saw the other car, felt a surge of panic when he saw that someone was standing next to it.

“谁在那里！发生什么事了？”

“Who’s there! What happened?”

“没事的，布莱恩，”斯纳尔斯布鲁克平静地说。“是雪莉。她来帮你的。她知道发生的一切，而且她站在你这边。”

“It’s all right, Brian,” Snaresbrook said quietly. “It’s Shelly. She’s here to help you. She knows about everything that is happening and is on your side.”

布莱恩的喉咙很紧，说话非常费力。

Brian’s throat was so tight that it took an effort to speak.

“你知道多久了？”当雪莉来到他面前时，他问道。

“How long have you known?” he asked when Shelly came and stood before him.

“就过去一周。自从我告诉斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士我要离开军队，因为他们对你做了什么。我让她相信我想帮助你——她相信了我。”

“Just for the last week. Ever since I told Dr. Snaresbrook about my leaving the military because of what they were doing to you. I convinced her that I wanted to help you— and she believed me.”

“就在那时，我告诉了她你打算做什么。布莱恩，我非常担心你还没有准备好独自面对外面的世界。我冒了这么大的风险，她很真诚——她在这里而不是宪兵队就证明了我是正确的。我一直很关心你，坦率地说，我不想让你知道她在这件事中所扮演的角色，直到你安全离开监狱。”

“That’s when I told her what you were planning to do. I have a great fear, Brian, that you are not ready to tackle the outside world on your own yet. I took the calculated risk that she was sincere—her presence here instead of the military police is proof that I was correct. I have been very concerned about you and, frankly, I did not want you to learn about her part in this affair until you were safely away from your prison.”

布莱恩颤抖着吸了一口气，缓缓呼出——然后对着黑暗微笑。“你说得对，医生。我觉得我以前不可能做到。但现在一切都完成了——我感觉很棒！欢迎加入，雪莉。”

Brian took a shuddering breath, let it out slowly—and smiled into the darkness. “You’re right, Doc. I don’t think I could have hacked it before. But now that it’s done—I feel great! Welcome aboard, Shelly.”

“感谢你们让我帮忙。我会和你们一起去。你们不会孤单一人。”

“Thank you both for letting me help. I’m coming with you. You are not going to be alone.”

“我得考虑一下。稍后再说。现在我们最好赶紧行动。”他解开领带，拉下军装。“少校相信你的故事了吗，博士？”

“I’ve got to think about that. Later. Right now we had better get moving.” He unknotted his tie and pulled off the army shut. “Did the Major buy your story, Doc?”

“他喜欢你，布莱恩，他们似乎都喜欢你。我确信直到早上都不会有人靠近这个房间。”

“He likes you, Brian, they all seem to. I feel certain that no one will go near the room until the morning.”

“我希望如此。但当他们发现我失踪时，事情就会变得很糟。你知道我为他们所有人感到难过。从某种意义上说，这是一种非常卑鄙的伎俩。他们肯定会被放进酸奶里。”

“I hope so. But when they do find that I’m missing it’s going to really hit the fan. You know I feel sorry for them all. In a way it’s a really dirty trick to play. They’ll be in the yogurt for sure.”

“现在考虑这个问题有点晚了，不是吗？”

“A little late to think about that, isn’t it?”

“不，我已经走了那条路。我在计划越狱时已经深思熟虑了。我为他们感到难过——但他们是我的狱卒——我需要逃离监狱。现在，计划是什么？”

“No, I’ve already gone that route. I thought long and hard about it when I was planning the escape. I feel sorry for them—but they were my jailers—and I needed out of jail. Now, what’s the plan?”

“雪莉接手这里。我要回 Megalobe，在那里的实验室里做一些工作。过夜。这会让事情变得有点混乱，甚至可能阻止他们将我与逃跑联系起来。谜团越大，你成功的机会就越大。我甚至会把我的连接机器装箱并放回车里，这样他们就很难将丢失的盒子与你的逃跑联系起来。所以让我们把斯文拖出去，把它放进雪莉的车里。我回来得越快，效果就越好。”

“Shelly takes over from here. I’m going back to Megalobe, do some work in my lab there. Spend the night. That will muddy the waters a bit, perhaps even prevent them from tying me in with the escape. The bigger the mystery the better the chance you have to pull it off. I’ll even box my connection machine and put it back into the car so they will have trouble tying a missing box with your escape. So let’s drag Sven out and put it in Shelly’s car. The faster I get back, the better it will be.”

做完这些后，两人在脸颊上轻轻一吻，匆匆道别，然后就分开了。当另一辆车掉头驶回 Megalobe 时，Shelly 启动引擎向西行驶。Brian 望着远处的群山，感到比刚知道自己自由时更加轻松。

As soon as this was done, after a quick peck on the cheek and hurried good-byes, they separated. When the other car had made a U-turn and headed back toward Megalobe, Shelly started her engine and drove west. Brian looked out at the hills moving by, felt an even greater sense of relief than he had when he first knew he was free.

“我很高兴你在这里，”他说。“也许我们最好还是在一起。至少要在一起一段时间。”他看了看手表。“照这样的速度，我们最迟应该在 11 点到达边境。”

“I’m glad that you are here,” he said. “And maybe we better stick together. At least for a while.” He looked at his watch. “At this speed we should reach the border by eleven at the latest.”

“你确定吗？我以前从来没这样开过车。”

“Are you sure? I’ve never driven this way before.”

“我也没有——我记得是这样。但我读了很多旅游指南和地图。路上应该不会堵车，而且总路程只有八十七英里。”

“Neither have I—that I remember. But I have been reading lots of guidebooks and maps. There shouldn’t be much traffic and the total drive is only eighty-seven miles.”

此后他们就沉默了：现在没有什么可说的，却有很多事情要考虑。

They were silent after that: there was very little now to say but a lot to think about.

他们在布劳利前拐下 78 号公路，向南朝埃尔森特拉和卡莱西科行驶。写着“墨西哥”的路牌引领他们绕过市中心，来到边境口岸。十点半左右，海关检查亭出现在前方。布莱恩第一次感到紧张。

They turned off 78 before Brawley and headed south toward El Centra and Calexico. The signs reading MEXICO led them around the town center to the border crossing. It was just half past ten when the customs booths appeared ahead. For the first time Brian felt nervous.

“所有的旅游书都说去墨西哥很方便。是吗？”

“All the travel books say that there is no hassle getting into Mexico. Is that right?”

“来吧，带上你的钱。我从来没被阻止进去过——甚至没人盯着我看。”

“Come and bring your dollars. I’ve never been stopped going in—or even been looked at for that matter.”

当他们驾车越过国界时，美国海关官员并没有出现在他们面前。那名带着大枪、肚子更大的墨西哥官员只是看了一眼他们的车牌，然后转身离开。

There were no American customs officers in sight when they drove across the national boundary. The Mexican official, sporting a large gun and even larger stomach, just glanced at their license plate then turned away.

“我们成功了！”当他们沿着遍布花哨商店和酒吧的街道前进时，布莱恩大声喊道。

“We did it!” Brian shouted as they rolled along the street of garish shops and bars.

“我们确实做到了！接下来呢？”

“We sure enough did! What’s next?”

“首先是计划有变。原本的计划是让医生送我和斯文回美国。她根本不知道我未来的计划是什么。”

“A change of plan for one thing. The original idea was for the doc to drop me and Sven off and go back to the States. She had no clue as to what my future plans would be.”

“你？”

“Do you?”

“当然！我今晚要坐火车去墨西哥城。”

“Positively! I’m going to take the train to Mexico City tonight.”

“我也是。”

“So am I.”

“你确定吗？”

“You sure?”

“积极的。”

“Positive.”

“好吧。我们坚持原计划，只是你开车过境，再打车回来——”

“All right. We stick to the original plan except you take the car back across the border, return by cab—”

“不行。太复杂，太耗时。而且会留下痕迹。我们把车停在这里，钥匙插在点火开关上就行了。”

“Nope. Too complicated, too time-consuming. And it leaves a trail. We just leave the car here with the key in the ignition.”

“它会被偷的！”

“It’ll get stolen!”

“就是这个主意。如果当地的偷车贼够狠的话，车牌应该会彻底消失。这比在卡莱西科的停车场找到车牌来指示我们去往何方要好得多。”

“That’s the idea. It should vanish completely if the local car thieves are up to scratch. That’s a lot better than having it found in a parking lot in Calexico to show which way we went.”

“你不能这么做。钱……”

“You can’t do that. The money…”

“无论如何我都想要一辆新车。也许有一天我可以拿到保险。所以没别的话了。车站在哪边？”

“I wanted a new car anyway. And maybe someday I can collect the insurance. So not another word. Which way is the station?”

“我会看看街道地图。”

“I’ll look at the street map.”

他们很轻松地找到了墨西哥国家铁路公司。雪莉开车经过车站，拐过街角，来到一条光线昏暗的街道，把车停在一盏烧坏的路灯下。她从后备箱里拿出一个小行李箱，记得把钥匙留在那里，然后帮布莱恩把沉重的箱子抬了出来。

They found the Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico easily enough. Shelly drove past the station and around the corner to a badly lit street, parked under a burnt-out streetlight. She took a small suitcase from the trunk, remembered to leave the keys, then helped Brian lift out the heavy box.

他说：“这是第一步，也是最重要的一步。”

“The first step—and the biggest one,” he said.

“火车还有一小时二十一分钟才开，”盒子用低沉但可能带有警告的语气说道。

“One hour and twenty-one minutes are left before the train leaves,” the box said in muffled but possibly admonitory tones.

“时间足够了。耐心点——我们才是拖箱子的人。”

“More than enough time. Be patient—we’re the ones dragging the box.”

在雪莉放弃之前，他们已经到达了车站入口。

They got it as far as the station entrance before Shelly called quits.

“够了！你看着这个东西，我看看他们是否会做出像红帽子一样奇异的东西。”

“Enough! You watch this thing while I see if they rise to something as exotic as a redcap.”

几分钟后，她和那个男人一起回来了。他戴着一顶破旧的帽子，戴着军衔徽章，推着一辆手推车。

She was back a few minutes later with the man. He was wearing a battered cap, his badge of rank, and pushing a handcart.

“我们得买票，”布莱恩一边说，一边把搬运工的手推车的金属边缘挪到了箱子下面。他希望那个人会说英语。

“We have to buy tickets,” Brian said as the porter eased the metal edge of the hand truck under the box. He hoped that the man spoke English.

“没问题。你要去哪里？”

“No problem. Where are you going?”

“墨西哥城。”

“Mexico City.”

“没问题，你们就跟着我吧。”

“No problem. You people, you just follow me.”

发现窗栅后面那个面色不悦的女人也会说英语，他松了一口气。是的，头等舱还有空位。她手边的古老机器吐出了两张票，她亲手盖了章。唯一的问题就是钱。

The unhappy-looking woman behind the window grille also spoke English, he was relieved to find out. Yes, there was a first-class compartment available. The ancient machine at her elbow disgorged two tickets, which she hand-stamped. The only problem was money.

“不准收美元，”她皱着眉头说道，好像这是他的错。“只收国家货币。”

“Don’t take dollars,” she said, scowling, as though it were his fault. “Only moneda national.”

“我们不能在这里换钱吗？”雪莉问道。

“Can’t we change money here?” Shelly asked.

“变更已关闭。”

“The change is closed already.”

直到门房说“我有个朋友，你去换钱”时，布莱恩的慌乱才稍稍缓解了一些。

Brian’s surge of panic was only slightly relieved when the porter said, “I got a friend, change money.”

“在哪里？”

“Where?”

“在那边，他在酒吧工作。”

“Over there, he work in the bar.”

酒保笑容满面，非常乐意把比索兑换成美元。

The bartender smiled broadly, was more than happy to sell pesos for dollars.

“你知道，我必须收取与银行不同的费用，因为我在兑换时遭受了损失。”

“You know I gotta charge different from the bank because I lose on the exchange.”

“随你怎么说吧，”布莱恩一边说，一边把几张美钞递给了他。

“Whatever you say,” Brian said, passing over the greenbacks.

“我敢肯定他又在骗你！”当那人走向收银台时，雪莉嘶嘶地说。

“I’m sure he’s cheating you!” Shelly hissed when the man went to the till.

“我同意。但我们要上车了，这才是最重要的。”

“I agree. But we’re getting on the train and that’s what counts.”

无论他是否被骗，看到用美元兑换成厚厚一捆比索时，他都感到无比的欣慰。

Cheated or not he felt immensely relieved to see the thick bundle of pesos that he got in return for his dollars.

十二点差八分，搬运工把箱子放在车厢地板上，把十美元小费装进口袋，关上门离开了。谢利拉下窗帘，布莱恩锁上门，打开箱子。

It was eight minutes to twelve when the porter put the box on the floor in the compartment, pocketed his ten-dollar tip, closed the door behind him as he left. Shelly pulled down the curtain while Brian locked the door and opened the box.

“在墨西哥出售美元的正确汇率是——”

“The correct rate of exchange for selling dollars in Mexico is—”

“请对我们保密，好吗？”布莱恩一边说，一边拿出他的航空包。“到目前为止，你的旅行还愉快吗，斯文？”

“Keep it a secret from us, will you please?” Brian said as he took out his airline bag. “Been enjoying your trip so far, Sven?”

“如果观察黑色汽车后备箱内部是一件令人愉快的事情，那么我就享受到了。”

“If looking at the inside of dark car trunks is enjoyable, then I have enjoyed myself.”

“情况只会越来越好，”雪莉说。

“It can only get better,” Shelly said.

远处传来车厢联轴器的叮当声，火车震动起来，开始移动；一阵威严的敲门声震得车门嘎嘎作响。

There was the clank of distant couplings and the train shuddered and began to move; an imperious knock rattled the door.

“我去拿，”雪莉说。“你最好放松点。”

“I’ll get that,” Shelly said. “You had better relax.”

“我很乐意。”

“I would love to.”

等到他砰地一声关上箱子后，她才打开锁并打开门。

She waited until he had slammed the box shut before she unlocked and opened the door.

“请出示车票。”售票员说道。

“Tickets please,” the conductor said.

“是的，当然。”他把他们递过去。列车员打了他们一拳，指了指座位。

“Yes, of course.” He passed them over. The conductor punched them and pointed to the seats.

“当您准备休息时，只需将沙发靠背拉下来，床已经铺好了。上铺就是这样放下的。祝您旅途愉快。”

“Just pull the back of the couch down when you are ready to retire, the bed is already made up. The upper bunk swings down like this. Have a pleasant journey.”

布莱恩锁上身后的门，无力地坐到座位上。这真是不平凡的一天。

Brian locked the door behind him and dropped onto the seat limply. This had been quite a day.

火车加速时摇晃不已，车轮在铁轨上发出咔哒声，外面灯光闪烁。他拉开窗帘，看着郊区从车厢里飞驰而过，然后是远处的农场。

The train swayed as they picked up speed, the wheels clicked over the rails, lights moved by outside. He opened the curtain and watched the suburbs stream past, then the farms beyond.

“我们成功了！”雪莉说。“我这辈子从没见过这么美丽的景象。”

“We’ve made it!” Shelly said. “I’ve never seen a more lovely sight in my life.”

“我确信那景色非常有趣。”那个低沉的声音说道。

“I am sure that it is a most interesting view,” the muffled voice said.

“抱歉，”布莱恩说着，再次打开了盒子。斯文把眼柄伸出来，这样他也能透过窗户看到外面。布莱恩关掉灯，他们看着风景飘过。

“Sorry about that,” Brian said as he opened the box again. Sven pushed his eyestalks out so he could see through the window as well. Brian turned off the lights and they watched the landscape drift by.

“我们什么时候到那儿？”雪莉问。

“What time do we get there?” Shelly asked.

“下午三点。”

“Three in the afternoon.”

“进而？”

“And then?”

布莱恩沉默不语，望着黑暗，仍然不确定。“雪莉，我仍然认为我应该自己做这件事。”

Brian was silent, looking out into the darkness, still not sure. “Shelly, I still think I ought to be doing this on my own.”

“胡说。一分钱一分货，一分货，他们不是这么说的吗？”

“Nonsense. In for a penny, in for a pound, isn’t that what they say?”

“爱尔兰人确实这么说。”

“They say it in Ireland all right.”

“我认为你应该接受雪莉的援助，”斯文说。

“It is my belief that you should accept Shelly’s offer of aid,” Sven said.

“我有问过你的意见吗？”

“Did I ask for your opinion?”

“没有。但她的建议很好。你病得很重，记忆力有些欠缺。你可以寻求她的帮助。接受吧。”

“No. But her suggestion is a good one. You have been quite ill, your memory has gaps in it. You can use her help. Take it.”

“投票失败，”布莱恩叹了口气，“计划很简单——但你最好带上护照。”

“Outvoted,” Brian sighed. “The plan is a simple one— but you had better have your passport with you.”

“是的。斯纳尔斯布鲁克博士一提到她要去墨西哥边境，我就收拾行李走了。”

“I do. Packed it in as soon as Dr. Snaresbrook mentioned she would be going to the Mexican border.”

“我必须做的就是走在任何来找我的人前面。”

“What I must do is stay ahead of anyone who comes looking for me.”

“去墨西哥驻扎吗？”

“Go to ground in Mexico?”

“我曾想过这个——但那没有用。墨西哥和美国警方在追捕毒贩方面合作非常密切。我敢肯定，如果需要追踪我，绍尔希特将军会把我标记为罪犯。所以我必须去墨西哥以外的地方。我查了一下航班时刻表，很多国际航班在傍晚从墨西哥城起飞。所以我们买了机票离开了这个国家。”

“I thought of that—but it’s no good. The Mexican and American police cooperate very closely in chasing down drug runners. I am sure that General Schorcht would tag me as a criminal if that was needed to track me down. So I have to go further than Mexico. I checked the schedules and a lot of international flights leave Mexico City in the early evening. So we buy tickets and leave the country.”

“有什么特别想去的目的地吗？”

“Any particular destination in mind?”

“当然。爱尔兰。你会记得我是爱尔兰公民。”

“Of course. Ireland. You’ll remember that I am an Irish citizen.”

“这真是个好主意。那么我们去爱尔兰——然后呢？”

“That’s a brilliant idea. So we get to Ireland—then what?”

“我要试着找到 Bociort 博士——如果他还活着的话。这可能意味着我要去罗马尼亚一趟。那些偷走我的第一个人工智能并试图杀死我的人仍然逍遥法外。我要找到他们。原因有很多。复仇可能是其中之一，但生存才是主要原因。他们的威胁消除后，我就可以不再提心吊胆了。而 Schorcht 将军再也没有借口给我找麻烦了。”

“I am going to try and find Dr. Bociort—if he is still alive. Which will probably mean making a trip to Rumania. The people who stole my first AI and tried to kill me are still out there. I am going to find them. For a lot of reasons. Revenge might be one of them, but survival is the main one. With their threat removed I can stop looking over my shoulder. And General Schorcht will no longer have an excuse to cause me trouble.”

“阿门。”她打了个大大的哈欠，捂住了嘴。“不好意思。不过如果你有我一半累的话，我们应该睡一觉。”

“Amen to that.” She yawned widely and covered her mouth. “Excuse me. But if you are half as tired as I am we should get some sleep.”

“既然你这么说了——是的。”

“Now that you have said it—yes.”

他拉下窗帘，打开灯。正如他承诺的那样，两个铺位已经铺好，并轻松摆放到位。

He pulled down the curtain and turned on the lights. As promised, the two berths were made up and swung easily into position.

“我去拿上衣，”雪莉说着，打开行李箱，拿出睡衣和晨衣，抓起钱包。“马上回来。”

“I’ll take the upper,” Shelly said, opening her suitcase and taking out pajamas and a dressing gown, grabbed her purse. “Be right back.”

她回来时，唯一亮着的灯是她床铺上方的那盏小灯。布莱恩在被子下面，斯文把窗帘拉高了一英寸，向外张望。

When she returned the only light on was the small one over her berth. Brian was under the covers and Sven had raised the curtain an inch and was looking out.

“晚安，”她说。

“Good night,” she said.

“晚安，”斯文说。除了轻微的鼾声外，再没有别的声音了。

“Good night,” Sven said. A soft snore was the only other sound.

三十九
39

2024 年 12 月 20 日
December 20, 2024

 

 

他们在餐车里吃早餐时，风景从眼前飘过。小村庄、丛林和山脉，当他们沿着科尔特斯海行驶时，偶尔瞥见一眼大海。当他们喝完咖啡时，电话响了，布莱恩看到另一个用餐者从夹克口袋里掏出电话接了电话。

The scenery flowed by while they ate breakfast in the dining car. Small villages, jungle and mountains, an occasional glimpse of ocean as they skirted the Sea of Cortez. While they were finishing their coffee a phone rang and Brian saw one of the other diners take it from his jacket pocket and answer it.

“我太蠢了，”他说。“我应该早点想到的。你带手机了吗？”

“I’m being stupid,” he said. “I should have thought of it before this. Do you have your phone with you?”

“当然。不是每个人都这样吗？”

“Of course. Doesn’t everyone?”

“现在还不行。你知道无论你在哪里都可以接电话。你有没有想过其中的原理？”

“Not me, not now. You know that you can receive a phone call no matter where you are. Did you ever think of the mechanism involved?”

“不是的。这是那些你认为理所当然的事情之一。”

“Not really. It’s one of those things you take for granted.”

“这对我来说太新了，所以我研究了一下。现在到处都有光纤和微波链路，蜂窝网络遍布世界各地。当你想打电话时，你只需输入号码，最近的基站就会接受并转发。你可能没有意识到，你的手机总是开机，总是处于待机状态。当你在小区之间移动时，它会通过将你当前的位置发送到你的家庭交换机的内存库来自动登录。因此，当有人拨打你的号码时，国内或国际电话系统总是知道在哪里找到你并转接来电。”

“It was so new to me that I looked into it. There are fiber-optic and microwave links everywhere now, cellular nets right around the world. When you want to make a call you just punch it in and the nearest station accepts it and passes it on. What you might not realize is that your phone is always on, always on standby. And it logs in automatically when you move between cells by sending your present location to the memory bank of your home exchange. So when someone dials your number the national or international telephone system always knows where to find you and pass on the incoming call.”

她瞪大了眼睛。“你的意思是它知道我现在在哪里？任何有权力的人都能获得这些信息？”

Her eyes widened. “You mean it knows where I am now? That anyone with the authority could obtain this information?”

“当然。比如绍尔希特将军。”

“Absolutely. Like General Schorcht for instance.”

她喘着气说：“那我们就得把它扔掉！把它扔下火车——”

She gasped. “Then we have to get rid of it! Throw it off the train—”

“不会。如果电话坏了，就会向维修部门发送信号。你不会想引人注意的。我们可以肯定，目前还没有人在找你。但当他们发现我失踪并开始搜寻时，他们一定会联系所有和我一起工作的人。我们回车厢去吧——我有个主意。”

“No. If a phone goes out of commission a signal is sent to the repair service. You don’t want to draw any attention to yourself. We can be fairly sure that no one is looking for you yet. But when they find that I’m missing and the search begins, they will be sure to contact everyone who worked with me. Let’s go back to the compartment—I have an idea.”

窗户下面有一块嵌板，看上去很完美。布莱恩指着它。

There was a panel under the window that looked perfect. Brian pointed to it.

“斯文，你认为你能把这些螺丝取出来吗？”

“Sven, do you think you can take those screws out?”

斯文转头看了看。“很简单。”

Sven swiveled his eyes to look. “An easy task.”

MI 用操纵器形成了一个螺丝刀头，迅速拧下了固定塑料面板的螺丝。面板后面的空间里有两根管子和一根电缆。布莱恩指了指。

The MI formed a screwdriver head with its manipulators and quickly took out the screws that held the plastic panel in place. There were two pipes and an electric cable passing through the space there behind the panel. Brian pointed.

“我们只需将您的电话放在这里即可。塑料面板不会阻挡任何信号。如果军方打来电话而您不接听，他们将非常忙于追踪在墨西哥境内移动的信号。等他们解决问题时，我们早已不见踪影了。”

“We’ll just put your telephone in here. The plastic panel won’t block any signals. If the military call and you don’t answer they are going to have a busy time tracking the signal while it’s moving around Mexico. By the time they sort it out we will be long gone.”

午餐时间，火车驶离特皮克，向内陆驶往瓜达拉哈拉，准时抵达墨西哥城。斯文已安全收拾好行李，准备迎接来取行李的搬运工。他带他们去了 Depósito de Equipajes，在那里办理了所有手续。布莱恩指着旁边的银行。

The train pulled out of Tepic at lunchtime and turned inland towards Guadalajara, reaching Mexico City exactly on time. Sven was packed safely away and ready for the porter who came for their luggage. He led the way to the Depósito de Equipajes, where they checked everything in. Brian pointed to the bank next to it.

“我们要做的第一件事就是筹集一些比索。我们不想重演墨西卡利惨案。”

“The first thing we do is get some pesos. We don’t want a repetition of Mexicali.”

“进而？”

“And then?”

“我们找一家旅行社。”

“We find a travel agency.”

走出布埃纳维斯塔火车站，墨西哥城又冷又湿；雾霾刺痛了他们的眼睛。他们无视出租车站，穿过人群，沿着 Insurgentes Norte 步行，直到来到第一家旅行社。这家旅行社很大，窗户上的牌子上写着“英语服务”，这是一个充满希望的迹象。他们转身进去。

Outside of the Buenavista railroad station, Mexico City was cold and wet; the smog hurt their eyes. They ignored the cab rank and walked out through the crowds and along Insurgentes Norte until they came to the first travel agency. It was a large one and a placard in the window said english spoken, a very hopeful sign. They turned in.

“我们想飞往爱尔兰，”布莱恩告诉坐在大办公桌后面的那个男人。“越快越好。”

“We would like to fly to Ireland,” Brian told the man behind the large desk. “As soon as is possible.”

“恐怕这里没有直飞航班，”这位代理人一边说，一边转向电脑，调出了出发航班表。“每天有一班美国航空的航班经纽约市转机，还有一班达美航空的航班经亚特兰大转机。”

“I’m afraid that there are no direct flights from here,” the agent said as he turned to his computer and brought up the tables of departing flights. “There is an American flight that connects daily through New York City—and a Delta flight through Atlanta.”

“那非美国航空公司呢？”谢利问道，布莱恩点头表示同意。安全离开美国后，他们并不急于返回，尽管时间很短。最后，他们决定乘坐墨西哥航空飞往古巴哈瓦那，三小时后再乘坐俄罗斯航空公司的图佩洛夫航班飞往香农。机票以比索计价，但代理人打电话给银行询问了当前的汇率。

“What about non-American carriers?” Shelly asked, and Brian nodded agreement. Safely out of the States they were in no hurry to return, however briefly. In the end they settled for MexAir to Havana, Cuba, with an Aeroflot Tupelov leaving three hours later for Shannon. The tickets were priced in pesos, but the agent called the bank for the current rate of exchange.

“我们还是把现金留着吧，”雪莉说。“我们会需要它的。用我的信用卡吧。”

“Let’s hold on to the cash,” Shelly said. “We’re going to need it. Use my credit card instead.”

“他们会追踪到你的。”

“They’ll track you down.”

“就像电话一样——我早就走了。”

“Like the phone—I’ll be long gone.”

“现金或信用卡都可以，”代理人说着，把预订表拿过来。“美国护照？”

“Cash or credit card, both okay,” the agent said, and pulled over the booking form. “American passports?”

“一个。另一个是爱尔兰人。”

“One. The other is Irish.”

“没问题。这只需要几分钟。”计算机链接检查了信用卡账户，预订了座位并打印了机票。“祝您旅途愉快。”

“That will be fine. This will only take a few moments.” The computer link checked the credit card account, booked the seats and printed the tickets. “I hope you enjoy your flight.”

“我也希望如此，”他们回到街上时，布莱恩说道。关于护照的询问令人沮丧地提醒他们，他们必须通过海关。旅行手册对此已经说得很清楚了，他知道自己会遇到麻烦。他希望他能通过所谓的Mordida 来避免它。他很快就会知道答案。

“I hope so too,” Brian said when they were back in the street. The query about their passports was a depressing reminder that they were going to have to pass through customs. The travel books had been quite clear about this and he knew he faced trouble. He hoped he could avoid it by what was called the mordida. He would soon find out.

“我又冷又湿，”雪莉说。“我们有时间买件雨衣吗——或者一件毛衣？”

“I’m cold and wet,” Shelly said. “Do we have time to buy a raincoat—maybe a sweater?”

他看了看手表。“好主意。我们到机场还有足够时间。我们去那家百货商店试试吧。”

He looked at his watch. “A good idea. More than enough time before we have to be at the airport. Let’s try that department store.”

他又买了两件衬衫、内衣、一件轻便夹克和雨衣。这些只是可以放进随身行李袋的基本物品。雪莉做得比这好得多，她购物得如此之好，以至于她不得不再买一个小行李箱。回到火车站，布莱恩找出存根，接回斯文和他们的行李，然后打车去机场。

He bought two more shirts, underwear, a light jacket as well as the raincoat. Just the basic items that would fit into the carry-on bag. Shelly did far better than that, shopping so well that she had to buy another small suitcase. Back in the train station Brian dug out the stub, retrieved Sven and their bags, then took a cab to the airport.

值机柜台没有出现任何问题。他们看着雪莉的行李和装在行李箱里的证件在传送带上慢慢移开，航空公司的工作人员从他们的机票上撕下纸张，并把它们钉在登机牌上。

There were no problems at the check-in counter. They watched Shelly’s bag and the crated MI move slowly away on the belt as the airline clerk tore out sheets from their tickets and stapled them to the boarding cards.

“我可以看一下您的护照吗？”

“Might I see your passports, please?”

这第一个障碍很容易克服。她只想看第一页，看看护照是否有效，是否过期。她微笑着把护照递还给她。谢利第一个通过了安检。他紧随其后，抓着护照和登机牌，把包放在 X 光机的传送带上，然后穿过旁边的拱门。机器发出哔哔声，保安转过身来，用阴暗而怀疑的眼神看着他。

This first hurdle was easy enough to get over. All she wanted to do was look at the first page to see if the passports were current and had not expired. She smiled and passed them back. Shelly went through security first. He followed, clutching his passport and boarding pass, putting his bag on the belt of the X-ray machine before he stepped through the archway next to it. The machine bleeped and the security guard turned to him with a dark and suspicious look.

他从口袋里掏出硬币，甚至没有掏出来，取下黄铜皮带扣，也把它放在托盘上。他穿过拱门，拱门再次发出哔哔声。

He took the coins from his pocket, even undipped and removed his brass belt buckle and put that on the tray as well. Stepped back through the arch, which bleeped again.

然后布莱恩意识到发生了什么。磁场检测到了金属和电子电路。

Then Brian realized what was happening. The magnetic field detected metal—and electronic circuitry.

“我的头，”他指着耳朵说。“一场事故，一次手术。”不是电脑——简单点。“我的头骨里有一块金属板。”

“My head,” he said, pointing at his ear. “An accident, an operation.” Not a computer—keep it simple. “I have a metal plate in my skull.”

警卫对此最感兴趣。他使用了磁场手部探测器，只有靠近布莱恩的头部时才会发出哔哔声。那里没有武器；他被挥手放行。每个人都只是在做自己的工作。

The guard was most interested in this. He used the magnetic field hand detector, which only bleeped when it was near Brian’s head. No weapon there; he was waved through. Everyone was just doing their job.

包括海关官员。他是一个皮肤黝黑、留着优雅小胡子的男人。布莱恩把护照递给他时，他慢慢地翻了翻，然后又回去重复了一遍。抬起头，皱起了眉头。

Including the customs officer. He was a dark-skinned man with an elegant mustache. When Brian gave him his passport he flipped the pages slowly, went back and repeated the action. Looked up and frowned.

“我没有看到签证记录显示你从哪里进入墨西哥。”

“I do not see the visa entry showing where you entered Mexico.”

“你确定吗？能再给我看一下护照吗？”他假装翻看护照，然后把一张一百美元的钞票塞到护照页中间，生怕自己出丑。读到有关贿赂的报道是一回事，真正尝试行贿又是另一回事。他确信自己很快就会被逮捕。

“Are you sure? Can I see the passport again?”  He pretended to look through it and, with the great fear that he was making a total fool of himself, slipped a hundred-dollar bill between the pages.  It is one thing to read about bribes—another to really attempt bribery. He was sure he would be under arrest within moments.

“我不知道我需要签证。我们是开车过境的。我不知道签证的事。”

“I didn’t know I needed one. We crossed the border by car. I didn’t know about a visa.”

他把护照推回去并惊恐地看着官员打开它。

He pushed the passport back and watched with horror as the officer opened it.

“这种事时有发生，”这位官员说。“可能会出错。但你需要两张签证章。一张用于入境，一张用于出境。如果这位女士和你在一起，她也需要两张签证章。”

“These things happen,” the officer said. “Mistakes can be made. But you will need two visa stamps. One to enter the country, one to leave. If the lady is with you she will need two stamps as well.”

那名男子一脸无聊地将未盖章的护照归还。布莱恩翻阅了空白页——没有钱也没有签证——然后意识到发生了什么。

The man looked bored as he returned the passport unstamped. Brian flipped through its empty pages—empty of money as well as visas—then realized what was happening.

“当然。两张邮票，不是一张。我明白。”

“Of course. Two stamps, not one. I understand.”

他们俩都明白了。又有三张百元大钞和第一张一样，砰的一声，他拿回了护照。谢利也受到了同样的对待。他们终于通过了，可以上路了！

They both understood. Three more hundred-dollar bills went the way of the first; there were two thuds and he had the passport back. Shelly’s was treated in the same way. They were through and on their way!

“我看到的是不是我想的那个？”谢利在他耳边嘶嘶地说。“你是个骗子，布莱恩·德莱尼。”

“Did I see what I thought I saw?” Shelly hissed in his ear. “You are a crook, Brian Delaney.”

“我跟你一样惊讶。我们先找到登机口坐下吧。这种事可不轻松。”

“I am as surprised as you are. Let’s find our gate and sit down. This kind of thing is not easy on the nerves.”

飞机只晚点了一个小时起飞，剩下的旅程就这么一晃而过。他们只能在飞机上打个盹，疲劳开始显​​现。哈瓦那只是一个灯光昏暗的转机休息室，座椅是硬塑料的。这次俄罗斯航空公司的航班晚点了两个小时起飞。他们吃了一些味道不好的航空餐，喝了一些格鲁吉亚香槟，最后睡着了。

The plane was only an hour late in leaving; the rest of the trip passed in a blur. They could only manage to doze on the plane and fatigue was beginning to tell. Havana was just a dimly lit transit lounge with hard plastic seats. The Aeroflot flight left two hours late this time. They ate some of the tasteless airline food, drank some Georgian champagne and finally fell asleep.

香农的黎明刚刚过去。飞机穿过云层密布的天空，低空飞过在绿色田野中吃草的奶牛，接近跑道。布莱恩穿上外套，从头顶的行李架上取下包。他们和其他疲惫的旅客一起默默地离开了飞机。另一架跨大西洋航班也在同一时间抵达，所以他们在胡子拉碴的男人、睡眼惺忪的女人、呜咽哭泣的孩子的队伍中拖了很久。雪莉先通过了，护照上盖了签证章，转身等他。

It was just after dawn in Shannon. The plane dropped down through the cloud-filled sky, came in low over cows grazing in green fields as they approached the runway. Brian pulled on his coat and took down his bag from the overhead rack. They left the plane in silence along with the rest of the weary travelers. Another transatlantic flight had arrived at the same time, so they were a long time shuffling along in the line of unshaven men, bleary-eyed women, whimpering and wailing children. Shelly went through first, had a visa stamped in her passport, turned to wait for him.

“欢迎回家，伯恩先生，”这位精神抖擞、精神抖擞的海关官员说道。“出去度假了吗？”

“Welcome home, Mr. Byrne,” the wide-awake and sprightly customs man said. “Been away on a holiday?”

布莱恩已经为这一刻做好了准备，他的口音是纯正的威克洛口音，没有一丝美国口音。“你可能会这么说——成千上万的人不会这么说。食物令人震惊，他们似乎认为收费过高是一种生活方式。”

Brian had been prepared for this moment and his accent was purest Wicklow without a trace of American. “You might say so—thousands wouldn’t. The food’s a shock and they seem to think that overcharging is a way of life.”

“这很有意思。”男人手里拿着橡皮图章，但他没有使用它。相反，他抬起冰冷的蓝眼睛看着布莱恩。

“That’s very interesting.” The man had the rubber stamp in his hand but he was not using it. Instead he raised cold blue eyes to Brian.

“您现在的地址？”

“Your current address?”

“基尔玛格 20 号。在塔拉。”

“Number 20 Kilmagig. In Tara.”

“一个漂亮的小村庄。主街上有小学，教堂对面就是。”

“A nice little village. Main Street with the primary school just across from the church.”

“除非他们把它顶起来，并移到半英里外的路上，否则就不是。”

“Not unless they’ve jacked it up and moved it a half mile down the road, it isn’t.”

“没错，没错，我肯定把它和其他地方搞混了。但还有一个小问题。伯恩先生，我毫不怀疑你是爱尔兰人，我也不会拒绝一个人进入他的出生地。但法律就是法律。”他向一名警察打手势，警察点点头，朝他们走了过去。

“True, true, I must have gotten it confused with someplace else. But there is still one little problem. That you are Irish I don’t doubt, Mr. Byrne, and I wouldn’t be one to deny a man access to the land of his birth. But the law is the law.” He signed to a garda, who nodded and strolled their way.

“我不明白。你检查过我的护照——”

“I don’t understand. You’ve checked my passport—”

“我确实有，这既有趣又令人费解。签发日期完全正确，所有签证似乎都井然有序。但我发现有一件事难以理解——这就是我要求你和警察一起去办公室的原因。你看，这种护照已经被新的欧洲护照取代了。这种特殊样式的护照已经十多年没有签发了。现在你不觉得这很有趣吗？”
